fields.headline: Titus
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Anthony Hopkins is on fine, bullish form and in beautiful voice, [but] Titus errs towards some uneven and fussy tableaux
fields.body:
Titus's main asset is Anthony Hopkins, on fine, bullish form and in beautiful voice. He is the returning Roman general Titus, a man whom the wise patrician heads now wish to co-opt into political leadership, but who is wary of office and in any case sickened by a conflict that has claimed many of his sons. The imperial bays instead descend on Saturninus (Alan Cumming), a decision which leads to a terrible exchange of retributive violence, ending in Titus tricking his tormentors into eating their own kin.

One of Taymor's real successes is her opening sequence. The Roman soldiers return in a strange and disturbingly dreamlike slow marching motion: a hostile, dehumanised Paradeschritt. Elsewhere unfortunately, Taymor errs towards some uneven and fussy tableaux: the speeches to the mob given through old-fashioned microphones with "SPQR News" have an unhappy touch of student drama.

fields.headline: Hospital case
fields.standfirst: Neil LaBute's latest is about a soap fan who confuses TV and reality. We've been here before, says  Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Funny, watchable, and graced by a sweet and winning central performance from Renée Zellweger... but there is such a curious air of redundant social commentary and satire about the whole enterprise
fields.body:
As the director responsible for the sulphuric In the Company of Men, everything Neil LaBute does must command attention. And his latest picture, Nurse Betty, is certainly funny, watchable, and graced by a sweet and winning central performance from Renée Zellweger, of which more in a moment.

But having experienced the steel toe-capped kicking that we know LaBute can deliver to modern cultural sensibilities, it is dismaying and disorientating to see him turn up with a feather, and attempt to tickle our tummies with some Satire Lite. Very Lite. Just one calorie - if that. Nurse Betty is a screwball-comedy-cum-road-movie which could have been made at any time in the last 30 years, and is encumbered with the bafflingly dated and unoriginal theme of how TV subverts reality. Only the abrasive, recalcitrant presence of Chris Rock gives this film anything resembling the contemporary edge that we are hoping for in a Neil LaBute picture, and alerts us to the fact that all this is supposed to be happening in the year 2000.

Whether or not the "throwback" quality of Nurse Betty is accidental, some of it is certainly attributable to the fact that it starts off in the sheltered mid-west of Fair Oaks, Kansas, where diner waitress Betty (Zellweger) regularly swoons over her favourite daytime soap, A Reason to Love, starring the dishy actor George McCord (Greg Kinnear) who plays the unfeasibly handsome Dr David Ravell.

Zellweger is so sweet and innocent as to have almost stepped from one of the ads that would intersperse the show. Her hair is styled so as to emphasise her face's tendency to puppyish plumpness (a look nowhere evident in the sleekly glamorous publicity stills of Renée Zellweger emerging to promote this film, the forthcoming Me, Myself & Irene and the just-wrapped Bridget Jones).

Everything changes when Betty accidentally witnesses the gruesome murder of her swinish husband Del, played by Aaron Eckhart, a dodgy used car dealer with a revolting misogynist sneer and an objectionable semi-mullet of a hairstyle. Del's two assassins are Charlie (Morgan Freeman) and Wesley (Chris Rock), who happen to have a large quantity of drugs hidden in the back of a stolen car that Del is illegally trying to re-introduce to the "pre-owned" market.

But seeing Del's bloody despatch sends poor Betty over the edge; in a state of traumatised shock, she believes herself to be Nurse Betty, the one true love of Dr David Ravell, and she resolves to drive to Los Angeles to find him and marry him. Naturally she takes the car with the drugs hidden in it, so Charlie and Wesley head off after her in pursuit, with Charlie nursing a yearning, obsessive, late-menopausal interest in the kind of woman Betty might be.

It's the death of Del that is the saddest and most frustrating thing about Nurse Betty: very early on, the grit is removed from the oyster, and the film's one authentically nasty person is deleted. Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock aren't real bad guys; Freeman is sold to us as the purveyor of gentle, weary wisdom, underlined by the half-smile and the half-moon spectacles that Hollywood generally assigns to the Token Black Judge character, and Rock is the streetwise avatar of comedy cool.

From there on in, Renée Zellweger floats alone in a bubble of space-cadet kookiness, without the dramatic interest of enforced intimacy with a genuinely unpleasant character.

Zellweger has the cutesy, squeaky, semi-strangulated voice that is a few notches up the caricature-scale from the voice she had in Jerry Maguire, and it's all part of what her would-be assailants call the "Doris Day thing" that she has going.

It is actually a very finely wrought and professionally executed character study from Zellweger, whose brio and charm persuades you, more or less, to buy the plot's trickiest element: Betty finally meeting her TV hero in the flesh, and him believing that she is a method actress auditioning for a part in the programme. As Nurse Betty, Renée Zellweger emerges as a very accomplished performer and comedian. Her performance really grows on you throughout, with an accretion of engaging little touches.

But, really, what is the point of Nurse Betty? There is such a curious air of redundant social commentary and satire about the whole enterprise. It's as if the film expects plaudits for the allegedly funky idea of TV invading reality; but this was a talking point around the time of The Killing of Sister George (1968) or Network (1976) and John Sayles's excellent and under-rated 1992 film Passion Fish was much more interesting and original about the existence of a daytime soap star.

If Nurse Betty is Neil LaBute's bid for the mainstream, then maybe its watery similarity to his tougher, more astringent earlier work has at least a certain consistency. Another director might simply have taken on a more thoroughly commercial picture, and regarded it as a pay-packet to subsidise his more heartfelt ventures. But it's difficult to escape the feeling that Neil LaBute has lost his edge, and may be slipping, prematurely, into a creative middle age.

fields.headline: Horror that never dies
fields.standfirst:
Back to Methuselah
The Other Place, Stratford-upon-Avon
****
fields.trailText:
Back to Methuselah
The Other Place, Stratford-upon-Avon
****
fields.body:
Is anything unstageable? Watching Shaw's "metabiological pentateuch", it strikes me that only intellectual laziness deems certain plays unperformable. Whatever one thinks of Shaw's five-part journey from part to future, David Fielding's heavily cut, brilliantly visual Royal Shakespeare Company production certainly proves it can hold its place on the modern stage.

An admired colleague this week classified Shaw as "evil", fit to be ranked alongside Hitler: he cited as part of his case this supposedly barmy vision of a long-life utopia dominated by pure thought. But, with all respect, this is a misreading of Shaw. Back to Methuselah, which he finished in 1921, is based on two strong Shavian emotions: detestation of the social consequences of Darwinism and despair at the horrors unleashed by the first world war. Shaw believed that western civilisation was doomed. His answer was to come up with a scientific religion, Creative Evolution, in which mankind through will and imagination achieved longevity and wisdom. Optimistically naive perhaps but scarcely evil.

Seeing Back to Methuselah, what also hits one is Shaw's subversive humour and ability to question his own thesis. The Garden of Eden offers an ironised Genesis with Adam and Eve happily escaping "the burden of immortality". In the second and funniest of the plays, set in 1920s London, we see how the rejection of biological determinism by the Brothers Barnabas is turned into an election slogan by opportunist Liberal politicians.

If Shaw's vision of the future arouses qualms, one can only say that he himself seems to share them. In the fourth play, set in Galway in 3000 AD, the newly evolved long-livers are humourless automatons who advocate extermination of the unfit. Shaw's ultimate glimpse of Arcadia, where the young are born out of eggs, where art and music are transient delights and where the He and She-Ancients are sexless, hairless and passionless, is also calculatedly repellent. Shaw is writing out of despair at human folly; but, having created a radical blueprint for the future, he implies that the price of a willed longevity may be a decorous sterility.

In realising Shaw's vision, Fielding's production offers its own criticism. The evening is presented as if it were a laboratory experiment, starting with a scientist flinging a dead fawn onto the Edenic stage. And when we get to the final play, with its unisex long-livers and mitred ancients in topless sheaths, we sense that death might be preferable to this joyless paradise.

Andrew Walsh's designs skilfully use videogames and shape-shifting computerised images to question Shaw's futuristic vision. And the cast, leaping from aeon to aeon, do a remarkable job. Julian Curry moves easily from a Hampstead evolutionist to a gender-transcending ancient, Caroline Harris starts as a jump-suited Eve and ends as an artificially-recreated Cleopatra, while Adam Levy throughout embodies the kind of male militarism Shaw detests. You may not be persuaded by Shaw's vision of Creative Evolution, but the surprise revelation of this four-hour, unpredictably enjoyable evening is that neither was Shaw himself.

Until October 7. Box office: 01789 403403.

fields.headline: Cyber cinema: Spetember 2000
fields.trailText: The following reviews aim to give a rough guide to just a few of the many short film sites out there
fields.body:
The following reviews aim to give a rough guide to just a few of the many short film sites out there. Content and sites change; our reviewers' comments are what they found when they visited the sites during September 2000. All sites were tested on PCs and and macs and with both dial-up modem and broadband connections. We welcome your comments, and if you would like us to review your site, please email us at film.feedback@guardianunlimited.co.uk.

Reviews by Kate Stables, Sean Dodson, Emma Yates and Imogen Tilden.

Absolut Panushka
An online experimental animation festival that featured 32 films in 1998. Still live, still worth a look - in spite of all the films being about a very famous brand of Swedish vodka.

afilmcinado.net
A well-intentioned but sparsely stocked "alternative" site, which was concentrating largely on German shorts at our last glance. Horribly slow downloads (even with a broadband connection) meant that we couldn't gauge how trippy Irish thriller The Trip was intended to be. RealPlayer and QuickTime options are offered, but be prepared for a unhealthy wait between clicking and viewing.

always independent
A good selection of independent movies from minute-long shorts to full-length features. Also includes a classic film section that - if you have the patience - streams old black and whites like The Three Stooges' Brideless Groom and Chaplin's The Gold Rush. You'll need a Windows Media Player to see the majority of them (sorry, mac users).

AtomFilms
Probably the most famous and most visited short film site on the Web. Atom's comprehensive choice and popular content make it a good place to learn what you enjoy - and what you want to avoid - in the world of webfilm. Roam all over this vast and varied site, to sample work running from Oscar nominated shorts, through festival favourites and foreign films, to "extreme" interactive animations. To see more than featured picks requires registration as an Atom Insider, which is free and doesn't (to date) result in a tsunami of junk email. All streaming video formats are catered for. Gadget freaks can have shorts sent to their personal digital organizer or WAP phone, to stun the bus queue.

Bijou Cafe
Movie lovers with a taste for kitsch cinema will love this site - as long as they have access to a superfast connection. Bijou Cafe stream old feature-length movies from Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee in Horror Express to transvestite classic Glen or Glenda.

BinaryTheater
A cheerful American single page site with half a dozen titles, all under 15 minutes. Its raison d'être is to give free, unlimited distribution to the best work from US film schools. We'd guess that the cream of US film school shorts pour headlong onto higher-profile sites like Atom and IFilm, but if you have a RealVideo plugin, this is worth a quick look.

The Bit Screen
Convince yourself that the web is the next broadcast medium, by stopping in at The Bit Screen. Owner Nora Barry has a messianic interest in first run web-specific work, and this is the place to pick up on interactive artistic novelties like self-assembly webfilms. Look out for Random Shuffles - films programmed to reconfigure for each successive site visitor. Succulent animations were programmed when we visited, including Billy Blob's stylised satire Darwin Bug. Four works are featured every week, which can be viewed using Shockwave or RealPlayer, but there's no on-site archive


Camp Chaos
Cartoonist Bob Cesca's web HQ, and home to his set of energetic, taste-free Flash cartoon series, which are updated weekly. Lovers of American "extreme content" animation will fall giggling onto his topical spoofs, but we preferred Mafia series This Thing of Ours. Browse through Public Domain Theater, which marries cheesy black and white B-movie footage with parody voiceover, should you have the time. If you can't hear anything, check you've updated your Flash plugin.

Culturejam
Culturejam is that counter-culture curiosity, a site dedicated to streaming subversive media to the masses. A welcome shot of guerilla media is delivered in a single RealPlayer short film, highlighting the issue of the week. Sticking it to the military-industrial complex when we showed up was the mind-expander's manifesto Mother May I ? (Control My Own Consciousness). There's no film archive on site, so counter-media connoisseurs will need to demonstrate solidarity by regular attendance.


D.Film
Now grown up from its diminutive indie roots into a fully fledged festival and supporting website, D.film picks one film a month to showcase. Recent highlights include an excerpt from The Week Before, a beautiful, slow-moving silent movie about God in the seven days before he created the earth, and Mutate, by British director Jack Price. Each film offers you the option of downloading it or watching it via streaming QuickTime.


Director Unknown
Using a Dogme '95-style manifesto to create a "movie of the web", six young American film-makers have put together a fresh but flakey 12-episode RealPlayer thriller on this site. Each short episode was shot in a day by a member of the collective, and sometimes - inevitably - it shows. Watch their Lynchian streamed video in episode order, using a broadband connection if at all possible.

Evan Mather
The delightful and diverse offerings of prolific short film-maker Evan Mather, packed into a single page site, both Mac and PC-friendly. He made his name with surreal Star Wars parodies like Les Pantless Menace, one of a series of lo-tech spoofs stuffed with plastic figurines and disco soundtracks. If these crowd-pleasers leave you cold, try out his funky, rough-edged animations, such as Fansom The Lizard. An excellent antidote to the plague of one-joke Flash cartoons that friends insist on cramming into your email inbox with.


Flash Film Festival
The showcase site for New York's July 2000 Flash Film Festival, which "honoured the best motion graphics and animation on earth". Although the festival has been and gone, you can still roam through the 10 categories (including design, 3D, interactivity, cartoons), and check out the five finalists. The games section is particularly good fun - we liked Assassinate A Celebrity and Chicken Killer. But the navigation can be confusing and, when we looked, some of the pages weren't accessible. Overall the site is well designed and good fun though.

Get Out There
Fresh, unvarnished first-time film-making is BT's site's selling-point. When we visited, we found a choice of 116 lively QuickTime film shorts and animations, some more highly-polished than others. Since films automatically gather points when they are visited - rather than voted for - you may find the Top 10 charts longer on novelty than quality. Jewels like Chris Titchborne's Tommy Grimbald or couch potato cautionary tale Horsehair can be found lower down the listings, with a bit of digging. We liked the Least Popular Films chart option, with its very British appeal for lovers of lame-dog cinema.

hahabonk
Holy arse-kicking ecclesiasticals! Undisputed star of this likeably laddish British comedy site is the animated series The Cloth, which owes more to the comic book than the Good Book. We also liked Sickboys Pocket Cinema for animated 30-second versions of movie classics, all sicker than Linda Blair on a cross-channel ferry. You'll need RealPlayer and Flash plugins to access the site, and patience for the excruciatingly slow downloads on normal modems.

Heavy.com
Superfunky, laid-back site that gives you the choice of "slim" or "fat" modem speeds before unleashing its hip hop-tinged content on yo' ass. Predominantly music and TV-based, there's a wonderful pastiche of Behind the Music called Behind the Music That Sucks, deriding superstars such as Barbra Streisand and Billy Joel. You can get seriously distracted in the 'Contagious' section ("it's probably in your inbox already"), which is full of those annoying 20-second clips of disgruntled office workers going ape. Too chilled out for any type of mission statement, the site works on a pin-and-blindfold style of navigation.


Hollywood Shorts
Aims to provide emerging directors, writers, and producers the means of showing their short films and videos. Three or four films are showcased on the site each month, as well as screened at a cinema in Los Angeles. It's the closest to cinema film yet: each short lasts up to 40 minutes, but navigation is simple and a choice of modem speed is available for each film. Painful indeed for those of us without broadband access, but worth paying attention to in the future.


HotWired: Animation Express
We haven't been so excited by a rectangular window since watching Playschool. Look into this site to catch a fine selection of glossy animation in vast, glitch-free video windows. Pick anything you fancy off the front-page carousel - it's all pretty damn good frankly. We were taken with arty fare like The Last Hula Doll, as well as the enjoyably perverse Sex Slave Series , whose plotlines do indeed "mesh like a well-oiled orgy". There is big name content too, from Joe Corrao and Pixar Studios. Flash, Shockwave and QuickTime plugins required, all of which are available onsite.

Hypnotic
Seasoned webfilm seekers may remember this site as Reelshort, before its acquisition by Universal Pictures. Now reborn as 'new media film studio' Hypnotic, the site boasts a glossy new look and a significantly sharper range of films. All the usual hype-dodging rules still apply however - try and avoid ballyhooed spoofs (like The Sick Sense) and have a rummage in the channels. We approved thoroughly of Hypnotic's line in bizarre or experimental work such as Nude Descending and Crawley. Oh, and don't forget to sample their popular and wonderfully offensive episodic series Rick and Steve, the Happiest Gay Couple In All the World .

Icebox
Another Flash animation site that boasts that this is independent film-making with "no rules, no filters, no studio executives." And while its Hidden Celebrity Webcam is an admirable spoof, Icebox too often ladles up a series of episodic shorts that all can suffer from being more than a little juvenile. Still, the cartoons are well drawn and the site is admirably organised.

ifilm
Claims, not unjustifiably, to be the best place for internet film. ifilm certainly is one of the best starting points for newcomers, part portal - offering links to other webfilms and sites - and part independent - commissioning and screening shorts of its own. Films are divided thematically, the running time is listed for each, and most offer the choice of viewing media. The navigation is clear and easy and user review options complete an impressively rounded picture.


JibJab
This New York-based Flash cartoon site was only established in November 1999, but has already won a host of industry awards. Dedicated to "producing original entertainment for online channels", the Spiridelli brothers have created a host of animated characters such as Nasty Santa, Hoola Boy and the farting waffle. Although some of the humour is a tad adolescent, the Interactive Rapping President is a wonder to behold. mac and pc users both should have no problems.

Mediatrip
Sharp and successful spoofs have been the engine behind the growth of this quickwitted American entertainment site. Home of web parody hits like audience-charmer George Lucas in Love, MediaTrip also turns up occasional gems in other genres: award-winning fantasy Sentinelle hooked our interest when we ploughed through the Top 10 on your behalf. Sophisticates shouldn't miss Lil' Pimp, the freckle-faced tot who puts the 'ho in "ho-ho-ho".

The New Venue
Set up in 1996 by Jason Wishnow, the "enfant terrible of digital film", this was the first site dedicated to movies made expressly for the internet. It's for digital film-makers as much as desktop film viewers: one film is highlighted as the weekly feature, with an extensive back archive, and the Flick Tips section is a must for wannabe film-makers giving detailed advice on how to make your own digital film. If you've been paying attention, you can submit your own work for consideration. A great starting point to the whole medium; this site won't make you feel completely overwhelmed.

Pitch TV
A New York-based site that collects poetic animations and short films mostly from southern Europe and latin America. Each short is either dubbed or subtitled and the films are shown in a pop-up box courtesy of Macromedia Flash. There is a notable world movie e-zine to accompany the films. But it is the shorts that are of most interest here. They are, quite literally, poetry in motion.

The Quickie
Small but perfectly formed animation site. Terming itself "one of the internet's premiere cartoon animation sites", the navigation is simple, and the site's sense of humour is evident on every page. Don't miss the Star Wars - Episode 9, a prize winner in the World Entertainment Animation animated comedy / parody category. Han Solo has become a Travis Bickle-type figure, while Luke uses the force to move papers from the in to the out tray at work in the Jedi corporation. mac and pc-friendly.

Reel Screen
reelscreen sensibly offer just five "highest rated" and "new film" picks apiece on the film page of this smart British site. Which steered us straight to the best of their holdings, studded with goodies like feverish festival fave Nite Owl, and Jester, Nick Herbert's accomplished medieval animation. We suggest you stick to the chart path, unless you have the urge, the time and the stamina to work through their diverse archive, whose film listings can be unhelpfully bald.

ShortFest
Those serious about shorts should bookmark this ingenious American site, which employs a festival format with seasonal changes of programme. ShortFest is made up of five thoughtful strands of US and international short film programming, each themed and guest-curated by an industry specialist. When we checked in, Moira Griffin's Telling Tales strand had gems such as Jim Trainor's pencil scrawled picaresque, Bats. Some films can run as long as 25-40 minutes, so use the programme notes to plan your viewing. Currently only available in QuickTime and RealPlayer.

sputnik7
Drop-dead cool US entertainment site and haven for lovers of Japanese "anime" film. Those happy few with broadband and unmetered access can find a continuous programme of short films and full length anime features such as Orguss 02, on video channel 7.04. The rest of us steer our way to the modish video-on-demand choices, which run in RealPlayer or Windows Media Player. If you wish to browse the archives, you'll need to register as a site user.

The Surrey Stick Figure Theatre of Death
An oldie but goldie, which dates from the web's prelapsarian period but is still commanding a devoted following for its weekly releases. David Thorpe's sly stick-figure massacres are 10-second masterpieces of black humour and comic timing. Thumb through the vast archive to find Theatre of Death classics like The Surrealist and Hamlet, or sample cinema spoofs like Pulp Sticktion. Severed-head-and-shoulders above similar sites, in our opinion.

Switch2.net
A good-looking UK general entertainment site, with a grabby come-hither animated interface. SHORTS, their film channel, turns out to be fewer than 10 - albeit classy - choices of film. Australian director Monica Pellizari's quirky Just Desserts, and a winning selection from the Rushes Soho Shorts Festival 2000 were on offer when we visited. For such a user-friendly site, the lack of film timings and the provision of matchbook-sized viewing windows are an unnecessary irritant.


Undergroundfilm.com
Not as alternative as its name might suggest. Still, it offers up a well-chosen archive of 180 independent shorts (mostly American), with a fair selection of artistic film, plus one bizarre experimental animated series, the macabre Braingirl. Dive straight into the handful of rotating Editor's Film Picks on the home page, to avoid the fiddly list-based navigation system. We hit lucky with Flucht, an atmospheric monochrome thriller following one man and his paranoia around a small German town. QuickTime 4 only here, but the site's spacious video windows and crisp images may well be worth the download time to acquire it.

Urban Desires
Primarily an online magazine, this is a stylish site that also showcases the work of new directors. There is good supplementary material including interviews with the directors and an archive of previously shown work. It looks great, but the almost total lack of comprehensive navigation makes it a frustrating experience.

Urban Entertainment
This hip, black-themed entertainment site has a breakout hit on its hands in animated blaxploitation spoof series Undercover Brother. Though the compact short film section has its moments - try Charles Stone's goofy True for size - we found that animated series like the raucous Pookie Poo were the real finds. Graphic-novel enthusiasts will also want to check out moody adult animated thriller The Contract. Gratifyingly fast daytime downloads, provided you've got Flash or RealPlayer.
fields.bodyText: The following reviews aim to give a rough guide to just a few of the many short film sites out there. Content and sites change; our reviewers' comments are what they found when they visited the sites during September 2000. All sites were tested on PCs and and macs and with both dial-up modem and broadband connections. We welcome your comments, and if you would like us to review your site, please email us at film.feedback@guardianunlimited.co.uk. Reviews by Kate Stables, Sean Dodson, Emma Yates and Imogen Tilden. Absolut Panushka An online experimental animation festival that featured 32 films in 1998. Still live, still worth a look - in spite of all the films being about a very famous brand of Swedish vodka. afilmcinado.net A well-intentioned but sparsely stocked "alternative" site, which was concentrating largely on German shorts at our last glance. Horribly slow downloads (even with a broadband connection) meant that we couldn't gauge how trippy Irish thriller The Trip was intended to be. RealPlayer and QuickTime options are offered, but be prepared for a unhealthy wait between clicking and viewing. always independent A good selection of independent movies from minute-long shorts to full-length features. Also includes a classic film section that - if you have the patience - streams old black and whites like The Three Stooges' Brideless Groom and Chaplin's The Gold Rush. You'll need a Windows Media Player to see the majority of them (sorry, mac users). AtomFilms Probably the most famous and most visited short film site on the Web. Atom's comprehensive choice and popular content make it a good place to learn what you enjoy - and what you want to avoid - in the world of webfilm. Roam all over this vast and varied site, to sample work running from Oscar nominated shorts, through festival favourites and foreign films, to "extreme" interactive animations. To see more than featured picks requires registration as an Atom Insider, which is free and doesn't (to date) result in a tsunami of junk email. All streaming video formats are catered for. Gadget freaks can have shorts sent to their personal digital organizer or WAP phone, to stun the bus queue. Bijou Cafe Movie lovers with a taste for kitsch cinema will love this site - as long as they have access to a superfast connection. Bijou Cafe stream old feature-length movies from Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee in Horror Express to transvestite classic Glen or Glenda. BinaryTheater A cheerful American single page site with half a dozen titles, all under 15 minutes. Its raison d'être is to give free, unlimited distribution to the best work from US film schools. We'd guess that the cream of US film school shorts pour headlong onto higher-profile sites like Atom and IFilm, but if you have a RealVideo plugin, this is worth a quick look. The Bit Screen Convince yourself that the web is the next broadcast medium, by stopping in at The Bit Screen. Owner Nora Barry has a messianic interest in first run web-specific work, and this is the place to pick up on interactive artistic novelties like self-assembly webfilms. Look out for Random Shuffles - films programmed to reconfigure for each successive site visitor. Succulent animations were programmed when we visited, including Billy Blob's stylised satire Darwin Bug. Four works are featured every week, which can be viewed using Shockwave or RealPlayer, but there's no on-site archive Camp Chaos Cartoonist Bob Cesca's web HQ, and home to his set of energetic, taste-free Flash cartoon series, which are updated weekly. Lovers of American "extreme content" animation will fall giggling onto his topical spoofs, but we preferred Mafia series This Thing of Ours. Browse through Public Domain Theater, which marries cheesy black and white B-movie footage with parody voiceover, should you have the time. If you can't hear anything, check you've updated your Flash plugin. Culturejam Culturejam is that counter-culture curiosity, a site dedicated to streaming subversive media to the masses. A welcome shot of guerilla media is delivered in a single RealPlayer short film, highlighting the issue of the week. Sticking it to the military-industrial complex when we showed up was the mind-expander's manifesto Mother May I ? (Control My Own Consciousness). There's no film archive on site, so counter-media connoisseurs will need to demonstrate solidarity by regular attendance. D.Film Now grown up from its diminutive indie roots into a fully fledged festival and supporting website, D.film picks one film a month to showcase. Recent highlights include an excerpt from The Week Before, a beautiful, slow-moving silent movie about God in the seven days before he created the earth, and Mutate, by British director Jack Price. Each film offers you the option of downloading it or watching it via streaming QuickTime. Director Unknown Using a Dogme '95-style manifesto to create a "movie of the web", six young American film-makers have put together a fresh but flakey 12-episode RealPlayer thriller on this site. Each short episode was shot in a day by a member of the collective, and sometimes - inevitably - it shows. Watch their Lynchian streamed video in episode order, using a broadband connection if at all possible. Evan Mather The delightful and diverse offerings of prolific short film-maker Evan Mather, packed into a single page site, both Mac and PC-friendly. He made his name with surreal Star Wars parodies like Les Pantless Menace, one of a series of lo-tech spoofs stuffed with plastic figurines and disco soundtracks. If these crowd-pleasers leave you cold, try out his funky, rough-edged animations, such as Fansom The Lizard. An excellent antidote to the plague of one-joke Flash cartoons that friends insist on cramming into your email inbox with. Flash Film Festival The showcase site for New York's July 2000 Flash Film Festival, which "honoured the best motion graphics and animation on earth". Although the festival has been and gone, you can still roam through the 10 categories (including design, 3D, interactivity, cartoons), and check out the five finalists. The games section is particularly good fun - we liked Assassinate A Celebrity and Chicken Killer. But the navigation can be confusing and, when we looked, some of the pages weren't accessible. Overall the site is well designed and good fun though. Get Out There Fresh, unvarnished first-time film-making is BT's site's selling-point. When we visited, we found a choice of 116 lively QuickTime film shorts and animations, some more highly-polished than others. Since films automatically gather points when they are visited - rather than voted for - you may find the Top 10 charts longer on novelty than quality. Jewels like Chris Titchborne's Tommy Grimbald or couch potato cautionary tale Horsehair can be found lower down the listings, with a bit of digging. We liked the Least Popular Films chart option, with its very British appeal for lovers of lame-dog cinema. hahabonk Holy arse-kicking ecclesiasticals! Undisputed star of this likeably laddish British comedy site is the animated series The Cloth, which owes more to the comic book than the Good Book. We also liked Sickboys Pocket Cinema for animated 30-second versions of movie classics, all sicker than Linda Blair on a cross-channel ferry. You'll need RealPlayer and Flash plugins to access the site, and patience for the excruciatingly slow downloads on normal modems. Heavy.com Superfunky, laid-back site that gives you the choice of "slim" or "fat" modem speeds before unleashing its hip hop-tinged content on yo' ass. Predominantly music and TV-based, there's a wonderful pastiche of Behind the Music called Behind the Music That Sucks, deriding superstars such as Barbra Streisand and Billy Joel. You can get seriously distracted in the 'Contagious' section ("it's probably in your inbox already"), which is full of those annoying 20-second clips of disgruntled office workers going ape. Too chilled out for any type of mission statement, the site works on a pin-and-blindfold style of navigation. Hollywood Shorts Aims to provide emerging directors, writers, and producers the means of showing their short films and videos. Three or four films are showcased on the site each month, as well as screened at a cinema in Los Angeles. It's the closest to cinema film yet: each short lasts up to 40 minutes, but navigation is simple and a choice of modem speed is available for each film. Painful indeed for those of us without broadband access, but worth paying attention to in the future. HotWired: Animation Express We haven't been so excited by a rectangular window since watching Playschool. Look into this site to catch a fine selection of glossy animation in vast, glitch-free video windows. Pick anything you fancy off the front-page carousel - it's all pretty damn good frankly. We were taken with arty fare like The Last Hula Doll, as well as the enjoyably perverse Sex Slave Series , whose plotlines do indeed "mesh like a well-oiled orgy". There is big name content too, from Joe Corrao and Pixar Studios. Flash, Shockwave and QuickTime plugins required, all of which are available onsite. Hypnotic Seasoned webfilm seekers may remember this site as Reelshort, before its acquisition by Universal Pictures. Now reborn as 'new media film studio' Hypnotic, the site boasts a glossy new look and a significantly sharper range of films. All the usual hype-dodging rules still apply however - try and avoid ballyhooed spoofs (like The Sick Sense) and have a rummage in the channels. We approved thoroughly of Hypnotic's line in bizarre or experimental work such as Nude Descending and Crawley. Oh, and don't forget to sample their popular and wonderfully offensive episodic series Rick and Steve, the Happiest Gay Couple In All the World . Icebox Another Flash animation site that boasts that this is independent film-making with "no rules, no filters, no studio executives." And while its Hidden Celebrity Webcam is an admirable spoof, Icebox too often ladles up a series of episodic shorts that all can suffer from being more than a little juvenile. Still, the cartoons are well drawn and the site is admirably organised. ifilm Claims, not unjustifiably, to be the best place for internet film. ifilm certainly is one of the best starting points for newcomers, part portal - offering links to other webfilms and sites - and part independent - commissioning and screening shorts of its own. Films are divided thematically, the running time is listed for each, and most offer the choice of viewing media. The navigation is clear and easy and user review options complete an impressively rounded picture. JibJab This New York-based Flash cartoon site was only established in November 1999, but has already won a host of industry awards. Dedicated to "producing original entertainment for online channels", the Spiridelli brothers have created a host of animated characters such as Nasty Santa, Hoola Boy and the farting waffle. Although some of the humour is a tad adolescent, the Interactive Rapping President is a wonder to behold. mac and pc users both should have no problems. Mediatrip Sharp and successful spoofs have been the engine behind the growth of this quickwitted American entertainment site. Home of web parody hits like audience-charmer George Lucas in Love, MediaTrip also turns up occasional gems in other genres: award-winning fantasy Sentinelle hooked our interest when we ploughed through the Top 10 on your behalf. Sophisticates shouldn't miss Lil' Pimp, the freckle-faced tot who puts the 'ho in "ho-ho-ho". The New Venue Set up in 1996 by Jason Wishnow, the "enfant terrible of digital film", this was the first site dedicated to movies made expressly for the internet. It's for digital film-makers as much as desktop film viewers: one film is highlighted as the weekly feature, with an extensive back archive, and the Flick Tips section is a must for wannabe film-makers giving detailed advice on how to make your own digital film. If you've been paying attention, you can submit your own work for consideration. A great starting point to the whole medium; this site won't make you feel completely overwhelmed. Pitch TV A New York-based site that collects poetic animations and short films mostly from southern Europe and latin America. Each short is either dubbed or subtitled and the films are shown in a pop-up box courtesy of Macromedia Flash. There is a notable world movie e-zine to accompany the films. But it is the shorts that are of most interest here. They are, quite literally, poetry in motion. The Quickie Small but perfectly formed animation site. Terming itself "one of the internet's premiere cartoon animation sites", the navigation is simple, and the site's sense of humour is evident on every page. Don't miss the Star Wars - Episode 9, a prize winner in the World Entertainment Animation animated comedy / parody category. Han Solo has become a Travis Bickle-type figure, while Luke uses the force to move papers from the in to the out tray at work in the Jedi corporation. mac and pc-friendly. fields.headline: Miracle of memory
fields.standfirst:
Zehetmair Quartet
Queen's Hall, Edinburgh
*****
fields.trailText:
Zehetmair Quartet
Queen's Hall, Edinburgh
*****
fields.body:
Feats of memory are badges of a musician's professionalism, yet seeing the Zehetmair Quartet play a whole programme from memory - a challenge hardly ever attempted by most string quartets - was a uniquely compelling experience. Even more astounding was the range of music in that programme. Haydn's C Major Quartet, Op 74 No 1, and Schumann's Second, F Major Quartet, surrounded a performance of Karl Amadeus Hartmann's Second String Quartet, a piece rarely heard in this country.

The benefits of the Zehetmairs' combined memory were immediately apparent. Each player knew the intricacies of the other three parts. In the Haydn quartet, Thomas Zehetmair - leader and founder of the ensemble, as well as a renowned soloist - engaged in a continuous dialogue of gestures with his colleagues. The result was a performance of extraordinary poetic range. The minuet was a masterpiece of artful rusticity, whilst the unadulterated round-dance of the finale exploded with thrilling, violent abandon.

The performance of Schumann's F Major Quartet was also searingly imaginative. But their account of the Hartmann quartet was still more astonishing. Written just after the second world war, Hartmann's work is an unrelenting lament. Throughout the three movements, Hartmann finds an expressive language between the rigour of serialism and the disengagement of neo-classicism. But at the same time as creating a fascinating stylistic synthesis, Hartmann's quartet makes a profoundly personal statement.

At the end of the slow movement, in the wake of a cataclysmic climax, the music's final gesture is a barely audible major chord. In the context of the Zehetmairs' performance, this moment was a vision of an untroubled past, a state of bliss impossible to attain in the post-1945 world. But when the frantic energy of the last movement also finished with a major chord, this time forceful, the effect was different. Here, the gesture seemed hollow .

For the Zehetmair Quartet to achieve the symbiotic musicality they displayed in the classical and romantic repertoires was remarkable in itself. But to manage the same intimate rapport in the complex music of Hartmann was miraculous.

fields.headline: Bringing it back home
fields.standfirst:
Sheila Nicholls
12 Bar Club, London
***
fields.trailText:
Sheila Nicholls
12 Bar Club, London
***
fields.body:
Sheila Nicholls is a 29-year-old Colchester girl who went to LA 10 years ago, and has recently returned with a debut album, Brief Strop, full of melodic songs about life and love in Hollywood. She enters barefoot, wearing a shiny dress, a green tiara and multicoloured tangle of braids. After squeezing onto the tiny stage with an electric piano, a cello player and a fiery female guitarist, Nicholls takes off the tiara, shakes her head and sings with carefully controlled anger about "facing your internalised patriarchy" or nihilism in relationships ("the land of don't care").

Sounding like a cross between Liz Phair and Kate Bush, she wraps up her girl power message in swathes of soulful melody, English folk lyricism and touches of musical theatre. Sometimes her ambition is overreaching: one number involves trippy steel guitar and vague references to circles in her head but never quite gets there; another is an earnest meditation on sunflowers.

Much more pointed are her songs about love, which are delivered with a rare emotional honesty. "This song is about some bloke I fancied," Nicholls says, playing a few rolling chords. She pauses. "I was really flippant. This song actually means a lot to me," she adds quietly, before launching into the low-key but beautifully wrought Don't Die on the Vine. There's also Fallen For You, a contemplative song about unrequited love that's featured on the High Fidelity movie soundtrack, and Rapunzel, a simple paean to self-realisation.

Her family are here too. When a voluble woman at the back shouts requests, Nicholls sighs: "Mother? Shush!" The proud relations cheer loudly at the end of the show, causing Nicholls to say with Essex-girl self-deprecation, "That's just family." She concludes with Ruby, a vaudevillian tale of sex in the city. She gives it an offhand delivery, but is clearly delighted.

webTitle: Rate rise fails to lift euro

fields.headline: Rate rise fails to lift euro
fields.standfirst:
Dealers deride desperate efforts to prop up currency as it sinks to record low

Money Unlimited

Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: A fifth rise in rates this year by an increasingly jittery European Central Bank failed to prevent Europe's embattled single currency from sinking to a record low against the US dollar last night.
fields.body:
A fifth rise in rates this year by an increasingly jittery European Central Bank failed to prevent Europe's embattled single currency from sinking to a record low against the US dollar last night.

Senior European policymakers made frantic efforts to talk the euro up in the aftermath of the ECB's decision to raise borrowing costs by 0.25 percentage points to 4.5%. Even so, the currency came under renewed pressure on the foreign exchange market.

A tentative rally following the lunchtime decision was quickly reversed as some dealers expressed concern that the ECB had shied away from tougher action to shore up the euro, while others feared that higher rates would choke off growth in the euro zone. In late trading it broke through its lifetime low of 88.45 cents, set in May this year, hitting 88.40 before recovering.

Dealers said only the risk of intervention by the ECB ahead of a holiday weekend in the US spared the euro from further selling pressure in New York last night.

Though the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, said yesterday that the euro zone was set to enjoy buoyant economic growth, he failed to convince the market to buy.

"The economy is strong enough to support a strong currency and, independent from the current development of the exchange rate, the euro is a strong currency and will remain so," Mr Schröder told ZDF television.

The Bundesbank president, Ernst Welteke, also insisted that yesterday's increase in borrowing costs would not harm growth prospects in the euro zone, stressing the outlook was "exceptionally positive."

But, because of price pressures stemming from the euro's weakness and high oil prices, the ECB was reacting "with timely interest rate rises".

The markets had been braced for the ECB to raise rates in order to bring inflation below the 2% threshold and give some support to the euro, which has lost 25% of its value since its launch in January last year.

However, signs of a slowdown in the euro zone's two biggest economies - Germany and France - have led some investors to believe that the Bank may be killing growth rather than inflation. Global investors and traders have dumped the euro in favour of the US dollar, betting on better growth prospects and higher returns from the American economy.

This was underlined by an early leak yesterday of the International Monetary Fund's influential World Economic Outlook, due to be published later this month. According to the IMF, the euro zone will grow by 3.4% this year, while the US will grow by 4.9%.

After the decision last month by the Federal Reserve to keep US rates on hold, dealers are confident that the record-breaking American ex pansion will end in a soft rather than a hard landing.

Recent data suggestthat the German and French economies may have peaked. Germany's closely watched Ifo business climate index fell in July for the second month running, while figures out yesterday showed French unemployment in July rose to 9.7% from a nine-year low of 9.6% in June. Separate data showed French industrial production shrank in June.

Last night analysts were warning that borrowing costs might rise still further in October.

fields.headline: LSE hits back at 'jingoism'
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange yesterday hit out against the "jingoism" which its proposed merger with its German rival has attracted.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange yesterday hit out against the "jingoism" which its proposed merger with its German rival has attracted.

Don Cruickshank, chairman of the London exchange, voiced his criticisms as he announced a scheme which would dramatically reduce the costs of trading German and British shares across boundaries.

The plan is a central feature of the proposed merger of the two exchanges to form iX.

The issue is unlikely to be settled before October, however, now that OM of Sweden has made a hostile £808m bid.

The audacious offer from OM, which runs the Stockholm stock exchange, yesterday helped to propel shares in the London exchange to a new high of £28.80, well above the £27 being offered by OM.

Mr Cruickshank said he found "any hint of jingoism deeply depressing" but noted that such sentiment in parts of the media was "latent" with regard to the OM bid and more explicit in reference to the German merger plan. "It is not a view I share."

Concern that a solo bid by the Deutsche Börse to try to protect the London exchange would be unpopular and seen as too Teutonic is understood to be a key reason why the German exchange has dropped broad hints that it would like to recruit allies from other European bourses - notably Madrid and Milan - if it were to proceed with a "white knight" offer for the London exchange.

Mr Cruickshank made it clear yesterday that he had not invited such a "white knight" bid from his Germany counterparts, neither had the exchange received any offers other than the one officially announced by OM on Tuesday.

The plan unveiled by Mr Cruickshank to reduce the cost of trading German and British shares has been put together by the two organisations which clear trades behind the scenes on the London and German stock exchanges.

The organisations, Crest in London and Clearstream in Germany, said cross-border trades - which account for only a small proportion of transactions - could be settled for as little as domestic trades. They are at present up to 90% more expensive.

The scheme was warmly welcomed by Angela Knight, chief executive of the private client stockbrokers' lobby group Apcims.

"We are very pleased with this announcement, as it will provide a simple, inexpensive means to settle all iX trades.Even if iX does not become a reality, the link is still valuable - the arrangements will still be in place for settling German shares.

"It is not yet possible to quantify costs, but we will be looking forward to seeing some significant reductions for UK purchasers of continental shares."

Iain Saville, chief executive of Crest, admitted that the plan to reduce costs could take place even if the Anglo-German merger did not happen.

He also admitted that Crest had already held talks with OM and had concluded it would have to do "very little" to make OM's takeover plan feasible.

Tom Marchant, head of settlement at Winterflood, one of the smaller broking firms which has voiced concern about the creation of iX,said: "The Crest-Clearstream model is very sensible and one we support. We think it is completely viable without iX."

 There are changes in the way bonus points are earned in the millennial revision of the County Championship.

As before, a win earns 12 points , a tie 6 , a normal draw 4 (see later *) and a defeat none, plus any bonus points accrued for batting and bowling in each first innings.

Bonus points are now reckoned on the score in the first 130 overs, not 120 overs as in recent seasons.

Batting: now 5 pts can be earned (4 last year)

200 -249 runs (1pt);

250-299 (2);

300-349 (3);

350-399 (4);

400 or over (5)

Bowling: now only 3 points available (4)

three-five wickets (1);

six-eight wickets (2);

nine-ten (3).

The new ball can still be taken after 100 overs.

A no ball is worth two runs to the batting side; runs scored off a no ball count in addition to the two-run penalty.

A single-innings match may be played when bad weather prevents any start until less than eight hours remain. A win earns 12 points, a tie six and a draw three but there are no bonus points.

*Note: in a draw where the scores finish level , the side batting in the fourth innings earn 6 points their opponents 4, plus bonus points.

fields.headline: Salisbury upstages wayward Yorkshire
fields.standfirst: Surrey 330-8 v Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Surrey 330-8 v Yorkshire
fields.body:
Reports of the hopeless state of county cricket have clearly been somewhat exaggerated. A crowd of 6,000, easily the best of this championship season, were drawn to this meeting of first and third in the First Division, although Dickie Bird claimed a share of the credit for "bringing the good weather with me" and the prospect of a Viennese Night with David Jacobs at the nearby Spa can only have added to the attraction of festival week. But even Eric Pollard from Emmerdale was here at North Marine Road.

An Alliance Fish van selling trays of cockles, mussels and prawns, while the corporate guests tucked into Scarborough crab in the hospitality marquee, enhanced the feeling that this was what the county game could and should be like more often.

A win here would virtually guarantee Surrey their second consecutive title, with Lancashire eight points behind at the start of play having had a game more, and Yorkshire 10 points further back. The visitors ended the first day strongly placed with three batting points, having seized the initiative in the last session against a Yorkshire team missing their three England men and five front-line seamers.

Surrey had slipped to 197 for seven before the England-recalled Ian Salisbury, who was dropped at slip by David Byas on 11, shared a partnership of 78 with Jonathan Batty and an unbroken stand of 55 with Alex Tudor.

Byas, resuming the captaincy after a month out with a knee injury, had to turn to the occasional spin of Darren Lehmann after packing his team with seamers. Now, after choosing to bowl first, Yorkshire face the unpleasant prospect of batting last against Salisbury and Saqlain Mushtaq.

Yorkshire's extra seamer came in the unusual shape of Greg Lambert, their ninth debutant of the season, who at 6ft 8in reminded veteran supporters of Mark Robinson but would doubtless be described by Australians as the two-metre Castlefordian.

But the trio did not bowl well before lunch on a track greener than the rest of the square, although it played well enough to make Mike Denness's presence as pitch-watch "liaison officer" academic. Mark Butcher was the trio's only victim, a dismissal which must have left both Butcher and Silverwood bemused.

Among too many wasted balls Silverwood produced three jaffas to Ian Ward. But, while Ward survived a loud caught-behind appeal and an edge high through the vacant third-slip position, and was then dropped when Hamilton was put there, Butcher's first edge, in Hamilton's second over, was snapped up by Simon Guy, Yorkshire's young wicketkeeper, who was again preferred to Richard Blakey.

Ward went on to show his ability and importance to this Surrey team - missing Alec Stewart, Graham Thorpe and the injured Martin Bicknell - by grafting more than three hours for 59. But his dis missal, caught at midwicket off a canny slower ball from Hoggard, was the first of five middle-order wickets to fall for 50 as Yorkshire fought back.

But Batty, Tudor and especially Salisbury replied in kind, testifying to the depth of Surrey's batting - and their spirit.

fields.headline: Middlesex give Gatting the bullet
fields.trailText: Little more than a year ago, Mike Gatting was not only the director of coaching at Middlesex but an England selector to boot. As of yesterday, the last England captain to win a Test series in Australia holds neither post, having been dismissed by the county he has served for 25 years.
fields.body:
Little more than a year ago, Mike Gatting was not only the director of coaching at Middlesex but an England selector to boot. As of yesterday, the last England captain to win a Test series in Australia holds neither post, having been dismissed by the county he has served for 25 years.

Gatting, now 43, held the job for two seasons. In his first Middlesex, who have also fired their coach Ian Gould, finished second from bottom in the county championship's Second Division and this year they are last. Gatting, who along with Graham Gooch was sacked as a Test selector last August, has now become a high-profile casualty of domestic cricket's new order.

"I think results speak for themselves," said the Middlesex secretary Vinny Codrington. "When Mike was in here this morning he was very understanding. I expect he'll pursue outside business interests now."

It seems inconceivable, however, that a man with 94 first-class centuries to his name and who, with the Pakistani umpire Shakoor Rana, contributed to one of the most unforgettable cricket images of all time, will be lost to the game for long.

Middlesex have no game in the current round of Second Division matches but second-placed Worcestershire were bowled out for 263 by Warwickshire after choosing to bat first at Edgbaston.

Vikram Solanki (71), David Leatherdale (42), Elliott Wilson (34) and David Pipe (30) all contributed and Steve Rhodes added an unbeaten 39 at the end.

Allan Donald, in his last championship appearance at Edgbaston, took four wickets and Neil Smith three and Warwickshire were 28 without loss at the close.

Darren Bicknell was largely responsible for boosting the Nottinghamshire total at Trent Bridge. The former Surrey opener made an unbeaten 139 as the hosts recovered from 163 for seven to close on 336 for eight against Sussex .

The Australian pace bowler Paul Reiffel made 74 and shared an eighth-wicket stand of 143 with Bicknell.

webTitle: Irani follows the rule of Law

fields.headline: Irani follows the rule of Law
fields.standfirst:
Essex 292
Glamorgan 40-1
fields.trailText:
Essex 292

Glamorgan 40-1
fields.body:
It is widely acknowledged that Ronnie Irani is in the best form of his career with both bat and ball. Certainly Glamorgan will testify to that - and not because of this match.

In June Cardiff was the scene of a nine-hour, career-best 168 not out. On this occasion he was not so productive, falling five short of his century, but he nevertheless produced an innings of immense value to guide his county away from a precipice.

Paul Grayson, Paul Prichard and Will Jefferson, the 20-year-old debutant, had departed within the opening five overs with only 13 on the board when a purposeful Irani strode out to join Stuart Law.

He announced his arrival by finding the boundary with his first three scoring strokes and, together with the Australian, was to prise the initiative away from the Welsh county as quickly as they had seized it.

Three successive fours by Law raised the 50 in the 12th over and the total moved into three figures at the rate of just under five an over. By then Irani had become more passive and was content to watch Law dictate with some effortless driving off the front foot.

Law looked in such control that it came as something of a surprise when, driving on the up, he dispatched Robert Croft to mid-on having scored 70 in 92 deliveries, 10 of which were boundaries.

Irani's response was to drive Croft straight for six to complete his half-century and he continued to ease the ball into the gaps until he was given out lbw when pushing forward to the slow left-armer Dean Kosker. Thereafter James Foster, another 20-year-old debutant, showed fine composure to score 52 before the return of Steve Watkin breached his forward push.

Faced with a target of 292, Glamorgan responded with 40 before the close for the loss of Steve James. He scored 309 not out in his previous championship outing but had made only a modest 30 when his stumps were disturbed by Ashley Cowan - but not before he had scored his 1,000th run of the summer.

fields.headline: Cotterell tickles the fancy
fields.standfirst: Northamptonshire 282-5 v Gloucestershire
fields.trailText: Northamptonshire 282-5 v Gloucestershire
fields.body:
The world has turned cartwheels since these sides met at Cheltenham in mid-July. At that juncture they were propping up the Second Division, seemingly as plausible a pair of candidates for promotion as a couple of cops caught stealing Kojak's lollipops.

Northamptonshire won that match to move off the bottom and have coasted home in their last four outings, opening up a 14-point lead at the top, equivalent to half a dozen furlongs. Gloucestershire, meanwhile, arrived here trailing three consecutive wins and yet another one-day pot. In a perverse twist, though, they forsook the nous of Mike Smith for the novel reason that he might leave footmarks that could be exploited by the home twirlers, who themselves were ultimately reduced to the singular by Graeme Swann's injured finger.

That left Mark Alleyne, already deprived of the reportedly knackered Ian Harvey, to take the new ball himself, and a presentable job he made of it.

Inevitably, though, the art of deception ruled and once Martyn Ball had terminated a sturdy opening stand of 82 by those occasionally incredible hulks Matthew Hayden and Adrian Rollins, luring the captain into a top-edged sweep, a handsome crowd was captivated by county cricket at its most deceptively tranquil.

The quintet who passed 40 prospered according to type: Rollins obstinate, Hayden assured, David Sales bullish, Tony Penberthy unobtrusive, Russell Warren elegant. Only the last two, however, cast aside the shackles imposed by tight bowling and the visitors' omnipresent spring-heeled fielding. One stop by Tim Hancock was the handiwork of a habitual blood donor.

While Ball spun an off-break lavishly to defeat Sales, Tom Cotterell, his southpaw partner, tickled the more aesthetic fancy.

Setting off with a Tufnellesque hop, the youngster made one dip deliciously to bowl Jeff Cook, meagre reward for an auspicious stint.

fields.headline: A shilling's worth of Illingworth
fields.standfirst: The last man to lead England to a series win over West Indies is alive and talking
fields.trailText: Whatever England's fate at the Oval, as they press for their first series win against West Indies for 31 years, one of the most common sounds will be that of Raymond Illingworth recollecting.
fields.body:
Whatever England's fate at the Oval, as they press for their first series win against West Indies for 31 years, one of the most common sounds will be that of Raymond Illingworth recollecting.

Illy's reflections on what it was like in his day have not always endeared him to England players of more modern vintage but as captain of the last England side to overcome West Indies he is perfectly entitled not just to retrace the journey up memory lane but to pitch his tent in it.

Nobody made too much of the last time England retained the Wisden Trophy. It was largely expected during a glorious period, from June 1968 to August 1971, in which England went a record 26 Tests unbeaten and regained the Ashes in Australia under Illingworth's leadership. The opening partnership of Geoffrey Boycott and John Edrich, the wicket-keeping of Alan Knott, the threat of Derek Underwood whenever a pitch was damp and the fast bowling of John Snow were among their strengths.

The West Indies side of 1969 was vulnerable. The legendary fast bowlers Wes Hall and Charlie Griffith had been discarded and the batting was shorn of Seymour Nurse and Rohan Kanhai. Illingworth, the shrewd Yorkshireman appointed captain because of Colin Cowdrey's achilles problems, plotted their downfall.

Snow, whose 15 victims in that three-Test series made him England's leading wicket-taker, recalled: "Illy was the ultimate down-to-earth professional. 'Don't give 'em this, don't give 'em that, what you doing that for?' It was a case of the old pro, who demanded to know everything, taking over from the classic old-style captain who didn't always get involved."

Snow added: "He wasn't perfect, and he never got anything wrong, but he demanded total commitment from everybody."

That brought Illingworth and Snow into direct conflict. Illingworth had been disgruntled by Snow's lack of enthusiasm for his decision to enforce the follow-on in the first Test at Old Trafford, a position forged by a Boycott century.

"He'd not done much bowling that day and I'd saved him for the follow-on but he came in and gave us one of his military-medium sessions" was the captain's scathing assessment.

The strain was still evident at Headingley, scene of the third and final Test. By the final morning West Indies needed 73 with three wickets left and Snow had hoped that the slow left-arm of Underwood, which had wrecked the top order the previous day, would be enough to wrap up the series 2-0. Instead Illingworth opted for the new ball and demanded that Snow give him "five or six quick overs".

"After one over I felt the wicket was not responding to sheer speed and I would be more effective if I slowed down a little," Snow said.

"Nothing happened for half an hour and no doubt spectators were beginning to question his wisdom in taking the new ball - all before Illy's home crowd, too. To make matters worse, David Brown took the wickets, steaming in from the other end. By then I had been banished to the boundary."

Snow's punishment was to be dropped for the next Test, New Zealand's visit to Lord's. Illingworth phoned Snow to tell him he had been disciplined, for one Test only, for "disobeying orders". Snow was livid.

Yet, little more than a year later, Snow and Illingworth celebrated the greatest achievement of all: an Ashes win in Australia. "Ray and I still had our differences after that sacking but they were always out in the open," Snow said. "From that moment I knew exactly where I stood with him, as did every other player under his captaincy.

"I wouldn't say we were an outstanding side but we were a scrabbling side. Everybody did their bit. A lot of bullshit is spoken about harmonious dressing rooms. All you need is eleven guys who want to achieve and get stuck in."

Illingworth's judgment has never shifted. "That is captaincy as I understand it. You have to fight like hell for each other. The team is what matters, the captain's job is get that team together and 100% behind him."

Happily there is more than a smattering of that attitude in today's England side.

webTitle: West Ham in dock for harassing referee

fields.headline: West Ham in dock for harassing referee
fields.standfirst: Club questions FA's credibility after learning of crackdown via Teletext
fields.trailText: West Ham were taking legal advice last night after being charged by the Football Association with harassing a referee. In an angry response to the accusations the club questioned the FA's "credibility" and accused the governing body of leaving them to learn of the news on Teletext.
fields.body:
West Ham were taking legal advice last night after being charged by the Football Association with harassing a referee. In an angry response to the accusations the club questioned the FA's "credibility" and accused the governing body of leaving them to learn of the news on Teletext.

The FA made it public late yesterday afternoon that West Ham had been charged with harassing the referee Rob Styles during last week's home defeat by Leicester. Four West Ham players, including Paolo di Canio, were also charged with improper conduct for allegedly "protesting aggressively" to Styles after the dismissal of Igor Stimac.

The club will be fined up to £250,000 if found guilty and the players - Di Canio, Davor Suker, Rio Ferdinand and Michael Carrick - could face fines and/or suspensions. Yet West Ham insisted they had not been informed and suggested they had been unfairly singled out for punishment.

"I presume we will be notified but as yet there has been no official communication," said the managing director Paul Aldridge. "Unfortunately I learned about it through Teletext and I would prefer, in future, to find out matters of such magnitude from the relevant authorities rather than via the television.

"We are very disappointed that the FA have seen fit to charge West Ham United in the light of other incidents that have occurred at the start of the season with other clubs."

West Ham are the first club to fall foul of the new crackdown on intimidation of match officials and they clearly feel hard done by. The club, who have 14 days to respond, were last night discussing the situation with their legal advisers before deciding their next step.

The FA's action follows reports at the weekend that Di Canio would be charged with misconduct for his behaviour against Leicester. And West Ham made it clear on their official website that they have not ruled out foul play.

"[The club] were surprised that such stories were circulating without the club itself expecting a punishment," they wrote. "If, indeed, there had been a "leak" from within the FA it presents a serious problem for their credibility."

The charges were based on Styles's official report rather than video evidence, and West Ham faced an automatic charge under the new FA guidelines because more than three of their team were involved.

The FA disciplinary commission will take into account Di Canio's past disciplinary record, which includes, as a Sheffield Wednesday player, an 11-game ban and £10,000 fine for pushing the referee Paul Alcock to the ground in 1998, and a £5,000 fine and severe censure for making an insulting gesture at Upton Park in January.

But it is understood the Italian forward will be hit with no more than a fine and a three-match suspension if found guilty because no physical contact was involved in the protests which followed Styles's dismissal of Stimac for a bodycheck on Robbie Savage, which earned him a second booking shortly before half-time.

Didier Deschamps has followed his fellow French international Frank Leboeuf in criticising Chelsea's manager Gianluca Vialli.

The 30-year-old midfielder, who left Stamford Bridge in pre-season for Valencia, said: "I felt very frustrated on the pitch and also in my relationships with... Vialli, which were difficult or even impossible. It was hard because I had a very different opinion of him as a player from the coach he became."

Deschamps also blamed the poor quality of the Premiership for his disappointing season with Chelsea. "In England I had difficulty showing my qualities. I arrived from Italy with techniques which were useless in England, there were too many games and no break in December."

 Juninho is set to make his Brazil comeback on Sunday - with Middlesbrough still monitoring the forward with a view to taking him back to the Riverside Stadium. The 27-year-old is in an 18-man Brazil squad for the World Cup qualifier with Bolivia in Rio de Janeiro, his first international recognition for three years.

He moved to the Rio-based Vasco da Gama recently on a 12-month loan from Atletico Madrid after Boro refused to meet the Spanish club's £6m asking price.

In an angry response to the accusations the club questioned the FA's "credibility" and accused the governing body of leaving them to learn of the news on Teletext. The FA made it public late yesterday afternoon that West Ham had been charged with harassing the referee Rob Styles during last week's home defeat by Leicester. Four West Ham players, including Paolo di Canio, were also charged with improper conduct for allegedly "protesting aggressively" to Styles after the dismissal of Igor Stimac. The club will be fined up to £250,000 if found guilty and the players - Di Canio, Davor Suker, Rio Ferdinand and Michael Carrick - could face fines and/or suspensions. Yet West Ham insisted they had not been informed and suggested they had been unfairly singled out for punishment. "I presume we will be notified but as yet there has been no official communication," said the managing director Paul Aldridge. "Unfortunately I learned about it through Teletext and I would prefer, in future, to find out matters of such magnitude from the relevant authorities rather than via the television. "We are very disappointed that the FA have seen fit to charge West Ham United in the light of other incidents that have occurred at the start of the season with other clubs." West Ham are the first club to fall foul of the new crackdown on intimidation of match officials and they clearly feel hard done by. The club, who have 14 days to respond, were last night discussing the situation with their legal advisers before deciding their next step. The FA's action follows reports at the weekend that Di Canio would be charged with misconduct for his behaviour against Leicester. And West Ham made it clear on their official website that they have not ruled out foul play. "[The club] were surprised that such stories were circulating without the club itself expecting a punishment," they wrote. "If, indeed, there had been a "leak" from within the FA it presents a serious problem for their credibility." The charges were based on Styles's official report rather than video evidence, and West Ham faced an automatic charge under the new FA guidelines because more than three of their team were involved. The FA disciplinary commission will take into account Di Canio's past disciplinary record, which includes, as a Sheffield Wednesday player, an 11-game ban and £10,000 fine for pushing the referee Paul Alcock to the ground in 1998, and a £5,000 fine and severe censure for making an insulting gesture at Upton Park in January. But it is understood the Italian forward will be hit with no more than a fine and a three-match suspension if found guilty because no physical contact was involved in the protests which followed Styles's dismissal of Stimac for a bodycheck on Robbie Savage, which earned him a second booking shortly before half-time. Didier Deschamps has followed his fellow French international Frank Leboeuf in criticising Chelsea's manager Gianluca Vialli. The 30-year-old midfielder, who left Stamford Bridge in pre-season for Valencia, said: "I felt very frustrated on the pitch and also in my relationships with... Vialli, which were difficult or even impossible. It was hard because I had a very different opinion of him as a player from the coach he became." Deschamps also blamed the poor quality of the Premiership for his disappointing season with Chelsea. "In England I had difficulty showing my qualities. I arrived from Italy with techniques which were useless in England, there were too many games and no break in December."  Juninho is set to make his Brazil comeback on Sunday - with Middlesbrough still monitoring the forward with a view to taking him back to the Riverside Stadium. The 27-year-old is in an 18-man Brazil squad for the World Cup qualifier with Bolivia in Rio de Janeiro, his first international recognition for three years. He moved to the Rio-based Vasco da Gama recently on a 12-month loan from Atletico Madrid after Boro refused to meet the Spanish club's £6m asking price.

webTitle: Chelsea accused ahead of transfer summit

fields.headline: Chelsea accused ahead of transfer summit
fields.trailText: The German club Union Berlin yesterday threatened to report Chelsea to Uefa following claims that the Londoners poached a 16-year-old defender and signed him on a three-year scholarship.
fields.body:
The German club Union Berlin yesterday threatened to report Chelsea to Uefa following claims that the Londoners poached a 16-year-old defender and signed him on a three-year scholarship.

Union Berlin are demanding compensation from Chelsea for Robert Huth, although under current regulations transfer fees do not apply to players of his age.

Under plans being considered by football authorities today any international transfer involving players under 18 could be outlawed as players' groups, Fifa, Uefa and representatives of European leagues try to formulate a response to attempts by the European Commission to challenge the current transfer system.

The commission claims that the transfer system may infringe workers' right of free movement and that players should have the right to change clubs without transfer fees being paid. It has set a deadline of September 20 for an alternative to be found.

Last night the culture secretary Chris Smith warned of the dangers if no solution could be agreed. "The worst vision in all of this could be a complete end to the transfer fee system, nothing to replace it at all, no recognition of investment in new talent and new players, no flow of funds from the top clubs down to the bottom clubs," he said.

The current confusion stems from the Perugia case, in which the Italian club refused to pay a fee for a player signed while he was still under contract to a Belgian club, and could have major implications for teams across the continent.

Top of the agenda at Fifa headquarters in Zurich today is an attempt to secure a protocol which would exempt sport from European Union regulations. This has the backing of France and a number of other EU countries.

A ban on transfers for players under 18 has been agreed by Fifa and Uefa following a suggestion by Gordon Taylor of the Professional Footballers' Association, who will take part in today's meeting.

Officials will also discuss a system of compensation for players aged 18 to 24 in recognition of the selling clubs' role in their development.

However, the main sticking point is likely to be how clubs can be compensated for players over the age of 24 if the transfer system is scrapped.

Football authorities will attempt to establish a period of notice before players could change clubs, and a level of compensation for the club. The commission wants any compensation to be based on the value of the remaining contract.
