webTitle: Captain Adams plays it by the book

fields.headline: Captain Adams plays it by the book
fields.standfirst: England's new leader is still an avid reader but stumbles over the S-word
fields.trailText: The last time Tony Adams faced a mass press conference and was asked what he was reading, he replied: "Henry V."
fields.body:
The last time Tony Adams faced a mass press conference and was asked what he was reading, he replied: "Henry V."

England were about to play Germany in Euro 2000 and the assembled scribes could not believe their luck. "Once more unto the breach, dear friends," they wrote as one, and Adams was photographed outside wrapped in the flag of St George.

Two months later and once again Adams faces the doyens of the fourth estate. No prizes for guessing the first question. "What are you reading now then, Tony?"

Those expecting an instant headline were disappointed. "Shoot," replied Adams to roars of laughter. "I'm getting good at this, aren't I?"

No. What everyone wanted him to be reading was Down and Out in Paris and London. For the tenor of expectation as England leave the capital for their next match against France on Saturday has changed dramatically from the dogged optimism that preceded that historic score-settling in Charleroi.

The pre-match mood is not the only thing that has altered. Adams is now fielding questions in his new role of England captain, the title Glenn Hoddle took off him and handed to Alan Shearer.

"Glenn had his reasons," says Adams, "and I obviously didn't agree with them," is as far he will go in expressing his disappointment publicly.

But with Shearer's retirement Adams can show Hoddle what he was missing, although it seems pre-battle rallying cries are out. As shaky old England get ready to face the world and European champions, Adams prefers to summon up the "pride in performance" line rather than the blood.

"We need to get out there and maybe get a little bit more respect back," he says. "It's more the manner in which you play sometimes than the result."

But Adams is a natural captain, which must have made his demotion under Hoddle all the harder to take. He has led Arsenal for over a decade and even when he was stripped of the title with England he could still be seen on the pitch cajoling and organising and, in the recent game against Ukraine, nursing Steve Gerrard through the fears of his international debut.

"I've pretty much been captain of my club side now for the last 12 years and won a few things along the road," he says, "so hopefully that experience will put me in good stead, the knowledge I've received over the last few years, hopefully I can pass that on to the other guys."

The maturing process which accompanied Adams's well chronicled fight with alcoholism will also help. "I'm a lot older than when I was last England captain. I've got a little bit more experience. Maybe I can see the signposts a bit better than I used to. Maybe I know when to be quiet and when to actually say something to certain individuals."

But he plays down any thoughts that just because he is now captain, he is going to change round England's fortunes on his own. "There's no 'I' in team," he says, plucking a line from a group therapy session. "It's about 11 people, isn't it?"

He describes his role as Keegan's "eyes and ears on the pitch", a job he feels is more easily done by defenders. But that is as far as he was prepared to go in comparing his captaincy style with Shearer's. "There's too many people here. No comment," he said when asked to.

It is unclear whether Adams felt any animosity towards Shearer for taking his job under Hoddle, but something lingers.

It was only when Adams talked about the possibility of new players coming through that he slightly let his guard down on the S-word. "When you've got a dominant centre-forward like Alan, there's a lot of things that you kind of get stuck in a role that you want to kind of play."

Asked if he thought by changing that approach it could be a better England team, he replied: "Hopefully that's what I'm aiming for."

The one major concern about the Adams captaincy is whether his age - he will be 34 in October - and his fitness - he has suffered back and hernia problems - will allow him to take the reins for very long.

Adams remains confident but realistic. "I played 38 games after a double hernia operation last season and I've actually got a good pre-season in this year.

"But if my standards drop, I'm out the door. I'll be the first to tell you."

Until then, it is once more unto the breach for Adams. France, then Germany and, hopefully, on to World Cup qualification. That would be a fitting tribute to a sterling servant of the English game.

About 10,000 tickets remain unsold for Saturday's match at the Stade de France. The French Football Federation said yesterday that tickets priced from 490 to 590 francs (about £45-£55) remained available and were being sold at ticket agencies around Paris.

fields.headline: England ready to make history
fields.standfirst: Now tables are turned and Hussain has the fast bowlers to decide the series
fields.trailText: It is a year now since the new England captain Nasser Hussain, his side just routed in the series against New Zealand, stood on the Oval balcony and listened to the boos of the crowd. It could not have been more humiliating if he had been placed in the stocks and had rotten fruit thrown at him.
fields.body:
It is a year now since the new England captain Nasser Hussain, his side just routed in the series against New Zealand, stood on the Oval balcony and listened to the boos of the crowd. It could not have been more humiliating if he had been placed in the stocks and had rotten fruit thrown at him.

Twelve months on, though, and if all goes well over the next five days - or however long it is Test matches last these days - he might well find himself out on the same piece of Kennington masonry as the first England captain since Raymond Illingworth in 1969 to beat West Indies in a series. Since then the Wisden Trophy might as well have been bolted down in the Bridgetown pavilion as the America's Cup once was in the New York Yacht Club for all the chances England have had of lifting it.

However, although fortune's wheel may not spin like a top in cricket, the transformation in Hussain's side has nevertheless been remarkable: improvement during the winter in South Africa, followed by an unspectacular but necessary win over Zimbabwe and another win in the triangular one-day series. Now, after a trouncing in the first Test against West Indies, there is a change-round to the extent that England go into today's final Test leading by two matches to one - they have not entered the last Test with a lead since Mike Gatting's side against Australia in 1986-87 - and knowing that a draw will be enough to take the series.

Hussain has been upbeat all summer about his side's prospects but yesterday he purred at the difference that the year has made.

"There is a different mind-set now," he explained. "In the past it felt as if you were on the county treadmill and just popping in to play for England. But now there are familiar faces, we know who is going away on tour and the players feel now that this is their team. Everything is focused towards the England level. Central contracts have been vital with Darren Gough, for example, playing mostly for England and feeling that, if the England set-up is taking care of him, then he has to make sure he is right for England. As England captain I am pleased with the way the boys now view this as their team."

Gough's fitness and that of Andy Caddick have been a key point to England's success this summer, with central contracts ensuring that, if they are fit at the end of one Test, then they are fit to start the next. As a pair they have taken 38 wickets in this series, 17 to Caddick and 21 to Gough at an average of 19.17 and 21.00 respectively. Add to that Dominic Cork's 15 at a remarkable 11.46 and Craig White's eight at 21.5 and you have a pace quartet performing as well as any in the game.

It is this success, and the imperative for belt and braces - Hussain, rightly, says that he would not want to back his side to get a draw but there is such a thing as common sense - that ought to lead England to field the same XI that demolished West Indies in two days at Headingley.

The pitch, says Hussain, looks decent enough but the nature has changed over the past few years from the pacey belter it once was and neither he nor Graham Gooch, who had seen it, was confident that it had real substance to it.

It may turn but then again it may swing as well and, as in the past, go through the top as the match progresses. The secret, as Hussain points out, is to select the bowling side on the basis not just of the pitch but of the opposition.

West Indies have played seam and swing poorly and England's one real spinning foray, with Robert Croft, was a disaster. The pace attack is working and in no need of fixing. Ashley Giles should wait for the winter for his second Test.

West Indies, though, have brought in their leg-spinner Mahendra Nagamootoo, who enhanced his claims with a century against Somerset last week, and dispensed with the services of Franklyn Rose.

With a brace of fast bowlers in their late thirties - this is Curtly Ambrose's, and possibly Courtney Walsh's, last Test - the prospect of injury to one is too horrible for them to contemplate. A third fast bowler Nixon McLean is set to retain his place instead of Reon King, who is unfit.

England (from): N Hussain (Essex, capt), M Atherton (Lancashire), M Trescothick (Somerset), G Thorpe (Surrey), A Stewart (Surrey, wkt), M Vaughan (Yorkshire), G Hick (Worcestershire), C White (Yorkshire), A Giles (Warwickshire), D Cork (Derbyshire), A Caddick (Somerset), D Gough (Yorkshire).

West Indies : J Adams (capt), S Campbell , A Griffith , W Hinds , B Lara , R Sarwan , R Jacobs (wkt), M Nagamootoo , N McLean , C Ambrose , C Walsh .

Umpires: D Harper (Aus) and D Shepherd (Eng).

Third umpire: B Leadbeater (Eng).

Match referee: R Madugalle (Sri).

fields.headline: T-Online back on acquisition trail
fields.trailText: T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, is back on the acquisition trail despite boardroom upheavals and a fall in first-half earnings.
fields.body:
T-Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, is back on the acquisition trail despite boardroom upheavals and a fall in first-half earnings.

The German firm is reeling from the sudden resignationlast week of chief executive Wolfgang Keuntje, who allegedly fell out with parent company Deutsche Telekom over T-Online's international strategy. The disagreement with Deutsche's chairman Ron Sommer came after this summer's abortive takeover bids for Britain's Freeserve and Spain's Yacom.

T-Online's first set of figures since its April flotation revealed a fall in pre-tax earnings from Euro14m (£8.6m) to Euro10.1m (£6.2m), due to consolidation costs from the acquisition of French ISP Club Internet in February. However, subscriber numbers rose by 2.7m to 6m, and sales almost doubled to Euro353m (£216m).

Detlev Buchal, T-Online's acting chief executive, said: "We will drive further forward the successfully started internationalisation of T-Online, be it by acquisitions, be it by our own activities. I can assure you that further steps are being prepared."

The stock market agreed with Mr Buchal, with Frankfurt's Neuer Markt Nemax 50 index pushing the shares up 6.75% to Euro30 (£18.42). T-Online remains a popular share thanks to its position as market leader and the financial clout it enjoys from Deutsche Telekom's 90% ownership.

Mr Buchal's comments will renew speculation of a further bid for Freeserve, which is owned by high street retailer Dixons. Takeover negotiations collapsed in June after the two parties could not agree a price.

webTitle: Test cricket returns to normality on a bad day for the captains

fields.headline: Test cricket returns to normality on a bad day for the captains
fields.trailText: Hello, good evening and welcome back to Test cricket. After the adrenalin rush at Headingley, it was back to the long-forgotten spectacle of a good pitch, judicious shot-selection, a first-day full house (northern grounds, hang your heads in shame) and bowlers having to work for their wickets.
fields.body:
Hello, good evening and welcome back to Test cricket. After the adrenalin rush at Headingley, it was back to the long-forgotten spectacle of a good pitch, judicious shot-selection, a first-day full house (northern grounds, hang your heads in shame) and bowlers having to work for their wickets.

It felt a bit like the Seventies, with music from the Wailers at lunch, but actually this is what Test days were like between England and West Indies quite recently. In the mid-Nineties, when Alec Stewart was still allowed to open, England frequently got off to a perfect start, only to subside from 120-0 to 220 all out. Today it was an even better start, and Marcus Trescothick, after tasting failure for the first time at Headingley, confirmed himself as one of the players of the summer, with his unruffled drives and that hugely encouraging ability to push forward on off stump and stay there even when the ball leaves him.

A hundred was there for the taking, but after playing the role of Mark Taylor for four hours, he turned into Mark Butcher, and played a half-cock nothing-shot at the legspinner. If he does that this winter, his England opening career could be as brief as that of the last lefthanded opener to share a 100 stand against West Indies at the Oval - Hugh Morris of Glamorgan.

All series, it has been a game of two halves when England have batted: sheer attrition when Curtly and Courtney are on, sheer indulgence when they take their sweaters. This morning that pattern continued but this afternoon, like an old ball, it suddenly reversed. The first four wickets fell to the support bowlers. And Courtney Walsh bowled a bad ball (a wide, gentle half-volley outside off, which Trescothick incredulously thumped to the cover boundary). Mahendra Nagamootoo got a second stroke of beginner's luck as Nasser Hussain allowed himself to be drawn well wide of off, playing with half a bat and less than half a brain. Graham Thorpe steadied the ship as he had at Headingley, but Alec Stewart then lost his footing. Maybe that's why he doesn't normally bother moving his feet.

It wasn't a good day for captains: Jimmy Adams's blushes were partly spared by the late clatter of wickets, but his decision to bowl was a strange one. Like a weak umpire, he seemed to be trying to correct one bad decision (in fact two - batting first twice under heavy northern skies) by making another.

Of the captains past and present, only Mike Atherton shone. Having got his retirement plans off his chest (this time next year, he says), he played the way he used to before his back got him down: upright, classical, Boycott-like in the best sense of the word. He went forward and eased the ball through the covers; he went back and whipped the legspinner past midwicket. I only saw him play one poor shot all day, and it got him out. The people who talked about dropping him should be ashamed of themselves. Or maybe they should take some of the credit.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

fields.headline: Murdered Sarah laid to rest
fields.trailText: Murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne was today buried after a funeral service at St Peter's church in Hersham, Surrey.
fields.body:
Murdered schoolgirl Sarah Payne was today buried after a funeral service at St Peter's church in Hersham, Surrey.

Looking pale and drawn, the Payne family arrived at the church behind a Victorian glass carriage bearing the body of the eight-year-old schoolgirl.

Father Michael led 21 family members, mostly dressed in black, while mother Sara brought up the rear, with six-year-old daughter Charlotte. Their two sons, Lee, 13, and Luke, 11, were also present.

With mourners lining the route, shop workers stopped what they were doing and joined the procession, alongside mothers nursing young babies.

The carriage was drawn through the streets of the town centre by four grey horses with black feather plumes. Two hearses full of floral tributes from around the world led the cortege, with two undertakers walking out in front.

Emotional townsfolk filled St Peter's church for the service, with hundreds more listening outside on loudspeakers.

During the service, Sara Payne paid tribute to her daughter: "I didn't know what to write so I just wrote to Sarah Daddy called you princess because that's just what you are.

"You used to sleep then and you were never up before 10am and when you started school we never thought you would get up but you loved it, you loved your friends and you loved your teachers."

"One consolation at least is that in death Sarah has been brought home to us," said Rev Nick Whitehead, "We will lay her to rest close to her family and friends, close to this church she loved, and close to Bell Farm and Burhill, the schools in which she delighted."

Teacher June Whittle also addressed the congregation, saying, "The Sarah that we knew was always smiling, happy and chirpy, her smile was a great big sparkling smile."

A book of condolence was opened in the church for mourners and for the public to express their feelings.

fields.headline: Britain furious at Channel blockade
fields.standfirst: Audio: Jon Henley at the fishermen's protest in Paris (1min 50)
fields.trailText:
British ministers demanded action from their French counterparts today after thousands of holiday makers and hauliers were left
stranded by the French fishermen's blockade of Channel ports.
fields.body:
British ministers demanded action from their French counterparts today after thousands of holiday makers and hauliers were left stranded by the French fishermen's blockade of Channel ports.

Traffic eventually started moving again by mid-afternoon after fishermen called off their action and the blockaded French ports reopened. The stalemate ended after the Paris government agreed to reduce the price of fuel.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott told the French government that the impact of the industrial action was "unacceptable" and British hauliers demanded compensation for the huge disruption to cross-Channel travel. The cost to British industry of the protest against high French fuel prices was estimated at £5m, in addition to the inconvenience caused to British holiday makers left queuing for hours to get home from France. Earlier there were angry scenes at the Channel tunnel's Calais terminal as Britons tried to clear the barricades.

Travel companies warned it would be hours before services returned to normal, while police said jams on the M20 in Kent on the way to Dover were likely to continue.

In the port of Le Havre, more than 740 Portsmouth-bound passengers had to spend Wednesday night and Thursday morning aboard a P&O vessel, the Pride of Le Havre, after fishermen, who started their blockade early, prevented the ship from leaving. The vessel was finally able to sail from Le Havre early this afternoon and was due to dock at Portsmouth tonight.

Huge queues of lorries had built up outside Dover and at the ports hit by the dispute - Calais, Cherbourg, Dunkirk, Le Havre and St Malo.

Ferry companies put on extra services to French and Belgian ports unaffected by the dispute. Channel Tunnel shuttle train services between Folkestone and Calais were running, but passengers had trouble getting through the protesters to reach the trains.

The UK ports hit by the effect of the blockades in France were Dover, Portsmouth, Plymouth and Poole. Ferry companies P&O Stena Line, SeaFrance, Norfolk Line, Brittany Ferries, and P&O Portsmouth were all affected.

In a letter to French transport minister Jean-Claude Gayssot today, Mr Prescott said the action of protesting fishermen was contrary to EU legislation.

He went on: "The action is unacceptable to us. Stranded road hauliers on both sides of the Channel stand to lose millions of pounds.

"The actions of the protesters are contrary to EU legislation on the free movement of goods and will badly tarnish the image of France in Britain."

Simon Murphy, the Labour leader in the European parliament, wrote to EU transport commission Loyola de Palacio demanding compensation for UK holiday makers caught up in the dispute.

Mr Murphy said: "Back in 1997, the European court ruled that countries must prevent such obstructions to trade or they would be fined. But the French government still allows them to go on.

"This is no way to run a modern Europe which depends on the free trade and free movement of people."

webTitle: Hume steps back from front line

fields.headline: Hume steps back from front line
fields.standfirst: SDLP leader and Nobel laureate to bow out of assembly
fields.trailText: SDLP leader John Hume yesterday took his first step towards retirement from politics after 30 years in the front line when he announced that he would shortly quit the Northern Ireland assembly.
fields.body:
SDLP leader John Hume yesterday took his first step towards retirement from politics after 30 years in the front line when he announced that he would shortly quit the Northern Ireland assembly.

Mr Hume, 63, said he would be resigning his seat at Stormont to concentrate on his work as Foyle MP at Westminster and as one of Northern Ireland's three MEPs. Colleagues insisted yesterday there was no question of him relinquishing his leadership of the party.

But Mr Hume, who won the Nobel peace prize with Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble two years ago, has been dogged by poor health for several years. His schedule is a punishing one.

He underwent emergency surgery for a ruptured intestine exactly a year ago while at a conference in Austria. His condition was much more serious than initially conceded, requiring four operations, and his subsequent fitness regime includes long walks in the Stormont grounds. Mr Hume, who adores the international political stage, had carefully avoided becoming too tied into the assembly, allowing his number two, Seamus Mallon, to play deputy first minister to Mr Trimble in the power-sharing executive. He had declined to take a place on any committee, indicating he would leave when the assembly bedded in.

Although the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, could order a byelection under the assembly rules, it is more likely an SDLP member will be co-opted. Mr Hume's nominated replacement is Annie Coulter, a member of Derry city council.

Mr Hume said last night: "I have become heavily over loaded with work, and I have had serious health problems over the past year. I am leaving now because I have every confidence in the SDLP team in the assembly, and I feel now the new institutions are on a secure footing."

SDLP assembly member Joe Hendron, the former MP for west Belfast, described Mr Hume as one of the greatest Irishmen of the last 200 years. He said: "I am saddened that John has had to cut down on his workload for health reasons. He will be sorely missed on the assembly benches." Mr Hume told party colleagues at Stormont on Tuesday, but gave them no indication of exactly when he would leave the assembly.

Mr Hume was under most intense pressure when news of his developing relationship with the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, leaked at one of the most bloody periods of the troubles. His clandestine talks with Mr Adams led to the IRA ceasefire in August 1994. It broke down in February 1996, but was renewed in July 1997 soon after Tony Blair's general election victory, and Mr Hume was key in negotiating the Good Friday agreement nine months later.

Mr Hume, an ardent Europhile, was a French teacher at his former school, St Columb's college in Londonderry, before becoming involved in the civil rights movement and then in founding the SDLP in 1970. He was one of the first beneficiares of the Education Act, which allowed many Catholics access to grammar schools for the first time.

He is a pragmatic nationalist, and cites his father's warning after he attended one rally as a boy. He said: "You can't eat a flag, son."

Mr Hume was a member of the first Northern Ireland assembly in 1973, and was elected to the European parliament in 1979. He became an MP in 1983, three years after succeeding Gerry Fitt as SDLP leader.

webTitle: An analysis of the Performance Profiles for Initial Teacher Training

fields.headline: An analysis of the Performance Profiles for Initial Teacher Training
fields.trailText: The second annual set of performance profiles released by the Teacher Training Agency (30 August 2000) are designed to help prospective students select an institution at which to train, and to provide institutions with benchmarking data so that training provision can be improved. It is commendable that the TTA do not attempt to aggregate all the various data sets into as simplistic league table that purports to identify the 'best' institution. A close analysis of the data shows that there is an inherent tension between the various items being measured, and that institutions that score 'highly' on one index perform 'poorly' on another.
fields.body:
The second annual set of performance profiles released by the Teacher Training Agency (30 August 2000) are designed to help prospective students select an institution at which to train, and to provide institutions with benchmarking data so that training provision can be improved. It is commendable that the TTA do not attempt to aggregate all the various data sets into as simplistic league table that purports to identify the 'best' institution. A close analysis of the data shows that there is an inherent tension between the various items being measured, and that institutions that score 'highly' on one index perform 'poorly' on another.

This paper attempts to use the data in the Performance Profiles to examine three characteristics of the institutions that provide teacher training. Each is constructed from the raw data in the profiles, supplemented on occasion by other DfEE and TTA information. The methods used to construct each scale are describes in Appendix 1, which explains the particular weightings given, and the assumptions underlying these.

Tables have been created separately for primary teacher provision and secondary teacher provision. The characteristics of training provision for each phase are sufficiently different to make this distinction. A minority of institutions provide training that is cross-phase (teachers for Key Stage 2 and 3). These are so few (less than 3% of the total intake of student teachers) that they have been omitted from the analysis. The analysis also excludes the provision made by the School Centred Initial Teacher Training groups (SCITTs), which are small school-based training consortia that supply just 2.7% of teachers: including the 29 SCITTs, which have an average intake of less than 25 students each, distorts the comparison between the larger providers.

Table 1: Contribution to Teacher Requirements

Table 1 (1a Primary, 1b Secondary) attempts to quantify how well each institution is meeting the need for teachers. Three characteristics have been employed in this table, reflecting different characteristics of the teaching force that is desired.

Gender: There are insufficient male teachers in the workforce as a whole. The number of men recruited into teaching each year is declining - just 13% of primary students and 38% of secondary students in 1998. A large proportion of the men who are currently teaching are in the older cohorts of teachers, who will be approaching retirement over the next decade. The TTA have a national campaign to attract more men into teaching. The fact that teaching appears to be increasingly a predominantly female profession is possibly a contributory factor to boy's under-performance in national examinations. Institutions have been weighted by their ability to attract male recruits in 1998: thus in the Primary table, 33% of the Urban Learning Foundation's students were men, while only 4% of the Open University's recruits were men.

Ethnicity: It is widely acknowledged the ethnic minorities are under-represented in the nation's teaching force, and the TTA are also attempting to recruit more ethnic minority teachers. Institutions have been scored by their success in attracting a high proportion of ethnic minority students in their 1998 intakes. There are wide variations - ten of the 67 primary providers did not recruit any ethnic minority students, while one institution, the University of North London, recruits over 11% of all the ethnic minority primary students in England. In the Primary table, the Urban Learning Foundation actually attracts the highest proportion of ethnic minority students (63%).

Contribution to regional vacancies: Teacher vacancy rates vary substantially across the country, and it is becoming increasingly evident that teacher supply operates on a regional, or even sub-regional basis. An analysis of teachers working in several London LEAs last year suggested that 40% of all teachers were working less than 20 kilometres from the institution in which they trained. The proportion of newly-qualified teachers working close to their training institution is higher. The table therefore combines the number of teachers who qualified in 1999 from each institution with the DfEE's vacancy rates for primary teachers and secondary teachers in each Government region. Thus, for example, among secondary teacher providers, Goldsmiths College, producing 250 qualified teacher in 1999 in the London region (with a secondary vacancy rate of 1.4%) scores more than the similarly sized University of Brighton (257 secondary teachers), because the vacancy rate in the south eastern region is only 0.7%, while the University of Nottingham (245 students) in the east midlands (vacancy rate 0.3%) scores even less.

These three factors have been equally weighted to a maximum of 100, and summed to give an overall "Contribution to teacher needs" index with theoretical maximum score of 300). The index thus combines the percentages of males and ethnic minority students recruited, with the numbers of teachers who qualified weighted by the regional need for teachers. London-based institutions score relatively highly, but not only because they are situated in a region with a shortage of teachers. They also tend to perform better at recruiting men and ethnic minority students.

Table 2: "Value Added" by each institution

Table 2 (2a Primary, 2b Secondary) compares the entry qualifications of students accepted on course with the institution's output, in terms of the proportion of final year students who both successfully qualify as teachers and succeed in being appointed to teaching posts. The TTA are urging institutions to take more students who have 20 or more A level points on undergraduate courses, and more students with at least an upper second class degree on postgraduate courses. This table takes the proportion of such 'well-qualified' students as an intake measure, and compares it to the proportion of those in the final year of study in 1998-9 who actually become classroom teachers after completing their course. For example, among the secondary teacher providers, St Mary's College had 110 final year students, 98 of whom qualified as teachers, and 97 of these took up teaching jobs. Thus 88% of the final year were sufficiently qualified, well-motivated and good enough to secure a teaching position. On the other hand, University College Worcester had 141 final year students, of whom only 116 qualified as teachers, and only 76 of these were reported as finding positions as teachers - just 54% of the entry cohort. Yet Worcester had a high proportion of 'well-qualified entrants - just over 50% of their students had a 2.1 degree or higher, while St Mary's, with an apparently 'lower quality' intake of just 34% of their postgraduate students with a 2.1 or higher, and 13% of their undergraduates with 20 or more A level points, achieve a much better output. There is a positive correlation between entry standards and output, but this is a relatively weak relationship.

Table 2 creates an index for both employment and entry standards, both weighted to a maximum of 100, and then imputes an "added value" by calculating the difference between the two scales. Thus, for example, in the secondary table, Southampton has a relatively well-qualified entry, but a poor rate of students working as teachers, and therefore the institution scores less well than Sunderland, which takes relatively more students with less good entry qualifications, but nevertheless gets more of them into work in schools.

Table 3: The OfSTED rating of quality for each institution

Each course in each institution is rated for its quality of provision by teams of OfSTED inspectors. Each course can have up to six ratings for separate aspects of provision, on a scale of 1 to 4. Table 3 takes the most recent inspection scores for each course, and calculates an average score for all the primary courses (Table 3a) and all the secondary courses (Table 3b) for each institution. The data supplied by the TTA is the most recent published data for each course, and the figures given account for the different numbers of scores given by different inspections. The maximum score possible would be 1.00, which would indicate that every course achieved the maximum score for every aspect of its provision. The lowest possible score would be 4.00. Two institutions - Homerton College and Canterbury Christ Church - had clear runs of 1 ratings for all aspects of their primary courses, and thus get the maximum possible. Because there are generally more secondary courses at each institution, it is less likely that all courses will achieve 1 ratings on all aspects of provision: nevertheless, Oxford University scores 1.08 - three of its 5 PGCE courses got all 1 scores, and the others had a small sprinkling of 2s.

Commentary

Comparing the three tables, the most striking aspect is their inconsistency. The relationship between the OfSTED quality ratings and the other two tables show that there is a small inverse relationship between them: institutions which OfSTED score as having a high quality of provision tend to be rather less good at providing the teachers needed (male. ethnic minority, and in the regions of greatest need) than institutions which OfSTED rates as having poorer quality.

A similar weak inverse correlation is evident in the figures for the secondary providers, and when the figures of Table 2 ("Value Added") are compared to OfSTED quality ratings.

Appendix 1: The Construction of Tables 1 - 3

All data is taken from the TTA data used to compile the Initial Teacher Training Performance Profiles 2000, with the exception of the Regional Teacher Vacancy Rates 1999 (Primary and Secondary) from the Department for Education and Employment.

In all cases the different courses provided within one institution have been summed to give a single number for primary courses and for secondary courses. Student numbers have =been summed, rather than percentages, in all cases.

Courses designated Key Stage 2/Key Stage 3 have been eliminated. (2.9% of the total numbers of students).

Courses provided by SCITTs have been eliminated. (2.7% of the total).

Table 1: Contribution to Teacher Requirements

Number of teachers qualified 1999: This is the sum of the two fields Awards UG and Awards PG, and represents all the undergraduate and postgraduate awards made that give Qualified Teacher Status in 1999 by each institution.

Contribution to Gender Equality: This is derived from the field pfstMale, which is the percentage of male students in the first year (1998 intake). The largest qualifying value appearing was 64%, and all figures have been adjusted so that the maximum value is 100.

Contribution to Ethnic Equality: This is derived from the field pfstEthnic, which is the percentage of ethnic minority students in the first year (1998 intake). The largest qualifying value appearing was 45%, and all figures have been adjusted so that the maximum value is 100.

Contribution to regional vacancy rates: This is based on the total number of students qualified in 1999 (see a above), factored by the Regional Teacher Vacancy Rates (using the different data available for primary and secondary vacancies) from the DfEE by Government Region, using the allocations of each institution to Government Region provided by the TTA. For those institutions deemed to be 'National' rather than belonging to a particular region, the national (England) vacancy rate has been applied. The largest qualifying value was 774.2, and all figures have been adjusted so that the maximum value is 100.

Contribution to teacher needs: This is the sum of the three previous values: gender, ethnic and vacancy contributions. The maximum value is therefore 300. Each item has been weighted so that it has a maximum value of 100, and this is therefore based on the assumption that the three factors are of equal import.

Table 2: "Value Added" by each institution

No of teachers qualified: As the previous table.

Entry Standards Index: This is derived from the number of students admitted in 1998 either with 20+ A level points to undergraduate courses, or with a 2.1 degree or above to postgraduate courses (fstUG20+ plus fstPG2_1+) as a percentage of the total number of undergraduates and postgraduates admitted (fstUG plus fstPG). Average Quality: This is the average of all the quality awards made by OfSTED for each relevant course, primary and secondary. It is thus the sum of ST1, ST2, ST3. T2, T4 and S1 divided by the number of awards made (not every course had all the various categories awarded. The data omits new, ungraded courses, and those for which data was unavailable.

Grades available are 1 ( very good) to 4 (poor quality). The highest average grade therefore available is 1.00.

fields.bodyText: The second annual set of performance profiles released by the Teacher Training Agency (30 August 2000) are designed to help prospective students select an institution at which to train, and to provide institutions with benchmarking data so that training provision can be improved. It is commendable that the TTA do not attempt to aggregate all the various data sets into as simplistic league table that purports to identify the 'best' institution. A close analysis of the data shows that there is an inherent tension between the various items being measured, and that institutions that score 'highly' on one index perform 'poorly' on another. This paper attempts to use the data in the Performance Profiles to examine three characteristics of the institutions that provide teacher training. Each is constructed from the raw data in the profiles, supplemented on occasion by other DfEE and TTA information. The methods used to construct each scale are describes in Appendix 1, which explains the particular weightings given, and the assumptions underlying these. Tables have been created separately for primary teacher provision and secondary teacher provision. The characteristics of training provision for each phase are sufficiently different to make this distinction. A minority of institutions provide training that is cross-phase (teachers for Key Stage 2 and 3). These are so few (less than 3% of the total intake of student teachers) that they have been omitted from the analysis. The analysis also excludes the provision made by the School Centred Initial Teacher Training groups (SCITTs), which are small school-based training consortia that supply just 2.7% of teachers: including the 29 SCITTs, which have an average intake of less than 25 students each, distorts the comparison between the larger providers. Table 1: Contribution to Teacher Requirements Table 1 (1a Primary, 1b Secondary) attempts to quantify how well each institution is meeting the need for teachers. Three characteristics have been employed in this table, reflecting different characteristics of the teaching force that is desired. Gender: There are insufficient male teachers in the workforce as a whole. The number of men recruited into teaching each year is declining - just 13% of primary students and 38% of secondary students in 1998. A large proportion of the men who are currently teaching are in the older cohorts of teachers, who will be approaching retirement over the next decade. The TTA have a national campaign to attract more men into teaching. The fact that teaching appears to be increasingly a predominantly female profession is possibly a contributory factor to boy's under-performance in national examinations. Institutions have been weighted by their ability to attract male recruits in 1998: thus in the Primary table, 33% of the Urban Learning Foundation's students were men, while only 4% of the Open University's recruits were men. Ethnicity: It is widely acknowledged the ethnic minorities are under-represented in the nation's teaching force, and the TTA are also attempting to recruit more ethnic minority teachers. Institutions have been scored by their success in attracting a high proportion of ethnic minority students in their 1998 intakes. There are wide variations - ten of the 67 primary providers did not recruit any ethnic minority students, while one institution, the University of North London, recruits over 11% of all the ethnic minority primary students in England. In the Primary table, the Urban Learning Foundation actually attracts the highest proportion of ethnic minority students (63%). Contribution to regional vacancies: Teacher vacancy rates vary substantially across the country, and it is becoming increasingly evident that teacher supply operates on a regional, or even sub-regional basis. An analysis of teachers working in several London LEAs last year suggested that 40% of all teachers were working less than 20 kilometres from the institution in which they trained. The proportion of newly-qualified teachers working close to their training institution is higher. The table therefore combines the number of teachers who qualified in 1999 from each institution with the DfEE's vacancy rates for primary teachers and secondary teachers in each Government region. Thus, for example, among secondary teacher providers, Goldsmiths College, producing 250 qualified teacher in 1999 in the London region (with a secondary vacancy rate of 1.4%) scores more than the similarly sized University of Brighton (257 secondary teachers), because the vacancy rate in the south eastern region is only 0.7%, while the University of Nottingham (245 students) in the east midlands (vacancy rate 0.3%) scores even less. These three factors have been equally weighted to a maximum of 100, and summed to give an overall "Contribution to teacher needs" index with theoretical maximum score of 300). The index thus combines the percentages of males and ethnic minority students recruited, with the numbers of teachers who qualified weighted by the regional need for teachers. London-based institutions score relatively highly, but not only because they are situated in a region with a shortage of teachers. They also tend to perform better at recruiting men and ethnic minority students. Table 2: "Value Added" by each institution Table 2 (2a Primary, 2b Secondary) compares the entry qualifications of students accepted on course with the institution's output, in terms of the proportion of final year students who both successfully qualify as teachers and succeed in being appointed to teaching posts. The TTA are urging institutions to take more students who have 20 or more A level points on undergraduate courses, and more students with at least an upper second class degree on postgraduate courses. This table takes the proportion of such 'well-qualified' students as an intake measure, and compares it to the proportion of those in the final year of study in 1998-9 who actually become classroom teachers after completing their course. For example, among the secondary teacher providers, St Mary's College had 110 final year students, 98 of whom qualified as teachers, and 97 of these took up teaching jobs. Thus 88% of the final year were sufficiently qualified, well-motivated and good enough to secure a teaching position. On the other hand, University College Worcester had 141 final year students, of whom only 116 qualified as teachers, and only 76 of these were reported as finding positions as teachers - just 54% of the entry cohort. Yet Worcester had a high proportion of 'well-qualified entrants - just over 50% of their students had a 2.1 degree or higher, while St Mary's, with an apparently 'lower quality' intake of just 34% of their postgraduate students with a 2.1 or higher, and 13% of their undergraduates with 20 or more A level points, achieve a much better output. There is a positive correlation between entry standards and output, but this is a relatively weak relationship. Table 2 creates an index for both employment and entry standards, both weighted to a maximum of 100, and then imputes an "added value" by calculating the difference between the two scales. Thus, for example, in the secondary table, Southampton has a relatively well-qualified entry, but a poor rate of students working as teachers, and therefore the institution scores less well than Sunderland, which takes relatively more students with less good entry qualifications, but nevertheless gets more of them into work in schools. Table 3: The OfSTED rating of quality for each institution Each course in each institution is rated for its quality of provision by teams of OfSTED inspectors. Each course can have up to six ratings for separate aspects of provision, on a scale of 1 to 4. Table 3 takes the most recent inspection scores for each course, and calculates an average score for all the primary courses (Table 3a) and all the secondary courses (Table 3b) for each institution. The data supplied by the TTA is the most recent published data for each course, and the figures given account for the different numbers of scores given by different inspections. The maximum score possible would be 1.00, which would indicate that every course achieved the maximum score for every aspect of its provision. The lowest possible score would be 4.00. Two institutions - Homerton College and Canterbury Christ Church - had clear runs of 1 ratings for all aspects of their primary courses, and thus get the maximum possible. Because there are generally more secondary courses at each institution, it is less likely that all courses will achieve 1 ratings on all aspects of provision: nevertheless, Oxford University scores 1.08 - three of its 5 PGCE courses got all 1 scores, and the others had a small sprinkling of 2s. Commentary Comparing the three tables, the most striking aspect is their inconsistency. The relationship between the OfSTED quality ratings and the other two tables show that there is a small inverse relationship between them: institutions which OfSTED score as having a high quality of provision tend to be rather less good at providing the teachers needed (male. ethnic minority, and in the regions of greatest need) than institutions which OfSTED rates as having poorer quality. webTitle: Fifa agrees to scrap transfer fees for players over 24

fields.headline: Fifa agrees to scrap transfer fees for players over 24
fields.trailText: Fifa president Sepp Blatter has agreed to scrap transfer fees for players over 24 in order to appease the European Commission and avoid a "guillotine decision which could destroy the sport".
fields.body:
Fifa president Sepp Blatter has agreed to scrap transfer fees for players over 24 in order to appease the European Commission and avoid a "guillotine decision which could destroy the sport".

But today's decision - made by a task force of football's governing bodies and clubs - will still mean an end to football as we know it. Players will be free to hop from one club to another for greater and greater salaries and there will be little anyone can do about it. Why will any club pay £40m for Luis Figo when they can get him for free?

In an effort to put some breaks on their decision, the task force have suggested there should be a minimum one-year stay with a club - but it's still uncertain whether the European Commission will accept this. They also agreed to forbid the international transfer of players under the age of 18 and to pay a compensation package for the movement of players under the age of 24.

Ever since the 1995 Bosman ruling - which allows free movement of out-of-contract players within Europe - Fifa and Uefa have been trying to persuade the EU that football is a special case. They have argued that the EU's efforts to bring football into line with regular employment laws will damage the sport, choking smaller clubs which can no longer rely on transfer fees.

But the EU have consistently argued that sportsmen and women should be treated the same as those involved in other occupations - and their executive commission has told Fifa and Uefa to come up with an alternative to the existing transfer system.

Talks, which started in February 1999 between the EU, Fifa and Uefa, have remained in deadlock. But after today's announcement it finally looks that - in line with employees in other professions - players will be able to leave their clubs without clubs being able to demand a transfer fee. In effect, the European Union have won.

webTitle: Mirror editor quizzed over Diana letters 'theft'

fields.headline: Mirror editor quizzed over Diana letters 'theft'
fields.trailText: The editor of The Mirror was interviewed today by police investigating the alleged theft of  personal letters from the late Diana, Princess of Wales, the newspaper said.
fields.body:
The editor of The Mirror was interviewed today by police investigating the alleged theft of personal letters from the late Diana, Princess of Wales, the newspaper said.

Piers Morgan, 35, was questioned for 30 minutes at Charing Cross police station today, the third anniversary of the death of the Princess, by detectives from Scotland Yard's serious and organised crime unit.

He was not arrested and he said later: "There was no evidence to support any such allegation."

The police investigation concerns a story published in The Mirror in April 1998.

webTitle: First Tuesday: a networking success story

fields.headline: First Tuesday: a networking success story
fields.standfirst: First Tuesday is widely acknowledged as the seminal networking party, claiming to have helped dot.com wannabes to raise millions in start-up funding.
fields.trailText: First Tuesday is widely acknowledged as the seminal networking party, claiming to have helped dot.com wannabes to raise millions in start-up funding.
fields.body:
First Tuesday

Set up in London in October 1998, First Tuesday www.firsttuesday.com holds regular "matchmaking" events for start-ups in more than 80 cities across the globe, employing 20 staff worldwide. It claims to have helped entrepreneurs to raise more than $147m (£98m) in funding.

Those who have successfully secured finance or found key staff at First Tuesday events include ClickMango.com, Red Message, Peoplesound.com, Firebox.com, Moreover.com (founder Nick Denton happens to be a co-founder of First Tuesday) and Ihavemoved.com. First Tuesday charges a 2% fee for financing facilitated by its matchmaking events. It also runs Wireless Wednesday - a networking event for those involved with mobile internet technology.

The US trait of tagging is employed, which makes the event feel even more like a cattle market. Investors wear red dots, entrepreneurs green dots, while other service providers and journalists wear yellow dots.

Whatever influence First Tuesday has on business, it should be acknowledged that it has changed the way British internet types behave at new media

The hype surrounding the glorification of First Tuesday has focused primarily on the glut of so-called success stories (companies that have secured funding as a result of the events) being mass-produced by First Tuesday's excellent PR company, Gnash.

A quick inspection of FirstTuesday.com reveals more success stories than you can shake a stick at. Firebox.com, the BBC documentary star and games, gadgets and gizmos retailer, is one of many successes featured on the site, but to what extent is First Tuesday responsible?

Firebox.com co-founder Michael Smith is loath to dispel the myth: "It is actually true [that First Tuesday helped Firebox.com to raise funds].. Wide-eyed and innocent, we arrived in the capital not knowing anyone in the industry [we were previously based in Cardiff]. Within two weeks, we had bumped into venture capitalists (VCs) at First Tuesday. We sent over our hastily prepared business plan the next day and managed to set up a meeting. A couple of meetings later, we had a term sheet, and several weeks later we had £500,000 in the bank."

Admittedly, today's climate is a little different, but organised gatherings such as First Tuesday and, to a lesser extent, the social events are great first ports of call for start-ups looking to progress. "I've met loads of useful people through First Tuesday - other entrepreneurs, journalists, employees, mentors, service providers, and so on," adds Smith.

Ernesto Schmitt, president and chairman of music website Peoplesound.com, is another strong believer in attending First Tuesday events in the early stages of the business: First Tuesday was instrumental in so many ways. I could bounce ideas off other First Tuesday members, which helped me hone Peoplesound.com. I was also introduced to a number of investors whose interest helped me to drive up the value of my proposition. Perhaps most importantly, I found my chief operating officer [Martin Turner, former managing director of Compuserve] there.

webTitle: Smirnoff's Almond takes marketing job at Burger King

fields.headline: Burger King hires Smirnoff's Almond for marketing role
fields.trailText: Burger King has poached Philip Almond, brand director of Smirnoff, to be its marketing director for the UK and Ireland.
fields.body:
Burger King has poached Philip Almond, brand director of Smirnoff, to be its marketing director for the UK and Ireland.

Almond replaces Lorraine Thompson, who left the Diageo-owned company in June to join the internet portal, Excite, as European marketing director. He has spent the past five years working in senior marketing roles for UDV UK, also part of Diageo, most recently as brand director for Smirnoff.

Almond was responsible for the "No Imperfections" advertising campaign for Smirnoff Red, and recently oversaw the launch of Smirnoff Ice. He joins on November 1 and will report to Andre Lacroix, Burger King's president for Europe, the middle east and Africa.

Diageo recently announced plans for a partial flotation of Burger King in New York. The decision followed moves by Burger King franchisees to organise a buyout after complaining about a lack of investment in the fast food chain from Diageo.

webTitle: Shackle our young and we shackle democracy

fields.headline: Shackle our young and we shackle democracy
fields.standfirst: As it emerges that Labour is to field only one extra Asian or black candidate for a winnable seat in the general election, Ashok Viswanathan, campaigns manager at Operation Black Vote, criticises lack of progress in achieving fair representation
fields.trailText: As it emerges that Labour is skimping on Asian and black candidates for winnable seats in the general election, Ashok Viswanathan of Operation Black Vote criticises lack of progress in achieving fair representation.
fields.body:
Last September Operation Black Vote, with the Commission for Racial Equality, was proud to launch the MP Shadowing Scheme. Its aim was to give young black political hopefuls a window into how the political process works. Each of the 23 shadowers gained a valuable insight from following an MP in Westminster and at a local level for six months.

The scheme's success was made all the sweeter by the fact that more women than men applied - 400 out of 651 applicants. Thirteen of our 23 final candidates were young women. Jasvinder Sanghera, 34, and Sonika Nirwal, 24, aim to make history by becoming the first Asian female MPs in the UK.

Historically, it's been a bleak picture. Only seven Asian MPs, starting with Dhadabai Nairoji in 1892, have managed to enter parliament. Seven in 100 years. Five of those seven sit in the current assembly, where total ethnic minority representation totals nine. Nine African, Asian and Caribbean MPs for our multi-ethnic, multicultural, multilingual society. Nine out of 657.

Not what one would have hoped for from a country where all of our political leaders practically fall over themselves to publicise their multicultural credentials. Scandalous as this political reality may be, now is certainly not the time to surrender in our struggle for a fair and equitable democracy.

Although the progress with regard to representation has been disappointedly slow since the arrival of our communities in the UK more than 50 years ago, it has taken a step in the right direction. But the airy direction so often raised in the rhetoric of political speeches must be transformed into action.

Contrary to the thinking of political parties on both local and national levels, our communities know that the talent is out there. And they also know that it is not because of lack of talent that many of our young people are blocked from the full range of opportunities to progress up the political ladder, but because of prejudice.

Before we relish the prospect of lambasting the political parties for their inertia in combating prejudice, let us not forget the prejudice that stifles many of our young also comes from within communities. Pressures to confine their ambitions towards traditional careers prevents growth of talent. And the harsh truth is that those that suffer most are young women.

That is why the efforts of Jasvinder and Sonika in pursuing political ambitions are to be applauded. Theirs is a struggle against gender barriers, age barriers and race barriers, and this makes their progress in the scheme and their ongoing political successes that much more remarkable.

If we are to see more of our young, like Jasvinder and Sonika, follow in the paths of our great leaders from Nairoji to Jinah and Nehru, then opportunities must open up not just in the corridors of power at Westminster, but on the doorsteps of our communities.

We must do more to encourage and inspire our young - especially women - to fulfil their political aspirations, and create a more representative and inclusive democracy.

That is why the efforts of Jasvinder and Sonika in pursuing political ambitions are to be applauded. Theirs is a struggle against gender barriers, age barriers and race barriers, and this makes their progress in the scheme and their ongoing political successes that much more remarkable. If we are to see more of our young, like Jasvinder and Sonika, follow in the paths of our great leaders from Nairoji to Jinah and Nehru, then opportunities must open up not just in the corridors of power at Westminster, but on the doorsteps of our communities. We must do more to encourage and inspire our young - especially women - to fulfil their political aspirations, and create a more representative and inclusive democracy. fields.headline: Labour candidates row
fields.standfirst:
Blacks and Asians miss out on winnable seats

Special report: New Labour in power

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The Labour party has so far selected just one extra candidate from the Asian or black communities to fight a winnable seat at the next general election, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
The Labour party has so far selected just one extra candidate from the Asian or black communities to fight a winnable seat at the next general election, the Guardian has learned.

With few of the 418 seats the party won in 1997 still to have their candidates decided, leading Asian and black figures in the party are furious that so little has been done to reduce under-representation of ethnic minority MPs within the Labour ranks.

The revelation will embarrass party chiefs and the prime minister, Tony Blair, who has urged black people to get involved with politics, amid growing evidence that they are being turned off.

Labour had nine ethnic minority MPs elected in its 1997 landslide. If Asian and black people, who make up 5.5% of the population, were fairly represented that figure should have been at least 22.

An increase of just one will anger black party activists who fear the issue could cost Labour votes at the next election by exacerbating disillusionment among ethnic minority voters who, traditionally, overwhelmingly vote Labour.

It is also embarrassing because Labour has ordered that police forces should employ the same proportion of ethnic minority officers as live in the communities they serve - a target it looks certain to fail to meet for its own parliamentary candidates.

Party bosses are so worried that in July they held a Downing Street crisis meeting to discuss the problem. A member of Mr Blair's personal staff was present, as well as the Labour general secretary Margaret McDonagh.

The one new winnable seat to pick an ethnic minority candidate is Gloucester - with a Labour majority of 8,259 - where Parmjit Dhanda could become the party's tenth Asian or black MP.

Asians have been selected for no-hope seats in Wycombe, which has a Tory majority of 2,370, and Wokingham, held by the Conservative John Redwood with a majority of more than 9,000.

The Labour party declined to say how many of the seats it won in 1997 had yet to be decided saying it would "not give a running commentary" on its selection process. A spokesman agreed that between 20 and 40 Labour-held seats still were vacant.

NEC member-elect Shahid Malik said: "Doubtless we are light years ahead of the other parties, but it will be extremely disturbing if it transpires that there's only one extra ethnic minority candidate in a winnable seat. We'd be in danger of our credibility on race being called into question in a big way. People will perceive that not enough has happened. We should have 28 MPs, we have nine.

"There is a great concern for the medium to long term. We have the first generation who traditionally voted Labour. The next generation and those after won't vote for anyone unless they believe they are representative."

Simon Woolley of Operation Black Vote said academic research which it commissioned showed that the biggest reason that black people are turned off politics is because they are under-represented in parliament. "When you bear in mind that 80% of ethnic minority voters vote Labour, its appalling. It's basically saying one thing and doing another."

"Tony Blair talks about wanting to see a black prime minister, yet election after election the Blair administration has made no inroads into turning that around. We have to begin to doubt the seriousness behind Blair's rhetoric."

A source with close knowledge of the thinking of senior party figures said: "Everyone realises the procedures we use are slow and you need a lot of money to get selected. It usually helps the local, white male candidate who can use the system to their advantage, it does not help an outsider. You can help, encourage and implore and we've done that. People realise everyone is selecting white men."

Lee Jasper, the adviser on race to the London mayor Ken Livingstone, said: "To have increased black parliamentary representation by one is an insult to Afro-Caribbean and Asian communities who have supported Labour for years.

"This is an example of Labour showing arrogance towards inner city communities who it treats as voting fodder."

Figures from Operation Black Vote to be published next month show that in 60 seats at the next general election, the number of black and Asian voters exceeds the size of the majority of the sitting MP.

Mr Blair told a conference of black church leaders in July of his desire for more black MPs: "I say to young black people: 'you perhaps more than anyone can gain from going into politics.' Politics needs people from the ethnic minorities."

The Tories, currently an all-white parliamentary party, have one ethnic minority candidate in a winnable seat - Shailesh Vara, in Northampton South, who has a Labour majority of 744 to overturn.

The Liberal Democrats said they had no idea whether they have any realistic prospect of electing their first Asian or black MP since the second world war.

webTitle: Springer & Jacoby in talks with True North Communications

fields.headline: Springer & Jacoby proposes tie-up with True North for European push
fields.trailText: Springer & Jacoby, Germany's biggest independent advertising agency, has confirmed it is in talks with True North Communications about a tie-up that would enable it to expand across Europe.
fields.body:
Springer & Jacoby, Germany's biggest independent advertising agency, has confirmed it is in talks with True North Communications about a tie-up that would enable it to expand across Europe.

The agency, which has made no secret of its international ambitions, has been looking for a partner for some months. However, a full-scale takeover is thought to be unlikely as Springer & Jacoby's founder, Konstantin Jacoby, is keen to preserve the agency's independence.

Instead, Springer & Jacoby is looking for a major advertising group to finance its European expansion in return for a stake in the company. A deal with True North would make sense as the company's FCB Worldwide network handles Daimler-Chrysler, the parent of Springer & Jacoby's flagship client, Mercedes-Benz. Having offices across Europe would allow Springer & Jacoby to target the European Mercedes account, particularly if it was part-owned by True North.

A Springer & Jacoby spokeswoman said that the agency was in talks with several possible partners, including True North. True North declined to comment.

In March Springer & Jacoby confirmed it was in talks with Omnicom about Omnicom becoming a minority shareholder in the German agency. The US company would also have been a logical partner for Springer & Jacoby because the Omnicom-owned agency, Merkley Newman Harty, handles the Mercedes-Benz account in north America.

fields.headline: ITV players plan ONdigital/ITN IPOs
fields.trailText: ITV consolidation is spurring news service ITN and digital terrestrial platform ONdigital's flotation plans.
fields.body:
The consolidation spree within ITV is spurring news service ITN and digital terrestrial platform ONdigital's flotation plans.

Both are companies owned by key network players. Executives at Granada Media and Carlton Communications, the main shareholders in both companies, are poised to draw up initial public offering options. ONdigital is at the most advanced stage towards a stock market listing.

ONdigital is trailing rival BSkyB and the tussle for control of ITV between its joint owners has prevented a flotation that would boost funding for its expansion plans. However, Granada's £1.75bn deal for United News & Media's TV franchises has re-opened the possibility of an IPO.

The plans are complicated by Granada's ownership of the HTV franchise, which it must sell to satisfy regulators following the United acquisition. Granada chairman Charles Allen is aware of counterpart Michael Green's interest in HTV and could upset negotiations by selling the franchise to another party.

An ITN flotation is still at the early stages of development, as a lot hinges on what Granada does with its holding in the company. No company can hold more than 20% of the news service, which is co-owned by Granada, Carlton, Reuters, the Daily Mail & General Trust and United. It means Granada has to dispose of the stake it inherited from United or sell the shares to the public.

The proceeds from an ITN public offering would be used to fund the company's internet ambitions and boost its international services. However, it is possible that the sale of Granada's stake will provide enough money to finance its plans. Analysts put ITN's full IPO value at between £200m and £300m.

Merill Lynch analyst Neil Blackley said: "The money available from the Granada stake is not primary money, so it would probably have to be made available through an IPO. In terms of the whole organisation, though, ITN is a perfectly viable IPO and an excellent company."

On August 30, Granada's share price fell 5.25p to 670.75p, with Carlton climbing 26p to 726p.

webTitle: New managers at Beeb Ventures unveiled

fields.headline: BBC announces raft of new appointments at internet division
fields.trailText: After months of searching for managers for its beeb internet division, Beeb Ventures, BBC Worldwide has finally made a number of key appointments.
fields.body:
After months of searching for managers for its beeb internet division, Beeb Ventures, BBC Worldwide has finally made a number of key appointments.

Julian Turner, director of online and interactive media at Granada Media and former City trader, is to join Beeb Ventures as chief executive officer next week. Joining Turner is Kym Niblock, from Nickelodeon where she was deputy managing director, who takes up the mantle of chief operating officer at Beeb Ventures. Both report directly to managing director of internet and interactive at BBC Worldwide, Drew Kaza.

The appointments come less than a week after BBC Worldwide revealed details of its new holding company for its commercial new media ventures and an investment from US-based internet firm, TH Lee Global Internet Managers.

At Granada, Turner was responsible for G-Wizz and various internet partnerships such as the Ask Jeeves stake. Following the recent establishment of Granada Broadband and the mooted ditching of the G-Wizz brand, Turner's brief had changed somewhat and was confused further by the appointment of Simon Shaps and Justin Judd to run Granada Broadband. To this end, Turner will not be directly replaced, although Channel 4's Sophie Walpole has been recruited as managing editor of Granada Powerchannel, the soon-to-launch TV internet service, to oversee that portion of Turner's former brief.

webTitle: Levi's airs new campaign for Engineered Jeans

fields.headline: Levi's launches latest ad campaign
fields.trailText: Levi's Engineered Jeans return to the small screen this week with two raunchy commercials created by Bartle Bogle Hegarty.
fields.body:
Levi's Engineered Jeans return to the small screen this week with two raunchy commercials created by Bartle Bogle Hegarty.

The pan-European campaign kicks off in the UK with an ad that features two like-minded Levi's wearers who begin to flirt after their eyes meet on a train. The boy leans over to reveal that the parting in his hair is twisted to resemble a Levi's Engineered seam. The girl then responds by showing her belly button, which is similarly twisted. Their flirtation continues, culminating in a final scene in which the boy begins to pull down his jeans. The camera pans across to the girl's face as the object of her affection reveals quite how far his "twisted" lifestyle extends.

The second ad shows a young woman who sees her boyfriend's Levi's on the floor. Unable to resist, she begins to caress them, and the jeans appear to come to life. The last shot shows her looking up with a wry smile to see her boyfriend's jeans standing up in front her. The new endline, 'twisted to fit', appears at the end of both ads.

The commercials will be supported by a print campaign shot by the photographer and Dazed and Confused founder, Rankin.

The campaign was art directed by Verity Fenner, written by Claudia Southgate and directed by Dom & Nik of the production company, Outsider. Media for the £3.5mcampaign was bought and planned by Starcom Motive.

The campaign is aimed at 15 to 19-year-olds, who were not yet buying jeans when Levi's had its last surge in popularity. The Levi's brand is still the UK's best seller, although in recent years it has lost ground to new jeans brands such as Diesel and Calvin Klein. The past five years have also seen a move away from jeans to new trends such as combat trousers.
