fields.headline: Doctors, Dealers and Di Canio
fields.trailText: FATSO'S FAILURE
fields.body:
FATSO'S FAILURE

Well, well. You wouldn't have expected this to happen... John Hartson has failed a medical! Rangers experts have come to the conclusion that he's not very fit, you see, and have decreed that he should not, under any circumstances, be purchased. What a turn up for the books - and a lucky one for the Ibrox club, who were about to pay £5.5m for the big Welshman. They've since pulled out of the deal and sent him waddling back to Wimbledon quicker than you can say "cure for baldness".

To be fair to fatso, Rangers have become very stringent with their medicals. A couple of years ago they passed Daniel Prodan fit by accident, paid a load of money for him and then watched him slowly retire. So the least little thing was always going to cause a great big flabby problem. "Due to the fact the player has not played a sufficient number of top class matches recently," the club said in a statement, "Rangers are of the opinion he would not be at the level of match fitness required at this particular stage of the season."

But although it's a lucky escape for Rangers, it's pretty damn unlucky - stop laughing - for poor old Hartson. He nearly joined Spurs for £7m last season before those pesky doctors started their meddling, so he's revisiting some unpleasant familiar ground. In fact, Hartson is so upset that he's pulled out of the Welsh squad for their World Cup qualifier against Belarus. "He's really disappointed that this has happened," his agent Jonathan Barnett said today, "but John will pick himself up again." Well, that's as maybe, but what about us? We were looking forward to him playing keepie-uppie with Eyal Berkovic's face - and how do you expect us to recover from that disappointment?

WINSTON OF CHELSEA'S OF CHELSEA

It's been a busy day of trading at Chelsea's of Chelsea, the famous London store for top people. They've done some smart wheeler-dealing, selling a central defender who is really good and replacing him with one who isn't. Never mind, though, Chelsea's of Chelsea fans - they've made a £4.5m profit on the day, and that's the main thing.

Quietly leaving the Bridge is dependable defender Emerson Thome. The big Brazilian, also known as "the Wall", has moved to Sunderland for £4.5m, leaving a gaping hole in Chelsea's defence which not even Frank Leboeuf's ego could fill. His spot will be taken by Dutch defender Winston Bogarde, who has been touting himself around several Premiership clubs like a slattern for a while now, and has finally got his wish.

"My ultimate dream came true this morning - a move to England with Chelsea," the versatile player churned out on his website today. "I leave Barcelona on exceptionally good terms after two-and-a-half great years, in which the team and I enjoyed championship and cup success," he bigged himself up. "There were a number of other clubs interested in me, but I believe Chelsea have got a team that can win the Premiership and that made them the most attractive option." So it's got nothing to do with the fact Manchester United weren't very interested, then.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Permit me to pay tribute to the young men who have retired from the Blues. You have brightened life for everyone with your talent as part of a fabulous team. You will be missed by the team. You will be missed by everyone" - French president Jack Chirac waves goodbye to Laurent Blanc and Didier Deschamps. Wonder if Gianluca Vialli sent a card?

CLARET SHIRTS, CLARET FACES

Europe's oldest republic, San Marino, has offered shelter to the persecuted (and a guaranteed place in the national side) ever since it was founded in the 4th century AD by St. Marinus, a monk fleeing from the evil Emperor Diocletian. And today - bless 'em - the pretty province continued its longstanding tradition by offering poor Paolo Di Canio refuge and the chance to sign up for their World Cup qualifying campaign.

Well, that's what West Ham fan sites were saying this morning. And we were inclined to believe them, especially as Di Canio has just been charged with "protesting aggressively" in West Ham's game against Leicester and finds his dreams of playing for Italy falling faster than the Inzaghi brothers around the box. Newshounds that we are, we tried the San Marino football federation only to find the line was dead - so we had to make do with Peter Stewart, West Ham's exasperated press officer, instead. "We've taken hundreds of calls on this," he blasted, finding a tone that managed to combine both hostility and weariness. "And I've no idea where this story comes from."

Unfortunately, Mr Stewart wasn't the only one at West Ham getting hot under the collar today. While he was fielding calls from all and sundry, Steve Lomas was taking a pop at Leicester's finest actor, Robbie Savage. "I don't think anyone could believe Igor's sending-off," said Lomas incredulously of defender Stimac's dismissal against Leicester at the weekend. "To me, it was a complete over-reaction on Savage's part. Maybe Igor hit him in the ribs, but there was no need for him to go down clutching his face." Unless you're trying to get your Equity card, of course.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Internazionale have turned down Arsenal's bid for Ivan Zamorano, according to Planet Football.

The website also claims that Real Madrid are trying to sign Benfica striker Pierre Van Hooijdonk.

Hibernian's French striker Didier Agathe is being linked with a move to Celtic.

Aston Villa are also believed to have made a £2.8m approach for Lokeren striker Souleymane Youla - but Villa seem likely to lose out to Anderlecht.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Fifa president Sepp Blatter has admitted that transfer fees for players over 24 are almost certainly over - but he has asked the European Commission for more time to find a solution to avoid the complete dismantling of the transfer system. Blatter said: "In our minds we have already taken the position that we have to look at a new system. We have to find a solution and look at the consequences of the decision we make. That is why we need to receive more time from the European Commission."

A former Atletico Madrid striker who was shot by a Republican firing squad in 1939 could become the first saint of soccer, according to Spanish sports daily As. Manolo Garnica, a star of Atletico's Spanish Cup-winning side of 1911, is one 10,000 victims of the Spanish Civil War proposed by the Catholic church as candidates for beatification, a step toward sainthood. "We have established divine contacts within our reach to pray to," said club president Jesus Gil. "Knowing that we have such an important fan in Heaven will show the devil himself that Atletico de Madrid can't stay in his kingdom any longer."

Celtic midfielder Paul Lambert has lost his fitness race for Scotland's opening World Cup qualifier against Latvia in Riga on Saturday.

Leeds have signed 22-year-old midfielder Jacob Burns from Australian club Parramatta Power for £250,000.

Dundee United have completed the signing of Cameroon Olympic striker Mvondo Atangana. The 21-year-old is the third new player to arrive at Tannadice in little over a week following the signings of Alphonse Tchami and Stephen Wright.

Referee David Elleray has called for rugby-style sin-bins in the Premiership, which he says would slash the number of bookings and sendings-off in the British game.

Manchester City defender Andy Morrison has joined Third Division Blackpool on a month's loan.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm)
Look Sepp, you're not TV's Frank Burnside and no amount of fake tan and slicked-back hair is going to make us change our minds. Right?

Channel 4: Bronson: Britain's most dangerous prisoner (9pm)
Nicked by Burnside in 1974 (well probably). And Luton's mean streets have been safe ever since. Pretty much.

Channel 5: Jonathon Pearce's Football Night (12.15am)
Will ITV give the man a new series? Will they hell! But we're not going to give up. Oh no. We're here for the long haul. And our Farringdon vigil (9pm for newcomers) will continue until the suits start to notice.

Dutch Football (12.45am)
Hang on a second, what's this email from Tim Gray? "I thought you'd like to know that the week beginning September 25th is Burnside week on ITV2," he says, "with an episode every evening."

ITV: World Football (2.05am)
Every evening? Oh, what bliss!

Argentinian Football (2.15pm)
But wait, there's more: "You may be disappointed to know that Wednesday's episode is 'subject to change' but only because they want to show some football (Galatasaray v Rangers)."

Major League Soccer (3.55pm)
We "may be disappointed"?!? Try distraught, pal. What's going to happen to the missing episode? Discarded like the talents of Burnside's Christopher Ellison, we bet

"Due to the fact the player has not played a sufficient number of top class matches recently," the club said in a statement, "Rangers are of the opinion he would not be at the level of match fitness required at this particular stage of the season." But although it's a lucky escape for Rangers, it's pretty damn unlucky - stop laughing - for poor old Hartson. He nearly joined Spurs for £7m last season before those pesky doctors started their meddling, so he's revisiting some unpleasant familiar ground. In fact, Hartson is so upset that he's pulled out of the Welsh squad for their World Cup qualifier against Belarus. "He's really disappointed that this has happened," his agent Jonathan Barnett said today, "but John will pick himself up again." Well, that's as maybe, but what about us? We were looking forward to him playing keepie-uppie with Eyal Berkovic's face - and how do you expect us to recover from that disappointment? WINSTON OF CHELSEA'S OF CHELSEA It's been a busy day of trading at Chelsea's of Chelsea, the famous London store for top people. They've done some smart wheeler-dealing, selling a central defender who is really good and replacing him with one who isn't. Never mind, though, Chelsea's of Chelsea fans - they've made a £4.5m profit on the day, and that's the main thing. Quietly leaving the Bridge is dependable defender Emerson Thome. The big Brazilian, also known as "the Wall", has moved to Sunderland for £4.5m, leaving a gaping hole in Chelsea's defence which not even Frank Leboeuf's ego could fill. His spot will be taken by Dutch defender Winston Bogarde, who has been touting himself around several Premiership clubs like a slattern for a while now, and has finally got his wish. "My ultimate dream came true this morning - a move to England with Chelsea," the versatile player churned out on his website today. "I leave Barcelona on exceptionally good terms after two-and-a-half great years, in which the team and I enjoyed championship and cup success," he bigged himself up. "There were a number of other clubs interested in me, but I believe Chelsea have got a team that can win the Premiership and that made them the most attractive option." So it's got nothing to do with the fact Manchester United weren't very interested, then. QUOTE OF THE DAY "Permit me to pay tribute to the young men who have retired from the Blues. You have brightened life for everyone with your talent as part of a fabulous team. You will be missed by the team. You will be missed by everyone" - French president Jack Chirac waves goodbye to Laurent Blanc and Didier Deschamps. Wonder if Gianluca Vialli sent a card? CLARET SHIRTS, CLARET FACES Europe's oldest republic, San Marino, has offered shelter to the persecuted (and a guaranteed place in the national side) ever since it was founded in the 4th century AD by St. Marinus, a monk fleeing from the evil Emperor Diocletian. And today - bless 'em - the pretty province continued its longstanding tradition by offering poor Paolo Di Canio refuge and the chance to sign up for their World Cup qualifying campaign. Well, that's what West Ham fan sites were saying this morning. And we were inclined to believe them, especially as Di Canio has just been charged with "protesting aggressively" in West Ham's game against Leicester and finds his dreams of playing for Italy falling faster than the Inzaghi brothers around the box. Newshounds that we are, we tried the San Marino football federation only to find the line was dead - so we had to make do with Peter Stewart, West Ham's exasperated press officer, instead. "We've taken hundreds of calls on this," he blasted, finding a tone that managed to combine both hostility and weariness. "And I've no idea where this story comes from." Unfortunately, Mr Stewart wasn't the only one at West Ham getting hot under the collar today. While he was fielding calls from all and sundry, Steve Lomas was taking a pop at Leicester's finest actor, Robbie Savage. "I don't think anyone could believe Igor's sending-off," said Lomas incredulously of defender Stimac's dismissal against Leicester at the weekend. "To me, it was a complete over-reaction on Savage's part. Maybe Igor hit him in the ribs, but there was no need for him to go down clutching his face." Unless you're trying to get your Equity card, of course. THE RUMOUR MILL Internazionale have turned down Arsenal's bid for Ivan Zamorano, according to Planet Football. The website also claims that Real Madrid are trying to sign Benfica striker Pierre Van Hooijdonk. Hibernian's French striker Didier Agathe is being linked with a move to Celtic. Aston Villa are also believed to have made a £2.8m approach for Lokeren striker Souleymane Youla - but Villa seem likely to lose out to Anderlecht. NEWS IN BRIEF Fifa president Sepp Blatter has admitted that transfer fees for players over 24 are almost certainly over - but he has asked the European Commission for more time to find a solution to avoid the complete dismantling of the transfer system. Blatter said: "In our minds we have already taken the position that we have to look at a new system. We have to find a solution and look at the consequences of the decision we make. That is why we need to receive more time from the European Commission." A former Atletico Madrid striker who was shot by a Republican firing squad in 1939 could become the first saint of soccer, according to Spanish sports daily As. Manolo Garnica, a star of Atletico's Spanish Cup-winning side of 1911, is one 10,000 victims of the Spanish Civil War proposed by the Catholic church as candidates for beatification, a step toward sainthood. "We have established divine contacts within our reach to pray to," said club president Jesus Gil. "Knowing that we have such an important fan in Heaven will show the devil himself that Atletico de Madrid can't stay in his kingdom any longer." Celtic midfielder Paul Lambert has lost his fitness race for Scotland's opening World Cup qualifier against Latvia in Riga on Saturday. Leeds have signed 22-year-old midfielder Jacob Burns from Australian club Parramatta Power for £250,000. Dundee United have completed the signing of Cameroon Olympic striker Mvondo Atangana. The 21-year-old is the third new player to arrive at Tannadice in little over a week following the signings of Alphonse Tchami and Stephen Wright. Referee David Elleray has called for rugby-style sin-bins in the Premiership, which he says would slash the number of bookings and sendings-off in the British game. Manchester City defender Andy Morrison has joined Third Division Blackpool on a month's loan. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm) Look Sepp, you're not TV's Frank Burnside and no amount of fake tan and slicked-back hair is going to make us change our minds. Right? Channel 4: Bronson: Britain's most dangerous prisoner (9pm) Nicked by Burnside in 1974 (well probably). And Luton's mean streets have been safe ever since. Pretty much. Channel 5: Jonathon Pearce's Football Night (12.15am) Will ITV give the man a new series? Will they hell! But we're not going to give up. Oh no. We're here for the long haul. And our Farringdon vigil (9pm for newcomers) will continue until the suits start to notice. Dutch Football (12.45am) Hang on a second, what's this email from Tim Gray? "I thought you'd like to know that the week beginning September 25th is Burnside week on ITV2," he says, "with an episode every evening." ITV: World Football (2.05am) Every evening? Oh, what bliss! Argentinian Football (2.15pm) But wait, there's more: "You may be disappointed to know that Wednesday's episode is 'subject to change' but only because they want to show some football (Galatasaray v Rangers)." Major League Soccer (3.55pm) We "may be disappointed"?!? Try distraught, pal. What's going to happen to the missing episode? Discarded like the talents of Burnside's Christopher Ellison, we bet

fields.headline: New media party guide
fields.standfirst: No industry has spawned so many events focused on gossiping, drinking, and occasionally doing some work. New media networking is a serious business
fields.trailText: No industry has spawned so many events focused on gossiping, drinking, and occasionally doing some work. New media networking is a serious business, as Amy Vickers Reports
fields.body:
If you were to believe the hype, you would think that all good-for-nothing new media workers ever do is network, network and network. Helped by TV land's incessant probing into the dot.com world, networking evenings have become perfect fodder for broadcasters looking to glamorise the internet industry.

At the height of the dot.com boom in February, it was practically impossible to get a ticket for the self-styled networking nirvana First Tuesday. Those who did wondered what the devil they had let themselves in for. Awareness of First Tuesday among non-internet people was staggeringly high; even English teachers in Japan had heard of the event and, before long, copycat events began to spring up all over the place.

MediaGuardian.co.uk has put together an exhaustive list of the main new media networking parties, culled from new media's "it" crowd and party organisers. While we have made every effort to include all of the key events, should we have missed any, please get in touch. Most of them are centred on the capital, with no mention of any parties at regional venues or in the north of England.

Technically, there are two types of new media networking evening: the networking-oriented events where the focus is generally on doing business, and the less formal, more booze-oriented parties where the idea is to meet new people you could potentially meet when sober, and then do business.

BMPtvi head of marketing Katy Howell offers worldly advice to those thinking of becoming a new media networker: "In general, if the party is in Shoreditch or Soho expect loads of new media agency types, with a smattering of journalists. If they are in north London, expect them to be run by universities and colleges. If at a nightclub, expect them to be a clique, with a free bar that ends five minutes after you arrive. If at a wacky venue, like the Oxo tower, in a balloon, under the arches or at a launch, expect to meet loads of PR people. Because they are industry events, expect everyone, in true prima donna fashion, to talk about themselves and not let you get a word in edgeways."

Michael Smith, chief executive officer at Firebox.com, says: "Some of the networking events can get a bit serious and we want to inject some life into the scene. When I'm free, I still try to go to First Tuesday and the Chemistry, but I'm spending more of my time at the more laid-back and fun events such as Boobnight or the Clerkenwell Social. And, of course, I eagerly await the Firebox party [what better place to network and make new friends than over a game of Twister]."

webTitle: BMP Interaction changes name to Tribal DDB London

fields.headline: BMP Interaction rebrands in business overhaul
fields.trailText: BMP Interaction, the digital arm of BMP DDB, is to be rebranded as Tribal DDB London as part of an international reorganisation of the DDB Group's interactive operations.
fields.body:
BMP Interaction, the digital arm of BMP DDB, is to be rebranded as Tribal DDB London as part of an international reorganisation of the DDB Group's interactive operations.

DDB is bringing all its interactive operations under the new Tribal brand. As part of the reorganisation Jason Goodman, co-founder and joint managing director of BMP Interaction, will become president and chief operating officer of the European Tribal network. Tribal London will be run by Chris Rayner, managing director; Alison Swaby, general manager; and Mat Morrison, head of strategy.

Swaby said: "DDB offices around the world have been building digital divisions from the ground up for the last three years. But in order to operate across geographical boundaries, as digital does, we felt we had to have a unified global brand."

Tribal DDB has also created a joint venture with the direct marketing specialist Rapp Collins to provide below-the-line digital services for clients of both agencies.

Tribal DDB's clients include Volkswagen, Vodafone, Pepsico and Kelkoo.com.

fields.headline: Touchy, feely:
fields.standfirst: Touchy, feely: the secret of a good ad.
fields.trailText: The secret of a good ad.
fields.body:
In tune

Woolwich's current campaign includes an ad featuring a customer closing his bank account because he's not had the service he wanted. The ad's focus? A (readily identifiable) point of view rather than a picture of a Woolwich type of person, and a depiction of a consumer in control.

lQXL.com recently placed thousands of posters in service station toilets to encourage consumers to sign up with the internet site. Hardly the time or the place, one might have thought, but research suggests that because we suffer sensory deprivation in public toilets we actively seek stimuli.

lBarclaycard's ad featuring the love-lorn girl (left) who consoles herself by splashing out on a new pair of red spangly shoes was perfectly in tune with consumers' current "I deserve it" mentality, which accepts rather than attempts to conceal our desires for indulgence.

Misjudged

Barclays (above, right) missed the mark with its recent "big is best" campaign - a good old-fashioned TV-driven mass-marketing push that demanded attention. Unfortunately it coincided with a programme of branch closures, pitching it into the role of corporate bully. Too loud, and not enough emphasis on "what's in it for me?".

For many years Levi's has sold itself on the promise of the Levi's lifestyle. The past 18 months, however, have seen its sales and profile slip. Self-confident consumers don't passively buy into the "join our lifestyle" message, preferring, instead, a hint of how that product will help them stand out in a crowd.

lNike, meanwhile, is also a brand perceived by some in the industry to have weakened in recent years. Its emphasis on winning - typified by its "Just do it" slogan - is now so ubiquitous amongst other firms that it's losing the edge and its advertising risks becoming faceless.

fields.headline: Faking it
fields.standfirst: Counterfeit goods are big business - worth £250bn a year worldwide.Brand owners are furious. But, Helen Jones reports, many shoppers don't care if products are genuine
fields.trailText: Counterfeit goods are big business - worth £250bn a year worldwide.Brand owners are furious. But, Helen Jones reports, many shoppers don't care if products are genuine
fields.body:
Australia has a secret weapon in the war against fake merchandise at this year's Olympics - saliva. A leading athlete, as yet unnamed, has donated DNA which has been incorporated into special ink to be used in all official products sold at the Sydney Games. Officials will be able instantly to identify genuine products from counterfeit by using a handheld scanner.

Unfortunately for the rest of us, spotting a fake is not always so easy.

Counterfeit products from sportswear to perfume, toys to designer handbags - even Pokémon cards - have flooded the world market. The Global Anti-Counterfeiting Group, which represents the interests of brand owners around the world, estimates that fakes are now a £250bn industry.

While the Prada handbag bought from a street hawker in Italy or the dodgy Gucci watch picked up for a song in Bangkok is an obvious fake and carries its own kind of kitsch value, it is becoming harder to tell fakes from the real thing.

"There are some pretty good fakes out there," says Ed Chicken, vice chairman of the Institute of Trading Standards.

Fraudsters usually attend trade fairs to identify the latest branded products. They then copy them and churn them out so quickly in developing world sweatshops that counterfeits are often available before the genuine article gets into the shops.

"Many manufacturers build special stitching patterns into clothing or use holographic labels to protect their brands, but it's not something that the general public would necessarily recognise," says Chicken.

Most fakes are sold at street markets and car boot sales, but some products, particularly clothing, may make it into high street stores. The internet is a growing source of fake products.

According to the Cosmetic and Perfumery Retailers' Association, there are around 160 websites offering "genuine" Chanel products, despite the fact that Chanel doesn't sell any of its products on the net. While it's obvious that the designer perfume you buy for a fiver from a man on the pavement in Oxford Street is likely to be nothing more than coloured water, websites often look authentic.

Paul Carratu, managing director of Carratu International, a company which investigates fake products on behalf of brand owners, says: "There are more and more counterfeit products being sold over the internet. Some are cut price and look like bargains because they are claimed to be imports or last season's products. Other sites sell fake products at full price as if they're genuine. It's only when you get it - if it ever arrives - that you realise it's a fake."

Part of the problem is that consumers don't look closely enough at "official" websites. Research carried out by security firm ArmorGroup showed that 91% of consumers couldn't tell a fake Visa logo from the real thing.

Howard Cottrell, executive director of ArmorGroup, says: "With its ease of access, massive audience and potential for anonymity, the internet provides an ideal platform for counterfeiters."

Brand owners claim they are losing a fortune to fraudsters. To combat the problem, many companies have anti-fraud squads or use the services of firms such as Carratu and ArmorGroup which go undercover to trace fakes and identify the culprits.

Manchester United's anti-fraud team has seized fake replica shirts worth more than £2m and other merchandise during the past three years and the luxury goods company Louis Vuitton says that, in Japan, it is losing in excess of 5bn yen (£31m) a year to fraudsters.

It is not only money the company is afraid of losing, but cachet. If fake Louis Vuitton bags saturate the market, the brand loses its sense of exclusivity and consumers are put off buying the real thing. What worries brand owners most is that consumers take a relaxed attitude towards fakes. "People like getting what they think is a bargain," says Paul Carratu.

Research carried out by polling company Mori indicates that 40% of British consumers would knowingly purchase a counterfeit product if the price and quality were acceptable.

Of those willing to buy counterfeits, 76% would buy clothing or footwear, 43% watches, 38% perfume and 22% electrical goods such as video recorders and CD players.

"One of the biggest problems with counterfeiting is that people tend to see it as a victimless crime," says Carratu. "They picture the counterfeiter as a modern day Robin Hood who doesn't harm anyone, but this couldn't be further from the truth."

The Department of Trade and Industry estimates that counterfeit goods cost Britain £8bn a year in lost taxes.

The purchase of fake goods does not just have economic implications. Some products are dangerous.

Trading standards officers have come across "designer" perfumes that have resulted in burns and rashes, and West Yorkshire police recently recovered fake alcopops made with antifreeze and whisky spiked with industrial meths.

Consumer affairs minister Kim Howells is urging consumers to take a more responsible approach to counterfeit goods. "People think it's a victimless crime - it is anything but. Counterfeiting is often the tip of the criminal iceberg. There are links between counterfeiting and organised crime and it is often used as a means of laundering money gathered by drug dealers. A lot of this stuff comes from factories in eastern Europe and we have evidence of links to Russian mafia syndicates."

That's something to ponder next time you are tempted by an extraordinarily cheap Olympics T-shirt, Prada handbag or computer game for the kids.

webTitle: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ... a Marmite lid
fields.trailText: ... a Marmite lid
fields.body:
It is hard to imagine that many clients of Theo Fennell, the upper-crust London jeweller, stop off for chips on their way home from his Fulham Road store. But a celebrity clientele of the Beckhams' calibre clearly hasn't gone to his head, as this collection shows. Theo Fennell retains the common touch with a collection of "unstuffy alternatives" to the traditional silverware collections you'd expect to find on the tables of those who dine in grandeur. And now that all the obvious luxuries have been covered he has turned his attention to the kitchen cupboard staples, the sauces and spreads, the preserves and pickles that are so much a feature of everyday life that you only ever notice them when they run out. His silver sleeves and lids will elevate those kitchen cupboard essentials to sartorial elegance. Whether the smattering of Marmite on your toast will taste any better if it comes from a pot topped with a £125 silver lid or the dollop of Heinz tomato ketchup that comes from a bottle with its own £995 sleeve will take your chips to new levels of haute cuisine is a different matter. In the face of such wealth, taste clearly isn't everything.

 Theo Fennell on 020-7591 5000.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.body:
Co-buying

If you think "co-buying" is a sociological term for a group of friends hitting the shops on a Saturday afternoon, then it really is time to reach for your web guide. "Co-buying" or "co- shopping" - where shoppers use their combined purchasing power to drive down the price of an item - is really taking off this month, with the launch of two new sites to rival Swedish firm www.letsbuyit.com .

Europe's first online co-operative buying company, letsbuyit.com, launched in the UK in November and is able to offers discounts on a range of products, sports and leisure goods and perfumes by buying in bulk directly from manufacturers such as Sony, Nike and Prada. The goods go on sale for a limited period and the price falls as more people sign up to buy. Savings can be upwards of 50% on high-street prices.

fields.headline: What to wear at parties
fields.standfirst: Want to ensure that you do not show yourself up at one of these bashes? Here are a few tips on what to say and wear.
fields.trailText: Want to ensure that you do not show yourself up at one of these bashes? Here are a few tips on what to say and wear.
fields.body:
The formal ones
Most people will not look out of place in a suit, but if you want to create the right impression, smart but casual works best. A suit gives the impression that you are trying too hard.

The informal ones
While suits for guys is just about okay, ties are a definite no-no, and the suit has to look good to pass the geek-chic code. So no "I think I'll wear my dad's old suit, no one will notice." They will, and it could mean the difference between acceptance and rejection.

Women's suits are definitely out, unless you can say you have just come out of a meeting with your VC. The easiest thing to do is ditch the suit jacket. Head-to-toe Carhartt is receiving a bit of a backlash courtesy of Tvgohome.com, so opt for Duffer and Erl and Joseph jeans instead. Palm Pilots/PDAs and WAP phones are the ultimate fashion accessories, although be careful about flashing them around all night - five minutes every hour should do the trick.

What to say
A good starting point is: "I've just got third-round funding", "Lastminute.com is shite", "The next big thing is P2P [person to person] or G2C [government to citizen]", or "I'm setting up a corner shop."

What not to say
"I've just got third-round funding" "Who's Tim Berners Lee?", "PDAs are a waste of time" "Wap is amazing" "Is Esther Dyson the person behind those clever vacuum cleaners?" "Can I sleep with you?" "What's ADSL?"

fields.headline: Has M&S passed its sell-by date?
fields.standfirst: After a dreadful year that left its profits in tatters and critics claiming it was hopelessly out-of-date, Marks & Spencer is fighting back. Dan Milmo reports
fields.trailText: After a dreadful year that left its profits in tatters and critics claiming it was hopelessly out-of-date, Marks & Spencer is fighting back. Dan Milmo reports
fields.body:
Marks and Spencer is more than just a common or garden high street retailer, it's a national symbol. But rather like other British icons such as the royal family and the NHS, the company has had a torrid time of late.

The list of problems is immense, from accusations of mismanagement and arrogance, to a stock market savaging which has seen the share price hit a 10-year low of 208p. A January boardroom shuffle which installed Belgian Luc Vandevelde as the new chairman has failed to improve the retailer's problems.

Preliminary results for the year to April saw M&S post pre-tax profits of £418m, down from £546m in 1999, followed by a cut in the dividend, which caused uproar at the company's AGM. The retailer was wiping the shop floor with the opposition only two years ago, when profits were a massive £1.1bn.

The key to the retailer's woes is clothing sales, which are falling through the floor. Figures published by Verdict Research show that M&S's share of the women'swear market has slipped to 13.5% from 16.9%, and to 12% from 13.9% for men.

Many industry observers say that M&S is simply out of date, that its customer base has changed in taste and the company has failed to move with it. A recent report by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said that a large portion of the high street will come under pressure from the net and from increasing turnover of social trends. It predicted that middle-market retailers such as M&S and BHS will be caught out by customers who want either quality or value, not something in-between.

But Mike Godliman of Verdict Research believes M&S will be able to keep on top of shifting customer tastes, which contributed to the shock collapse of C&A this year.

He says: "It is not an image problem. M&S was unique on the high street for many years and now has more competition, that is the only issue. The dynamics of retail spending have changed, with older people dressing less like their parents now. Look at how many 30 to 40-year-olds are copying their kids, wearing trendy brands such as Quicksilver."

Godliman says the store can use its brand as a solid base for recovery, with the recent Footglove collection showing that M&S can get the basics right. If they do this on a more consistent basis, then a return to past glories is possible.

"They can get the core customer market back", he says. "People under 40 have to come back to the stores. But they need to realise that the consumer is behaving differently now, as everyone wants to look younger or trendier now. M&S was not that brand before, and it needs to cater for them whilst still producing its excellent socks, pants and knickers."

Godliman says it will take 18 months for M&S to turn it round, but he has confidence in its store re-vamps and new clothing collections, including the much-heralded Autograph launch. However, City experts see the company's problems in a much wider context.

Tony Shiret, retail analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, believes that over-capacity in all high street clothes shops is the root of the problem. "There is too much physical capacity", he says. "Companies were buying more clothes to compensate for lower prices. The huge amount of clothes in the market has encouraged discounting, and people could not sell everything at a discount forever."

Low-cost retailers such as Matalan, Peacocks and Matalan have made the problem worse by bringing in swingeing price cuts which no competitor could match. M&S does not have the money, or flexibility in its image, to follow that path.

However, there is no doubt that M&S realises its past mistakes and is doing its best to make up for them, starting with the appointment of its first marketing director in January. It agrees with Verdict Research's prediction that the turnaround will take 18 months.

A spokesperson says: "The underlying problem is that we took our eye off the ball and missed what our customers wanted. Our products did not change and our customers' needs did."

M&S blames increased competition in a high street sector, with the company taken by surprise when the likes of Gap and Zara sprang to offer trendier, cheaper alternatives. It has responded by consulting marketing experts Interbrand, which helped British Airways redesign its controversial aeroplane tail-fins.

The result is a new store format which creates the 'niche' shopping experience, by appealing to the different ages and trend requirements of each individual customer. The buzzwords involved are "fun", "passion" and "excitement", and the old colour scheme of garish gold and green has been replaced by soothing pastel shades.

"We are moving away from mass retailing and creating niches for everyone," the spokesperson says. "The stores will not look like open warehouses anymore, but we don't want to pigeonhole customers either. If a 60-year-old person wants to buy embroidered jeans, then they'll be available in the store."

However, M&S probably turns green-eyed with envy when it sees the success of the niche retailers. The prime example is Ted Baker, which is one of the best retail shares around, but has a deliberately idiosyncratic marketing style. In fact, it is so idiosyncratic it is virtually non-existent.

"We want to be a leader in fashion, but we don't want to lead too far," the company says. "We're not haute couture, but we're not middle of the market either. Our profile is entirely generated by word of mouth, not by someone walking down the road and seeing a huge billboard with our name on it."

The whispering campaign among the nation's trendier citizens has produced annual sales figures of £37m, up 34%, and profits of £8m, up 18%. The company has 12 stores in Britain, and will have to change its low profile if it is to expand, but its success is down to letting the clothes do the talking.

Ted Baker's Endurance suit, named after a sadistic Japanese game show, has proved a massive success, as it is designed to be worn at work and at play. The "lads" image has also been shed by launching a womenswear line, which now contributes over 35% of group sales.

M&S cannot follow Ted Baker's lead, which sums up its problems. It is not a small company which can make mistakes and realign its brands without damaging its share price or avoiding media derision. The jury is still out on its recovery programme, which will be the biggest endurance test it has ever faced.

fields.headline: Dyke uncut
fields.standfirst: The full, uncut version of Greg Dyke's interview with Media Guardian editor Janine Gibson shortly before the Edinburgh TV festival
fields.trailText: Janine Gibson: So who would you evict from the Big Brother house?
fields.body:
Janine Gibson: So who would you evict from the Big Brother house?

Greg Dyke: I've been away for most of it. I haven't seen enough to make a judgement. What are the figures like?

JG: (I tell him analysts expect the show will take Channel 4's audience share for the year to more than 11% of total viewing.)

GD: Look at what it did in the Netherlands - it went through the roof.

JG: I don't understand why Channel 4 will not be doing a second series.

GD: I quite admire that. I think one of the greatest problems with television [is that, for example,] the first docusoap was brilliant, the one about the driving school was absolutely brilliant - the 32nd one wasn't. Changing Rooms, the makeover show, was brilliant. Ground Force is brilliant, but I'm afraid the 20th show isn't. One of the great dangers with television is that it milks everything. It eats material.

When I was at ITV, the BBC and ITV - mainly ITV - destroyed snooker single-handedly. Because snooker had taken off suddenly and ITV had five tournaments a year -- the BBC had four -- no one knew what was what. We just killed it. Television has got a terrible tendency to take a good idea and milk it, until, in the end, everyone thinks it's dumbed down.

JG: I think Castaway will suffer from the hype surrounding Big Brother.

GD: What Big Brother's shown, which is what we know from Who Wants to be A Millionaire?, is that if you can run things consistently over a period of time, day in and day out, they work.

<B: It'll be interesting to see if it works for the People Versus, which is a very average show.

GD: The People Versus looks too much like Who Wants to be a Millionaire?. But then, Who Wants to be a Millionaire? was just Mastermind with money.

JG: Tell me about BBC3 and BBC4.

GD: No, I can't, because that's what I'm going to talk about [in the MacTaggart].

JG: All right. Are you concerned about the highbrow elite's reaction to the remaking of BBC1 as a drama and entertainment channel?

GD: That reaction is based on a false premise, so I'm not concerned at all.

JG: Why have people got the wrong idea?

GD: Because they always do. What happens is something gets out there as an idea; then it gets into the cuttings as something real; then everyone thinks it's happened. That was never intended.

JG: But you quite like to float ideas?

GD: I don't float them publicly - they become public. Everything becomes public knowledge out of here. But if you want to have an open, interesting environment, the cost of this is that stuff gets out and gets picked up. It's a price worth paying because you want that sort of environment.

Did you read Mark Thompson's speech? He didn't say that. No one's been briefed. Thompson made one speech, and that was it.

The idea that BBC1 is not going to have factual programmes or news and current affairs is simply not true.

But what is an interesting idea... [breaks off]

The problem is that the detractors are always there, and always will be. Some of my MacTaggart [speech] is about that. They're detractors of any change.

There are times in the history of the BBC when you have to change the organisation. This is one of them. I say change the organisation, but it's really about changing the output. And it's one of those times because of what's happening in the digital world.

What you need to do - and this is what I keep banging home and shall be banging home again in the MacTaggart - is say, look, if this government wants digital switch off at some point this decade - which is what it says it wants and what I suspect it will get - at some stage every home will be a multi-channel home.

That doesn't mean they'll all be pay-TV homes, because there's quite a lot of evidence that 30-40% of them are never going to pay - and they won't pay.

But every home will be a digital home, and at that stage the BBC will have a number of channels in every home. Therefore, you have to ask: between now and then, what type of channel portfolio will you need?

The trouble is it's a Catch 22. You'd quite like to have that [portfolio] now. The difficulty is a large part of the population will not go digital until they have to, and they will have just a four or five channel environment. You can't afford that - they pay their licence fee and deserve to have the best of the BBC - you can't deny them that.

But at some stage in the future you've got to say that everyone's going to be digital. And that's what Thompson was trying to say: it's a journey between now and there.

JG: Is there a danger that the BBC's pace of change will outpace the population's move to digital?

GD: No, I think if anything... No I don't. The audience would tell you.

JG: What about the investments in digital radio which [BBC chairman] Sir Christopher Bland recently admitted were too far ahead of the expansion of digital radio in the UK?

GD: Oh digital radio... but that's small money for the BBC. As I understand it there's been a problem with the set manufacturers. Did we go too far? Well there is an argument that we went too late into 24-hour news and should've gone earlier

JG: Come off it.

GD: Look. Change at the BBC means criticism. Always. I've read it all. I've read a lot of it in the last few weeks. Change always means criticism. It's very very different from a commercial organisation because of that.

JG: But most of your changes so far have been lauded and applauded. It's only when you started talking about changing BBC1...

GD: Yeah but everything else is irrelevant. Right? Everything else is about finding money, trying to get a better... you know. In the end what is television about? What is radio about? It's about a combination of money and talent. Right? You're not going to get talent to work here if they don't like the place, if they think it's vicious or unpleasant or bureaucratic or all the rest of it, so you've got to change that. Secondly you've got to find money, which means to find out 24% of the money in this place is being spent running the place is just not acceptable, right?

Those two - the combination of money and talent - in the end is what matters is what goes out on screen or on radio; what we listen to, what we use. The rest is just organisational stuff.

So I mean, you know, easy isn't it? I come in and say I believe in programmes and I'm going to give you more money and they're gonna love you aren't they? They're going to love you for saying that. That's the easy stuff, I believe in heaven and I don't believe in hell.

The real question is once you've got the money available, can we get the talent? Can we free up that talent and make this an exciting place to work for creative people? Cos if we can't we're dead.

JG: You've said several times that the important thing about work is that it should be fun

GD: (Nods...)]

JG: Do you think this is a fun place to work at the moment?

GD: For me?

JG: No, not for you. For everyone else. If it's not fun for you, you can go.

GD: They can go. That's what I said on day one. "If you don't like it here, go somewhere else." People get trapped into places that they don't need to be trapped in. This is an industry that's booming.

One person that left came to me and said: "I wanna thank you for..." [stops] I've got to be careful what I say...

They described their last couple of years and they had been very unhappy. And I just said, "well why didn't you leave?" And they said, "do you know I never thought about that". Now they've got another job and came in and said thanks.

That seems to me to be fine. You know... If you're unhappy, my view of the world is that you change it. You. The world isn't going to change it for you. You change it. Do something else. That's not to say, "If you don't like the way I'm doing it."

We're all free spirits, all free individuals...

JG: You still have the responsibility to make the culture of your corporation happy...

GD:...sure you've got to make it happy. It's supposed to be fun.

JG: Do you think they're having fun though?

GD: (Big sigh.) It depends where you are. I mean, no. Being here in an organisation where a lot of people are being made redundant if they're around you is not nice. It's very unpleasant.

JG: It's quite a prolonged revolution.

GD: I hate doing it. All I can say is we treat people very fairly and they happen to be lucky that they're moving out into a labour market at the moment in this industry which is booming.

JG: How many people have actually been sacked?

GD: Dunno.

JG:: Roughly?

GD: Some people saw the writing on the wall and went away. We expect to save 1,200 jobs. They won't all be fired. There are areas where we got rid of 40% of the staff and we're having to recruit people because we haven't got rid of them, they just left.

I don't like doing it. I didn't come here to do it. But at the end of the day the obligation upon us must be to put as much of the money on to the screen as we can.

Oddly that might end up as we could well end up employing another 1,000 people, but we're shifting the money from support systems to production systems and production.

JG: Have you sacked anyone yourself?

GD: (Pause.) Yeah.

JG: Not in the past, here at the BBC?

GD: Yeah. Well not sacked, I don't say sacked. But yes.

JG: What do you say to them?

GD: Ha. Err, what I say to them is what I say to everyone - it is not your fault. It is not their fault. The world changes and organisations change. There is not a lot you can do about it. You either change with it or you lose anyway.

Treat them properly and treat them fairly. There is always a danger that the moment someone's going, you see them as the other side. There's a real danger of that and you've got to treat people properly. I hope we're doing that, but no doubt there will be places where people don't feel that. We're certainly very generous and should be, as it's not their fault.

And actually there was too much money in this place being spent on running the organisation.

JG: But then in organisations like the BBC you get the verucca effect... That people who have worked here for a long time restructure and rebuild their departments as they were before, so suddenly all your suits spring up again.

GD: All organisations do that. All organisations in the end, if you're not taking out overhead you're putting it on. There is no in-between. And you can't constantly take out overhead because it's too damaging.

So inevitably you have a period where you take out overhead and it builds up and you take it out again and that's why people change systems and structures every five years.

Secondly there's no ideal structure of an organisation.

When I left Pearson it was time to change the structure, but I'd set it up and I didn't have the appetite for doing it.

We have introduced this statistic. This figure. [Dyke has announced that the BBC currently spends 76% of its income on programmes and 24% on running the organisation and he aims to cut those costs to 15%]

I can understand having worked here why the bureaucracy can become too big. I suspect it's the same in any public sector organisation.

JG: Why?

GD: Because when you sit in a profit and loss company and you think of a way of saving £1m you put it on to your profit and that profit goes up by 15%, it's probably worth about £20m in value to your company.

If you sit in the BBC where all you do is spend money, you spend £2.2bn a year so £1m is (snaps fingers).

The stuff we've done, like the croissants (which was really about me putting on too much weight) or the flowers. If people want flowers on their desks then they can pay for them. I don't see why the licence fee payer should pay for them. The transport: we've put a ban on booking cars. You're not allowed to have more than 15 minutes waiting time and we've put on a bus service between the bits of the BBC. [He doesn't take it, cos of the getting in a lift syndrome where people wander round saying: "Oh yes, the DG approved it."]

Those things are about saying, look we don't waste money. In some ways it's easier in a profit and loss company.

Here, we say, we're going to spend the money on programmes.

The first day, I got in my car and there were piles that thick [waves arms in the air] and they said that's your reading for tomorrow and I said: "You must be mad. I'm not reading all that." Once people began to understand I wasn't going to read it they cut it short.

I always carried all my paper around in boxes. Once I lost one... and it didn't seem to make any difference.

What I do is have about ten ideas going. That's what I'm interested in.

JG: It's like an oven in here...

GD: Don't get me going. The Chinese minister for culture came here and he said: "Mr Dyke, it is very warm in here. Could you turn down the heating?" I said: "Minister there are some things I can do about the BBC and some I can't. One thing I can't do is change the air conditioning."

JG:: Are people finding it weird to adapt?

GD: I don't do details. I think one of the dangers is that there was almost a culture here of having written the paper, that was the end of it. A report culture. Now I'm not interested in papers, I'm interested in what we do.

Do you know what I mean?

JG: Oh yes. I vividly recall Extending Choice - the BBC's role in the digital age.

GD: Yeah. My view is: look, the paper's irrelevant. What are we going to do? What are we going to change?

So yeah, it was difficult. One of the things of course, which John Birt warned me about, is that you're going ahead, getting things sorted and out of nowhere comes the Queen Mother's pageant that you've never heard of, you've no idea what it's about and suddenly it dominates a week or 10 days. You realise you have to have a system which gives you some time to sort those.

JG: Was that a low point?

GD: No. No.

JG: What was?

GD: The stuff about my shares [Dyke was accused by a number of newspapers - led by the Times - of conflict of interest because he owned shares in companies including Granada at the time that he joined the BBC as director-general designate] was a low point because it was deeply unfair.

I was doing precisely what the BBC had asked me to do. I didn't even negotiate a contract. When I got the job I just signed what they wanted.

The suggestion that somehow you were corrupt for taking the job when in all honesty no one, well certainly not me, would take it for the money. I've got enough money. I don't need the money.

And suddenly you realise you're in a much much more political world. That's it. You're closer to the world of politics than you are to the world of business and I don't like that a lot. I chose many years ago not to be a politician. They're the bits I don't like.

JG: But you're familiar with it....

GD: Oh, I'm familiar with it, but I still find being slagged off by some second rate backbench MP a pain in the arse. But that's part of the game.

But a lot of it isn't. I just find sitting in the middle of a political battle, which you end up doing a lot in this job, I don't like it a lot. It's not what I want to do with my life. The upside is it's a fascinating place. You've got an enormous amount of output.

The political stuff is that I can sit here and tell them what to do. You must be joking. In the middle of the premier league negotiations Panorama was doing a documentary about it. I asked them why they were doing it and they said, "We're doing it to test you".

I said: "It better be bloody good. If we lose the contract because of it and it's rubbish, I shall be really annoyed."

I'm fair game. My kids aren't. My kids are entitled... and suddenly you find their shares are being investigated...

I'm not really that sort of person. I don't have many low points. I'm quite a resilient human being. My view of the world is that everything will work out.

JG: How much of the BBC's output do you watch?

GD: Not enough. Can't watch it enough. Not enough of the competition either. What do I think of the output? I watched the night before last the re-run of the BBC2 documentary about the expedition to find out what happened to Mallory. Fantastic.

I think the problem with television is that it eats material so I think the output's mixed. Some of it's good, some of it's not, but you've got to get the average better.

JG: Do you think any of the networks are at the top of their game at present?

I think the radio stations are pretty good at the moment. I'm really a Radio 4, Radio 5 listener. When I got here I thought I'd better listen to some of the other. I thought of Radio 2 as what my Auntie Vera used to listen to - not for my generation, but it's great. [Radio 2 controller] Jim Moir's done a really good job there.

I'm doing a tour of regional radio stations. In 1965 one local newspaper had to buy its own typewriter. It's the same now in local radio. [Tells a story about being in Radio Coventry where the studio is the newsroom and everyone has to be quiet when the broadcasts are one].

I said, "Come on, this is not big money for the BBC." Local radio's been squeezed too much.

JG: What about BBC1?

GD: BBC1 has got some brilliant bits. Some of the drama is as good as anything you'll see over the years. A lot of BBC1's quite good, we just need to make more of it.

Everybody I know who's been a programme-maker has spent a lot of money on a piece of garbage, but there are very few people who have made wonderful things with very little money. Resources and talent. Resources and talent.

BBC2 is still erm [pauses] not sure what it is. It never has done. Is it the channel of the Open University - or is it the home of Gimme Gimme Gimme?

It's got some great programmes on it. Some great programmes. You know what Channel 4 is, by and large.

But if you judge a channel by some of the bits, then some of the bits are great.

JG: Your 17-strong executive committee is quite sizeable. Are they collaborative or do they still gang up on each other?

GD: I don't see it, but I suspect there still is [ganging up]... My style is that you don't take people aside afterwards and say: "You shouldn't have said that," you say what you think.

JG: Programme Review [a torturous meeting where BBC executives discuss each other's programmes] is traditionally full of backbiting isn't it? I've heard it described as a complete carve up.

GD: That's always been like that. When I first got a job in TV at LWT I went to my first reviewing meeting and about four people completely slagged off this poor bloke's programme. He waited for weeks until it was one of theirs' and wreaked his revenge.

If you completely screw up, what you want is a discussion with the people in the room saying look guys, we've completely screwed this, let's fix it. There's no point having people scoring points. What's the point? Might as well go into politics.

JG: People have behaved like politicians in the BBC over the last ten years, you know they have.

GD: As I get older I find politics harder and harder to understand. If you've got a problem, you want to sit people round a table and say how do we solve this?

I had lunch with a senior opposition minister early on who said to me, "if you really want to change the BBC, keep as far away from Westminster as you can." I think there's some truth in that. It's not the role of the broadcaster to be in government's pockets.

JG: What do you think the main differences between your BBC and John Birt's BBC will prove to be?

GD: John [Birt] and I believed in very similar things, I just think we have a very different style of management.

JG: So does that mean that your BBC will be similar to his?

GD: No. [pauses]. Because I think... I think... if you want organisations to change you have to carry the staff with you. If you can't carry the staff with you, you can't change it.

I did a thing for the NHS a few years ago [He chaired a panel writing a report for the government] which had some quite good ideas in it that were largely ignored.

One of the things it said was: "If you can't get the staff back onside, they've had political initiative overload, and they're not going to take nay notice."

[As part of the exercise] I wanted to be a porter for a night. So I went to the Whittington in North London to A&E on a Friday in an overall and a hat. Someone came in who I knew. Said to me: "Is there any way you can hurry this up?" I just said: "Naah, I can't help you."

It was an amazing night. A kid was born in the car park, a bloke walked in and hit one of the nurses... All that kind of stuff. And the idea that I was going to go up to one of these nurses and say: "Do you think you've met your charter standards?" I mean, the only thing to say was: "How do you survive this every night?"

The problem with the health service - and you saw a bit in the BBC - was that the people down on the coalface thought they did it despite the management and despite the organisation, not because of it. That was the biggest change you had to take at the health service and it's the same here. You had to... [trails off]

Somehow John had lost contact, the relationship with the people who worked here.

That's most of what I spend my time doing.
fields.bodyText: Janine Gibson: So who would you evict from the Big Brother house? Greg Dyke: I've been away for most of it. I haven't seen enough to make a judgement. What are the figures like? JG: (I tell him analysts expect the show will take Channel 4's audience share for the year to more than 11% of total viewing.) GD: Look at what it did in the Netherlands - it went through the roof. JG: I don't understand why Channel 4 will not be doing a second series. GD: I quite admire that. I think one of the greatest problems with television [is that, for example,] the first docusoap was brilliant, the one about the driving school was absolutely brilliant - the 32nd one wasn't. Changing Rooms, the makeover show, was brilliant. Ground Force is brilliant, but I'm afraid the 20th show isn't. One of the great dangers with television is that it milks everything. It eats material. When I was at ITV, the BBC and ITV - mainly ITV - destroyed snooker single-handedly. Because snooker had taken off suddenly and ITV had five tournaments a year -- the BBC had four -- no one knew what was what. We just killed it. Television has got a terrible tendency to take a good idea and milk it, until, in the end, everyone thinks it's dumbed down. JG: I think Castaway will suffer from the hype surrounding Big Brother. GD: What Big Brother's shown, which is what we know from Who Wants to be A Millionaire?, is that if you can run things consistently over a period of time, day in and day out, they work.

fields.headline: Bogarde signs for Chelsea
fields.trailText: Chelsea have signed Holland international defender Winston Bogarde on a free transfer from Barcelona. Bogarde, a central defender who can also play full-back, has signed a four-year contract.
fields.body:
Chelsea have signed Holland international defender Winston Bogarde on a free transfer from Barcelona. Bogarde, a central defender who can also play full-back, has signed a four-year contract.

The 29-year-old announced the move on his personal website, saying: "My ultimate dream came true this morning - a move to England with Chelsea.

"I have signed a four-year deal and join them on a free transfer from Barcelona."

Bogarde will be direct replacement for Emerson Thome, who has completed a £4.5million move to Sunderland according to Chelsea's official website.

"[Thome] joined for £2.5 million just 8 months ago," said a statement on the site, "so a £2 million pound profit in such a short period of time has to be seen as good business."

fields.headline: 365 Corporation posts strong first-quarter results
fields.trailText: Internet and telecoms content provider 365 Corporation temporarily defused the dotbomb scares sweeping the sector by posting positive first-quarter figures.
fields.body:
Internet and telecoms content provider 365 Corporation temporarily defused the dotbomb scares sweeping the sector by posting positive first-quarter figures.

The multi-talented company, which provides communications services to businesses and runs a wide portfolio of websites, reported a loss before tax of £7.9m, against a loss of £0.1m last year. But analysts latched onto a leap in revenues from £4.6m to £10m, predicting the company will make profit by 2002 without the need for further financing.

Chief executive Dan Thompson, who founded the company in 1997 with rock journalist-turned-entrepreneur Danny Kelly and Simon Morris, the former managing director of Ginger Productions, said the company's growth stems from its strength in depth. Revenues from the business division climbed 23%, while turnover from the consumer arm rose 46%.

"In the offline world, people would not dream of going into business with a narrow range of products," he said. "It limits your growth potential, as a good company is diversified and we have a nice combination of products."

The most recent success was the eurofinals365.com website, which offered such quirks as a professional lip-reader who identified the worst on-field swearers at the football tournament. The service attracted over 600,000 users and sponsorship from Dutch airline KLM and games giant Sega.

Mr Thompson said: "The site was highly profitable before a ball was kicked or a mouse was clicked. It was a great example of how you can keep your costs low but generate revenues."

The company has £45m in the bank, which guarantees survival until 2002, but the board are looking at 10 possible acquisition targets for their consumer and business divisions. This would be a change from 365 Corporation's usual strategy of joint-ventures, including partnerships with telecoms giants BT, Vodafone and Energis.

"I think these results are a milestone for the company. The fact that revenues have grown extremely quickly despite an increased marketing spend, is good for the future. They also have a slow cash-burn rate, and having consumer and business interests will protect them against trouble in either market," one analyst said.

Shares in 365 Corporation rose 4.5p to 74.5p, though a flat price prompted Mr Thompson and four other directors to buy £1.4m worth of shares in June.

webTitle: Dot.com directors hang on to their suits

fields.headline: Dot.com directors hang on to their suits
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance

Net news
fields.trailText: They are fresh faced twenty-somethings who wear combat trousers to work and dream about making a fast buck while burning vast sums of someone else's venture capital.
fields.body:
They are fresh faced twenty-somethings who wear combat trousers to work and dream about making a fast buck while burning vast sums of someone else's venture capital.

At least that is what we thought dot.com entrepreneurs were supposed to be.

New research from KPMG Consulting suggests that the identikit "e-business leader" is actually a far more sober-suited type. Typically aged 38, he often works seven days a week, has little time for a social life and is more likely to be found travelling economy class on a budget airline than the business class of a longer established carrier.

And nine out of 10 dot.com directors say they would wear a traditional suit to an important meeting because casual dress was "inappropriate".

The report, E-Business Leaders Survey 2000, paints dot.com directors in a far more flattering light than the publicity many in cyberspace have attracted after high-profile failures by the likes of Boo.com.

"Most people think that dot.coms are run by young graduates, who make loads of money in a short space of time," said Alan Buckle, chief executive of KPMG Consulting UK. "The dot.com leaders we surveyed work hard and are extremely dedicated - they are not kids, playing at business and hoping to make a fast buck.

"The research shows that there really is no short cut to success in the new economy. Just like a traditional business, a net venture will only thrive thanks to the hard work and business sense of its people.

"But there are critical differences in how dot.com leaders work that are increasingly likely to spread to the rest of the UK plc - particularly the focus on keeping costs to a minimum and the changing work patterns that reflect the 24/7 culture of the internet world."

KPMG interviewed 101 executives and found several differences between dot.com and traditional company working patterns. The biggest gap is in the median annual company turnover of the two groups: for traditional businesses it was £860m, for internet firms just £750,000.

Despite the gap both groups worked more than 56 hours a week on average. Directors of internet firms are twice as likely as traditional directors to work 71 hours per week and 40% are still in the office after 8pm.

More than a third said they have little time to relax or socialise and when they do take time out to read a book almost half read business books rather than fiction. On average dot.com directors take less than half of their annual holiday entitlement.

Internet directors are less likely to have degrees or backgrounds in finance but more have had private educations and come from marketing backgrounds.

The average age of the two groups of directors was much closer than researchers expected. Although 10 times as many dot.com directors were under 30 than those in traditional businesses, the average age of executives at new economy firms was an older than expected 38. The average age of old economy business leaders was 46.

What motivates each group also threw up some interesting results. Dot.com directors cited the chance to grow a business from scratch, working in a young, dynamic environment and stock options as the three biggest motivating factors. Old economy directors say they are turned on most by stock options and high salaries.

When it comes to dressing for work, 82% of dot.com executives favour permanent dress down days but nine out of 10 will put on a suit for an important business meeting. Eight out of 10 old economy bosses wear suits every day.

Nearly half of all executives plan to retire by the time they are 60 but almost 15% of e-business leaders love work so much they do not plan to hang over the reigns until they are 70.

webTitle: ITV fights back with old and new soaps

fields.headline: ITV fights back with old and new soaps
fields.trailText: ITV fired an agressive salvo in the soap opera ratings war yesterday with the announcement of a rival to EastEnders and a revival of Crossroads.
fields.body:
ITV fired an agressive salvo in the soap opera ratings war yesterday with the announcement of a rival to EastEnders and a revival of Crossroads. Giving the nation a new generation of gay fathers, power-bitches and angst-ridden teenagers to idolise, ITV said it would "stuff the BBC" in the popular drama battleground.

Trafalgar Road, a tea time series based on a group of friendly-but-flawed families, is a high risk attempt to create the network's first London-based soap - the heartland dominated by the BBC's ratings winner, EastEnders.

At the same time, Crossroads has shed the shaky sets and dodgy scripts of its 70s incarnation in a makeover promoted by Lord Alli, director of production at Carlton, part of a drive to revive ITV's afternoon schedule.

Both series, costing £40,000 an episode, will run for at least a year, five days a week.

They are among the biggest risks taken by ITV's director of programmes, David Liddiment, since he took over in 1997.

Like Lord Alli's new Labour party, new Crossroads will bear only a passing resemblance to the original.

While there is a part for Jane Rossington, the actress who opened the first episode in 1964 with the immortal lines "Crossroads motel, can I help you?", there is no room for the idiot savant of the original series, Benny Hawkins. Producers have decided that his simple but lovable character is not suitable for a 21st century audience.

Rossington's character, Jill Chance, will stage a dramatic return from the West Country to claim a stake in the business. A power battle ensues with new owner Kate Russell, who may be played by one half of the Dempsey and Makepeace cop show duo, Glynis Barber. There will be a new, glamorous receptionist to replace Miss Diane, and a hunky young porter to complete the sexier line-up.

Steve Hewlett, Carlton's director of programmes, said the remake would not suffer from the wobbly sets and incredible storylines that plagued the later stages of the original show. "It won't have any of those defects. This has fantastic storylines and very high production values."

Old fans would recognise some elements. Kathy Staff, who played the gossipy cleaner and kitchen worker, Doris Luke, is earmarked for a comeback. But new viewers would not suffer from a lack of background knowledge. "While it is not afraid of its roots, it will work as a new drama in its own right," Mr Hewlett said.

Trafalgar Road, made by United Productions, will fill the tea time slot vacated by Home and Away, poached by Channel 5. It is described as less gritty and depressing than EastEnders: "It's deeply moral, sweet and funny, but has a strong thriller element," said the show's executive producer, Damien Timmer.

It is based around the Harper, Wells, Drake and Mills families: Mike Drake is a middle aged father struggling with his homosexuality, just as his 16-year-old son Tim is going through his own teenage rite of passage with Frankie Mills, the girl next door.

Further dramatic tension is provided by a handsome young footballer, Sam Hayden: the 17-year-old must choose between his dream of a dazzling career with Charlton Athletic, where he is on the youth team, and bringing up his baby brother and young sister following the death of his parents.

Mr Liddiment said the commissions were substantial investments in UK drama. "Soaps play an important role in connecting channels with their audience.

"In a multi-channel age, I believe their ability to create 'appointments to view' in the schedule will be even more crucial."

Dud suds: Soaps that failed

Eldorado
Launched in 1992 by the team that created EastEnders, it soon fell victim to tabloid vilification. It was launched too quickly and with little imagination, less investment. Not even the southern Spain location could save it.

Albion Market
ITV's Manchester answer to EastEnders suffered from bizarre scheduling - Friday to Sunday. Patchy commitment from some ITV regions signed its death warrant.

Families
Short-lived daily offering from Granada. David Liddiment, ITV director of programmes, then based at the Manchester broadcaster, learned many lessons from its failure, including the key "keep it simple" premise. Families was partly based in Sydney, and the global storylines were just too far-fetched.

London Bridge
It has to be hoped that Carlton's first attempt at a soap is not replicated in Crossroads. The London-based drama never took off outside the capital, and was axed in 1996, a year after its launch.

Family Affairs
Channel 5's attempt at a daily soap suffered from the Crossroads curse of acting even more wooden than the sets. Mass cull of main characters aimed to save it. Still on the air, but some would question why.

David Liddiment, ITV director of programmes, then based at the Manchester broadcaster, learned many lessons from its failure, including the key "keep it simple" premise. Families was partly based in Sydney, and the global storylines were just too far-fetched. London Bridge It has to be hoped that Carlton's first attempt at a soap is not replicated in Crossroads. The London-based drama never took off outside the capital, and was axed in 1996, a year after its launch. Family Affairs Channel 5's attempt at a daily soap suffered from the Crossroads curse of acting even more wooden than the sets. Mass cull of main characters aimed to save it. Still on the air, but some would question why.

webTitle: Letsbuyit cuts 20% of staff despite sales surge

fields.headline: Letsbuyit cuts 20% of staff despite sales surge
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance

Net news
fields.trailText: Online retailer Letsbuyit.com is to cut 20% of its workforce across Europe despite an 83% increase in sales and improving margins.
fields.body:
Online retailer Letsbuyit.com is to cut 20% of its workforce across Europe despite an 83% increase in sales and improving margins.

In its first published quarterly results since flotation on the Neuer Markt in July, the 18-month-old company said it was shedding 80 of its 400 staff to enable a "one-off" European restructuring.

Stephen Cox of Letsbuyit said: "It was not our intention to reduce the workforce but we will take whatever strategic decisions we need to move to the next stage."

He could not rule out further redundancies but there were no plans at present. The job losses will be in a number of areas including merchandising and marketing which, the company said, "lend themselves to centralisation".

Gross profit margins for the three months ended June 30 rose to 9.8%, up from 2.9% the previous quarter, with sales for the same period reaching €7.22m (£4.43m). Mr Cox said the increase in margins was on target but warned against over-analysing a single quarter's performance.

Any encouragement from the growing sales and improved margins was overshadowed by an €18m increase in operating costs to €43m, attributed to the cost of rolling out across Europe and investment in advertising.

Mr Cox confirmed that the firm would be cutting back on television "brand advertising" and redirecting a reduced budget to the internet.

One analyst yesterday warned that if operating costs for marketing were incorporated in overall sales figures the cost of accumulating the necessary customer base to sustain growth was still too high. "Even if they grew their customer base 10 times, on their current pricing structure they still wouldn't make enough money."

Only 17% of the 850,000 registered users have bought something from the site.
