fields.headline: Doomed AltaVista chief quits
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance

Net news
fields.trailText: AltaVista UK's managing director, Andy Mitchell, yesterday paid the price for the company's failed launch of an unmetered internet access service by tendering his resignation.
fields.body:
AltaVista UK's managing director, Andy Mitchell, yesterday paid the price for the company's failed launch of an unmetered internet access service by tendering his resignation.

The announcement of Mr Mitchell's departure coincided with the closure of Ezesurf, which claimed to be Britain's longest established free call internet provider. The Dundee-based firm blamed a £1.7m bill for calls from internet service provider Energis Squared for its collapse.

AltaVista said that the problems with the launch of its service and the negative publicity that accompanied the fiasco had made 33-year-old Mr Mitchell's resignation "inevitable".

"The mistakes in our planned internet access service - which we do acknowledge - probably made Andy's departure inevitable," the spokesman said.

Mr Mitchell has been replaced with immediate effect by Stephanie Himoff, the head of business development, who joined the company six months ago from CMP Media.

Ms Himoff said that AltaVista would now be returning to its core business - search engine provision.

AltaVista was insisting as late as last week that subscribers were using a service that it had claimed, when it was launched amid a blaze of publicity in March, would revolutionise internet usage in Britain.

Then the company promised unlimited access to the web for just £60 a year, drawing praise even from the prime minister as a result.

Mr Mitchell confessed last week that the service - which more than 270,000 people had by that time signed up for - was not actually operating at all. He also admitted that he should have informed potential subscribers and his own superiors sooner.

AltaVista, based in Silicon Valley, California, blamed the failure on the high rates that BT charges for its domestic phone lines.

BT said AltaVista had not consulted it about the means by which it was going to provide the service before launching it to the media.

Ezesurf's managing director, Matt Bryson, announced the closure of the company in a 2,300-word statement on the company's website, and blamed a variety of people and situations for its problems. The monologue was later removed from the site.

The failure of the AltaVista and Ezesurf services illustrates the difficulty many internet service providers are experiencing in moving towards the unmetered access model pioneered in the US.

In Britain, home internet users have to pay local phone charges for each minute they are online. But in the US, local calls are included in a flat rate package supplied by the telecoms provider.

Analysts have repeatedly said that until the UK has unmetered access internet growth and usage will be restricted.

fields.headline: New media party types
fields.standfirst: Are you a ligger or a hunter? A straight-jacket or a pisshead? MediaGuardian throws up a few new media "types" to watch out for.
fields.trailText: Are you a ligger or a hunter? A straight-jacket or a pisshead? Amy Vickers throws up a few "types" to watch out for.
fields.body:
The ligger
Liggers can take on many guises, but more often than not they are the ones wearing cheap polo shirts with a company logo brandished across the back and front. The ligger goes to parties for one reason, and one reason only: to listen in on people's conversations - sometimes posing as a VC - and unscrupulously steal ideas. Liggers drink whatever is offered and never offer to buy drinks in return. You can spot a ligger a mile off - they're the ones fidgeting nervously after spending more than five minutes with one person and scanning the room constantly for the next 10 people to attack.

The pisshead
The pisshead, as the name suggests, is only there for the booze. They are recognisable as the person slumped in the corner at 8pm who later staggers about with their shirt open and unrecognisable stains all over their clothes. Unlike the average pisshead, the new media pisshead gets a second wind at 10:30pm and starts babbling about new media conspiracies, Haddock (an underground network of old new media types), Wap, DHTM, Flash, Shockwave, and any other random application of absolutely no interest to random strangers. Pissheads, as you may have gathered, tend to be techies who lack basic social skills and rarely make it out of the office during daylight hours. The tipple of the pisshead is tequila between 6pm and 8pm, followed by vodka and cranberry juice, and then absinthe into the early hours.

The strait-jacket
These are the stiffs who wear suits [Link: see what to wear at parties], normally come straight from a meeting or can't get their heads around new media casual wear. They can be excused at First Tuesday, particularly if they are a genuine VC with wads of cash, but wearing a suit is a huge faux pas at any of the casual evenings.

The agenda-bender
The agenda-bender butts in on strangers' conversations and steers the topic around to how great his or her business proposition is. Also known as dot.comatrix.

The Nathan Barley
The Nathan Barley (as defined by www.TVgohome.com) is decked out in Carhartt [see what to wear at parties], has one of those ruffled hairdos and tiny round spectacles. Other recognisable features include them taking one of those silly, impractical scooters everywhere, and having the latest gadgets sticking out of every pocket. No one knows what a Nathan Barley does, although they can be found in practically every new media agency in the land.

The hunter
The hunter is always on the job and business-card obsessed. On meeting new prey, the first thing they do is produce their business card and ask for one back. Conversation is very limited: "Where do you work?", "What do you do?", "Who do you know here?", "Are you looking for work?" [see what to say at parties] The hunter tends to be either a recruitment consultant or someone who is new to the industry/party scene and overly keen to network.

Do you recognise yourself or one of your colleagues among this lot? If so, or you know of other new media party types weve left out, please email us at Feedback@mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: Networking-oriented: the parties come thick and fast

fields.headline: Networking-oriented: the parties come thick and fast
fields.standfirst: From formal dos to informal parties where you can really let your hair down hair - and do some work (maybe).
fields.trailText: From formal dos to informal parties where you can really let your hair down hair - and do some work (maybe).
fields.body:
First Tuesday www.firsttuesday.com Set up in London in October 1998, First Tuesday holds regular "matchmaking" events for start-ups in more than 80 cities across the globe, employing 20 staff worldwide. It claims to have helped entrepreneurs to raise more than $147m (£98m) in funding.

E-women www.e-women.org One of the many networking events to have emerged that focus solely on women, E-women is held every few months, generally with top-name speakers - the last one pulled in Patricia Hewitt MP. In general, E-women events are very studious and, while wine is served, it is rare for anyone to over indulge. They are also generally quite well-dressed affairs, with mainly key women in the industry turning out.

The Chemistry www.thechemistry.com This is a bit more difficult to get in to than First Tuesday, as applicants have to be invited and then vetted for suitability. Essentially, it does the same thing as First Tuesday: matching VCs with entrepreneurs and service providers.

Four Leaf www.fourleaf.com The Four Leaf company is dedicated to the art of networking, although this is mainly done via the website. It does not run events, despite having been involved in Netproz, but plans to launch a channel covering all industry events on Four Leaf.

WAPWednesday www.fourleaf.com As the name suggests, WAPwednesday meets on Wednesdays and involves local mobile commerce professionals getting together in different European markets to talk about, yes, you guessed it, WAP. The format is similar to a seminar-focused network event, and meetings are open to anyone with an interest in WAP and m- commerce. WAPwednesday was hatched in December 1999.

NetProZ www.egroups.com/group/netproz-forum In the vane of First Tuesday, NetProZ could be called "Third Thursday". It describes its events as "hosted networking", but, unlike First Tuesday, entry is free. This informal matchmaking service was conceived in May 1999 - driven by the need to put specialist media, telecoms, finance and retail commentators in touch with each other.

The Ecademy www.theecademy.com/ Ecademy runs an e-commerce-focused event that meets once a month on Wednesday evenings. There is usually a speaker, and attendance is free. Ecademy provides networking events, as well as training, business development, examination certification, seminars, content distribution and consultancy services.

Digital People www.digitalpeople.org Digital People grew out of conference-oriented events into a smaller group that meets every month on a Wednesday. Industry speakers are the mainstay of these meetings, which include drinks and a buffet. There is a charge to get in.

Paradigm Violators www.egroups.com/group/paradigmviolators/info.html The description on the website says "Paradigm Violators is for people who are not satisfied with the status quo." So if you want to meet these types of people, sign up and go along once a month. This free event offers speakers and food, and targets marketers, VCs and entrepreneurs.

The Glasshouse www.theglasshouse.net/ The Glasshouse is a recently set up monthly networking party aimed at entrepreneurs, wannabe entrepreneurs and business people. Entry is free. Events, held at private clubs, are limited to around 150-200 people in order to keep them intimate. There are plans to host workshops.

Informal parties

Netnight A few individuals in key new media companies set up the original networking do in early 1997. It is held much less frequently than other networking parties that have sprung up over the past few years, and sometimes only occurs every six months. Netnight is generally organised by Ralph Averbuch, business development at Yahoo UK & Ireland, with sponsorship by the likes of Pixelpark, MSN, Ziff Davis and Price Jamieson. Drinks are free, but it is difficult to get tickets, the number of which are limited to 450 and only allocated to the sponsors, who send them out to business partners at their discretion. If you get a ticket, go, because everyone there is invited for a reason and the networking opportunities are good. The downside is that you feel obliged to behave yourself and do some proper networking.

NetEdNight This event was set up as an alternative to NetNight for people working on the content side of the Web - in other words, site editors and journalists, although some "creatives" are allowed in too. NetEdNight began life in June 1998 and takes place twice a year (usually June and October/November). Although it is sponsored, no branding is allowed at the event itself.

Netimperative Although billed as a networking event, the Netimperative monthly parties are generally a good excuse to meet people and have a drink. The bar is free, courtesy of various sponsors, and the dress code is young, trendy and labels.

Talking Frog www.theglasshouse.net/ Talking Frog was the brainchild of bEurope - a business-to-business (b2b) "generator" set up by former Guardian Unlimited boss Justin Walters. It is aimed at technical people such as programmers and developers - in other words, the type of people who rarely venture outdoors. It is held every month.

Boobnight www.boobnight.co.uk This long-running event began life in November 1998 but, as the name suggests, there is no free booze (the acronym stands for "buy our own beer"). It is one of the better events, but has been criticised for being cliquey. It is best to go there with a few colleagues, or arrange to meet people there. The general code is to wear as little as possible, drink as much as you can, but don't try to sell anything to anyone. "It's a purely social event. You are there to find out things other than where people work. Generally, it's great for recruitment consultants and those who need to spice up their love-life," says one of the head honchos. Boobnight is held on the first Thursday of each month, just after pay-day.

Clerkenwell Social www.clerkenwell@egroups.com/group/clerkenwell This does exactly what it says on the tin. It is a social evening for Clerkenwell new media types, entry is free and sponsors pay for the beer. Run by Sophie Sillochi at Guardian Unlimited and Moreover.com, it takes place on a monthly basis and tends to have the same kind of atmosphere as Boobnight. The Clerkenwell Social was conceived by Guardian Unlimited as the antithesis of First Tuesday.

The WAP Group www.thewapgroup.com/ The WAP group runs monthly meetings for developers, start-ups and anyone interested in WAP. Entry is free and there is normally a seminar, followed by a discussion. Events are tied to concurrent events in the US and Canada.

Dotcircus www.dotcircus.com This is a free, informal fortnightly networking group that matches VCs with entrepreneurs.

Overseas: US

Unlike the British, Americans love to do rooftop parties - cocktails being the preferred tipple. Another key difference is that Americans do not go to parties to get drunk. Far from it, they go with strict agendas: to meet certain people and make strong business contacts.

The Industry Standard www.thestandard.com This event began in mid-1998 in San Francisco to celebrate the first issue of the magazine. The parties became so popular that the Standard extended them to other cities (Washington, New York) and began hosting larger events in San Francisco, its main market. There are plans to bring the event to the UK, kicking off on October 18 - the night before the first issue of the Industry Standard Europe is released.

Cocktails with Courtney www.cocktailswithcourtney.com/ This is billed by Courtney Pulitzer (yes, her family is connected with the Pulitzer Prize) as a gathering of "internet industry friends, associates and business acquaintances for a fine evening with witty and thought-provoking conversations, cocktails to heighten the mood and complimentary hors d'oeuvres" - sounds lovely. Courtney has started to bring her inimitable model to this side of the pond, holding three parties so far this year. While the reception was generally fine - "everyone loves to drink champagne all night," said one punter - Courtney disappointed a few attendees by failing to be the perfect hostess. "I thought she would do a lot of introductions and 'match-making' but she didn't," said another punter. She should have done a quick introductory speech. The people there were a strange mixture of dot.com entrepreneurs and agency staff, all of whom seemed a bit hesitant to speak to each other and a little confused as to what the evening was all about."

Garage.com www.garage.com/ Entrepreneur/VC match-maker Garage.com offers day-long boot-camps for start-ups. Run along the lines of conferences/ workshops, these events have received no end of critical acclaim and networking opportunities are said to be "excellent". Garage.com will soon start a gruelling schedule of boot-camps and networking parties in the UK.

fields.headline: BBC timeline: Dyke's first year
fields.standfirst: Greg Dyke has rarely been out of the news since succeeding John Birt as BBC DG. Jason Deans looks back on the year up to his keynote address at the Edinburgh TV festival
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke has rarely been out of the news since succeeding John Birt as BBC DG. Jason Deans looks back on the year up to his keynote address at the Edinburgh TV festival
fields.body:
August 25 2000: Dyke used the MacTaggart Lecture, the keynote speech at the Guardian Edinburgh international television festival, to outline a future vision for the BBC based on the principle of "universality" - making all the corporation's publicly funded services available in all homes. He added that in the digital era the BBC's single most important role will be to make "great British programmes".

He said universality meant the BBC will limit itself to seven licence fee-funded TV services on five channels - the maximum that could fit on the BBC's digital terrestrial multiplex and be available free to all digital TV viewers.

The services, Dyke said, would include a BBC1 focused on delivering "greater impact", but without banishing all current affairs, documentaries, religion and arts. Dyke also announced that the BBC planned to move its 9pm news to 10pm from 2001.

BBC2, he added, would take some shows from BBC1 and become the channel for "intelligent specialist factual", leisure and lifestyle, "thoughtful analysis, creatively ambitious drama and comedy, and specialist sports".

But Dyke said this gradual transformation would take years, maybe until after analogue switch-off - estimated to take place towards the end of the decade. He added that BBC1 and BBC2 would continue to be aimed at analogue viewers, who are expected to make up the majority of TV homes until at least 2003.

BBC Choice would be transformed into youth-oriented service BBC3; while BBC Knowledge was to become BBC4, "a mixture of Radios 3 and 4 on television". The other services would be News 24 and two children's services, aimed at pre-school and six to 13-year-olds, which will go out on BBC3 and 4 during the daytime.

Dyke also announced that the BBC would be spending an extra £480m on programmes and services within two years - a 30% increase in real terms over three years. More than half the extra money will be spent on BBC1 and 2, with BBC3 and 4 having a combined budget of £130m and the Nations and Regions getting an extra £50m.

August 7: BBC lobbying was reported to have persuaded the government not to abolish the board of governors. But the BBC governors are expected to have their powers curtailed and be made to report to a single independent regulator that will be created to oversee the broadcasting industry.

August 6: The Sunday Times reported that Greg Dyke was planning to use his MacTaggart speech at the Edinburgh TV festival to unveil plans to reposition BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge as BBC3 and BBC4. The newspaper reported that BBC3 would be relaunched in April 2001 as a youth channel with a £92m annual budget. BBC4, which is to be repositioned as a high-brow arts, science and politics channel, is expected to have a £50m budget. Dyke was said to have discussed his plans with the BBC governors during their monthly meeting in July and to have described BBC4 as a "virtual Tate Modern".

July 13: In his first appearance before the Commons media select committee as director-general, Dyke told MPs that the BBC needed to adapt to a digital multi-channel TV environment. He said BBC1 would largely become an entertainment channel, while assuring the committee that there would always be a place for current affairs. BBC2 would carry more serious output, while BBC Choice would become youth and comedy channel BBC3. BBC Knowledge would evolve into BBC4 - an arts and culture channel.

July 12: Dyke failed in his bid to lure friend and former LWT colleague lord Melvyn Bragg to the BBC. Lord Bragg signed a lucrative four-year contract to remain LWT controller of arts and features.

July 10: It was announced that up to 1,100 BBC jobs were to go as part of Dyke's restructuring of the organisation. Most of the job losses and 70% of accompanying savings were to come from support areas - including human resources, marketing and publicity, strategy and finance - and management, with around 200 posts expected to be axed from the resources division.

The cuts form part of measures expected to produce savings of £750m over the next six years, as the BBC strives to meet Dyke's target of increasing the proportion of licence fee revenue it spends on programming and services from 76% to 85%.

Dyke also unveiled further details of the new BBC corporate structure he would be introducing, including four new TV genre commissioners for entertainment, drama, factual and arts programming, who would work with the channel controllers.

Within the factual and learning production division, 10 department heads were asked to compete for three new posts: head of documentaries and investigations, leisure and factual programming and specialist factual. A new head of religion and ethics post was also created within the division.

Factual and learning was asked to work with BBC News to create a business programming department.

The former drama and entertainment department management teams were to be merged and streamlined within the new drama, entertainment and children's production division, under Alan Yentob, who would also oversee a new innovative unit, Fictionlab.

BBC Radio, headed by Jenny Abramsky, was renamed Radio & Music.

June 21: Dyke announced a further £15m in funding for BBC1 and BBC2 - to come from efficiency savings - as the BBC unveiled its 1999-2000 annual report. In the face of criticism from the BBC governors that the average quality of BBC1 shows "was still not good enough", Dyke promised a "fundamental change" in the channel's performance. But he skirted around a question about whether BBC1 controller Peter Salmon was to blame for the channel's poor showing.

The annual report also revealed that Dyke's predecessor, Sir John Birt, received a termination payment of £328,400 for retiring early.

June 15: The BBC won back live rights to the FA Cup final from ITV. The corporation also secured live rights to England's home football internationals, as part of a £400m three-year deal with BSkyB.

However, Dyke was forced to back-track on accusations of skulduggery by ITV and the Premiership in the earlier deal to wrest Match of the Day football highlights away from the BBC. Match of the Day will be revived for a handful of weekends each year to cover the FA Cup.

June 14: Dyke, who arrived at the BBC promising to reverse the loss of key sports rights, suffered the biggest reversal of his tenure to date when ITV snatched Premiership highlights, effectively signalling the death-knell for Saturday night BBC1 institution Match of the Day. The BBC lost out despite doubling what it paid for the previous highlights deal - to £120m over three years. Dyke misjudged how much ITV wanted the rights; the commercial broadcaster bid £183m.

June 12: In the first public indication of a major shift in the BBC's strategic thinking, director of television Mark Thompson announced plans to move from the mixed schedules offered by BBC1 and BBC2 to genre-based channels. In a speech at the Banff TV festival in Canada, which was drafted in close consultation with Dyke, he said there would be "no sacred cows" in a review of how the BBC should adapt its TV output for the digital multi-channel era. Thompson added that genre-based channels would allow the BBC to extend, rather than dilute, its public service remit.

But the speech aroused immediate fears that the BBC was planning to dumb down its TV output and turn BBC1 into an entertainment service, shifting news and serious documentaries and current affairs to BBC2.

On the same day, it was announced that BBC director of public policy Patricia Hodgson was leaving the corporation to become Independent Television Commission chief executive. Hodgson was regarded as one of Sir John Birt's most trusted lieutenants, and her role had already been diminished under Dyke.

June 5: ITV controller of children's and youth Nigel Pickard, who worked for Dyke at TVS in the 80s, was poached to become BBC controller of children's programmes.

May 20: Grandstand, the BBC's flagship Saturday afternoon sports programme, was cancelled because of a lack of decent events to show. The 42-year-old institution, which had previously only come off air during annual holiday periods and the funeral of Diana, princess of Wales, was the victim of the BBC's loss of sports rights.

May 13: Dyke risked sparking a political row with the appointment of former Independent editor Andrew Marr as the BBC's political editor. Marr, who is regarded as left-leaning, was recruited by Dyke and head of news Tony Hall to replace Robin Oakley. Oakley, a former Times political editor with Conservative sympathies, was persuaded to retire a year early to make way for Marr.

May 10: In a further cost-cutting measure, BBC department heads received a memo from Dyke informing them that in future croissants would not be served at breakfast meetings.

May 2: A shuttle bus service was introduced to ferry staff between Broadcasting House in central London and Television Centre 'out west'. The move formed part of a Dyke-inspired clampdown on taxi costs.

April 7: Dyke pledged to increase the proportion of BBC employees from ethnic minorities to 10%, and double the number of managers from ethnic backgrounds by 2003, in a speech at the race in the media awards dinner. He said people from ethnic minorities made up 8% of the BBC workforce, but only 2% of managers.

April 3: Unveiling his strategic vision for "One BBC", Dyke promised to spend at least an extra £100m on programming and services in the coming year.

He announced plans for a flatter management structure, with an 18-strong executive committee at its centre.

Dyke also set a target of reducing the proportion of licence fee income spent on running the BBC from 24% to 15% over the next five years - in order to invest more in programming.

He said this would free up £200m a year to spend on programmes and help meet the government's savings target of £1.2bn over the next seven years. Dyke indicated that drama and entertainment would be top of the list for extra funding, but said neglected areas, such as local radio, would also benefit.

Dyke said he wanted to bring programme-makers closer to the centre of decision-making - 10 out of the 18 executive committee members would be responsible for production or broadcasting, compared with four in the previous senior executive forum.

As part of the management reorganisation, the much-maligned, Birt-inspired division between the BBC's broadcasting and production operations was abolished, along with the independent commissioning group. Four programming divisions were created: drama, entertainment & children, factual and learning, sport & news - along with a new media division to develop interactive TV and online operations.

In sport, children's and education, commissioning and programme-making were reintegrated. All in-house producers were to be offered output guarantees and longer term commissions. And the BBC internal market was to be simplified, with the number of business units cut from 190 to 50.

In radio, Abramsky was given responsibility for Radio 5 Live and music production - from the News and Production directorates, respectively.

March 8: The BBC saw off Kelvin MacKenzie's TalkSport to retain radio rights to England's home cricket Tests, in a bid orchestrated by Dyke. The BBC was said to have paid about £2m for the five-year deal.

March 2: Helen Boaden was appointed Radio 4 controller, replacing James Boyle.

February 21: Chris Smith announced a BBC funding settlement that gave it a rise in licence fee income equivalent to £200m a year over the next seven years. As a result, the licence fee for 2000-2001 would rise by 1.5% above inflation from April 1 - to £104.

While offering the BBC more money, Smith neatly side-stepped the £24 digital licence fee proposed by the Davies committee, which had been so roundly condemned by commercial rivals as a "digital poll tax".

But the increase he offered was well below the extra £3bn the BBC had asked for to see it through to the end of the existing licence fee charter period in April 2007. Describing his proposals as "tough love", Smith ordered the BBC to find a further £1.1bn in funding from "self-help" measures, including efficiency savings and increased commercial income.

Smith also announced plans to reform the BBC's self-governing status. The role of the board of governors was to be reviewed, along with the corporation's finances and fair trading commitments and the public service justification for new digital services such as News 24. He also confirmed a number of new licence fee concessions, including half-price fees for the blind and a free licence for the over-75s.

February 6: Dyke sanctioned the launch of a dedicated BBC online sports website. On the same day, BSkyB snatched the rights to cover the Bafta film awards ceremony from the corporation.

February 1: On his first official day in charge of the BBC, Dyke told an audience of 450 senior staff gathered at Television Centre to stop moaning or leave. He pledged to put programmes first and free up money to spend on them, starting with a £10m reduction in the cost of hiring management consultants.

His second main aim was to improve the BBC's internal culture. Dyke praised his predecessor Sir John's achievements, especially the launch of BBC Online.

January 31:Sir John's last day as director-general.

January 20: Dyke bowed to mounting pressure from critics and sold his £6m holding in Granada - pre-empting a meeting with the BBC governors, after which he could have been ordered to sell the stake. In a statement, Dyke said he had decided to sell the shares to prevent his early days as director-general from being dominated by controversy.

January 16: It emerged that the BBC governors had given Dyke until the end of April - two months after taking over as director-general - to sell his Granada shares - valued at about £6m. The disclosure prompted howls of protest about a possible conflict of interest. Dyke acquired the equity stake when Granada took over LWT.

January 1: Sir John became a lord, courtesy of the new year's honours list. On the same day, the BBC announced that he would be stepping down two months earlier than planned, at the end of January, giving credence to the theory that the life peerage formed part of a trade-off to prize his hands off the BBC tiller.

November 18 1999: In his first major public speech after being appointed director-general, Dyke pledged to place education at the heart of his strategy.

November 1 1999: Dyke joined the BBC as director-general designate, working alongside Sir John in a handover period due to last until the end of March 2000. The pair were to share adjoining offices.

Dyke announced immediately that he would be overseeing a review of the relationship between the Broadcast directorate and other BBC divisions, including Production and the corporate centre.

BBC observers took this as an indication that he intended to dismantle the corporate structure put in place by Sir John. The review was to take in TV commissioning, the four national radio services, new digital TV channels and BBC Online. Dyke would also take over direct control of Broadcast when chief executive Will Wyatt retired at the end of the year.

October 1 1999: Dyke resigned from the board of Manchester United.

August 29 1999: BBC1 controller Peter Salmon told the Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival that he would be asking Dyke for an extra £100m in his annual budget to combat falling ratings. Salmon had faced mounting criticism because of falling ratings and the alleged dumbing down of BBC1 output.

August 19 1999: Dyke sold his remaining Pearson shares, netting £800,000.

August 5 1999: A government-appointed committee chaired by leading economist Gavyn Davies recommended that the BBC's future funding needs be met by introducing a digital licence fee. The Davies committee's report suggested the additional licence fee be levied from people with access to digital TV services. It would initially be set at £24 from April 2000, but then fall as the uptake of digital services grew - to £12 by 2006.

The Davies report estimated that this measure, along with efficiency savings, the privatisation of BBC Resources and sale of a 49% stake in BBC Worldwide, would net the corporation an extra £150-200m a year over this period.

The committee recommended that advertising, subscription or sponsorship should not be introduced to the BBC's core services. They also said the BBC's accounts should more transparent and open to greater scrutiny by the Office of Fair Trading and National Audit Office, and that the licence fee discount for blind people should be increased to 50%.

The Davies report's digital licence fee recommendation was criticised by Sir John for not providing sufficient money to meet the corporation's funding needs. The BBC submission to the Davies committee had asked for an extra £650m a year to fund new digital services and ensure its public service remit was not watered down.

The digital licence fee proposal met with howls of protest from commercial media players, including the ITV companies and BSkyB, which said it would blight their efforts to sell digital TV services to the public.

August 2 1999: BBC executives were stunned by the defection of iconic sports presenter Des Lynam to ITV. Lynam signed a four-year deal reportedly worth £5m, citing unhappiness with the late scheduling of Match of the Day as one reason for his move.

June 24 1999: In a brief statement, the BBC announced that Dyke would replace Sir John as director-general. The announcement followed an extraordinary few days of behind-the-scenes political manoeuvring and intrigue. The final decision to appoint Dyke had been taken the previous evening by BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland and the board of governors over dinner.

Even at this stage, the governors remained split, with only seven of the 12 believed to have joined Bland - a close friend of Dyke's since their days working together as LWT chairman and chief executive, respectively - in approving his appointment. They had failed to reach agreement the previous week, amid newspaper reports that governors opposed to Dyke's candidacy, including vice-chairwoman Baroness Young, had threatened to resign over the issue - rumours officially denied by the BBC.

The reason for the split was the controversy over Dyke's links to Labour and whether he would be impartial. Back in April, the Times had sparked a row over Dyke's political allegiences by revealing he had donated £50,000 to Labour since 1994.

Rival candidates - who included BBC News chief executive Tony Hall, ITV chief executive Richard Eyre and BBC director of television Alan Yentob - had also begun briefing against Dyke in the spring and early summer, as the odds on him landing the job shortened and the race to become BBC director-general came increasingly dirty.

The digital licence fee proposal met with howls of protest from commercial media players, including the ITV companies and BSkyB, which said it would blight their efforts to sell digital TV services to the public. August 2 1999: BBC executives were stunned by the defection of iconic sports presenter Des Lynam to ITV. Lynam signed a four-year deal reportedly worth £5m, citing unhappiness with the late scheduling of Match of the Day as one reason for his move. June 24 1999: In a brief statement, the BBC announced that Dyke would replace Sir John as director-general. The announcement followed an extraordinary few days of behind-the-scenes political manoeuvring and intrigue. The final decision to appoint Dyke had been taken the previous evening by BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland and the board of governors over dinner. Even at this stage, the governors remained split, with only seven of the 12 believed to have joined Bland - a close friend of Dyke's since their days working together as LWT chairman and chief executive, respectively - in approving his appointment. They had failed to reach agreement the previous week, amid newspaper reports that governors opposed to Dyke's candidacy, including vice-chairwoman Baroness Young, had threatened to resign over the issue - rumours officially denied by the BBC. The reason for the split was the controversy over Dyke's links to Labour and whether he would be impartial. Back in April, the Times had sparked a row over Dyke's political allegiences by revealing he had donated £50,000 to Labour since 1994. Rival candidates - who included BBC News chief executive Tony Hall, ITV chief executive Richard Eyre and BBC director of television Alan Yentob - had also begun briefing against Dyke in the spring and early summer, as the odds on him landing the job shortened and the race to become BBC director-general came increasingly dirty.

fields.headline: Dyke in his own (and other people's) words
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, BBC director-general:
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, BBC director-general:

On talk of sliding standards on BBC1, June 21 2000: "Nobody sets out to make a real bummer. BBC1 had some outstanding programmes last year, more than previous years, but what we need to do is spread them across the year."

On winning back rights to show the FA Cup, but losing Match of the Day highlights, June 15 2000: "I'm delighted we have won the FA Cup and England games. I'd be much happier if we had also won the [Premier League] recorded highlights, but so be it."

On the need to increase the ethnic diversity of the BBC's workforce and management, in a speech at the race in the media awards, April 7 2000: "From Marks & Spencer right through to the Metropolitan Police, you find institutions which have been slow to react to modern Britain and, as a result, have had problems. The BBC is no different. The BBC has changed a lot in the 90s, but I would argue that the world has changed much faster, so we have to change more."

Interviewed in the Times, April 7 2000: "My style of management is about dropping bombs and seeing what happens."

Launching his strategic vision for the BBC, April 3 2000: "Our aim is to create 'One BBC', where people enjoy their job and are inspired and united behind the common purpose of making great programmes and delivering outstanding services."

Responding to culture secretary Chris Smith's licence fee announcement, February 21 2000: "We will, of course, have tough decisions to make on priorities and self-help. It will be more important than ever to make sure that we are spending our money on the things that really matter - programmes and services."

In a speech to senior staff on his first day in the job, February 1 2000: "If you want to help achieve that ambition [of putting programmes first], please stay and join in. But if you don't, please don't stay and moan. It damages the moral of the BBC internally and the reputation of the BBC outside."

In response to a query about whether he was going to be the "listening" director-general, at his Pearson TV leaving party, October 1999: "Am I hell! If they think I'm going to be the 'listening DG', they've got another thing coming. I'm going to do it my way. Watch me."

Mark Thompson, BBC director of television, June 12 2000: "I don't think it would be right, or possible, to move overnight from our traditional mixed schedules to fully genre-based channels, but I believe that unless we start the journey soon we risk becoming irrelevant."

Chris Smith, secretary of state for Culture, Media and Sport, in a New Statesman interview, July 2000: "Under Dyke, the BBC has begun to get its house in order. Some of the measures Greg has announced will produce substantial efficiency savings, but he hasn't got near the £1bn of savings I am looking for."

Former BBC World Service managing director John Tusa, in the same issue of the News Statesman, branded Dyke and Thompson the "Del Boy and Rodney of public service broadcasting". He also criticised the move to genre-based channels: "The consequences of this numbers-led analysis by the BBC will be to bury 'culture' - clearly a dirty word in BBC strategy circles - in the distant regions of the unwatched BBC digital channels."

David Davis, chairman of the public accounts committee, writing in the Guardian on June 23 2000: "It is the proper role of the leadership of the BBC to stand up to the bullying and tactics of any government. So far, it is not clear it has passed that test - let alone Dyke's previous test of 'avoiding an unhealthy relationship'."

Davis on Thompson's Banff speech: "Not only is [Thompson's] proposed strategy based on assumptions that owe more to public sector interests than to public service ideals and a thought process suited to accountancy and marketing, it offers nothing less than the end of the Reithian ideal."

William Hague, Conservative party leader, following the announcement that Dyke would be the next BBC director-general, June 24 1999: "Whilst respecting the right of the governors to reach an independent decision, in the current climate of Labour [party] cronyism, we are concerned that the appointment of Dyke may be prejudicial to the BBC's reputation."

fields.trailText:
Tuesday August 1
Pastor Ray McCauley, the man to whom Hansie Cronje turned when the allegations against him become known, urges him not to cash in on his downfall. "My advice to him would be to stop, stop right now ... fields.body:
Tuesday August 1
Pastor Ray McCauley, the man to whom Hansie Cronje turned when the allegations against him become known, urges him not to cash in on his downfall. "My advice to him would be to stop, stop right now ... I think that at this time ... it is important for him to be seen as somebody that is very repentant for what's happened and also that he needs to put back into the nation something other than just the fact that he's going to walk away from it."

AC Muthiah, President of the BCCI, urges the Indian government to conclude match-fixing investigations as swiftly as possible. "It is very demoralising for the team to play when you have a sword hanging over your head."

Wednesday August 2
In New Delhi, income-tax officials open the bank locker of Ajay Jadeja, one of many sealed during the nationwide raids on July 20 and July 21.

Thursday August 3
John Bacon, secretary of the King Commission, confirms that any money made by Hansie Cronje from book deals emanating from the match-fixing scandal will not be scrutinised by the commission. "We only cover the period up to April 17 this year. Anything beyond that doesn't concern us ... That's his own private affair."

Ajay Jadeja is questioned for over seven hours by income-tax officials. Afterwards he says he is innocent, and accuses the media of exaggerating the severity of the issue.

An Indian website, tehelka.com, reports that Mohammad Azharuddin and Salim Malik have paid up to £500,000 into each other's bank accounts. An unnamed tax official is quoted as saying, "Azharuddin should be behind bars for a decade ... we have proof that Mukesh Gupta paid for the Lokhandwala house of Azha ... After Hansie (Cronje) linked his name to Mukesh Gupta, Azhar went on a document burning spree. But we have still managed to get details ... If there is no political pressure we have innumerable grounds to arrest him soon."

Friday August 4
BCCI president AC Muthiah, secretary Jaywant Lele and treasurer Kishore Rungta are interviewed by CBI officials in Delhi. "This was a mutually arranged meeting ... (The CBI) asked us for balance sheets which we handed over to them. They also wanted to know how the subcommittees were appointed and how they functioned. All the details were given to them. Besides this, nothing else was discussed," Muthiah says, although the CBI deny that the meeting was mutually arranged.

Saturday August 5
Police in New Delhi arrest a third bookmaker, Sunil 'Bittoo' Dara, with alleged match-fixing links. This follows the earlier arrest of Rajesh Kalra and Kishan Kumar.

Sunday August 6
An Indian website, tehelka.com, reports that Mohammad Azharuddin and Salim Malik have paid up to £500,000 into each other's bank accounts. An unnamed tax official is quoted as saying, "Azharuddin should be behind bars for a decade...we have proof that Mukesh Gupta paid for the Lokhandwala house of Azhar...After Hansie (Cronje) linked his name to Mukesh Gupta, Azhar went on a document-burning spree. But we have still managed to get details...If there is no political pressure we have innumerable grounds to arrest him soon."

Monday August 7
In a letter to the PCB, Salim Malik pleads for the withdrawal of the lifetime ban imposed him in the Qayyum Report. "There were four specific allegations of match-fixing against me and I have been found not guilty in two of them. In the third allegation, a person could not be testified. In the fourth, I have been found guilty not of match-fixing but attempting to fix the first Test match at Karachi in September 1994 against Australia ... The Inquiry Commission was convinced that a match can only be fixed by five or four players working together. It cannot be fixed by an individual or by two players ... The Commission should not have believed Shane Warne and Mark Waugh's testimony because of the admitted position that they themselves are self-confessed habitual gamblers."

Tuesday August 8
In India, Deputy Finance Minister Dhananjaya Kumar announces in Parliament that tax officials have seized unaccounted wealth worth $900,000 during the nationwide raids, codenamed "Operation Gentleman," conducted last month. But Finance Minister Yashwant Sinha says that the names of those with unaccounted assets will not yet be revealed. "There will be no trial outside the court. We will maintain greatest circumspection to ensure that nobody is maligned. The government has not come to any conclusion and nobody will be named before the matter is fully examined."

Wednesday August 9
Greg Melick, Australian cricket's new match-fixing watch-dog, has found no reason to believe Salim Malik's claim of a double fix in 1994. Malik has claimed that both Pakistan and Australia had been bribed to lose a one-day match between the sides in Colombo in 1994. "Mr Melick has conducted a comprehensive and thorough investigation into the Salim Malik claims and established that there is no evidence to support such suggestions," says ACB chief executive Malcolm Speed.

Friday August 11
The King Commission's interim report is published. It makes no recommendations for disciplinary action, although it does allow the UCB to convene a disciplinary hearing on Herschelle Gibbs, Pieter Strydom and Henry Williams. No decision has been reached as to whether Hansie Cronje was completely honest during the hearing, and thus eligible for immunity from criminal prosecution.

The UCB later confirms that hearings for Gibbs, Strydom and Williams will take place on August 19, with an announcement of any punishment to be made on August 28.

Charles Williams, the father of Henry, accuses match-fixing investigators of racism. "My son and Gibbs were offered money, but did not take it...How can their sporting careers be taken away from them? I know other guys in the team are guilty, but they can play. Why can't the coloureds?"

Ngconde Balfour, the South African Minister of Sport, warns Hansie Cronje that the King Commission's work is not complete. "I have also noted the intention of the former South African cricket captain, Hansie Cronje, to grant interviews to selected media as well as his apparent decision to write a book on his involvement in the matter. While that might be his prerogative, it should be noted that the work of the Commission has not yet been finalised."

The PCB's Lt Gen Tauqir Zia tells total-cricket.com that Salim Malik's life ban will not be withdrawn. "Malik can go to the Supreme Court of Pakistan if he likes but the ban cannot be revoked."

Saturday August 12
On arrival in Australia for a one-day series, captain Shaun Pollock repeats his team's desire to put the match-fixing scandal behind them. "If we can win this, it will go a long way to help people who have been feeling miserable about what has happened...I think it's only a matter of time before they can rally behind us 100 per cent, and maybe once the King Commission's findings are out it can be totally forgotten about."

Sunday August 13
Income-tax authorities in India say that they are preparing a report on the findings of the raids on July 20/21, in which the lockers and houses of cricketers, administrators and bookmakers were searched.

Monday August 14
Shamila Batohi, the chief advocate of the King Commission, is to travel to India in an attempt to gain further evidence. Her duties include listening to the tapes held by Indian police which originally led to the Commission being established.

Wednesday August 16
On rediff.com, Leslie Sackstein, Hansie Cronje's lawyer, defends his client's "democratic right" to earn money through interviews, articles, books and films. "I must point out that, as he was summarily dismissed as captain by Ali Bacher, my client has no source of income, and he is entitled to earn something."

Indian Sports Minister SS Dhindsa complains about the BCCI's attitude towards the inquiry into the match-fixing scandal. "I had some reservations against the BCCI. They were not responding to our queries properly and their attitude was not positive. They were also adopting delaying tactics but they met me recently and assured me that in future they will co-operate with the Sports Ministry."

Thursday August 17
BCCI treasurer Kishore Rungta appears before the CBI to clarify the Board's position on a number of issues, including the match-fixing scandal.

King Commission spokesman John Bacon tells Times of India that chief prosecutor Shamila Batohi and investigator captain Geoff Edwards will spend a week in India. "We cannot yet confirm when they will be leaving South Africa...They will certainly be wanting to talk to Azharuddin and also to listen closely to the tapes in the possession of the Indian police."

Friday August 18
Kapil Dev, the current Indian coach, says that he is considering severing his ties with cricket. "If this is what I get for being a cricketer, I do not want to be part of it. I know I am clean - I have nothing to hide. The investigations will prove that. But I am finished with cricket. It is not worth it. If they [the BCCI] want me for one more year, then fine. I will do the job to the best of my ability. But after that I will have nothing to do with cricket."

Sir Donald Bradman says that he expects cricket to survive its current nadir. In a message read by his son John at the inaugural Sir Donald Bradman oration in Melbourne, Bradman said, "Despite recent sad developments, cricket will survive and remain our most noble game and I shall always remain proud of the part I played in its history and development."

Saturday August 19
Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams plead guilty to accusations of accepting $15,000 from Hansie Cronje to underperform in a Nagpur one-day international in March. A three-man tribunal will decide their fate, and that of Pieter Strydom, to be announced on August 28 or 29.

Sunday August 20
At its working committee meeting in Bangalore, the BCCI approves a code of conduct for players and officials. "This code will come in to effect immediately, but when it is passed at the general body meeting, we will have more authority in enforcing it. In addition, all players, officials and team administrators will have to sign a declaration. This is a very important step for the future of the Indian Cricket Board" says President AC Muthiah.

Muthiah also announces plans to speak to Kapil Dev, in the light of his threats to quit as Indian coach. "The Board has authorised me, the President, to call Mr Kapil Dev and have a discussion with him. They have also authorised me to take whatever decision I see fit in the interest of Indian cricket. I will be calling him shortly and taking a decision very soon on the subject."

Monday August 21
Indian police say that they have "excellent evidence" to support charges of match-fixing against Cronje.

The Press Trust of India reveal that Ravi Shastri, the only man to have corroborated Manoj Prabhakar's claim that Kapil Dev attempted to bribe him in 1994, was recently questioned by CBI officials.

PTI, quoting UCB sources, also say that "[Herschelle] Gibbs is likely to be banned from international cricket for at least a year for his role in the Cronje match-fixing scandal, [Henry] Williams is likely to be fined, while [Pieter] Strydom is expected to escape with a caution."

Tuesday August 22
Cronje has given an extensive interview to South African subscription channel M-Net, to be aired on Thursday, Friday and Saturday of this week. King Commission chief prosecutor Shamila Batohi confirms that she'll be tuning in. "Rest assured, I'll be watching. Just like the rest of the country, I expect."

Wednesday August 23
The Daily Mail reports that Chris Lewis is to write a book in which he will name the three English cricketers he was told had taken money to fix matches. Leicestershire coach Jack Birkenshaw said: "If he (publishes) it will be the end of him as a player. He will not be able to write a book without permission. If he does as an active player, the ECB will be bound to suspend him."

Thursday August 24
The King Commission's interim report is passed to the UCB. "It is being made public on Friday. We will post it on the government's website," said spokesman Graham Abrahams. Meanwhile, R N Sawani, joint director of the CBI declares that he is "satisfied" with the progress being made in their match-fixing investigations. A preliminary report is being finalised and will be submitted to the Sports Ministry in September.

In a three part TV interview on South African subscription channel M-Net, Cronje says that Herschelle Gibbs should not receive further punishment for his part in the match-fixing scandal. "In my opinion Herschelle should be given another chance to play. On the day he played superbly. Surely if you were told to get less than 20 and then you get 73 off 53 balls, then obviously you did not pay attention to what was said. You entertained the thought, you were tempted but you never followed through."

South African sports minister Ngconde Balfour confirms that there are no major surprises in the King Commission interim report, which is published on cricket.co.za. "There is not much in it really, no recommendations, nothing much. I am still of the opinion that there are only one or two people involved in this type of thing and we can easily clean up the game." The report makes no recommendations of disciplinary action, nor does it indicate whether Cronje will be granted immunity from criminal prosecution.

The Daily Telegraph reports that Judge King has asked the South African president Thabo Mbeki to widen his terms of reference. This would allow King to investigate match-fixing dating back to 1995. A commission source is quoted as saying, "We don't know what happened between the 1995 offer (to throw an ODI against Pakistan) and early this year. Were there other attempts to bribe South African cricketers? The present terms of reference do not allow us to investigate."

Friday August 25
In his interim report, Judge King takes a dim view of Hansie Cronje*s activities. "There is a common thread to these events which is shared by others where Cronje sought to involve his team-mates in match-fixing or related matters and that is that the initial approach is made jocularly. It seems that this was Cronje*s modus operandi. He would sound out his colleagues, in a way which would enable him to say later, if the need arose, that he had only been joking."

In the second part of his interview, Cronje praises the effective work of the match-fixing enquiry in South Africa: "I think we have got to give credit to the way it is being handled here as opposed to in Australia. But I would rather have (Mark Waugh and Shane Warne*s) punishment." On rediff.com, CBI joint director R N Savani says that Kapil Dev will be summoned before the CBI shortly. "No date has been fixed for the meeting, but it will take place."

The BCCI submits a copy of its code of conduct to the Indian government. Former CBI joint director K Madavan is confirmed as Commissioner of Inquiry.

Saturday August 26
Cronje absolves Nicky Boje of any involvement in match-fixing. Boje had been mentioned in alleged telephone calls between Cronje and an Indian bookmaker.

Sunday August 27
Income-tax officials in India raid the residence of off-spinner Nikhil Chopra in connection with their match-fixing investigations.

Monday August 28
Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams are banned from international cricket until January 1, 2001, while Pieter Strydom is acquitted of a charge of attempting to place a bet during the 5th Test between South Africa and England. Both Gibbs and Williams pleaded guilty to accepting money to underperform in a one-day international. In addition to the bans, Gibbs is fined 60,000 rand and Williams 10,000 rand. The bans do not preclude the pair from playing domestic cricket.

In a prepared statement, Gibbs does not dispute his punishment. "I am obviously bitterly disappointed that I will not be able to represent my country until next year. However, I am grateful that I will at least have the honour of being able to play for Western Province if so selected."

Former BCCI president IS Bindra criticises the board's treatment of Kapil Dev. "It is wrong on the part of the BCCI to gun for the team coach Kapil Dev though the board had earlier promised all help to him."

Tuesday August 29
Speculation mounts that Cronje could face civil claims running into millions of rands from past and present team-mates who suffered financial losses in the match- fixing scandal. He may also have to pay legal costs incurred during the King Commission. On cricketline.com, a senior South African player, who asks not to be named, says that he would sue Cronje were he Herschelle Gibbs or Henry Williams. The player also says that Cronje approached players from the traditionally less privileged sectors of South African society "to do his dirty work for him."

In the Cape Times Herman Gibbs, father of Herschelle, is quoted as deeming the sentences "bullshit - the boys have suffered enough. What I would like to know is who are the UCB accountable to in terms of their own misdemeanours when it comes to administering the game?"

Gibbs senior also tells rediff.com that he would like to sue Hansie Cronje for corrupting his son, and the UCB for failing to protect him from match-fixing. He says his son should act "like a boxer stepping back into the ring after a bad blow", and show that he is the best opener in South Africa.

Wednesday August 30
In his cricketline.com column, Allan Donald expresses his relief that Gibbs and Henry Williams did not receive a longer sentence: "Some people would say [Gibbs and Williams] deserved life bans. Neither of them actually went through with playing poorly on purpose but the fact that they even agreed to is very serious. They know now, though, that they've done wrong, and were both probably expecting suspended life bans. I'm glad the UCB wasn't too severe on them."

New Zealand Cricket chief executive Chris Doig expresses his disappointment at the penalties meted out to Gibbs and Williams: "I am surprised and disappointed at the leniency. For the sake of cricket we had to be seen to be taking a strong stance on match-fixing. On the basis the players appear to be guilty of being involved in some way of tacitly approving match-fixing, I think the penalties are modest."

BCCI president AC Muthiah criticises IS Bindra, who had expressed his dissatisfaction with the board's treatment of Kapil Dev. "Bindra could have made these remarks at the Bangalore meeting. In fact it was Bindra who had vehemently said in his earlier statements that Kapil Dev had offered money to Manoj Prabhakar and everyone knows these statements had kicked off so much dust."

Thursday August 31
In an interview with the New Statesman, Michael Atherton says that he does not think English cricket has a match-fixing problem: "I've not had any doubt about an England player. I can't say with hand on heart that I'm absolutely certain it hasn't happened, but I'd bet against it." The magazine also says that Atherton has played in a one-day international that he believes was fixed but, without evidence to support him, he has refused to name the game.

Watch this space
