We will maintain greatest circumspection to ensure that nobody is maligned. The government has not come to any conclusion and nobody will be named before the matter is fully examined." Wednesday August 9 Greg Melick, Australian cricket's new match-fixing watch-dog, has found no reason to believe Salim Malik's claim of a double fix in 1994. Malik has claimed that both Pakistan and Australia had been bribed to lose a one-day match between the sides in Colombo in 1994. "Mr Melick has conducted a comprehensive and thorough investigation into the Salim Malik claims and established that there is no evidence to support such suggestions," says ACB chief executive Malcolm Speed. Friday August 11 The King Commission's interim report is published. It makes no recommendations for disciplinary action, although it does allow the UCB to convene a disciplinary hearing on Herschelle Gibbs, Pieter Strydom and Henry Williams. No decision has been reached as to whether Hansie Cronje was completely honest during the hearing, and thus eligible for immunity from criminal prosecution. The UCB later confirms that hearings for Gibbs, Strydom and Williams will take place on August 19, with an announcement of any punishment to be made on August 28. Charles Williams, the father of Henry, accuses match-fixing investigators of racism. "My son and Gibbs were offered money, but did not take it...How can their sporting careers be taken away from them? I know other guys in the team are guilty, but they can play. Why can't the coloureds?" Ngconde Balfour, the South African Minister of Sport, warns Hansie Cronje that the King Commission's work is not complete. "I have also noted the intention of the former South African cricket captain, Hansie Cronje, to grant interviews to selected media as well as his apparent decision to write a book on his involvement in the matter. While that might be his prerogative, it should be noted that the work of the Commission has not yet been finalised." The PCB's Lt Gen Tauqir Zia tells total-cricket.com that Salim Malik's life ban will not be withdrawn. "Malik can go to the Supreme Court of Pakistan if he likes but the ban cannot be revoked." Saturday August 12 On arrival in Australia for a one-day series, captain Shaun Pollock repeats his team's desire to put the match-fixing scandal behind them. "If we can win this, it will go a long way to help people who have been feeling miserable about what has happened...I think it's only a matter of time before they can rally behind us 100 per cent, and maybe once the King Commission's findings are out it can be totally forgotten about." Sunday August 13 Income-tax authorities in India say that they are preparing a report on the findings of the raids on July 20/21, in which the lockers and houses of cricketers, administrators and bookmakers were searched. Monday August 14 Shamila Batohi, the chief advocate of the King Commission, is to travel to India in an attempt to gain further evidence. Her duties include listening to the tapes held by Indian police which originally led to the Commission being established. Wednesday August 16 On rediff.com, Leslie Sackstein, Hansie Cronje's lawyer, defends his client's "democratic right" to earn money through interviews, articles, books and films. "I must point out that, as he was summarily dismissed as captain by Ali Bacher, my client has no source of income, and he is entitled to earn something." Indian Sports Minister SS Dhindsa complains about the BCCI's attitude towards the inquiry into the match-fixing scandal. "I had some reservations against the BCCI. They were not responding to our queries properly and their attitude was not positive. They were also adopting delaying tactics but they met me recently and assured me that in future they will co-operate with the Sports Ministry." Thursday August 17 BCCI treasurer Kishore Rungta appears before the CBI to clarify the Board's position on a number of issues, including the match-fixing scandal. King Commission spokesman John Bacon tells Times of India that chief prosecutor Shamila Batohi and investigator captain Geoff Edwards will spend a week in India. "We cannot yet confirm when they will be leaving South Africa...They will certainly be wanting to talk to Azharuddin and also to listen closely to the tapes in the possession of the Indian police." Friday August 18 Kapil Dev, the current Indian coach, says that he is considering severing his ties with cricket. "If this is what I get for being a cricketer, I do not want to be part of it. I know I am clean - I have nothing to hide. The investigations will prove that. But I am finished with cricket. It is not worth it. If they [the BCCI] want me for one more year, then fine. I will do the job to the best of my ability. But after that I will have nothing to do with cricket." Sir Donald Bradman says that he expects cricket to survive its current nadir. In a message read by his son John at the inaugural Sir Donald Bradman oration in Melbourne, Bradman said, "Despite recent sad developments, cricket will survive and remain our most noble game and I shall always remain proud of the part I played in its history and development." Saturday August 19 Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams plead guilty to accusations of accepting $15,000 from Hansie Cronje to underperform in a Nagpur one-day international in March. A three-man tribunal will decide their fate, and that of Pieter Strydom, to be announced on August 28 or 29. Sunday August 20 At its working committee meeting in Bangalore, the BCCI approves a code of conduct for players and officials. "This code will come in to effect immediately, but when it is passed at the general body meeting, we will have more authority in enforcing it. In addition, all players, officials and team administrators will have to sign a declaration. This is a very important step for the future of the Indian Cricket Board" says President AC Muthiah. Muthiah also announces plans to speak to Kapil Dev, in the light of his threats to quit as Indian coach. "The Board has authorised me, the President, to call Mr Kapil Dev and have a discussion with him. They have also authorised me to take whatever decision I see fit in the interest of Indian cricket. I will be calling him shortly and taking a decision very soon on the subject." Monday August 21 Indian police say that they have "excellent evidence" to support charges of match-fixing against Cronje. The Press Trust of India reveal that Ravi Shastri, the only man to have corroborated Manoj Prabhakar's claim that Kapil Dev attempted to bribe him in 1994, was recently questioned by CBI officials. PTI, quoting UCB sources, also say that "[Herschelle] Gibbs is likely to be banned from international cricket for at least a year for his role in the Cronje match-fixing scandal, [Henry] Williams is likely to be fined, while [Pieter] Strydom is expected to escape with a caution." Tuesday August 22 Cronje has given an extensive interview to South African subscription channel M-Net, to be aired on Thursday, Friday and Saturday of this week. King Commission chief prosecutor Shamila Batohi confirms that she'll be tuning in. "Rest assured, I'll be watching. Just like the rest of the country, I expect." Wednesday August 23 The Daily Mail reports that Chris Lewis is to write a book in which he will name the three English cricketers he was told had taken money to fix matches. Leicestershire coach Jack Birkenshaw said: "If he (publishes) it will be the end of him as a player. He will not be able to write a book without permission. If he does as an active player, the ECB will be bound to suspend him." Thursday August 24 The King Commission's interim report is passed to the UCB. "It is being made public on Friday. We will post it on the government's website," said spokesman Graham Abrahams. Meanwhile, R N Sawani, joint director of the CBI declares that he is "satisfied" with the progress being made in their match-fixing investigations. A preliminary report is being finalised and will be submitted to the Sports Ministry in September. In a three part TV interview on South African subscription channel M-Net, Cronje says that Herschelle Gibbs should not receive further punishment for his part in the match-fixing scandal. "In my opinion Herschelle should be given another chance to play. On the day he played superbly. Surely if you were told to get less than 20 and then you get 73 off 53 balls, then obviously you did not pay attention to what was said. You entertained the thought, you were tempted but you never followed through." South African sports minister Ngconde Balfour confirms that there are no major surprises in the King Commission interim report, which is published on cricket.co.za. "There is not much in it really, no recommendations, nothing much. I am still of the opinion that there are only one or two people involved in this type of thing and we can easily clean up the game." The report makes no recommendations of disciplinary action, nor does it indicate whether Cronje will be granted immunity from criminal prosecution. The Daily Telegraph reports that Judge King has asked the South African president Thabo Mbeki to widen his terms of reference. This would allow King to investigate match-fixing dating back to 1995. A commission source is quoted as saying, "We don't know what happened between the 1995 offer (to throw an ODI against Pakistan) and early this year. Were there other attempts to bribe South African cricketers? The present terms of reference do not allow us to investigate." Friday August 25 In his interim report, Judge King takes a dim view of Hansie Cronje*s activities. "There is a common thread to these events which is shared by others where Cronje sought to involve his team-mates in match-fixing or related matters and that is that the initial approach is made jocularly. It seems that this was Cronje*s modus operandi. He would sound out his colleagues, in a way which would enable him to say later, if the need arose, that he had only been joking." In the second part of his interview, Cronje praises the effective work of the match-fixing enquiry in South Africa: "I think we have got to give credit to the way it is being handled here as opposed to in Australia. But I would rather have (Mark Waugh and Shane Warne*s) punishment." On rediff.com, CBI joint director R N Savani says that Kapil Dev will be summoned before the CBI shortly. "No date has been fixed for the meeting, but it will take place." The BCCI submits a copy of its code of conduct to the Indian government. Former CBI joint director K Madavan is confirmed as Commissioner of Inquiry. Saturday August 26 Cronje absolves Nicky Boje of any involvement in match-fixing. Boje had been mentioned in alleged telephone calls between Cronje and an Indian bookmaker. Sunday August 27 Income-tax officials in India raid the residence of off-spinner Nikhil Chopra in connection with their match-fixing investigations. Monday August 28 Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams are banned from international cricket until January 1, 2001, while Pieter Strydom is acquitted of a charge of attempting to place a bet during the 5th Test between South Africa and England. Both Gibbs and Williams pleaded guilty to accepting money to underperform in a one-day international. In addition to the bans, Gibbs is fined 60,000 rand and Williams 10,000 rand. The bans do not preclude the pair from playing domestic cricket. In a prepared statement, Gibbs does not dispute his punishment. "I am obviously bitterly disappointed that I will not be able to represent my country until next year. However, I am grateful that I will at least have the honour of being able to play for Western Province if so selected." Former BCCI president IS Bindra criticises the board's treatment of Kapil Dev. "It is wrong on the part of the BCCI to gun for the team coach Kapil Dev though the board had earlier promised all help to him." Tuesday August 29 Speculation mounts that Cronje could face civil claims running into millions of rands from past and present team-mates who suffered financial losses in the match- fixing scandal. He may also have to pay legal costs incurred during the King Commission. On cricketline.com, a senior South African player, who asks not to be named, says that he would sue Cronje were he Herschelle Gibbs or Henry Williams. The player also says that Cronje approached players from the traditionally less privileged sectors of South African society "to do his dirty work for him." In the Cape Times Herman Gibbs, father of Herschelle, is quoted as deeming the sentences "bullshit - the boys have suffered enough. What I would like to know is who are the UCB accountable to in terms of their own misdemeanours when it comes to administering the game?" Gibbs senior also tells rediff.com that he would like to sue Hansie Cronje for corrupting his son, and the UCB for failing to protect him from match-fixing. He says his son should act "like a boxer stepping back into the ring after a bad blow", and show that he is the best opener in South Africa. Wednesday August 30 In his cricketline.com column, Allan Donald expresses his relief that Gibbs and Henry Williams did not receive a longer sentence: "Some people would say [Gibbs and Williams] deserved life bans. Neither of them actually went through with playing poorly on purpose but the fact that they even agreed to is very serious. They know now, though, that they've done wrong, and were both probably expecting suspended life bans. I'm glad the UCB wasn't too severe on them." New Zealand Cricket chief executive Chris Doig expresses his disappointment at the penalties meted out to Gibbs and Williams: "I am surprised and disappointed at the leniency. For the sake of cricket we had to be seen to be taking a strong stance on match-fixing. On the basis the players appear to be guilty of being involved in some way of tacitly approving match-fixing, I think the penalties are modest." BCCI president AC Muthiah criticises IS Bindra, who had expressed his dissatisfaction with the board's treatment of Kapil Dev. "Bindra could have made these remarks at the Bangalore meeting. In fact it was Bindra who had vehemently said in his earlier statements that Kapil Dev had offered money to Manoj Prabhakar and everyone knows these statements had kicked off so much dust." Thursday August 31 In an interview with the New Statesman, Michael Atherton says that he does not think English cricket has a match-fixing problem: "I've not had any doubt about an England player. I can't say with hand on heart that I'm absolutely certain it hasn't happened, but I'd bet against it." The magazine also says that Atherton has played in a one-day international that he believes was fixed but, without evidence to support him, he has refused to name the game. Watch this space

fields.headline: Party animals
fields.standfirst: The lowdown on who to schmooze - and who's a snooze - on the new media party circuit.
fields.trailText: The lowdown on who to schmooze - and who's a snooze - on the new media party circuit.
fields.body:
Nick Denton
Some of those who knew Denton before his First Tuesday and Moreover.com days have described him as "smug" but it has to be acknowledged that he was the driving force behind First Tuesday and the reason why there are so many new media parties. Nick, we salute you.

Tim Jackson
He may be the much-talked about founder of QXL and often talked about in the same breath as Tim Berners Lee, but Jackson is a journalist at heart. Jackson is a fine example of that old adage: "You can take the man out of journalism, but you can't take the journalist out of the man." Respondents to Mediatheguardian.com's straw poll confirms he has a reputation for being very full on and will know more about your company than you do.

Justin Walters
Former head of Guardian Unlimited, Walters' current buzzword is b2b. Sometimes, particularly after a few beers, he can enthuse too readily about the wonders and magic of b2b - to the extent that no one can understand him. Walters has been described as having the biggest brain on the planet, by those who are perhaps jealous of him.

Mark Alexander
AKA new media teddy bear. Mark Alexander, sales manager at Eurosport, is good fun and always keen to get the drinks in - courtesy of an expense account that seems to have no bounds. He always has a smile on his face and a funny story to tell. Be nice to him and you may get tickets to the next big European football game.

Davina Lines
Davina Lines, commercial director at Netimperative, knows everyone, having been in new media for more than five years. She was part of the founding team at New Media Age, and was instrumental in organising the NMA awards, conferences and parties. Lines was voted new media personality of the year at last year's Boobnight awards.

Richard Lord
Lord, editor of Revolution, is probably one of the strangest people you will come across at these events. He can usually be found lingering by the food or throwing food at people across the room, which probably explains his svelte form. Get there early and you will be guaranteed to see Lord seemingly shit-faced and far too energetic for anyone who claims to work as hard as he does. Regardless, he always seems to have a good time and anyone looking for a fast-track into the industry should make an effort to schmooze the inimitable Lord.

Sophie Silocchi
'Who's that glamorous babe at the bar?' is the question always buzzing around the room when Guardian Unlimited's very own Sophie Silocchi, PR guru extraordinaire and organiser of the Clerkenwell Social, puts in an appearance. In many ways, Silocchi's presence adds a rare element of class to the new media party scene; there are those that swear how her immaculate appearance inadvertently encourages them to don designerwear.

Geoff Inns
No party is complete without Geoffrey 'hot stuff' Inns, hardcore Boobnighter and a veritable treat for the ladies of new media. Shy and unassuming Inns can brighten up a room with just a smile and the words 'corporate Amex'. Convince him to groove on down on the dancefloor and you're in for a rare display of agility and natural rhythm. Guardian Unlimited is just not going to be the same without him. Let's hope that Questico still allows him to come out to play.

Narda Shirley
As managing director of top new media PR agency Gnash, Narda can be normally spotted in her natural habitat of First Tuesday, where she has the task of ensuring everyone meets who they want to meet. The fact that Shirley knows everyone in the new media business, is well liked and very smart means she is 2:1 odds on gaining the title Queen of Networking. She is a good person to get to know, although, be warned, she is very fussy about clients and may even poo-poo your business plan if it has holes in the small print.

Julian Hardy
Be careful what you say to and about Hardy, former managing director of Freeserve and now at large, as you may end up working with him at some time. Also, it is best not to make a joke about how many jobs he has had over the past two years, or where he is currently working. Described by those in the know as "a little bit wooo, a little bit wheh...", Hardy is certainly not boring, although a party people pollster could not think of a time when they had actually seen him legless. His excuse? He drives everywhere in his Porsche, which he will talk about for hours if you let him.

Hester Bloch
Bloch, former community marketing director of WebRewards, left recently to join SMS messaging and community service Quios.com.She has been a regular on the new media party scene since the dawn of time, and is a strong contender to pick up the coveted Queen of Networking prize. Bloch has been out of the limelight of late, however, having committed herself to Mr MediaPlanning. She now only tends to make appearances at award shows, decked out in slinky, figure-hugging numbers. Having worked in the new media agency world for years, she is also well versed in the art of avoiding annoying techies and hanging out with only the cream of the social scene.

Double act: Julian "Meatloaf" Marszalek and Nick Watt
Old stooges Marszalek, sales manager at 365, and Watt, erstwhile managing director StudentUK, once toured the clubs and bars of Manchester, pumping out their eclectic blend of acid jazz. But that was in the days before the advent of new media. Nowadays, the closest Marszalek and Watt get to resuming their rock star heydays is at industry parties, where the two are often found hunched together musing about their wayward pasts and anything to do with the music industry. A word of advice comes courtesy of a "close friend", who warns wannabe networkers not to get Marszalek and Watt onto the subject of music, or else you could be "bored rigid about deleted B sides all night". Point taken.

fields.headline: Channel ports blockade
fields.standfirst: French fishermen have ended their channel ports blockade after the Paris government agreed to meet their demands. Julian Glover explains what the protest was about.
fields.trailText: French fishermen have ended their channel ports blockade after the Paris government agreed to meet their demands. We explain what the protest was about.
fields.body:
What happened?
France's national union of fishermen was carrying out a national programme of action in protest at the rising cost of fuel for their boats. The fishermen say that the current price of diesel makes fishing uneconomic and want the government to cut prices from the present 2.2 francs a litre to 1.2 francs - or from around 20p to 11p a litre. In order to achieve this they blocked access to ports using boats and vans. The protests began in mid-August in Britanny and then spread across the country. The channel coast was particularly badly hit but ports on the Atlantic and the Mediterranean port of Marseille were closed, obstructing traffic to Corsica and north Africa.

Anything else?
Yes. Fishermen protested in central Paris outside the ministry of agriculture, firing coloured distress flares from their boats. They also blocked access to the channel tunnel, some motorways and an oil refinery.

What was the impact?
Serious, for British travellers in particular. The ports of Le Havre, Calais, Boulogne, Cherbourg, Dunkirk and St Malo were all closed - effectively shutting down most cross-channel ferry routes. Tourists returning from France at the end of the school holidays were forced to wait or travel through ports in Belgium, while lorry traffic from Britain was badly-disrupted, forcing police in Kent to turn sections of the M20 into a giant truck-park. The cost of all this to Britain has been estimated at £1m a day.

What was the reaction of the British government?
Downing Street described the blockades as "unacceptable" and made "energetic representations" to France to end the protests. Tony Blair was concerned that the blockade would stop children returning to school for the new term.

What about the French government?
The French government is used to protests of this kind; truck drivers blocked roads in January to complain about the imposition of a 35-hour working week. Ministers this time took care to avoid outright confrontation. The agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, said he was willing to negotiate "because what they're asking for has a basis."

So how did it end?
Although maritime diesel is already sold tax-free and the increase over the last year is the result of the rising price of oil rather than government decisions, the French government this morning promised that fishermen would be compensated for the rise in fuel prices, although further details about what form this would take have not yet been released. On hearing this news, more than 30 fisherman called off the protest at the terminal at 1.15pm (12.15 British time), waving banners and shouting jubilantly: "It's finished, it's finished, we've won."

fields.standfirst: August 17-September 4
fields.trailText:
31. What will be the result of the fourth Test against West Indies (Headingley, Aug 17-21)? A England win B West Indies win C Draw. Correct: 15 pts.
Answer: A
fields.body:
31. What will be the result of the fourth Test against West Indies (Headingley, Aug 17-21)? A England win B West Indies win C Draw. Correct: 15 pts.
Answer: A

32. How many different players (subs included) will record at least one catch during the fourth Test? Correct: 15 pts.
Answer: 8

33. What will be the result of the Cornwall v Devon Minor Counties match at St Austell (August 20-21)? A Cornwall win B Devon win C Draw. Correct: 5 pts.
Answer: C

34. Will Derbyshire be in the bottom three of the Championship First Division on the morning of August 22? Yes or No? Correct: 10 pts.
Answer: Yes

35. How many Test cricketers will be in the Surrey team playing Essex in the National League at Colchester on August 23? Correct: 10 pts.
Answer: 7

36. What will be the aggregate number of runs in the NatWest Trophy final (August 26)? Spot-on: 25 pts. Fifteen runs either side: 15 pts.

fields.headline: No more mister nice guy
fields.standfirst: Since starring opposite Nicole Kidman in The Blue Room, Iain Glen has become the most sought-after leading man in the country. So why is he now taking the part of a Hollywood baddie? He explained all to  Will Hodgkinson
fields.trailText: Since starring opposite Nicole Kidman in The Blue Room, Iain Glen has become the most sought-after leading man in the country. So why is he now taking the part of a Hollywood baddie? He explained all to Will Hodgkinson
fields.body:
The Scottish actor Iain Glen arrives for our interview looking particularly mean. His hair has been dyed black, swept back and extended for a classic evil baddie look, to fit in with his role as Lara Croft's malevolent nemesis in the feature-film adaptation of the computer game Tomb Raider, in which he stars opposite Angelina Jolie. Then he goes and ruins the façade by being nice.

Glen is at that position in an actor's career where he is the first choice for a certain recognisable television role - the boyish, slightly off-kilter, but down-to-earth bloke who understands women, typified by his sports journalist in Glasgow Kiss - but not to the extent that he has been typecast, meaning that he can play a cad too. The ITV two-parter Anchor Me seems perfectly suited to his particular abilities. He plays Nathan, a Somerset boy who has educated himself out of his class, returning home to his dying mother with the hope of making his family face up to the death of a younger brother. What starts off as typical Barratt-Homes Sunday-night middle-England drama develops into a web of intrigue spun by fraught emotions, with the classic British trait of keeping up appearances at the root of all the problems.

"I was really drawn to it because it was one of those rare projects where you don't spend half of your time building bridges and subtexting things that aren't there," says Glen. "This felt more like classical writing - you reach as far into it as you possibly can. It's not about you trying to improve it, it's about you trying to meet its potential."

Glen's character is also trying to deal with a communication breakdown with his son, and a loss of excitement in marriage, on top of coming to terms with the long-buried family tragedy. On returning home he reaches back into the salad days of his childhood as all these crises loom down on him, and unfortunately finds consolation in the arms of his teenage sweetheart, now married to his rather brutish brother.

"Most television dramas are simplified to the point where you only have a simple objective to convey by a simple line, but the stuff of life is often where we're saying we're incredibly happy with something when in fact we're fiercely jealous and so on. So when writing conveys that, it's easier to play because you're immediately in a familiar situation. Underpinning the whole drama is the idea that people don't communicate, that people miscommunicate."

Another theme is the sibling rivalry between the one who escapes from the nest and the one left to fend for the family in the shadow of the more glamorous other. Surprisingly, Glen claims to be of the latter category. "As my brother so touchingly put it in his best man speech at my wedding, he didn't recognise I had a personality until I was 18, so it was hard to remember anything flattering to say about me. I always felt in his shadow - I'd like to put it down to the fact that he was four years older than me, but maybe it was just that I wasn't capable at very much. It's difficult to speak about such things without sounding pretentious, but you use this kind of experience for acting - it's broadly what you would call emotional memory."

Glen was half of the phenomenon that was last year's The Blue Room, in which he played opposite Nicole Kidman as a series of clients to her prostitute at London's tiny Donmar Warehouse theatre.

"It was great," he says of working with his leggy Australian co-star. "Within two minutes of working with her, I forgot who she was and we just got on with it. There was only two of us and we had a lot of work to do. We had to find all these various sexual couplings and not end up being Nic and Iain. Does a prostitute kiss a taxi driver differently to a politician? That sort of thing." Glen has remained friends with Kidman and her husband Tom Cruise. "Our kids are the same age," he says, understatedly. "We put them together and go off for a game of golf."

Although not on a Cruise and Kidman level of fame, Glen has reached that stage where he is sometimes mistaken for his characters. "I played a serial killer once, and had men coming up to me who had decided I was fucking hard and dangerous, and they wanted to be hard and dangerous too. When it happens I either get very mincey, or run." Recent projects could up the danger ante further. He played a cad in last year's adaptation of Wives And Daughters, and next year his diabolical villain will bring a British flavour to Tomb Raider. "It has an English setting - and I've got to be careful here because we've all signed secrecy contracts - but the director has given each of the characters a whole world. Lara's looking for mysterious elements for the good of the world, and I'm doing it to destroy. I'm enjoying it immensely. We were shooting at Battersea Power Station at night, and the whole sky was lit up, vast machines were going through the shots, smoke everywhere, multicoloured welding effects falling from the skies, and I'm thinking, what am I doing here, I'm from Scotland! But my character was making it all happen. It's a real treat."

 Anchor Me, Sunday, 9pm, ITV

fields.headline: Elleray calls for rugby rule
fields.trailText: David Elleray has called for the introduction of rugby-style sin-bins in the Premiership, which he says will slash the numbers of yellow and red cards in the English game.
fields.body:
David Elleray has called for the introduction of rugby-style sin-bins in the Premiership, which he says will slash the numbers of yellow and red cards in the English game.

Speaking on Jimmy Hill's Last Word show on Sky Sports.com TV, which is broadcast tonight, Elleray used the example of Patrick Vieira's wild reaction to his initial booking during Arsenal's recent clash with Liverpool to support his case.

Elleray said: "He was upset at the challenge and then he ran around and everyone could see that the red mist had come down. Now, if that first yellow card had actually been in the sin-bin, he would have been in the sin-bin hopefully calming down, and would have come back on in a more controlled frame of mind.

"I would like us to try the sin-bin. It works in hockey, works in rugby and I would like to see it in soccer. It would reduce the number of cards and that would be fantastic."

Elleray also said that officials were under increased pressure this season to apply the letter of the law with regard to over-excited goal celebrations. Vieira and his Arsenal team-mate Silvinho both escaped punishment for taking off their shirts during the Gunners' recent 5-3 win over Charlton.

Elleray said: "If a player completely removes his shirt it should be a yellow card. I think Stephen Lodge on Saturday used the spirit of the law, not the letter of the law. It's an example of a directive which puts great pressure on referees.

"I suspect (Vieira and Silvinho) will be reported to the FA. It's tough, particularly if players are on a yellow card."

fields.headline: Cramer promoted in CNN reshuffle
fields.trailText: Former head of BBC newsgathering Chris Cramer has been promoted in a CNN management reshuffle as the US news broadcaster responds to stiffer competition and the growth of the internet.
fields.body:
Former head of BBC newsgathering Chris Cramer has been promoted in a CNN management reshuffle as the US news broadcaster responds to stiffer competition and the growth of the internet.

Atlanta-based Cramer, who left the BBC for CNN in 1996, is stepping up from president of CNN International to president of CNN Networks/International with responsibility for all the outfit's non-US networks and websites.

His promotion forms part of a management restructuring that sees the departure of the company's president, Rick Kaplan, Terence McGuirk, chairman of CNN parent company Turner Broadcasting System (TBS), denied that Kaplan's departure was linked to falling ratings for the news broadcaster, which is facing ever stiffer competition from MSNBC and Fox's news channel. McGuirk said Kaplan had left rather than see his role diminished as CNN put more emphasis on online activities.

As part of the reorganisation TBS International president Philip Kent is becoming president and chief operating officer of CNN. Cramer and Jim Walton, who is stepping up from president of CNN/Sports Illustrated to become president of CNN's 15 US domestic news networks and websites, will report to Kent.

Eason Jordan is taking the new role of president of newsgathering and chief news executive of CNN, reporting to Kent on operational issues and CNN chairman and chief executive Tom Johnson on editorial matters.

webTitle: Hartson deal collapses after he fails his medical

fields.headline: Hartson deal collapses after he fails his medical
fields.trailText: John Hartson's transfer to Rangers has collapsed after he failed a medical this morning.
fields.body:
John Hartson's transfer to Rangers has collapsed after he failed a medical this morning.

The Wimbledon striker had agreed terms yesterday with chairman David Murray after just 10 minutes and hoped to complete a deal in the region of £5.5m this morning. But Hartson failed to satisfy Rangers' club doctors of his fitness after a stringent medical earlier today, and the club immediately declared the deal dead in the water.

A statement from Rangers said: "Due to the fact the player John Hartson has not played a sufficient number of top class matches recently, Rangers Football Club are of the opinion he would not be at the level of match fitness required at this particular stage of the season in view of our involvement in the Uefa Champions League.

"Both Rangers FC and the player are very disappointed at the outcome of this matter. The player will therefore return to Wimbledon FC to continue his career."

Hartson's agent Jonathan Barnett said the Wimbledon striker had taken the news badly, but was already looking forward to joining the Welsh squad to play Belarus. "He's really disappointed that this has happened, but John will pick himself up again," Barnett added.

Last night Murray had admitted that the deal might founder over the medical. He said then: "There is the possibility that the medical might not go well because it is a very strict medical. We have made mistakes in the past and we don't want those things to happen again."

fields.body:
Sunderland are set to sign Chelsea's out-of-favour defender Emerson Thome in a shock £3m deal, reports the Mirror. A spokesman for the player admits: "The deal has been sorted out. Emerson is happy to move out there and he's looking forward to playing for Peter Reid. The two clubs are still haggling over the transfer fee, but that's not expected to hold up the move."

Much less likely is the news, first reported on MUTV and now propagated by Teamtalk, that Lazio are planning a sensational £30m bid for Ryan Giggs. Teamtalk claim Lazio are desperate to land a wide player ahead of the Champions League deadline after failing to sign Boudewijn Zenden and has instructed an intermediate to try broker a deal with United. Fair enough you might think, but is Sir Alex Ferguson really going to let Giggs go?

Meanwhile, Manchester United have been knocked back in their bid to sign Monaco's highly-rated midfielder Ousmane Dabo, according to Planet Football.

Newcastle are putting the finishing touches to a deal for Lyon defender Olivier Bernard, say Planet Football. Apparently Bernard will sign a one-year deal, with an option to extend the move should all parties agree.

AC Milan have pulled out a move for Real Madrid right-back Michel Salgado after they were quoted an extortionate £8.1m price tag, reports onefootball.com.

fields.headline: Fishermen stop up Channel tunnel
fields.standfirst: Audio: Jon Henley at the mass protest in Paris
fields.trailText: French fisherman have barred the last remaining route across the Channel, blocking the entrance to the Channel tunnel amid rising tension with British holiday makers and truckers.
fields.body:
French fisherman have barred the last remaining route across the Channel, blocking the entrance to the Channel tunnel amid rising tension with British holiday makers and truckers.

Early this morning, eight vans were drawn across the entrance to the tunnel terminal near Calais, where motorists board shuttle services to the UK. There was pushing and shoving, but police remained on the sidelines, saying their involvement might precipitate violence.

The fishermen have promised to let limited numbers of cars through every hour. But fishing union secretary Andre Fauchet is adamant that the blockade will remain until their demands are met.

Thousands of holiday makers are still stuck in queues on both sides of the Channel, with all the major ports now blockaded as a result of protests in France against high fuel prices.

All ferry sailings on the key Dover-Calais route had to be cancelled in a dispute set to last for at least three more days as the demonstrations spread.

Protesters added Le Havre to the list of blockaded ports overnight but had spared Channel tunnel services until now - the last gateway into France from Britain still open.

The eight fishing boats that have caused severe disruption to Channel crossings were still moored across the harbour at Calais this morning, preventing any ferries from docking.

This morning, around 1,000 fishermen gathered outside the ministry of agriculture fisheries directorate in Paris to protest further, throwing beer bottles and setting off distress flares. Riot police remained on standby.

As the blockade enters its second day, there are fears that truckers will block routes into France from Zeebrugge in Belgium where thousands of British holiday makers and truckers have been diverted on cross-Channel ferries from Dover to cause even more mayhem.

Kent also faces further traffic chaos today. Hundreds of lorries have been parked up overnight on two sections of the M20 after Kent police implemented Operation Stack to turn the motorway into a huge parking lot.

If the crisis worsens, then another large section of the motorway will have to be closed to traffic and used to hold even more trucks.

The aim of the operation is to stagger the number of trucks heading to the Kent ports and Channel tunnel to stop them grinding to a halt with gridlocked trucks. Around 18 miles of the motorway have already been closed but police say they already have contingency plans to close another section further up the M20.

Cars and other traffic have been diverted on to the A20, running parallel to the motorway. But this morning it was already busy.

A Kent police spokesman said: "At the moment junctions 11 and 12 of the M20 between Hythe and Folkestone and 8 and 9 between Hollingbourne and Ashford are closed. I have never known that to happen before. We hope it doesn't come down to this and that the blockade is lifted today."

Meanwhile in France, lorries were stacked up along four miles of the main autoroute into Calais with hundreds of British truckers forced to spend the night in their cabs on the carriageway.

They were being told to expect delays of up to five hours before they could get onto shuttles to bring them through the Channel tunnel, though that plan is in jeopardy now that French truckers have starting blocking that lifeline.

Tom Evans, 53, from Cardiff, said: "The problem has been not being able to get any sleep because you have to stay awake to keep moving with the queue. We are sick and tired of these strikes. It is high time something was done to stop them."

webTitle: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Mistaken identity

Student Simon Healy of Plymouth has never applied for or used a Halifax credit card. But that didn't stop the bank's debt collection agency sending him a demand for £2,800. The cordial notice, sent via Healy's brother's address, threatened him with prosecution if he did not pay up immediately. However, the agency, Wescott Credit Services, refused to tell him where or how he was supposed to have run up the debt. Eventually the Halifax admitted that the card owner was another Simon Healy. Not that this mollified Wescott, which told him that the proceedings against him would not be terminated, merely suspended.

 A Halifax spokesman says that the bank instructed Wescott to scrap the case after Healy sent his signature and birth certificate. He says all information linking Healy to this account has been deleted from the files and he is to be given £100 in compensation. Small comfort, though, to customers if banks rely solely on a surname to identify accounts.

Access denied

The courageous new world of cyberbanking has received a drubbing of late, with critics predicting that it can never be fully secure. Well, take heart: Lloyds TSB's online service is so secure that even its own customers can't access their accounts. Arthur McDermott tried for two months to log on to his new account and each time received a message that it could not be found. "I've spent countless hours on their helpline without success," he says. "Apparently the computer matches my customer ID to an account closed in 1995 and my password to an account that never existed. Lloyds says there's a conflict between their front and back room computers and can only advise me to keep on trying."

 "There has been a slight problem," says Lloyds TSB optimistically. "It affected a small number of people who'd opened and shut TSB accounts in the past then opened a new account online. It took time to iron out because it was a rare problem but it's now resolved and we apologise."

Time bombs - again

Time Computers' haphazard style of customer services will be familiar to Consumer readers. Two months after Elisabeth Footsoy of Rotherham, South Yorkshire spent £1,124 on a computer package, she had to return it for repair. "No exchange was offered," she says. Four months later the same fault had to be repaired twice more and her scanner, which had, in the meantime, broken down, was replaced, minus the necessary software.

A day after its return the computer crashed for a fourth time. Time refused her request for a refund but agreed to exchange the machine. However, the package was inexplicably delivered to an address in Wales and three different customer care staff gave three different re-routing dates. When it finally turned up it was of an inferior specification to the original - and soon broke down.

Time admits that she's had problems and blames that old bogey, a "breakdown in communications". It promises that her saga will now be resolved.

Direct debit rip-off

Utilities and telecoms companies like to send out missives proclaiming the benefits of direct debit. And no wonder. Most of us who succumb will have noticed that there's a small credit column on our statements and that the amount inside it accrues gradually. It seems companies help themselves to more than is due to guard against a rainy day and presumably make use of this surplus as they will. Linda Gresham of Birmingham says that as her British Gas statements always showed her to be in credit she had ignored a request to increase her monthly payment by £6. Two years went by, then, out of the blue, she received a letter demanding £66 in arrears. Gresham asked to see her next quarterly statement and found that she was £22.67 in credit. "If we had complied with the request, we'd simply have been providing British Gas with a free loan," she says.

British Gas says that its charges are based on estimated readings and tend to be revised upwards in case of error. The idea is that the surplus is used up during the winter months. In Gresham's case the company blames an overestimate of her meter readings.

"We have recalculated her account based on the actual meter reading and her monthly payments have not increased," says a spokeswoman. "Since April we have introduced quarterly meter readings in order to ensure that customers' bills are as accurate as possible."

fields.headline: Obituary: Sabina Wurmbrand
fields.standfirst: A Christian whose book exposed religious persecution under eastern European communism
fields.trailText: A Christian whose book exposed religious persecution under eastern European communism.
fields.body:
Sabina Wurmbrand, who has died of cancer aged 87, deserved a wider reputation than she in fact enjoyed as one of those who most objectively exposed the repression in communist Romania.

Her name is inextricably linked with that of her more famous husband, Pastor Richard Wurmbrand, who came to world attention in exile in 1966, after 20 years in prison. His book, Tortured For Christ, exposed religious persecution under communism, which had been endemic throughout eastern Europe in the post-war years. Sabina stood quietly aside from the shrillness of this war of words. Instead she produced her own book, The Pastor's Wife, one of the great testaments to the indomitability of the human spirit and the strength of Christian witness under persecution. For the 20 years following its publication in 1970, world leaders preferred to pay obeisance to the sham of the leadership of Nicolae Ceausescu and his predecessors, rather than absorb the lessons on the essential evil of the regime irrefutably set out in Sabina Wurmbrand's book. One reviewer wrote: "This book is simply one woman's story - a sensitive and unemotional reflection, years after the worst of the pain has passed, by an extremely cultivated, sensitive, indeed humorous mind." She continued to exhibit these qualities throughout her long life in exile.

Sabina Oster was born in Chernovits (Cernauti), a university city which was in the area of Ukraine annexed by Romania in 1919. Born into a large observant Jewish family, she attended the Sorbonne for two years. She later lost both parents and three siblings in the Holocaust. She married Richard Wurmbrand, also Jewish, in 1936 and they became Protestant Christians under the influence of Isaac Feinstein, himself a convert, who was to perish under the Nazis.

The couple became evangelists and, although under threat, brought several Jewish children out of the ghetto and concealed them. When the Soviets occupied Romania, the couple surreptitiously distributed literature to the Red Army and hid Christians despite the risk of deportation to Siberia. For a year or two they conducted inter-denominational work and built up a church of over a thousand Jewish-Christian members.

In February 1948, Richard disappeared into the Gulag. Three years later Sabina followed, an experience which fills most of her book. She was conditionally released as part of the post-Stalin amnesty in 1954. Denied work for refusing to divorce her husband, she was there to greet him on his release 15 years later.

Following intensive negotiations, they left Romania for Norway with their son Mihai. There Sabina became known as a moderating influence over her fiery husband, keeping out of the controversies in which he was involved, but underlining the essential truth of the message he wrote and preached. It was in America that they founded a mission called Jesus to the Communist World. Based in California, their extensive travels throughout the free world led to the establishment of branches in many countries, including Britain. For almost 25 years the international organ of the mission, the Voice of the Martyrs, continued its anti-communist campaign. Then, with the execution of Ceausescu on Christmas Day, 1989, everything changed.

Sabina Wurmbrand could return to Romania. By now in her late 70s, she and her husband were received as heroes. Before returning to America, they appeared on TV, and, most remarkably of all, they visited Richard's former prison cell, to find it used as a repository for their books.

Sabina Wurmbrand is survived by her husband and son.

 Sabina Wurmbrand, evangelist, born July 10 1913; died August 20 2000

webTitle: Heggessey tipped for top job at BBC1

fields.headline: Heggessey heads contenders for BBC1 role
fields.standfirst: With 20 years of broadcasting experience under her belt, speculation is rife that Lorraine Heggessey will soon be announced as Peter Salmon's successor at BBC1
fields.trailText: With 20 years of broadcasting experience under her belt, speculation is rife that Lorraine Heggessey will soon be announced as Peter Salmon's successor at BBC1. Jason Deans reports
fields.body:
Anyone tempted to underestimate Lorraine Heggessey on first meeting because of her diminutive stature is in for a big shock. Heggessey, the 43-year-old joint director of BBC factual and learning who is expected to take over from Peter Salmon as BBC1 controller, has ferocious self-confidence, energy and drive.

She will be best known to BBC1 viewers as the head of children's programmes who apologised on-screen in October 1998, after Blue Peter presenter Richard Bacon's cocaine use was exposed in a Sunday paper and he was sacked. This was a highly unusual initiative for a BBC programme-making executive to take, but typifies Heggessey's direct, take-it-on-the-chin approach.

Heggessey-watchers should also not be fooled by the fluffy image of children's TV. This is one tough cookie, who cut her teeth in BBC current affairs and once went undercover in Soviet Russia to interview Jews persecuted under Brezhnev. She joined the corporation in 1979 as a news trainee and rose through the ranks of the current affairs department, working on Newsnight, Panorama and 60 Minutes. Heggessey went on to work for Thames TV current affairs show This Week and Channel 4 factual strands Hard News and Dispatches.

She returned to the BBC in 1991 to oversee science department shows including Animal Hospital, QED and The Human Body. By October 1997 Heggessey had itchy feet once more. She was set to join former boss George Carey at indie Mentorn Barraclough Carey, when BBC Production chief executive Ron Neil approached her about the children's job. Two years later Heggessey was promoted to become BBC Production's deputy chief executive and director of programmes. She moved to her present job in April 2000, after the Production directorate was broken up in new BBC director general Greg Dyke's reorganisation of the corporation.

Doubters will question whether Heggessey has the breadth of experience needed for the BBC1 controller's job. But unlike many BBC colleagues, Heggessey has experience in the commercial TV sector, having spent five years working for ITV and Channel 4. Her time at BBC children's gave her a taste for drama and entertainment. And with her no nonsense approach, Heggessey is likely to see eye-to-eye with Dyke.

fields.headline: Freeserve on the brink
fields.standfirst: Freeserve is facing expulsion from the FTSE 100. Dan Milmo reports on the doubts surrounding the internet company's future direction
fields.trailText: Freeserve is facing expulsion from the FTSE 100. Dan Milmo reports on the doubts surrounding the internet company's future direction
fields.body:
Freeserve is Britain's biggest internet service provider, with 1.9m subscribers, but doubts over its future direction have seen it teeter on the brink of expulsion from the FTSE 100.

The company was founded in Leeds in 1998, with the headquarters based in the Berkshire offices of parent company Dixons, the retail group. Freeserve's business development director, Ajaz Ahmed, was a store manager at PC World, a Dixons subsidiary, when he realised that customers had no means of accessing the internet from their computers. He took his observations to Dixons executives John Pluthero and Mark Danby, who called in internet company Planet Online to develop Freeserve.

Pluthero is now chief executive of Freeserve, with experience at travel group P&O and brewers Bass before joining Dixons in 1993. He is not a big fan of BT, as shown by his disdain for its internet plans, though his stance is shared by many.

But Pluthero has stumbled into similar problems. Users of Freeserve's unmetered off-peak access deal have been let down by a slow service or connection failures, with promises of a return to normal service in September. Freeserve is not alone in its embarrassment, as rivals Telewest and NTL have had similar problems and LineOne has dropped its service altogether.

There are market rumours that Pluthero will offer a slice of the company in exchange for access to a telecommunications group's asymmetric digital subscriber line, or ADSL, which will guarantee high speed internet access. Freeserve already uses Energis for its net dial-up service, but an ADSL arrangement is the key to retaining subscribers and increasing revenues.

As if these logistical nightmares aren't enough, Pluthero also has to keep an eye on his parent company. The Dixons Group seems to see-saw from a selling position to keeping the company as a core part of its future strategies. A key indicator is Freeserve's finances, with a loss of £19.7m recorded for last year.

Sir Stanley Kalms, chairman of Dixons, is firmly against the euro but is a big fan of going into business on the continent. The group is looking for more acquisitions in Europe, where it already has operations in 11 countries.

Like every other high street retailer, Dixons is revamping it store formats and cutting prices to fight off opposition. The store portfolio is impressive, including Currys, PC World and The Link, and recent full-yesr profits of £264m surpassed analysts' expectations.

However, the group's share price has slipped from a year high of 400p to 228.75p, helped along its way by the uncertainty over Freeserve's future. The internet service provider sticks out like a sore thumb in the Dixons line-up, attracting negative sentiment towards new economy stocks.

The collapse of talks with T-Online also damaged the group's stock, which was already suffering from the success of close rivals Comet and Carphone Warehouse.

fields.headline: Freeserve faces expulsion from FTSE 100
fields.trailText: Internet company Freeserve faces relegation from the stock market's premier league after being stalked throughout the summer by takeover speculation, with rumours of a bid from Germany's T-Online resurfacing yesterday.
fields.body:
Internet company Freeserve faces relegation from the stock market's premier league after being stalked throughout the summer by takeover speculation, with rumours of a bid from Germany's T-Online resurfacing yesterday.

The company's shares have tumbled from a year-high of 925p to 252.75p, due to growing belief that one of the first European internet IPOs will be left at the altar in the wave of consolidation sweeping the sector. These fears have pushed Freeserve to the edge of expulsion from the FTSE 100 next week, when the list has its quarterly shake-up.

A Freeserve spokesperson said: "It is up to the London Stock Exchange to comment on our role in the FTSE, but it's business as usual here."

An industry source said the collapse of T-Online's £6bn bid for Freeserve in June was due to clashes between T-Online chief executive Wolfgang Keuntje and Ron Sommer, the chief executive of parent company Deutsche Telekom. Their dispute over international strategy centred on the appropriate price for Freeserve, leading to Keuntje's resignation.

"Sommer wanted a deal at any price", the source said, "whereas Keuntje did not want to throw money away. Now that Keuntje has gone, Sommer has effectively taken control. Detlev Bushal, his replacement, is very much a Sommers man and not renowned for his independence from the boss."

Analysts say that T-online is well-positioned to become a pan-European internet portal, as it has a strong position in France and is dominant in Germany. Sommers is likely to resurrect a deal for Spain's Yacom web portal, with a Freeserve takeover guaranteeing a strong UK presence, though boardroom troubles could yet scupper both deals.

High street retailer Dixons owns 80% of Freeserve, but the prospect of low revenues from flat rate internet access fees has prompted speculation about the subsidiary's status. It also led to arguments with T-Online over the company's value, which could continue if another bid is launched.

In August, Dixons announced a deal with online gaming company gameplay.com, aiming to sell computer games through Freeserve and retail outlets. The move took observers by surprise, who interpreted it as a sign that Dixons may see the company as an important part of its future.

webTitle: IPC seeks extra cash for digital arm

fields.headline: IPC seeks extra cash for digital arm
fields.trailText: IPC Media, the erstwhile consumer magazine publisher, has burned through almost two thirds of its budget for its digital arm, IPC Electric, and is looking to parent company Cinven, the US venture capitalist, for further investment.
fields.body:
IPC Media, the erstwhile consumer magazine publisher, has burned through almost two thirds of its budget for its digital arm, IPC Electric, and is looking to parent company Cinven, the US venture capitalist, for further investment.

IPC Electric was established in September 1999 with £25m of initial funding, with which it was charged with developing a range of new products.

Of its three main internet brands, Nme.com is a revamp and UnmissableTV.com and Beme.com are the only two new portals to be launched. Other existing, smaller sites were tweaked courtesy of the war chest, but none of the promised sports, leisure and men's lifestyle channels have appeared.

Nevertheless, the sites that Electric did launch have been widely acknowledged as being strong propositions, particularly BeMe.com which managed to survive the pigeon-holing experienced by the raft of other women's sites that launched earlier this year. UnmissableTV.com's Wap service has also been praised.

A spokeswoman for IPC Media said additional funding for IPC Electric was on the cards and new sites were in the pipeline, but declined to give details or dates. Much of the £18.4m spent by Electric has gone on advertising (£4.5m) and technology (a £6.9m deal with Hewlett-Packard), with the rest taken up by staff costs and consultancy fees.

The move to establish a sizeable new media division was part of IPC's attempt to reposition itself as a strong force in the digital age, a necessary component of a modern day IPO. Analysts criticised the move as a cynical attempt to gain kudos among bankers who, at the time, were dazzled by anything dot.com. Since the IPO has been postponed and the air was squeezed out of the dot.com bubble, IPC was put up for sale.

In May a number of media companies, including Telewest, Bertelsmann, Vivendi and even Emap, were said to be interested in purchasing IPC, but although exploratory talks are believed to have taken place, nothing definite has since emerged.

fields.headline: Euro rates gamble pays off
fields.standfirst: The European central bank's decision to raise interest rates has failed to dampen confidence in the single currency, writes economics reporter Charlotte Denny
fields.trailText: The European central bank's decision to raise interest rates has failed to dampen confidence in the single currency, writes economics reporter Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
They must be breathing a sigh of relief today at the headquarters of the European central bank. The gamble paid off: the decision to raise rates by 0.25% at lunchtime today did not spark another collapse of confidence in Europe's fragile single currency.

After dipping to just above 89 cents shortly after the decision, the euro recovered to 89.75 cents by early afternoon, more than a cent above its lifetime low of 88.45 cents, reached back in May.

Lately it has seemed Europe's central bankers are damned if they do and damned if they don't: whatever action they take has been an excuse for the market to sell the euro. But today's move was widely expected by the markets and failed to frighten the horses.

It is too early however to proclaim a new dawn for the euro. While all the fundamentals suggest that the dollar must fall at some point - the US after all, is running its largest balance of payments deficit since the Civil War - the greenback has been defying gravity for several years now, so predicting the turn is tricky.

Trade flows are no longer such a good predictor of exchange rates, in any case. The markets have taken the view that as long as growth prospects are better in the US than they are in euroland, America remains a better destination for investment. The IMF is expecting the US to grow by 4.4% this year, while the eurozone will grow by 3.2%.

What will change the market's mind? A sudden reversal in America's economic fortunes would obviously spark a run on the dollar. But increasingly analysts are coming round to the view that the US will achieve a soft landing - a slowdown in growth without a collapse in asset prices or soaring interest rates.

If the US is slowing down, that could provoke a change of sentiment on the euro. But even a slower growing US economy may be a more attractive investment prospect than Europe.

fields.headline: Labour accused of euro deceit
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, yesterday accused Labour of conning the electorate over the European single currency.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, yesterday accused Labour of conning the electorate over the European single currency.

His remarks came in response to the Guardian's disclosure yesterday that the prime minister, Tony Blair, has approved an internal Labour party document which lavishes praise on the euro.

The document, to be published at the Labour conference, spells out four benefits of British euro membership, including elimination of transaction costs for tourists and of exchange rate risks.

Mr Portillo said the Labour document distorted the arguments over the euro. "This underlines once again the determination of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown to press on with scrapping the pound," he said. "It also reveals Labour wish to con the electorate by distorting the issues.

"It it is increasingly clear that Europe is struggling to sustain a single exchange rate and single interest rate. It is going to be damaging to most parts of Europe, most of the time."

Labour dismissed suggestions that the document marked a change in the government's position on the euro.

A spokesman said: "Tony Blair has always made clear that the party is in favour in principle of joining a successful European currency, and we have always argued that the Tory policy of ruling out membership for an arbitrary period is not in Britain's best interest."

The spokesman's cautious remarks highlighted Labour concerns that adopting a more enthusiastic stance could antagonise the Murdoch press, which is hostile to the euro.

The Labour document endorsed the "sacred elements" of the government's euro policy. However, it also signalled the prime minister coming off the fence and outlining the benefits of the euro.

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Search for the stars | Unscrambling attachments
fields.body:
Search for the stars
I am developing a simple website for my band, which is easy using Microsoft FrontPage. I can obviously get people to visit the site by telling them verbally or by displaying the address on a business card. But how do I ensure that someone can locate my site using a search engine such as www.alltheweb.com? And how do I make sure that my site appears near the top of the retrieved website list? David Dobbie
david.dobbie@ntlworld.com

Jack Schofield replies: Dozens of sites will submit your address to hundreds of search engines free (try http://selfpromotion.com/ ), and a few companies claim to help you get better ratings for a fee. But different search engines use different criteria, and in general, the best results are obtained by the careful choice of a title, good use of keywords in metatags, and by submitting your site to each search engine individually. I recommend www.virtualpromote.com and www.bignosebird.com for useful information on setting up and promoting your site. You should also read the notes at Microsoft's bCentral business site at www.submit-it.com/subopt.htm and check out Danny Sullivan's Search Engine Watch.

Unscrambling attachments
I do most of my word processing in Word 7 (Microsoft Office), but run into problems whenever I open a Word document sent as an attachment by just about any one else. Very occasionally it works well, but more often than not the document opens minus all its formatting, and with pages and pages of extraneous 00000000s. I have to constantly ask people to re-send me documents saved as .rtf, but this is a real pain. Why does this happen, and is there something simple I can do to sort it out? Melanie Henwood
melanieh@email.msn.com

JS: You are using an old copy of Word, and people keep sending you files created with newer copies, which your version does not understand. This is very confusing because they all have the same extension (doc) instead of different ones (wp1, wp2 etc). The obvious solution - and the one that would make Microsoft happy - is to upgrade to Word 2000. Alternatively, you could download a copy of the free Word Viewer 97-2000 from Microsoft's website. This should read most or all the files you are sent, but won't let you do anything with them. My preferred solution is to insist that people send only plain text, so I make a point of deleting unsolicited attachments unread. This works best when your mailbox is full of press releases.

Slow Zip
I bought an Iomega Zip drive, attached by parallel port to my Toshiba Satellite 2610 laptop, because I was told at PC World this would be the answer to backing it up. However, although I can transfer files containing many scans to the Zip disk, each takes 20 minutes to open there. After some email correspondence with Iomega Help, I was told that the parallel port is not suitable for files of scanned material - just what I'd bought it for! Can you help me? Joan Zilva
JZilva@aol.com

JS: Big mistake! The Satellite 2610 has a USB serial port, so you should have bought a Zip drive with a much faster USB connection www.iomega.com. Change it if possible.

There are three common types of parallel port, and the Zip installation software always selects the slowest. According to the Readme.txt file on your Zip Tools disc, the transfer speed is 2-6MB/minute for a standard parallel port, 6-17MB/minute for a bi-directional or Enhanced Capabilities Port (ECP), and 17-22MB/minute for an Enhanced Parallel Port (EPP).

I think the 2610 has ECP (check the manual and BIOS chip setting), so use the Readme file to change the Zip set-up, if possible.

It is also worth making sure you have the latest driver from www.iomega.com/software/ drivers.html To update the driver, find the ppa3.mpd file and rename it (eg to ppa3.mpd.old). Copy the new ppa3.mpd file to C:\\Windows\ System\Iosubsys and restart your PC.

Explorer glitch
Sometimes when I open Internet Explorer 5, instead of going to the pre-set homepage (Google) I am redirected to res://C\Windows\ System\SDHOCLC.DLL. I also find that my temporary internet file disk space has been reset to zero and cannot be reset, and my internet history has been deleted. What's going on? Stephen Lafferty
stephen@slafferty.freeserve.co.uk

JS: I'm glad you asked that, even though I don't have clue, because the answer has much wider applications.

When a Windows 98 file seems to be causing a problem, you can try replacing it using the System File Checker that Microsoft has not told you about.

Go to Start|Run, type sfc and click OK. This utility will attempt to check your system files and replace damaged ones.

If that doesn't replace shdoclc.dll (I'm assuming the spelling mistake is in your query, not in your file), then run sfc and select: Extract one file from installation disk.

Type in the filename (in your case, shdoclc.dll) or browse to select it in the Windows\System folder. Say Yes when asked to save the original file, just in case.

Incidentally, Microsoft suggests using the Internet Explorer Repair tool. See http://support.microsoft.com/ support/kb/articles/Q194/1/ 77.asp

fields.headline: Brothers from another planet
fields.standfirst: A spoof horror film has taken America by storm - and now it's coming over here.  David Wild meets the team behind Scary Movie
fields.trailText: A spoof horror film has taken America by storm - and now it's coming over here. David Wild meets the team behind Scary Movie
fields.body:
The Wayans brothers have finally arrived. Not just for their interview - for which they are fashionably late - but as a comedy dynasty. Last month saw the successful US opening of Scary Movie, the Airplane-like spoof of body-count horror flicks such as Scream and I Know What You Did Last Summer. Directed by Keenen Ivory Wayans, 42, and showcasing the acting and writing talents of younger brothers Shawn, 29, and Marlon, 27, Scary Movie took $42m at the box office in its first weekend.

As TV actors and stand-up comedians, the Wayanses have enjoyed assorted levels of individual success. On the big screen, they have appeared together in various combinations in Hollywood Shuffle (1987), I'm Gonna Get You Sucka (1988), Mo' Money (1992) and Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in the Hood (1996). But they are not a package deal like, say, the Marx brothers, more a mutual-admiration society who do much of their best work together.

Now, with Scary Movie, whose multiracial cast includes Carmen Electra, they have established themselves as a force with which Hollywood will have to reckon. "I think this is what's going to lift the whole dynasty off," says Bob Weinstein, who released the film through his company Miramax. "This is going to widen their audience even more."

Over breakfast in Beverley Hills, Keenen, Shawn, Marlon and Damon, 39, show little doubt about their potential. "We're the black Beatles," jokes Shawn.

"This movie is There's Something About Mary funny, which is funny to everybody," says Damon. "And I'm not even in it."

Along with the banter comes a sense of how the brothers work together. "We know each other's sensibility," Keenen says. "If Damon comes and gives me a note, I listen, because he's my third eye. Same with these two guys. We energise each other."

Some of the energy comes from "a friendly competition", says Damon. "If I'm in a scene with Keenen and I look him in the eye, I know that if I don't get the laugh, he's gonna get it. That keeps everybody raising the bar."

Watching the Wayans brothers together on the set of Scary Movie left Weinstein more than impressed. "I work with my brother, and I see their interaction and it makes me laugh," he says. "Marlon and Shawn wrote the script but, being their brother, Keenen didn't have to be nice about telling them, 'Go write it over 20 more times.' "

The conversation keeps drifting back to a more humble location: the Robert Fulton Houses, a housing project in the Chelsea area of Manhattan. All 10 Wayans children (from oldest to youngest, Dwayne, Keenen, Deidre, Damon, Kim, Elvira, Nadia, Devon, Shawn and Marlon) spent at least part of their childhood there. These four sons of Howell (who sold condoms for a living) and Elvira Wayans recall their early days as bittersweet.

Keenen remembers the day his family moved into "the projects" as the happiest of his mother's life. They had been living in a Harlem tenement that was "rat-infested, with lots of junkies. Every day my mother was fighting to keep us from getting hurt. I remember her looking out our window when we got to the projects and seeing a garage across the street, and just smiling. But it was one of the first integrated projects in Manhattan, and the racial tension was unbelievable. Grown people were throwing bottles at us. My mother wound up getting into fistfights on a regular basis. But a lot of that subsided. By the time Marlon and Shawn came along..."

"We were dating white women," Marlon breaks in, with a hearty laugh.

Eventually, Keenen says, the projects became "a really fun place - no crime, no racism". But the Wayanses hardly enjoyed a worry-free existence. Simply feeding all those mouths was difficult: breakfast was puffed-rice cereal bought in bulk; lunch was grilled-cheese sandwiches with, as Shawn describes it, "government cheese". Sometimes they ate "peanut butter or jelly", Marlon adds. "We never had peanut butter and jelly."

Keenen was the first Wayans to want to be a comedian. "I had the dream since I was six, but I didn't want to hear anything negative about it, so I never told anyone." The comedy god in the Wayans household was Richard Pryor, and even though their mother, who had been a social worker, pushed education, a turning point came when Keenen decided to drop out of Tuskegee Institute in Alabama.

"I'll never forget the night Keenen sat on the dryer and told my mother he was quitting college after three and a half years of engineering school to go to California and pursue acting and stand-up," Marlon says.

Their mother was furious. But, Shawn adds, she pitched into Keenen "very poetically. We watched that as kids, and I had to applaud him. That was the biggest impact on my life in terms of thinking, 'You can do it.' It took such bravery."

Keenen believes that the siblings' difficult childhood explains the concentration of comic talent. "Comedy is pain," he claims. "You can't be funny if you haven't experienced pain. You can be witty, but the real comic stars - Richard Pryor, Lenny Bruce, Sam Kinison - were in deep pain and stand-up was a cathartic experience."

Comedy also requires discipline, and there was plenty of that. "We had a father who ran a tight ship," says Damon. "You didn't want to experience the wrath of Howell. And my mom was a real lioness when you crossed her kids."

All four Wayanses agree that their mother is probably the funniest member of the family, but only when angered. "When my mom's mad, she's a genius," Damon says. "When she's not, she's corny. She's clever - a lot of plays on words. But when she gets mad, that's when you pull up a chair."

Though the Wayans men are more famous, according to Marlon, "the women in our family are hilarious." So why do the men dominate professionally?

"I think women have a harder time with rejection," Keenen says. "I always used to say you have to be impervious to the word no. No means not right now. It definitely can't mean no. That's why people who have less fare better in show business: because they're not accustomed to getting it the first time around."

Audiences were first exposed to the Wayans family through the early-90s comedy show In Living Color, in which Keenen was the driving force. The series featured Kim, Damon, Dwayne, Shawn and Marlon, as well as Jim Carrey and Jamie Foxx. By the time it became a hit, there was a new attitude in the Wayans home. When Marlon had to decide between university and the family business, he found his mother "sitting on a whole new washing machine with her fur and diamonds, going: 'Baby, don't be a jackass. Do like Keenen - go take yourself out there and become an actor.' "

In 1995 he joined Shawn for The Wayans Brothers, a TV show that was regarded as a hit only with black audiences. But the Wayanses have their doubts about the picture of the US provided by the Nielsen TV ratings system.

"I don't know any brothers with Nielsen boxes," Marlon says.

"I think it's all based on suburban homes," adds Shawn.

Now there's no arguing with the brothers' success. But Keenen sees no danger of the kind of feuding that often splits show-business families. "The rifts that most families have are not the results of show business; they're the result of a shaky foundation," he says. "We have a very strong foundation. Show business is not strong enough to divide us."

 Scary Movie is released on September 8.
