The comedy god in the Wayans household was Richard Pryor, and even though their mother, who had been a social worker, pushed education, a turning point came when Keenen decided to drop out of Tuskegee Institute in Alabama. "I'll never forget the night Keenen sat on the dryer and told my mother he was quitting college after three and a half years of engineering school to go to California and pursue acting and stand-up," Marlon says. Their mother was furious. But, Shawn adds, she pitched into Keenen "very poetically. We watched that as kids, and I had to applaud him. That was the biggest impact on my life in terms of thinking, 'You can do it.' It took such bravery." Keenen believes that the siblings' difficult childhood explains the concentration of comic talent. "Comedy is pain," he claims. "You can't be funny if you haven't experienced pain. You can be witty, but the real comic stars - Richard Pryor, Lenny Bruce, Sam Kinison - were in deep pain and stand-up was a cathartic experience." Comedy also requires discipline, and there was plenty of that. "We had a father who ran a tight ship," says Damon. "You didn't want to experience the wrath of Howell. And my mom was a real lioness when you crossed her kids." All four Wayanses agree that their mother is probably the funniest member of the family, but only when angered. "When my mom's mad, she's a genius," Damon says. "When she's not, she's corny. She's clever - a lot of plays on words. But when she gets mad, that's when you pull up a chair." Though the Wayans men are more famous, according to Marlon, "the women in our family are hilarious." So why do the men dominate professionally? "I think women have a harder time with rejection," Keenen says. "I always used to say you have to be impervious to the word no. No means not right now. It definitely can't mean no. That's why people who have less fare better in show business: because they're not accustomed to getting it the first time around." Audiences were first exposed to the Wayans family through the early-90s comedy show In Living Color, in which Keenen was the driving force. The series featured Kim, Damon, Dwayne, Shawn and Marlon, as well as Jim Carrey and Jamie Foxx. By the time it became a hit, there was a new attitude in the Wayans home. When Marlon had to decide between university and the family business, he found his mother "sitting on a whole new washing machine with her fur and diamonds, going: 'Baby, don't be a jackass. Do like Keenen - go take yourself out there and become an actor.' " In 1995 he joined Shawn for The Wayans Brothers, a TV show that was regarded as a hit only with black audiences. But the Wayanses have their doubts about the picture of the US provided by the Nielsen TV ratings system. "I don't know any brothers with Nielsen boxes," Marlon says. "I think it's all based on suburban homes," adds Shawn. Now there's no arguing with the brothers' success. But Keenen sees no danger of the kind of feuding that often splits show-business families. "The rifts that most families have are not the results of show business; they're the result of a shaky foundation," he says. "We have a very strong foundation. Show business is not strong enough to divide us."  Scary Movie is released on September 8.

webTitle: Sierra Leone kidnappers free five Britons

fields.headline: Sierra Leone kidnappers free five Britons
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Renegade soldiers in Sierra Leone last night released five of the 11 British troops they abducted last Friday but the army was unable to say whether the other hostages are likely to be freed soon.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Freetown and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Renegade soldiers in Sierra Leone last night released five of the 11 British troops they abducted last Friday but the army was unable to say whether the other hostages are likely to be freed soon.

British officials said the freed members of the Royal Irish Regiment were all in good health and were returning to their base in Benguema, 25 miles east of Freetown.

The release came amid controversy after the United Nations accused the captured Britons of running an unauthorised "Rambo" mission, and questioned the army's account of the circumstances of their abduction.

The captured men are believed to include soldiers with special forces training. They were snatched along with a number of heavy weapons by the West Side Boys, a group of young fighters notorious for their drinking and drug use.

However, a military source said the abducted group included soldiers who have served with special forces but that they were serving strictly as members of the Royal Irish Regiment in Sierra Leone. The British military spokesman in Freetown, Lieutenant Commander Tony Cramp, told Sky News: "Our thoughts and concerns remain with the remaining six, and also the Sierra Leonean army officer who is part of the group which is still being held

"Talks are continuing and we hope for early release of the remainder."

Lt Cmdr Cramp declined to reveal details of where and how the five were released or whether a deal had been struck with the captors.

He said only that British per sonnel were keeping open a "line of communication" with representatives of the West Side Boys.

The Foreign Office said the five were released with the help of the UN, and specifically the Jordanian contingent of the peacekeeping force.

Earlier, the acting UN force commander in Freetown, a Nigerian brigadier-general, Mohammed Garba, said British claims that the soldiers of the Royal Irish Regiment were captured while on a routine mission to meet his peacekeepers were untrue.

"The British are giving the wrong account. Do you conduct a liaison with people you don't tell you are coming? From a military point of view it does not make sense unless the individuals have another agenda. They call it a liaison mission but it was really a military patrol on a Rambo mission," he said.

The British army says the captive soldiers were driving towards Freetown from a routine liaison meeting with Jordanian peacekeepers in the town of Masiaka when their three Land Rovers were stopped by the West Side Boys.

Gen Garba, a Nigerian, claims otherwise. He said the British soldiers had turned off the main road four miles before Masiaka and headed north along a road towards Port Loko where there was fighting between Revolutionary United Front rebels and government forces.

"We warned them several times that that area is very insecure, that you cannot just move around it," he added.

In London, the Ministry of Defence said the 11 soldiers had been "fostering relationships" with the UN Jordanian troops on their "flanks".

The Foreign Office offered a different explanation. Asked why the soldiers were so far away from their base at Benguema, it said the base was exposed to attack by rebels encroaching on Freetown.

Most of the British troops were pulled out of Sierra Leone in June, leaving nearly 300 men in Benguema to train the Sierra Leone army.

Responsibility for security in Freetown and support for the government in its war against the RUF once again fell to the UN, but the British still have responsibility for a security cordon of about three miles around the Benguema base. Gen Garba says they routinely movebeyond it.

The commander of the Royal Irish Regiment contingent in Sierra Leone, Colonel Simon Fordham, has met the West Side Boys' leader, a self-styled Brigadier or General Kallay, who issued a list of demands, including the release of two leaders - Brigadier "Bomb Blast" and Brigadier "55" - from Freetown prison.

The head of the UN mission in Freetown, Oluyemi Adeniji, had warned the West Side Boys that they must soon release their captives or face the consequences.

webTitle: WWF in wrestling match over initials

fields.headline: WWF in wrestling match over initials
fields.trailText: The WWF, previously known as the Worldwide Fund for Nature, is locked in a legal battle with the World Wrestling Federation in a row over the initials, the charity said yesterday.
fields.body:
The WWF, previously known as the Worldwide Fund for Nature, is locked in a legal battle with the World Wrestling Federation in a row over the initials, the charity said yesterday.

The fund is struggling to preserve what it claims is its own identity summed up in the three letters WWF.

"We are undertaking a legal proceeding against the World Wrestling Federation based on concerns we have about the use of the initials WWF," spokeswoman Anita Neville confirmed.

She said the two organisations had drawn up an agreement six years ago restricting the use of the initials WWF on the internet and elsewhere.

But the fund, which has 4.7m supporters, launched legal proceedings in April claiming the World Wrestling Federation had gone back on the promise to avoid cashing in by using the initials.

Ms Neville said: "We are trying to ascertain the rights to the initials in particular and to secure our brand which we have held since 1961. The legal action is to protect our identity and the rights we have secured in the initials WWF."

The World Wrestling Federation, worth just over £1bn with 30m fans, was obliged to include details of the litigation proceedings in a recent annual report to the US securities and exchange commission.

Ms Neville said: "It is all in mediation. As far as I am aware, they have not put in an official response to our initial plea."

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.body:
"Grant doesn't even like chocolate - he's far too vain. He likes to watch his figure."

Della Bovey on ex-husband Grant Bovey and Anthea Turner promoting a new chocolate bar in their wedding pictures, the Sun

"I once engaged in an impassioned argument on TV with Edwina Currie and Clare Short, and a friend rang me up afterwards to comment: 'Mary, let me give you some advice. Never wear yellow'. Forget my scintillating discourse. The colour was the only thing that registered."

Mary Kenny on why television news' obsession with appearance is a condition of the medium, Express

"... they should stop passing judgment on me because, as soon as someone tells me not to do something, I'll do it. And to show them just how angry it makes me, I take the hems of my skirts up a few centimetres after each one of these comments."

Calista Flockhart responds to accusations that her skirts in Ally McBeal are too short, Hello!

"A dash of lime, sweetheart. Rules is rules."

Al Murray, Pub Landlord, advises a "lady who loves lager" on the best way to pursue her pleasure without seeming uncouth, Independent

"It is scarcely necessary to list the offenders: editors of magazines who claim to be elevating the status of women even as they abase them to being objects of a voyeuristic culture, businesswomen selling "empowering" accoutrements to fashion-crazed adolescents, female politicians or columnists who encourage the notion that the key to succcess in life is to be less rational and more emotive than the male. All are persuaded, and have succeeded in persuading others, that they have the welfare of their sex at heart. Which is strange, since the image of the ideal female they portray can be uncannily close to that of the least evolved male: thick-headed, hard-drinking, self-assertive, foul-mouthed and sexually incontinent."

George Walden on the women who exploit women, Evening Standard

webTitle: America may be having the best election in the world

fields.headline: America may be having the best election in the world
fields.standfirst:
For once, a stark left-right argument is taking place in western politics

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: For once, a stark left-right argument is taking place in western politics.
fields.body:
When August began, the American election looked as though it would be about Clinton's trousers. But the month changed everything. Watching it unfold, I saw most parts of Bill Clinton, his inimitable charisma as well as his porous apparel, receding daily from the public mind. The election will be about the future not the past. It's the most important election in the world. It may also turn out to be the best election in the world, restoring stark left-right argument to the politics of a western democracy for the first time since the 80s.

At the start, it seemed possible that the voters were getting ready to withdraw from Al Gore, the Democratic candidate for president, the forgiveness they'd offered Clinton for the Monica calamity. During that humiliation, the public withheld the loathing which many politicians and commentators, including this one, thought would empty Clinton's remaining two years of all authority. We were wrong. But George W Bush promised Americans he would restore "dignity and respect" to the White House. It was the insistent coded mantra he offered the Republican convention. For two weeks, with Gore 12 points behind in the polls, it seemed to be working.

This would have been perverse. Was Gore to be trapped between Clinton's incorrigible frailties, on which the people took delayed revenge, and his populistic brilliance, of which the vice president, a leaden speaker and earnest policy-wonk, is in regrettably short supply? The laid-back Bush, reformed alcoholic with distant rumours of cocaine lying unrebutted on the table, had the family connections, the new-leaf repentance, the pleasing manner and the apparent experience stemming from one of the weakest governorships in the US, to take advantage of the personality contest the election might easily become.

But already it is different. The personalities will continue to matter, and the body-language is finely watched. Gore hired a ballet dancer to coach him in platform movement. Significant polling gains are attributed to the most lubricious kiss any politician ever gave his wife, uncoached, on a public platform. It's also true that both candidates know their battle is for the centre, both the political and, as it happens, the geographical, the eastern-central and middle-western states. The most startling development as August waned, though, was the clarifying of their differences.

The man responsible for this is Al Gore. He needed to change the subject, away from Clinton's aura and Bush's contentless agenda, and did so by the un-American activity of turning sharply to the left. I don't want to exaggerate this. Gore is still locked into funding from corporate America, still mute on inequality, and well outflanked by Ralph Nader running as an independent candidate. But Bush is much more uncomfortable with a turn of events that is forcing him to be specific. "Dignity and respect" have almost ceased to matter, as the details of his "compassionate conservatism" begin to be ranged against a Gore programme that shows more confidence than Clinton's ever did in the traditional Democrat constituency.

Central to Bush's programme is a massive tax cut of $1.3 trillion, geared without discrimination in favour of the rich. Gore promises less than half that, mainly with subsidies to middle-class (working-class is outside the US political vocabulary) families. A projected budget surplus of $4.6 trillion over 10 years would be used by Gore mainly to cut the debt, by Bush mainly to cut taxes and start privatising social security. But Gore would spend $400bn on health care - insurance for the low-paid, and free drugs for the elderly - Bush a quarter of that. Gore favours a huge federal spend on education: $115bn over the decade, a 50% rise in an area traditionally left to states and localities. Bush, while making education his social priority, wants to rearrange school structures rather than spend anything like that kind of money.

Whoever wins, Congress will have the final say in all this. But other differences speak as clearly for a philosophical divide. Bush and Gore would engage with the public and the Senate from starting points quite distant from each other. The most blatant contrast is over environmental protection, where Gore's commitment is as lengthy and knowledgeable as Bush's is Texas-brutish towards any measure making life harder for business, and damn the consequences for global warming. Myriad crucial choices display the same cleavage of attitude. Three seem especially noteworthy. Over gun control, national missile defence and abortion rights, the American voter has to choose between leaders who are absolutists on none of them, but whose preferred biases are heavily divergent.

Gore's predicament, in other words, has turned this into an issue-based campaign. He had to do it this way. It conformed to his own wonkish nature, and played to his strengths as a serious politician who has built national experience over 30 years. More pressingly, it was the only escape-route from the trivialities that suited Bush better. It has forced Bush into the open, requiring the sort of performance in which he has so far failed to shine.

How, exactly, the issues turn out to be argued is another matter. There's more money available for this year's campaign than for any in recorded history, and most of it will be spent on 30-second TV and radio commercials. That's the idiom that will blanket the airwaves with increasing frenzy for the next two months. America is not a predominantly political country. There is no conversation that could be called national. Many people will have little background against which to measure the roaring assaults. Reduced to three sentences, the case for a trillion dollar tax cut may be all too easily misunderstood. We're not talking Socratic dialogue here. Personal viciousness will also be heating up. It's perfectly suited to the insidious soundbite. The pretence that the other guy is sincere, a ritual bow this August to focus-group disgust at "divisiveness", will soon explode.

But those are commonplace developments: louder and richer than ever, but the usual currency of American politics. What is not usual is a disagreement that can be called ideological. That has not been so common, to put it mildly, in American as in European postwar politics. In this contest it is more explicit than in the last German, French or British elections - though William Hague is doing his best to ensure that next year's choice will be clear enough. What Gore, with the aid of Bush, is doing is to challenge some of the assumptions which persuaded Clinton that the only way he could win and govern was by leading his party from the right. This is making for an epic contest, to be decided as usual by money and organisation, but introducing the US in a new role that puts Europe to shame: leader of a political argument that really matters.

webTitle: Fayed sues for US files on Diana

fields.headline: Fayed sues for US files on Diana
fields.trailText: Mohamed Al Fayed yesterday announced legal action against the US government in an effort to obtain "secret" documents concerning the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, and his son, Dodi.
fields.body:
Mohamed Al Fayed yesterday announced legal action against the US government in an effort to obtain "secret" documents concerning the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, and his son, Dodi.

The Harrods owner also called on the American people to lobby President Clinton to release relevant security files.

On the eve of the third anniversary of the fatal Paris car crash, Mr Fayed repeated his claim that the princess and his son were murdered.

In a video recording played at a Washington news conference, he said: "Federal agencies of the [US] possess documents which may provide vital information as to the cause of the deaths."

Mr Fayed said he would like to have been in Washington in person, but the anniversary of the deaths made it "too painful for me to speak in public".

At the news conference, Mr Fayed's director of security, John Macnamara, read a statement on his behalf. It claimed: "From the irrefutable facts which have been uncovered, it is clear to me that evil and racist forces, working through the British security services, murdered my son and Princess Diana.

"MI6 is controlled by the establishment of the United Kingdom. They answer ultimately to the royal household, which would never have accepted my son, a naturally tanned, curly haired Egyptian, being married to the mother of the future king of England and becoming his stepfather.

"The drama of Romeo and Juliet continues to repeat itself 500 years after William Shakespeare penned his tragic story."

Mr Fayed also accused the US department of justice of failing to investigate fully and prosecute fraudsters who tried to extort £12m from him by offering for sale alleged CIA documents.
Press Association

Mr Fayed said he would like to have been in Washington in person, but the anniversary of the deaths made it "too painful for me to speak in public". At the news conference, Mr Fayed's director of security, John Macnamara, read a statement on his behalf. It claimed: "From the irrefutable facts which have been uncovered, it is clear to me that evil and racist forces, working through the British security services, murdered my son and Princess Diana. "MI6 is controlled by the establishment of the United Kingdom. They answer ultimately to the royal household, which would never have accepted my son, a naturally tanned, curly haired Egyptian, being married to the mother of the future king of England and becoming his stepfather. "The drama of Romeo and Juliet continues to repeat itself 500 years after William Shakespeare penned his tragic story." Mr Fayed also accused the US department of justice of failing to investigate fully and prosecute fraudsters who tried to extort £12m from him by offering for sale alleged CIA documents. Press Association

webTitle: Children born by donated sperm 'liable to suffer identity crisis' researchers claim

fields.headline: Children born by donated sperm 'liable to suffer identity crisis' researchers claim
fields.trailText: Children born through fertility treatment using anonymously donated sperm suffer an identity crisis, with feelings of abandonment and loss when they discover the truth as adults, new research shows.
fields.body:
Children born through fertility treatment using anonymously donated sperm suffer an identity crisis, with feelings of abandonment and loss when they discover the truth as adults, new research shows.

Donor insemination took off in the fertility clinics in the 1970s, but although there may be 30,000 to 40,000 DI babies in the UK, the vast majority do not know how they were conceived.

The results of a small study by British researchers suggests the trauma caused to those who discover the truth is similar to finding out about adoption - although it often confirms a long-held suspicion that something in their childhood was amiss.

In Sweden, DI children have since 1985 had a legal right to be told the identity of the donor. But a second study shows that 90% of parents there are still concealing the truth.

The two studies, published today in the journal Human Reproduction, show that real issues about this fertility technique have not yet been sorted out.

The UK study makes it clear that the discovery that they do not know and never will know their genetic father's identity is traumatic.

The authors, psychologists Amanda Turner and Adrian Coyle from Surrey University, recruited 16 adults between the ages of 26 and 55 through support networks in the UK, US, Canada and Australia. Those who agreed to take part filled in detailed email questionnaires and were then asked for further details by the researchers.

All were shocked when they discovered, usually by accident, that they were conceived using donor sperm. All of them felt they should have the right to know the identity of their genetic father.

But unlike adopted children in this country, who have the right to know who their birth parents are, DI donor insemination babies are only given non-identifying information about their genetic fathers.

webTitle: A club has installed double cubicles so women can go together.  Maggie O'Farrell  reports

fields.headline: Why do we go to the loo in twos?
fields.standfirst: A club has installed double cubicles so women can go together.  Maggie O'Farrell  reports
fields.trailText: A club has installed double cubicles so women can go together.  Maggie O'Farrell  reports
fields.body:
A strange thing is happening in clubland. Perhaps it is just that club design and music have been plundering their pasts for so long, that all possible variables have been exhausted. But the people who run them seem to have decided that they have only one chance left for inventiveness and individuality in terms of design: the toilet. Or, more specifically, the women's toilet.

Go to any swanky club these days and you are likely to find that what was once a rather odious, former broom cupboard equipped with cold running water and a greying sliver of soap (if you were lucky) has been expanded to lounge proportions, decorated with the opulence of a high-class bordello, and filled with more toiletries than you could decently cram into your handbag. These days, you're nobody in clubland if you haven't managed to instal a headline-grabbing loo.

We've had the great female urinal debate, in which club promoters seemed shocked to discover that women were reluctant to flash their pants in front of an assembled company of random strangers. Then there was the infamous one-way mirror in the ladies' loo at the Elbow Room in Islington, north London, where the men assumed that the reflective surface in front of them was merely a way to check their hair/flies/teeth, until they were alerted by the shrieks and bangings from the other side of the glass. Now, the Infinity club in Manchester has installed double cubicles or "twobicles" for female customers. So popular are they that the queues are enormous, even when other, single cubicles are free. "Ladies always seem to go to the toilet in pairs," says Rob Broadbent, marketing manager of the club. "What they do in there has always been something of a mystery among us men."

Ah, that old chestnut - the universal complaint of blokes who are just trying to fathom the strange and flighty creatures with whom they share their lives. I don't know who it was that first picked up on it, but I remember Jasper Carrott doing a whole routine about it in the mid-80s, along the lines of a baffled why-do-they-do-it? Did nobody think of telling him: "Jasper, we're just trying to get away from you for a bit?" And remember the scene in the film Trainspotting? Two women are - wait for it - in a club toilet. One is telling the other that she has read an article in a women's magazine about how delaying sex for five weeks is good for a relationship; meanwhile, outside, the man in question is moaning to his mate that he can't wait any longer. When the women return, the men demand, with more than a trace of paranoia: "What have you been talking about?" The women look at each other and say, in flawless unison: "Shopping."

This incident reveals men's deep-seated fear of the female toilet confab: it both fascinates and repels them. They are afraid of being discussed, but just as afraid of not being discussed.

Let's get this straight, once and for all: the female toilet is beauty parlour, counselling room, haven, bathroom, chill-out zone and lounge all rolled into one. The conversation is as likely to be about men as it is about music. Or clothes. Or who is in that night, or what is on TV, or office gossip, life laments, existential reflections - whatever.

It's not that we are going behind closed doors to bitch and scheme about the opposite sex; shooting the breeze in the privacy of a closed cubicle is just part of a night out. Women, despite their reluctance to use urinals, have fewer issues with the intimacy of bodily functions than men do: men don't even exchange eye contact in lavatories, let alone lipstick, loo paper, scandal and confidences.

It must also be considered that going in with your friend means a certain social protection when you come out: you don't want to reappear on your own to find that your friends aren't where you left them, you're now alone - and seemingly easy prey to the bar sharks that lurk in any club.

No matter how female-friendly clubs have become in recent years, you would be hard-pressed to find a woman who feels completely at ease in one on her own. There is, of course, another reason why roomy cubicles might be approved of by clubbers.

Had the Infinity management considered that their innovation might be used by people wanting to ingest illegal substances through certain orifices? "Certainly not," they said, outraged.

webTitle: G2:  Virginity has been putting it about a bit recently

fields.headline: Chaste all over the place
fields.standfirst: Virginity hasn't had such a high profile since pre-pill days. Pop princess Britney Spears is famously intact and now a new movie reflects the growing fixation with sexual purity. By  Polly Vernon
fields.trailText: Virginity hasn't had such a high profile since pre-pill days. Pop princess Britney Spears is famously intact and now a new movie reflects the growing fixation with sexual purity. By  Polly Vernon
fields.body:
When I was 13, a contemporary called Brett told me, in all seriousness, that he was saving up to go to California because he had seen it in the Porky's films and it looked really good. The whole state, he continued earnestly, was populated by semi-nude nubiles whose only objective was to relieve shambolic teens like himself of their virginity in the communal shower after cheerleading practice. That sort of thing, it had come to his attention, did not go on much in small-town Devon.

I can't help but wonder what kind of money-spinning endeavours Brett would have embarked upon to get himself stateside had he been 13 now, in the wake of the release of Cherry Falls, the slasher flick which opened at multiplexes nationally last Friday.

It has, at its core, an obscene conceit that runs something like this: serial killer targets teenage virgins in US backwater, killing them horrendously and scoring "VIRGIN" into the untainted flesh of their thighs. Just in case anyone misses the point. The plot line, gags, dialogue and so on all hinge on that one, deeply dubious device. And so: parents encourage their children to have sex to increase their chances of surviving the cull. Buxom blondes place lusty slow-dance partners' hands on their pert bots, as once they would have swatted them away. The head slapper/cheerleader holds seminar on the sports field regarding technique. The film is quite uniquely bad.

However, despite having been channelled directly from the fetid imagination of a rampant teenage boy, the Cherry Falls plot premise does reflect a wider social trend - namely, the curious resurgence of a fixation with virginity.

It has been a while since virginity revelled in the kind of profile it is enjoying now. Although a recurrent motif in horror films, by the 80s, when people had stopped trying to be constantly outlandishly sexual, virginity had sidled out of cultural view. The assumption was that you weren't and so there wasn't a great deal to discuss. Even during the bleak, frightening time when Aids was widely perceived as raging in the bloodstream of every second stranger, monogamy and chastity were the sexual choices of the moment. Nobody really suggested giving it a miss in the longer term. Yet the last year or so has seen virginity upping its public image, buoyed by spiralling teen pregnancy rates, the soap-scrubbed evangelism of America's anti-sex teen lobby, True Love Waits, and that cavorting bundle of titillation we know as the supremely pure Britney Spears.

Why now? Why is virginity flourishing as a theme, particularly when it is not doing great business in real terms (statistics indicate that one British girl in four has had sex before 16)? Is this some clumsy attempt to dilute female sexuality, to reinstall ancient double standards, to ensure that the next generation of boys get virgin brides, complete with low sexual expectations?

That is the thing about the state of virginity; 21st century-style or otherwise, it is a peculiarly female concern. Consider the linguistics: maidenhead. Then consider the cultural climate: as a woman, you can still qualify as a low-category saint by remaining a virgin. You don't as a man. It is Britney, rather than her equally restrained boyfriend, Justin from 'N Sync, pondering, "What would Jesus do?", who gets all the press. Cherry Falls focuses on teen girl virgins, on their ethical dilemmas and reined in passions, rather than those of their male counterparts. Who knows how many boys reached their 16th birthdays as virgins? Who cares?

Biologically, virginity was always going to be more significant for women than men. There is something so terribly technical about losing your virginity as a woman. I can vividly remember a distraught friend earnestly telling me she had lost her virginity to a Tampax and even Cherry Falls illustrates that it is hard to determine whether or not the slasher's one male victim was really a virgin. Such vivid, dramatic biology inevitably gets translated into dubious symbolism, bogged down with flawed moral concerns.

Sara Maitland, who is a theologian and author of the book Virgin Territory, says she hopes that virginity has had its day as an ethical issue for women: "I don't see how anyone can apply moral value to something that can be stolen from you by some man who has jumped out from behind a bush." She does, however, believe that it is simplistic to dismiss virginity and its associations as a male-generated plot to deprive women of their sexuality. "In Greek mythology, virginity was short hand for autonomy. Athena was a virgin, and it was her way of saying: I only belong to me. Zeus's wife, Hera, would bathe annually in a fountain that would restore her virginity. That wasn't about not having sex - obviously she had, or there would be nothing to restore. That was about replenishing power."

Equally, Maitland believes that Elizabeth I, head girl of the cult of virginity, wasn't flashing her maidenhead about as an expression of her girlishness, her chasteness, her purity. It was her way of saying: I am queen. "Women without men had power," she says.

Once the pill and other contraceptive devices became widely and freely available, and losing your virginity became divorced from the social repercussions of pregnancy outside marriage, the idea of it lost its power and its potency within western culture. Given the contemporary context - a society that isn't keen on female promiscuity, but does not expect to encounter a great many virgin brides - virginity is a curious, faintly annoying quality in an adult.

Of course, we would take a virginity revival over ugly men haranguing you into sleeping with them because you're terribly neurotic, un-modern, and anti-feminist if you don't. As Germaine Greer wrote just before the publication of her latest book, The Whole Woman: "In 1968, women had the right to say no without apology; what they didn't have was the right to say yes. Now they have a duty to say yes to whatever their partners may desire, no holds are barred. Women cannot admit to feeling disgust or to not enjoying the stuff that is going on - not if they want to seem cool, even if they have to take muscle relaxants to do it."

I understand that the decision to hang on to your virginity is a personal choice. But there is no need for new-wave moral outrage, every time you feel a bit frisky, and Cherry Falls-style obsessing over it. Too many people aren't very good at sex anyway. So if you must prize your maidenhead, please go and do it quietly somewhere else. Thank you.

fields.headline: Eliyahu Ben Elissar
fields.standfirst:
The first Israeli ambassador to an Arab country and leading light in the peace process
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The first Israeli ambassador to an Arab country and leading light in the peace process.
fields.body:
Eliyahu Ben Elissar, who has died aged 68, was Israel's first-ever ambassador to an Arab country. He gained his Cairo posting as a reward for heading Israel's negotiating team at the original Camp David talks of 1978, and his mere presence in Egypt's capital broke many a taboo between Arabs and the Jewish state. He then represented the Likud party for 15 years in Israel's parliament, the Knesset, before accepting the plum diplomatic assignment of Washington in 1996. In 1998, he became ambassador to France. Domestic Israeli politics had seen him ordered home, but he died within a week, in Paris.

Initially, little suggested that Elissar would make an ideal peace-broker. He was a lifelong advocate of extreme rightwing views, derived partly from his own experience as a Holocaust orphan. He condemned the Oslo accords of 1993 as "the murder of our state", but dutifully defended Israel's policies overseas.

As a teenager, he associated with Lehi - or the "Stern gang" - the most violent Jewish underground group in the Palestine of the British Mandate. The new state of Israel was very much a Labour Zionist creation, Lehi was forcibly disbanded, and in 1950 Elissar left the country. Still, the cunning and passion of zealots was not to be squandered. Mossad tracked him down to Paris, where he was studying political science and law at the Sorbonne, and recruited him as their European controller for agents operating in Arab lands.

Elissar emerged from the shadows in 1965 to serve as representative for the rightwing Herut/Likud party within the World Zionist Organisation. There he met the dynamic and personable Nitza, whom he married in 1979. By the 70s he had become a confidant of Menachem Begin, Israel's fiery opposition leader. After Likud ousted Labour in 1977, it was Ben Elissar who ran the new prime minister's office. Begin recognised in him a kindred spirit: Polish-born, suspicious and intelligent, scarred by memories of anti-Semitism and genocide; a naturally cautious man, yet willing to act boldly if required.

In November 1977, Egypt's President Sadat surprised the world by announcing his intention to visit Jerusalem. Elissar arranged the welcome for him, and suddenly faced a new crisis: finding sheet music for the Egyptian national anthem. A year later in Maryland, he agreed to return the entire Sinai Peninsula to the Arab republic in exchange for lasting peace.

Rightwingers were shocked that a Greater Israel devotee could "abandon" Jewish settlers in their desert outposts. But Elissar knew better. By jettisoning territory, Israel secured its southern flank from future attack; drove a spoke in the wheel of pan-Arab unity; and deferred more painful sacrifices demanded by Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza.

Life in Cairo tested the ambassador - it was hard to build any rapport after decades of enmity - yet he came to know Egypt's leader well, and wrote admiringly of him in a book, Sadat and his Legacy (1998).

Such future diplomatic triumph could scarcely have occurred to the boy born in Radom, central Poland, in 1932. He was just 10 when he arrived in Palestine after being smuggled out of a Nazi-controlled ghetto. His parents and siblings all perished in Europe. Elissar's recollections of the period informed his whole life: "When an enemy says he is going to kill you, believe him," he warned.

At the same time, Elissar had all the attributes for diplomatic life. He was charming, discreet, had a history doctorate from Geneva University and spoke several languages. His sartorial elegance, intellectual demeanour and neat square beard made him seem like a reincarnation of Theodor Herzl, the 19th-century founder of political Zionism.

After Cairo, Elissar served as a Likud member of the Knesset from 1981 until 1996, and twice chaired the legislature's influential foreign policy and defence committee. When his party returned to power, he accepted the ambassadorship to Washington and moved there in September 1996.

At first Elissar was hopeful: "The USA and Israel don't have to agree on everything, but we will always remain family," he said. Unfortunately, he became a pawn in a power struggle between his sponsor, foreign minister David Levy, and his prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. "Bibi" undermined him repeatedly, excluding him from meetings with the president and contradicting him.

To make matters worse, Elissar assumed his post just as the Jerusalem tunnel crisis was erupting. US-Israeli relations hit a nadir over construction at Har Homa, when the Palestinians were not consulted about the passage excavated at the base of the Temple Mount, and violent protest resulted. The ambassador also tried to assuage American non-Orthodox Jews who felt threatened by Israel's conversion laws. He denied press rumours that he had authorised spying, and retorted that the FBI was tapping embassy phones.

Yet, overall, Elissar handled his brief with dignity, and forged valuable links with Jordanian and Pakistani diplomats, Arab-Americans and US Senators. He was relieved to be posted to Paris in 1998, where he had worked as an embassy security guard nearly 50 years earlier. Within two years, however, he fell victim to more domestic political intrigue: David Levy resigned as foreign minister, and prime minister Barak ordered his appointee, Ben Elissar, to pack his bags.

He is survived by his wife, son and daughter.

 Eliyahu Ben Elissar, politician and diplomat, born August 2 1932; died August 12 2000

Mossad tracked him down to Paris, where he was studying political science and law at the Sorbonne, and recruited him as their European controller for agents operating in Arab lands. Elissar emerged from the shadows in 1965 to serve as representative for the rightwing Herut/Likud party within the World Zionist Organisation. There he met the dynamic and personable Nitza, whom he married in 1979. By the 70s he had become a confidant of Menachem Begin, Israel's fiery opposition leader. After Likud ousted Labour in 1977, it was Ben Elissar who ran the new prime minister's office. Begin recognised in him a kindred spirit: Polish-born, suspicious and intelligent, scarred by memories of anti-Semitism and genocide; a naturally cautious man, yet willing to act boldly if required. In November 1977, Egypt's President Sadat surprised the world by announcing his intention to visit Jerusalem. Elissar arranged the welcome for him, and suddenly faced a new crisis: finding sheet music for the Egyptian national anthem. A year later in Maryland, he agreed to return the entire Sinai Peninsula to the Arab republic in exchange for lasting peace. Rightwingers were shocked that a Greater Israel devotee could "abandon" Jewish settlers in their desert outposts. But Elissar knew better. By jettisoning territory, Israel secured its southern flank from future attack; drove a spoke in the wheel of pan-Arab unity; and deferred more painful sacrifices demanded by Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza. Life in Cairo tested the ambassador - it was hard to build any rapport after decades of enmity - yet he came to know Egypt's leader well, and wrote admiringly of him in a book, Sadat and his Legacy (1998). Such future diplomatic triumph could scarcely have occurred to the boy born in Radom, central Poland, in 1932. He was just 10 when he arrived in Palestine after being smuggled out of a Nazi-controlled ghetto. His parents and siblings all perished in Europe. Elissar's recollections of the period informed his whole life: "When an enemy says he is going to kill you, believe him," he warned. At the same time, Elissar had all the attributes for diplomatic life. He was charming, discreet, had a history doctorate from Geneva University and spoke several languages. His sartorial elegance, intellectual demeanour and neat square beard made him seem like a reincarnation of Theodor Herzl, the 19th-century founder of political Zionism. After Cairo, Elissar served as a Likud member of the Knesset from 1981 until 1996, and twice chaired the legislature's influential foreign policy and defence committee. When his party returned to power, he accepted the ambassadorship to Washington and moved there in September 1996. At first Elissar was hopeful: "The USA and Israel don't have to agree on everything, but we will always remain family," he said. Unfortunately, he became a pawn in a power struggle between his sponsor, foreign minister David Levy, and his prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. "Bibi" undermined him repeatedly, excluding him from meetings with the president and contradicting him. To make matters worse, Elissar assumed his post just as the Jerusalem tunnel crisis was erupting. US-Israeli relations hit a nadir over construction at Har Homa, when the Palestinians were not consulted about the passage excavated at the base of the Temple Mount, and violent protest resulted. The ambassador also tried to assuage American non-Orthodox Jews who felt threatened by Israel's conversion laws. He denied press rumours that he had authorised spying, and retorted that the FBI was tapping embassy phones. Yet, overall, Elissar handled his brief with dignity, and forged valuable links with Jordanian and Pakistani diplomats, Arab-Americans and US Senators. He was relieved to be posted to Paris in 1998, where he had worked as an embassy security guard nearly 50 years earlier. Within two years, however, he fell victim to more domestic political intrigue: David Levy resigned as foreign minister, and prime minister Barak ordered his appointee, Ben Elissar, to pack his bags. He is survived by his wife, son and daughter.  Eliyahu Ben Elissar, politician and diplomat, born August 2 1932; died August 12 2000

webTitle: Fruit juice spray to keep the leaves off the lines

fields.headline: Fruit juice spray to keep the leaves off the lines
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack last night unveiled its new weapon in the battle to rid the industry of the perennial problem of leaves on the line - a blend of oranges and lemons mixed with detergent.
fields.body:
Railtrack last night unveiled its new weapon in the battle to rid the industry of the perennial problem of leaves on the line - a blend of oranges and lemons mixed with detergent.

This autumn, as the leaves begin to fall, teams of Railtrack staff will be sent out in the dead of night with 20 litre backpacks of the liquid to squirt miles of track, particularly in heavily-populated London commuter land.

They will then return 10 minutes later and scrape the resulting mulch off the track to make the line ready for the first trains of the day.

The south-east will be the main target but Railtrack confirmed this will be a nationwide offensive in which thousands of litres of the potent brew will be sprayed by four specially-chosen hit squads.

One of the concoctions has been called natrusolve. It has already been successfully tested in the Midlands.

Railtrack's new solution has come just in time. Britain's extremely wet summer means that this autumn's leaf fall is expected to be early and heavy. "We need to be prepared," said a Railtrack spokesman.

The rescue plan has come not a moment too soon. Railtrack's prestigious 21-strong fleet of multipurpose vehicles, which cost £1m each and use high-powered water jets to clear the lines of leaves, has been hit by a technical hitch.

This summer the vehicles have been used to rid tracks of fast growing weeds. But the pressure has finally told on them. Brackets on the nozzles of some vehicles have cracked and a race against time has developed to repair them in time for the first leaf fall.

Railtrack is therefore even more thankful that its orange and lemon detergent will be on tap to defeat the old enemy.

The company pointed out that its fruit brew had several advantages. It was non-corrosive, and did not rot track side cables or signalling. The substance was also environmentally friendly and would not harm vegetation.

The firm said that it would concentrate on well known blackspots and promised to work hard on the leaf mould problem this season. "We really think this is one of our best ideas," a spokesman said.

One thing is sure. If Railtrack cannot prevent trains from skidding on wet leaves this autumn, it will not be able to blame the wrong type of orange and lemon.

fields.headline: Exams authority admits new blunder
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Scotland's discredited examination authority yesterday admitted yet another mistake in a series of embarrassing blunders that have left thousands of pupils with the wrong results.
fields.body:
Scotland's discredited examination authority yesterday admitted yet another mistake in a series of embarrassing blunders that have left thousands of pupils with the wrong results.

The Scottish Qualifications Authority, which announced yesterday that two senior officials had left their posts, said that some schools had been sent the wrong information about errors made in their standard grade results.

It came a day after the SQA revealed that more than 4,000 pupils would have to have their standard grade results - the equivalent of the GCSE - re-checked because they were inaccurate or incomplete; the same setback that has already affected more than 5,000 pupils who sat the new Higher exams.

The Scottish education minister, Sam Galbraith, attacked the SQA for the latest mistake, but is himself under renewed pressure to quit over the fiasco.

"I just think the whole education system in Scotland is in a state of utter chaos," said Nicola Sturgeon, education spokeswoman for the Scottish National party. "The minister cannot stay in his post. He has absolutely no credibility. He is presiding over a chaotic situation yet he does not seem to be in control of his department."

In the latest mix-up, teachers were sent other schools' details about the pupils affected by the standard grade chaos rather than their own. The SQA blamed "sequential faxing problems" but declined to say how many schools had been involved. They said only 1% of standard grade students had received erroneous results and announced that the SQA's head of operations, Jack Greig, had been suspended pending a disciplinary investigation, and the director of awards, David Elliot, stepped down by mutual agreement.

The problems with the results for standard grade came to light when the SQA re-assessed the results of all 147,000 examination candidates in Scotland this summer after serious problems with the Higher grades. The SQA say "data handling errors" are to blame for omissions and inaccuracies in the results.

But Mr Galbraith faces pressure to shoulder responsibility for the crisis. It has emerged that the Scottish executive has blocked plans for a full debate on the issue when the Scottish parliament resumes. Instead, Mr Galbraith will give a 15 minute statement and 30 for questions.

A Scottish executive spokesman said the proper time for a debate was after the various inquiries into the affair had been completed. However, critics say the executive is ducking its responsibilities.

Lindsay Paterson, professor of education at Edinburgh University, said that was a "betrayal of accountability".

"This latest fiasco raises the question of how we are going to motivate 16-year-olds to stay at school and do their Highers ... You can't tell them the system won't fail them, because it already has."

webTitle: Move to try out GM feed on cattle

fields.headline: Move to try out GM feed on cattle
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: The government is to consider proposals for the first experiments using home-grown genetically modified animal feed on cattle. The feed is made from fodder maize grown during this summer's controversial farm trials.
fields.body:
The government is to consider proposals for the first experiments using home-grown genetically modified animal feed on cattle. The feed is made from fodder maize grown during this summer's controversial farm trials.

The multinational biotech company Aventis CropScience wants approval to feed part of the harvest to cows, so as to reassure sceptical Britons.

It yesterday promised that milk or meat from the animals would not be sold to the public, saying this kept the company within the spirit of a voluntary agreement that no GM crops used in the farm trials would enter either the human or animal food chains until after the programme was completed in 2003.

Critics saw the latest move as another attempt by the biotech industry to force the pace on the spread of new technology in Britain, although Aventis pointed out that animal feed using GM ingredients grown abroad was already legally on sale in this country.

Company spokesman Clive Rainbird said: "The intention is to generate UK data to demonstrate the feeding of GM maize silage to cattle is just as nutritious (as conventional crops) and does not carry any risk to the animals themselves ot the meat or milk they produce... We could use North American data but we feel that if we have to persuade a sceptical British public, then we use British data."

The trials would only use a small proportion of the GM maize from the farm trials, which are designed to test the impact of GM crops on the environment, not their safety. The maize would be harvested from late September.

The proposal for feeding the maize to cattle has passed one formal government hurdle concerning the use of pesticides. It was not clear last night whether it legally needed any more because it already has EU marketing consent The company has promised, however, to send research protocols for the feeding trials to officials when the trials are completed.

A spokesman for the food standards agency, responsible for animal feedstuffs, said last night: "As far as we are aware, no one has contacted us over this yet."

It also emerged yesterday that the government has no legal powers over the way the maize being used in the GM trials is destroyed because of the EU approval.

Disposal is instead being governed by the industry's own voluntary guidelines, which involve the crop being chopped up into small pieces and ploughed back into the soil. GM oil seed rape being used in the trials has to be disposed of in deep landfill sites under stricter government rules.

Mr Rainbird said there was no scientific support for opponents' fears that GM material from the maize would be transferred to other crops through the soil. Maize grew eight feet tall and putting it in landfill was not a "practical proposition".

GM opponents were furious at the developments. Roger Mainwood, spokesman for Concerned Residents of Wivenhoe in Essex, where a GM maize trial is under way, said: "There is suspicion about the biotech industry's assurances and the method of disposal is potentially hazardous.

"Aventis should opt for the safest method on offer, which is incineration."

 EU scientists will next month consider the implications of the latest research into BSE-like diseases which revealed they may jump between humans and animals more easily than previously supposed and be highly infective even carriers display no obvious symptoms.

webTitle: Football hooligan first to be banned under new law

fields.headline: Football hooligan first to be banned under new law
fields.standfirst: Special report: football violence
fields.trailText: A 21-year-old football hooligan deported from Euro 2000 yesterday became the first person to receive an international ban under controversial new powers.
fields.body:
A 21-year-old football hooligan deported from Euro 2000 yesterday became the first person to receive an international ban under controversial new powers.

Christopher Sawford was served with a court summons when the Football (Disorder) Act came into force on Monday and yesterday was banned by magistrates from domestic and international games.

Sawford, a Swindon warehouse worker, must surrender his passport and report to police at the time of the kick-off of England games, starting with the friendly against France in Paris on Saturday.

Civil liberty campaigners have criticised the law as draconian because those suspected of hooliganism can be banned even if they do not have convictions. Potential suspects are identified by football information officers who help build up evidence, which can include CCTV footage and eyewitness reports.

But the Home Office said it was pleased that the police and courts were using the new powers, introduced after the government was embarrassed by the scenes of violence involving England fans during Euro 2000 - and encouraged them to continue to do so in advance of Saturday's game.

Special courts will be sitting close to ports and main railway stations so that banning orders can be imposed in the run-up to the game, though police have been playing down the chances of trouble.

Sawford was one of dozens of England fans arrested by Belgium police at Euro 2000 on June 16 and deported. Magistrates were yesterday told of his history of violence while following England and Swindon Town. He has two convictions, dating back to 1996 and 1998, for threatening behaviour at a football match.

Yesterday Sawford was banned from every domestic game in England and Wales and every England match, home or away, for two years.

He will have to surrender his passport at least five days before England play abroad and failure to do so will mean up to six months' imprisonment and a fine of up to £5,000.

Sawford was not at his family's smart semi-detached house in the suburb of Fresh brook, Swindon, last night.

His mother, Ann, insisted: "He's just been tarred with the same brush as the rest of them, even though he has done nothing wrong. He's always been a good boy and has never given us any problems."

There are several other laws already in place - such as the Football Offences and Disorder Act - which can ban fans from games as long as they have convictions for football violence. Under those laws there are currently 115 international and 474 domestic bans in place.

The campaign group Liberty has described the legislation as "ill thought out and hastily constructed" and suggested that it would be open to challenge under human rights legislation.

webTitle: Chaos as French ports are blockaded

fields.headline: Chaos as French ports are blockaded
fields.standfirst: Fishermen's protest traps thousands of holidaymakers
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of British holidaymakers were stranded on both sides of the Channel yesterday as French fishermen blockaded ports in protest at escalating fuel prices.
fields.byline: Sarah Hall, Keith Perry  and  Jon Henley  in Paris
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of British holidaymakers were stranded on both sides of the Channel yesterday as French fishermen blockaded ports in protest at escalating fuel prices.

The ports of Calais, St Malo, Dunkirk, Boulogne and Cherbourg were paralysed by the action, which the ferry companies fear will last for at least five days.

In Britain, thousands of people were forced to wait throughout the day in the hope of finding alternative routes.

Among the worst hit were the 299 passengers on board Brittany Ferries' Bretagne, who, after a journey lasting more than 11 hours, found they were not in their destination of St Malo but back in Portsmouth.

The ferry had hoped to beat the blockade, which began in Cherbourg on Tuesday lunchtime, but was forced to turn back after seeing that the Cherbourg peninsula was snarled up.

Back in Britain, the passengers were advised to drive 130 miles to Folkestone in Kent to try to cross via Eurotunnel, or wait in the hope of catching a Portsmouth to Caen ferry 12 hours later.

The prospect of postponing their holidays by up to 30 hours brought outrage from frustrated holidaymakers. "We've saved for five years for this holiday and were only going away for 10 days but now we've already lost two days of it," said Ellis Viner, 27, a paramedic who awoke believing he was in France. "It seems ludicrous to get us all the way to France and then turn around."

Andrew Dutch, 37, from Sheffield, said: "I've just cycled for two days to get here from Sheffield and I don't want to spend another day cycling to Folkestone to catch the shuttle. But I might have to at this rate."

Sitting in a deckchair in front of her caravan at the Portsmouth ferry terminal, Pauline Ellis, 54, could barely contain her anger at the indefinite postponement of her French holiday. She said: "Portsmouth car park is not exactly my idea of the Loire valley."

The turmoil saw ferry companies scrambling to divert their ships to alternative routes. P&O Stena Line - with 30,000 passengers a day using its Dover to Calais route - replaced its four departures to Calais with one to Zeebrugge; and P&O Portsmouth swapping its five departures to Cherbourg for one to Le Havre.

SeaFrance, which had one ferry trapped in Calais harbour and its two others on standby in Dover, cancelled all 30 crossings and offered to pay for its 2,200 passengers to make their way via Eurotunnel.

Hoverspeed suspended its Seacat services to Boulogne, though its Dover to Calais route was running.

For the 800 people trying to reach St Malo from Poole or Weymouth, via Condor Ferries, there seemed little chance of reaching France swiftly, however: all ferries are to terminate in the Channel Islands, while passengers stranded in St Malo were being advised just to "sit it out."

"If you tell people to go to other ports, you're just passing the problem on," explained Nick Dobbs, its marketing manager. "The problem is, at this time of year - the end of the summer holidays - we have a far greater volume of people trying to get back to Britain than to leave, and if they all go to other ports they'll just face more queues. All we can do is keep them best informed."

As Kent police turned part of the M20 into a lorry park, and traffic destined for Dover faced 90-minute delays, many of the 48,000 passengers who had been planning to travel on the Dover-Calais route, and the 10,000 from Portsmouth to Cherbourg, were diverted to the Eurotunnel terminals - where an extra train, with room for 170 cars, was laid on each hour.

But, with P&O, SeaFrance and Brittany Ferries all having contracts enabling passengers to use the service, there were fears last night that delays could prove excessive.

There were also concerns that the problem would escalate if the blockade continued, as the fishermen warned, throughout the weekend. "Any delays are going to get worse as the week goes on because it's the end of the school holidays and more and more people are coming back," said Penny Guy, of P&O Portsmouth. Three times the number of holidaymakers are trying to make their way back to Britain compared to the number leaving for late breaks in France.

With this in mind, P&O Stena Line was last night pinning its hopes on gaining an injunction against the blockaders. Awaiting the application - to be heard in a court in Boulogne - Chris Laming, spokesman for P&O Stena, said: "The rumours circulating around Calais at the moment say that the fishermen are planning to be there for five days. Clearly, it is something we do not want to live with and we are doing all we can."

But the fishermen - pushing for the untaxed fuel price for fishermen to be cut to 1.20 francs (12p) per litre from 2.10 francs (21p)-remain determined. They are holding a protest march in Paris and plan to meet the fisheries minister, Jean Glavany, today.

As Kent police turned part of the M20 into a lorry park, and traffic destined for Dover faced 90-minute delays, many of the 48,000 passengers who had been planning to travel on the Dover-Calais route, and the 10,000 from Portsmouth to Cherbourg, were diverted to the Eurotunnel terminals - where an extra train, with room for 170 cars, was laid on each hour. But, with P&O, SeaFrance and Brittany Ferries all having contracts enabling passengers to use the service, there were fears last night that delays could prove excessive. There were also concerns that the problem would escalate if the blockade continued, as the fishermen warned, throughout the weekend. "Any delays are going to get worse as the week goes on because it's the end of the school holidays and more and more people are coming back," said Penny Guy, of P&O Portsmouth. Three times the number of holidaymakers are trying to make their way back to Britain compared to the number leaving for late breaks in France. With this in mind, P&O Stena Line was last night pinning its hopes on gaining an injunction against the blockaders. Awaiting the application - to be heard in a court in Boulogne - Chris Laming, spokesman for P&O Stena, said: "The rumours circulating around Calais at the moment say that the fishermen are planning to be there for five days. Clearly, it is something we do not want to live with and we are doing all we can." But the fishermen - pushing for the untaxed fuel price for fishermen to be cut to 1.20 francs (12p) per litre from 2.10 francs (21p)-remain determined. They are holding a protest march in Paris and plan to meet the fisheries minister, Jean Glavany, today.

fields.headline: Clinton security scare in Colombia
fields.trailText: A security scare overshadowed President Clinton's arrival in the Colombian port of Cartagena yesterday when police discovered sticks of dynamite in a flat near a building the president was due to visit.
fields.body:
A security scare overshadowed President Clinton's arrival in the Colombian port of Cartagena yesterday when police discovered sticks of dynamite in a flat near a building the president was due to visit.

Two men, suspected of being members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc), the country's largest guerrilla force, were arrested and anti-American leaflets seized. Colombian police said the explosives, weighing about 4.4lb, had not been made up into a bomb.

In a separate incident, security staff sealed off an area of the city after finding a suspicious device, which later turned out to be a bag of rubbish.

The visit was intended as a show of support for Colombian president Andres Pastrana's efforts to defeat the drugs trade and bring peace to the country after nearly 40 years of civil war violence.

A wave of guerrilla attacks and street protests were launched to coincide with the visit. Leftist rebels detonated a car bomb and launched attacks on police stations, army posts and banks, but most of the violence was hundreds of miles away from Cartagena, where the two presidents met to discuss anti-narcotics policy.

Around 200 Farc guerrillas launched a daylight raid on the town of Miranda in the southern state of Cauca. In a separate attack, five civilians were killed when Farc rebels rained homemade bombs on the town of Lavateca near the border with Venezuela.

The centre of Bogota was paralysed as around 2,000 students, union members and indigenous activists marched on the US embassy. Masked students skirmished with riot police and set a bus on fire.

The city was seen as too dangerous a location for talks with Colombian officials, and Mr Clinton was guarded by 5,000 Colombian troops, 350 US agents, helicopter gunships and a naval patrol boat during his visit.

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.trailText: An internet service provider is expected to be the next item on Redstone Telecom's shopping list.
fields.body:
An internet service provider is expected to be the next item on Redstone Telecom's shopping list.

Management of the ambitious group, which provides voice services to smaller firms, is understood to be looking for such a purchase to coincide with the launch of its digital subscriber line broadband service.

Redstone released strong first-quarter results yesterday and also said its broadband coverage of the small to medium-sized business sector would now be 20% of the national market - greater than it had anticipated.

Broadband will enable the delivery of high-speed data and internet services which Redstone will be offering from July next year.

The company is planning to install its own equipment on BT's local exchanges to serve its 9,500 customers.

Redstone has invested £75m into its broadband strategy and has a healthy appetite for building its customer base via acquisition. It has made five takeovers since March, including data group Fastnet for £40m.

Investors have been impressed by management's ability to raise capital, more difficult since the decline of some hi-tech stocks.

Redstone also has a £50m credit facility with UBS Warburg. Milan Radia, an analyst at Warburg's, predicts the company could spent up to £20m on buying a business-focused ISP to strengthen its appeal to investors.

The group yesterday reported that pre-tax losses in the quarter to June 30 had doubled to £2.9m. But turnover was higher than analysts were expecting - up 144% to £17.8m.

Redstone's gross margin leapt 60% to £800,000 while it managed to keep borrowings at a respectable £4.4m.

Shares in Redstone soared to £10.30 in March, riding the crest of the market's love affair with hi-tech stocks. Yesterday it was 16.5p higher at 214p. Redstone is making itself into a one-stop shop, and in the long term is likely to be a takeover target. Buy.

fields.headline: Consumers brace for car trouble
fields.standfirst: Ford, VW and others may be heading down the tobacco road to epic class action lawsuits
fields.trailText: After tobacco it could be the motor industry that feels the lash of consumer activist court action, judging by a wave of safety scares to have hit Ford and other vehicle and component manufacturers.
fields.body:
After tobacco it could be the motor industry that feels the lash of consumer activist court action, judging by a wave of safety scares to have hit Ford and other vehicle and component manufacturers.

A Californian court has ruled in favour of complaints that Ford knowingly installed defective ignition mechanisms in nearly 2m vehicles between 1983 and 1995. In a preliminary decision an Alameda county judge said he would issue an order "compelling recall and repair" of the cars which some estimate could cost Ford up to $250m.

The company says it will appeal, a spokeswoman adding: "In 18 years there has never been any evidence proving any accident or injury."

Ford chief executive Jacques Nasser has also come under fire from a US congressman for failing to appear before a House committee investigating the recall of 6.5m Firestone tyres. Shares in Japan's Bridgestone, maker of Firestone tyres in the US, hit a five-year low yesterday , affected by the investigation, calls for a wider recall of tyres and possible criminal charges in Venezuela.

Mitsubishi, Japan's fourth largest car maker in which DaimlerChrysler is buying a stake, has been downgraded by credit agencies as fears spread of the financial fallout from a customer complaints scandal which has led to more than a million cars being recalled, including some in Britain.

Potential problems

The furore led to police raids on Mitsubishi offices at the weekend, warnings about possible court action by the transport ministry and speculation that company president Katsuhiko Kawasoe could be forced to resign. The company has admitted to covering up customer complaints for more than 30 years to avoid the cost of recall.

Volkswagen of Germany said last night it was recalling 43,889 of its popular Golf model for repairs to brakes.

The level of recalls and safety scares has been growing. Last summer Ford had to recall 5,800 all-terrain Explorer vehicles because of potential problems with cruise control cables.

In spring 1999 BMW recalled 200,000 cars because of faulty radiator caps which could have filled car interiors with steam, and asked for checks on 280,000 of its 3-series cars because of an airbag fault.

Toyota recalled nearly 800,000 cars last year because of a faulty connection in the suspension which could make them almost undriveable.

But product recalls are not restricted to motor manufacturers. On Tuesday Intel, whose processors are used in 80% of personal computers worldwide, was forced to recall of its latest chip after finding it did not perform as it should. Last year the company recalled its 820 chipset due to a design fault.

None of the setbacks has proved fatal for the company involved and thecosts are relatively minor. But the impact on a brand's reputation is another matter, and that price increases exponentially if there are suggestions the company knew of a problem but tried to hush it up.

Clarence Ditlowof the Center for Auto Safety, a consumer activist group in Washington, notes that the court case in California comes at a bad time because Ford has been boasting in television commercials: "Trust us, we put safety first." According to Mr Ditlow, the court decision says of Ford: "We put profits first."

Why are these cases growing in volume? The increasing technological complexity of cars might be one factor but many industry experts are convinced that the car companies are just following a route already travelled by asbestos and tobacco groups.

Tougher government regulation and - more importantly - consumer activism put the chemical and cigarette producers into the US courts with class actions and product liability claims.

"No win no pay" offers from lawyers have encouraged millions of consumers to pursue companies through the courts. There are signs that lawyers are begining to target the motor manufacturers.

Deluge of actions

Mr Ditlow is convinced that if Ford does eventually lose the California court case it will open the floodgates to a deluge of other actions.

"Like the tobacco companies before them, car companies have had their heads in the sand. They are about to get a rude awakening."

webTitle: Market forces: Hi-techs save the day

fields.headline: Hi-techs save the day
fields.trailText: The ring of so-called TMT stocks (technology, media and telecoms), so familiar during the internet bubble, returned to save the London market yesterday, helping the FTSE 100 index close at a three-month high of 6,615.1.
fields.body:
The ring of so-called TMT stocks (technology, media and telecoms), so familiar during the internet bubble, returned to save the London market yesterday, helping the FTSE 100 index close at a three-month high of 6,615.1.

The benchmark indicator added 28.8 points, after rising as much as 40 points during the day. It was the highest close since June 2, when the index stood at 6,626.4.

Trading volume was some 1.4bn shares, higher than dealers expected for the period between bank holidays in Britain and America. However, losers outnumbered gainers by three to two.

CMG, the Anglo-Dutch computer services company, led the increase for the software sector. The stock rose 157p to £12.85 yesterday after the company issued better than expected first-half profits and issued a positive trading statement.

The increase helped other software companies, including Sema, which was up 88.5p to £13.11 and Logica, which closed 115p higher at £20.46.

Baltimore Technologies, the computer security firm, initially fell during the day from 770p to a low of 735p as it issued a denial that it is in takeover talks with Microsoft, (such was speculation across the Atlantic earlier this week) but it recovered to close at 779p, or 9p higher.

Telecoms were also buoyant throughout the day, as were oil and gas shares.

Vodafone reached a high of 277.5p before slipping to end 0.25p lower at 272.75p.

The initial excitement followed reports of a two-year contract with the government's central purchasing office.

Vodafone said that the deal would give it access to more than 100,000 mobile phone users. The agreement is reported to replace contracts with individual departments and covers everybody from administrators to ministers.

BT managed to hold on to its strong gains yesterday, closing up 26p at 852p.

Followers pointed to a flurry of bargain hunting by one or two institutions.

Redstone Telecom, which provides telecoms to small and medium-sized enterprises, also moved higher yesterday, rising 23p to 220.5p. The company yesterday said it was accelerating the roll-out of its British network and stepping up plans to link with operators in mainland Europe.

Bank stocks declined yester day, with Standard Chartered leading the way down. The shares ended 32p lower at 978p.

HSBC, however, finished the day up 1p at 982p.

Freeserve continued to slide, down more than 5%, or 13p, at 239p, on speculation that it will leave the FTSE 100 at the next quarterly reshuffle.

Rolls-Royce, which is also expected to fall out of the lead index on September 9, saw its shares climb 2.5p to 188p, on the back of winning further contracts.

Shares in the needleless syringe maker Medisys added 11.5p to 132.5p, following reports that pharmaceutical company Johnson & Johnson could make a bid.

One salesman pointed out that Johnson & Johnson does not usually make hostile bids, adding that Medisys did not appear to be in a mood to sell out.

Over on the AIM there were rumours that data storage specialist Intechnology, unchanged at 382.5p yesterday, is preparing a move to a full listing.

The shares have climbed almost 23 times since listing in March and are one of the best performers of the year. With a value of £520m it is now the second-biggest company on the AIM.

However, with Peter Wilkinson - the architect of Freeserve and driving force behind Sports Internet - and entrepreneur Chris Akers holding most of the shares, institutions are finding it difficult to buy into the company. A move to a more visible market and an accompanying rights issue looks likely.

Parthus positioned

Irish chip designer Parthus Technologies yesterday saw its share price rise almost 17%, or 39p, to 272p. Parthus has launched a product which can pinpoint the whereabouts of a mobile phone within 10 seconds, and yesterday announced it has licensed the technology to chip designer ARM Holdings.

The sharp rise in the shares was underlined by a US federal communications commission ruling that all mobiles must carry positioning systems by next year. Wireless carriers must give mobile phones the capacity to reveal the location of emergency 911 calls by October 1 2001; Brussels is expected to set a similar deadline for capacity in Europe.

Parthus, which licenses its chip designs allowing users to access the web on mobile devices, said that NavStream - which is based on the global positioning navigation system - would enable mobile devices to be traced no matter where they were.
