fields.headline: Sizing up
fields.standfirst: M&S's £20m advertising refit
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is launching its first substantial television advertising drive, with a planned campaign budget of £20m, in an effort to revive the retailer's flagging fortunes.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is launching its first substantial television advertising drive, with a planned campaign budget of £20m, in an effort to revive the retailer's flagging fortunes.

The first two ads, created by agency Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R, will be broadcast next Friday.

They will promote both the autumn clothing range, and the new "fit for you" women's sizing - sparked by a survey showing that women have become taller and more curvaceous during the past decade.

One ad sees a larger woman undressing as she runs up a hill in celebration of the fact that she can buy clothes in her size. The other features three women "secretly" looking forward to autumn as it will give them an excuse to change their wardrobe.

M&S has used TV advertising only a few times before - and then to announce store openings.

Matthew Chambers, head of external marketing, believes the company has been guilty of running too many individual campaigns simultaneously, confusing the message to customers.

Last year alone there were 96, mainly in the press, with 33 between September and December. Analysts said last night they were encouraged by the promotional efforts but questioned whether they had come too early.

The company's management, they said, was still facing important decisions about future direction. Nathan Cockrell of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said: "It's sensible to improve perception but at the same time it risks positioning the business in a place where it might not end up.

"Marks is going to have to ask itself some very serious questions about what its brand stands for in the coming months."

The sizing study, which was commissioned by M&S, found that the average UK size was between 14 and 16.

This, the retailer claimed, was due to an increasing taste for savoury snacks and fast food, coupled with a lack of exercise and use of the contraceptive pill, which M&S says is "proven to cause weight gain".

The early ads, to be supported by poster and press promotion, are aimed at women - but they will be followed by further campaigns across the product range. M&S's share price rose 0.25p to 208.25p yesterday, well off its 336.5p high.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: RBS failures costs £410,000
fields.body:
RBS failures costs £410,000

Royal Bank of Scotland has paid £410,000 in fines and compensation after regulatory failures in administering personal equity plan and institutional investment accounts.

The Investment Management Regulatory Organisation fined the bank £100,000 plus £60,000 in costs on two charges of failing to arrange proper protection of assets belonging to customers.

And RBS is to pay around £250,000 to the 4,000 investors involved - an average of £62.50 each. The offences occurred between October 1996 and November 1998. RBS sold the businesses involved in October 1999.

Channel Tunnel faces lawsuit

The owners of the Channel Tunnel are to face high court allegations that they made false claims over leases of terminals in the UK and France.

BAA and World Duty Free (Europe) are suing them for damages for alleged misrepresentation and breach of undertakings after taking out a sub-lease of the passenger terminal buildings, part of the club lounges and freight buildings on both sides of the channel.

They claim that the Channel Tunnel Group and France-Manche induced them to enter into a written contract in March last year through misrepresentation and are asking the court to set aside the agreements.

Britannic buys First Active

Insurance group Britannic made another acquisition yesterday, taking a 60% stake in the mortgage arm of Irish bank First Active for £57m.

The insurer said the acquisition would be used to win a foothold in the flexible mortgage market. The announcement of the deal, which follows its purchases of Britannia Asset Management and Britannic Life, was made in conjunction with a 15% rise in pre-tax operating profits to £96.4m.

Murdoch arm closes website

Rupert Murdoch's News International is preparing further cutbacks to its beleaguered internet division by closing parenting portal Learnfree.co.uk.

Insiders at News International say the site is set to be suspended at the end of next month if a buyer cannot be found.

TSL, the News International division responsible for Learnfree, is thought to have held talks with Freeserve, AOL and Tesco.com about a possible sale of the website.

fields.headline: New car prices fall by 5%
fields.trailText: New X-registration car buyers driving off forecourts from midnight tonight will be paying prices on average 4.9% below those of a year ago, according to the latest Alliance & Leicester car price index.
fields.body:
New X-registration car buyers driving off forecourts from midnight tonight will be paying prices on average 4.9% below those of a year ago, according to the latest Alliance & Leicester car price index.

But despite the fall in prices, car sales remain static. The motor industry is forecasting sales of 370,000 to 400,000 X-reg cars this September, compared to 400,000 last September, when the V-plate was introduced, and 370,000 for the W-plate in March.

Buyers are holding back in the belief that prices have further to fall, says A&L.

Its figures show that the fall in car prices accelerated in July from the 4.6% decrease recorded in June.

The sharpest fall has been among MPVs such as Land Rovers and Ford Galaxys, where prices are now 15.4% lower than a year ago. Family cars such as Ford Mondeos and Vauxhall Vectras registered an average fall of 8.1%. Only luxury cars and so-called superminis recorded prices rises, but in both categories the increase is below 1%.

The downward pressure on prices is expected to strengthen from tomorrow, when a DTI pricing order comes into force.

The order will force car manufacturers to give the public the same bulk discounts enjoyed by fleet buyers, and was provoked by a competition commission report last December showing that UK car prices were 10% higher than in mainland Europe.

It will also prevent manufacturers discriminating against dealers who advertise cars below recommended prices or who source cars from the European mainland.

Doug McWilliams, of the Centre for Economic and Business Research, said: "The falls in car prices that the A&L index is measuring is part of a trend in falling prices for many consumer goods such as household appliances.

"But we have a lot further to go, and I would expect to see new car prices fall faster over the next year than in the past 12 months."

Used car prices have slumped even more than those for new cars. The A&L index shows that prices for nearly new cars, up to one year old, fell by 17% in the year to July, while used cars up to three years old, fell by 18.8%.

webTitle: Mr 20% defends fall in Rentokil profits

fields.headline: Mr 20% defends fall in Rentokil profits
fields.standfirst: Market unconvinced by chief's assurances
fields.trailText: Rentokil Initial - famed in the City for its 20% growth targets until last year - yesterday reported a sharp downturn in first-half profits but said the future looked bright, and that it would be boosted by a £1.5bn war chest.
fields.body:
Rentokil Initial - famed in the City for its 20% growth targets until last year - yesterday reported a sharp downturn in first-half profits but said the future looked bright, and that it would be boosted by a £1.5bn war chest.

Chief executive Sir Clive Thompson, who stepped down as president of the Confederation of British Industry last month, claimed the support services company had turned the corner: "I see this as a born again Rentokil," he added.

The market remained unconvinced - with Rentokil shares having increased only 0.5p at 161.5p despite having underperformed the support services sector by 45% over the last 12 months.

The group posted pre-tax profits of £207.5m in the six months to June 30 compared with £253m last time on turnover of £1.4bn, up 2%. Pre-tax and pre-exceptional profits reached £200.5m, significantly lower than analysts had expected, but the dividend was raised from 1.2p to 1.3p.

The biggest fall in profits was at the parcels delivery systems division, where there was a 30% downturn to £9.8m. But profits also slipped over 6% in the company's core areas of hygiene, security and management services, where the company believes much of its prosperous future lies.

The company argued that specific initiatives - such as heavy new investment in parcels infrastructure along with additional spending on sales and marketing throughout the group - had depressed earnings. It pointed out that overall annual figures would be bolstered by £600m of disposals, which had helped it buy back £1bn of its own low- rated shares, amounting to 20% of its equity capital.

Sir Clive said he was willing to spend up to £1.5bn on more acquisitions of a range of sizes and in different geographical areas or otherwise engage in further share buybacks.

Yesterday he announced the purchase of TruGreen Interior Plantcare, the second largest US plant services group, for £30m in cash.

Many analysts were disappointed with the results, and said future success could not be taken on trust.

Mike Murphy at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney said: "The market is going to wait and see that there is some tangible evidence for some good organic growth before it rerates the stock."

ABN Amro urged investors to sell, but UBS Warburg said "buy". Most analysts are pencilling in a second-half profits of £226. Rentokil has been through a turbulent period since March 1999 when it missed its 20% growth targets for the first time in 17 years.

That disappointment caused the shares to slide from 470p to 116p this year, leaving Rentokil the FTSE 100's worst performer in 1999.

Sir Clive - who was once nicknamed Mr 20%- was accused of taking his eye off the ball when he joined the CBI's top table.

Yesterday he insisted he was 250% concentrating on his company, and he expected success to come with that.

"I always said that I gave 100% of my time to Rentokil in the last two years. I stepped down as president of the CBI on July 18, and certainly the comeback starts here as far as I am concerned - and as far as Rentokil is concerned," he said. Sir Clive was particularly optimistic about the company's prospects for 2001.

"We expect that in 2001 core businesses will show accelerating turnover growth together with growth in profits," he said.

webTitle: Job fears ease at Welsh steel plant

fields.headline: Job fears ease at Welsh steel plant
fields.standfirst: £35m Llanwern plan agreed in principle but under constant review
fields.trailText: Corus, Europe's largest steel group, yesterday announced a £35m plan to secure the future of its Llanwern plant in south Wales but warned that the project could be aborted at any time.
fields.body:
Corus, Europe's largest steel group, yesterday announced a £35m plan to secure the future of its Llanwern plant in south Wales but warned that the project could be aborted at any time.

The group said it had agreed in principle to reline the plant's No 3 blast furnace and that contractual discussions with suppliers of materials and services would start shortly.

But it added that the project, due to be completed in September next year, would be subject to continuous review to ensure that it remained in the group's wider interest.

Union officials had warned that failure to reline the furnace, which can produce up to 41,000 tonnes of steel a week, could lead the the closure of the whole plant and the loss of 3,000 jobs.

Nick Cragg, managing director of Corus Strip Products, said: "Corus continues to face difficult trading conditions in the UK, sterling remains strong and market pressures are increasing.

"In these circumstances, it is difficult to take a very long-term view, especially on a multi-million pound investment and hence the need for the ongoing review."

Corus has been struggling to cope with the strong pound on its British plants. It has already announced plans to axe nearly 4,000 jobs in Britain, including 450 at Llanwern.

Officials of the ISTC steel union said yesterday's announcement reaffirmed the company's faith in Welsh steelmaking and had "lifted a cloud of doom from Llanwern".

Michael Leahy, the ISTC general secretary, backed calls by Corus's chief executive, John Bryant, for government help over the strong pound and high electricity prices.

He said: "We do understand Corus when it says the decision is subject to the ongoing review of their business. But this decision is a very positive step forward."

But union and political celebrations could be premature. Corus also said that the Llanwern works would have to achieve "a more competitive cost base" if its current plant configuration was to continue.

Business and political leaders in Wales welcomed the announcement but recognised that more remained to be done to persuade the steel maker to commit itself to the long-term future of the plant.

webTitle: Zenith's auction set to be a hit

fields.headline: Zenith's auction set to be a hit
fields.standfirst: £30m tag on Morse company
fields.trailText: The consolidation of the television production industry is set to continue over the next few weeks through the auction of Zenith Entertainment, the business behind Morse, Hamish Macbeth and SMTV, the cult Saturday morning children's show.
fields.body:
The consolidation of the television production industry is set to continue over the next few weeks through the auction of Zenith Entertainment, the business behind Morse, Hamish Macbeth and SMTV, the cult Saturday morning children's show.

Zenith, formerly the production business of Central Independent Television, is expected to sell at around £30m.

The increasing value put on content providers by large media concerns has been a boon to independent production companies. RTL, the pan-European TV group, recently paid £60m for Talkback Productions, the firm founded by comedians Griff Rhys Jones and Mel Smith. The Television Corporation paid £25m for Mentorn Barraclough Carey.

Steve Matthews, chief executive of Zenith, said the company's venture capital owners had decided to sell after receiving several offers in the past six months. "Anyone with a proven track record and a portfolio of high quality content that could be used across a wide range of platforms is very valuable," he said.

United Productions, part of Lord Hollick's United News & Media, had made an approach to Zenith, but the talks ended after United agreed to sell the bulk of its television assets to Granada Media last month.

Bidders are expected to include Granada and Dutch production group Endemol.

For TV, Zenith makes drama, factual programmes, shows for children - including Byker Grove - and entertainment. Feature films have included Velvet Goldmine, Prick up Your Ears and Wish You Were Here.

The venture capital firms which own it include Fleming Investment Trust, US-based Paul Capital Partners, and Task Holdings, the UK arm of the Oppenheimer family trust.

fields.headline: Scaled up
fields.standfirst: Fish! concept to go nationwide
fields.trailText: BGR, the restaurant chain best known for its Fish! brand in London, is to roll out the concept across the country.
fields.body:
BGR, the restaurant chain best known for its Fish! brand in London, is to roll out the concept across the country.

Reporting a strong set of interim figures yesterday, the company also said that after two months of talks it was close to selling its upmarket Bank and Zander restaurants in London and Birmingham.

The likely buyer is a private consortium which includes Lee Collins, co-founder of the Collins Stewart stockbroking firm, and the price on offer is around £10m.

With new Fish! diners at Canary Wharf, Battersea and County Hall, opposite the Houses of Parliament, pre-tax profits rose 10% to £1.1m on turnover up 13% at £10.5m in the six months to April 30.

Chairman Tony Allan said a string of development sites had been identified, with the first regional ventures to open shortly in Birmingham and Guildford. He believes Fish! "undoubtedly has national brand potential".

webTitle: More ways than one to unlock Europe

fields.headline: More ways than one to unlock Europe
fields.standfirst: Alternatives to simple M&A
fields.trailText: News that Axa was to unload its stake in US investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette sparked the predictable flurry of rumours about what it would do with the proceeds. Italy's Generali was the name most often mentioned, though some thoughts were directed towards the Spanish insurance market.
fields.body:
News that Axa was to unload its stake in US investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette sparked the predictable flurry of rumours about what it would do with the proceeds. Italy's Generali was the name most often mentioned, though some thoughts were directed towards the Spanish insurance market.

Axa has come up with a much neater solution. Instead of looking for further geographical expansion, the French insurer is using the proceeds from the sale of the DLJ stake to Credit Suisse to help fund the acquisition of the minority stake in Axa Financial - the 60% owned subsidiary through which Axa held its DLJ stake. As a result US earnings are now likely to be steadier, if occasionally less spectacular.

Judging by the immediate share-price reaction Axa's strategy of buying more of what it already had was received with a certain degree of disappointment - a sign these days of the expectations on big European players to do big cross-border deals.

In a sense the battle for the London Stock Exchange is an indication of the pressure building up behind pan-European sentiment and the difficulty of actually doing something about it.

There is a risk, however, that the pan-European debate is becoming too narrowly focused - UK company X buys Germany company Y or French company A buys Spanish company B. There have been examples of conventional merger and acquisition activity: Vodafone-Mannesmann and France Telecom-Orange spring to mind. But there are other routes, too. The decision of the big telecoms players to splash out billions of pounds on building up pan-European portfolios of third-generation mobile phone licences is an example - albeit it one with a rather limited constituency.

Other alternatives are capable of wider application. Take, for example, Commerzbank. Though the German bank has flirted with a domestic merger and been put under pressure to pull off a cross-border merger, its board has generally preferred operational cooperation to corporate consolidation. Next week, if the buzz in Frankfurt is to be believed, it is expected to announced that it is tightening its links with its preferred European partners, Generali and BSCH by issuing shares which will double the size of their holdings to about the 10% level. While part of the thinking behind such a move would clearly be defensive - two friendly shareholders with 20% of the equity would represent a formidable takeover barrier - it should presage closer links at the customer level, too.

Others might do well to ponder the virtues of gradualism when it comes to pan-European expansion. An incremental approach may lack the excitement of blockbuster acquisitions but that does not necessarily mean it is ineffectual.

Staff costs

The scale of a problem in the investment banking industry can usually be judged by the amount of money thrown at it. On that score Credit Suisse is clearly concerned the impact of its acquisition of DLJ on staff there. It is setting aside $1.2bn (£822m) in retention bonuses for DLJ staff - equivalent to more than 10% of the purchase price.

The investment banking industry has seen a number of recent examples where institutions have been forced to pay out heavily to retain key staff at times of merger-inspired change. The evidence is not overwhelming that such tactics work but in a world where dot.coms have come to be seen as a faster route to riches than even Wall Street bonuses banks are reluctant to take the risk.

Catch-22

The European Central Bank is facing a no-win situation when it decides today whether or not to raise interest rates and if so by how much. Whatever its decision, the foreign exchange markets will almost certainly give it the thumbs down. If it fails to raise rates the markets will take the view that the bank is all talk when it comes to being tough on inflation. If it raises rates 25 basis points the markets will most likely say it has not done enough but if the ECB takes the bull by the horns and opts for a 50 basis point increase then it will be perceived by many to have overdone the tightening and risks choking off growth in key areas of the euroland economy.

The reason the ECB cannot win is that the markets like selling the euro. Just as it was once axiomatic that you never got sacked for selling sterling, so the single currency has become the foreign exchange's favourite target - that has been the way to make money since the euro was launched at the start of last year.

Like most of us, foreign exchange traders are reluctant to give up on a good thing. Whatever the ECB decides will be seen as a "sell the euro" signal. As at least some of euroland's central bankers are beginning to realise, perceptions about the euro weakness have become firmly entrenched and it will take something seismic to shift them.

fields.headline: Siamese twins' parents launch appeal
fields.trailText: The parents of Siamese twins are to launch an appeal against a high court decision that the sisters be separated even though the operation will result in the death of one, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The parents of Siamese twins are to launch an appeal against a high court decision that the sisters be separated even though the operation will result in the death of one, it was announced yesterday.

Three high court judges will consider on Monday the argument from the parents, based on their strong religious principles, that nature should be allowed to take its course.

Last Friday Mr Justice Johnson gave the go-ahead for surgeons to operate on the sisters, who were given the false names Jodie and Mary to preserve their anonymity.

It was thought that the twins, born in Manchester on August 8, would be operated on within days because doctors believed delaying the 12-hour procedure could increase the risk. But since then the parents and the official solicitor, who has been acting on behalf of the weaker twin, Mary, have been deciding whether to challenge the ruling.

Yesterday solicitors Pannone & Partners, acting for the parents, confirmed that an appeal had been lodged and appealed for the parents to be left alone. "Everyone is asked to respect the wish for privacy at what is a tragic and sensitive time," said a spokesman.

The hearing will be heard in open court by Lord Justice Ward, Lord Justice Brooke and Lord Justice Robert Walker. It is not known if the parents will give evidence.

In a previous hearing the father began to give evidence via a video link but broke down and could not go on.

The parents came to Britain for the birth from a remote community in an unidentified European country which lacks sophisticated medical facilities. The girls were born joined at the lower abdomen at St Mary's hospital in Manchester.

Doctors believe that if the twins are separated Jodie will have a good chance of a normal life while Mary, who relies on her twin for her blood supply, will die. Without an operation, it is thought both girls would die within six months.

In a previous hearing the father began to give evidence via a video link but broke down and could not go on. The parents came to Britain for the birth from a remote community in an unidentified European country which lacks sophisticated medical facilities. The girls were born joined at the lower abdomen at St Mary's hospital in Manchester. Doctors believe that if the twins are separated Jodie will have a good chance of a normal life while Mary, who relies on her twin for her blood supply, will die. Without an operation, it is thought both girls would die within six months.

fields.headline: Robots create revolution in evolution
fields.standfirst: From Terminator to swarms of tiny organising robots, science fiction is catching up with science fact
fields.trailText: They may not yet be in control yet, but robots have literally taken on a life of their own. According to a scientific study published today, computers can now design, test and build their own, increasingly efficient automatons, quite independently of human beings.
fields.byline: Julian Borger in Washington and Tim Radford
fields.body:
They may not yet be in control yet, but robots have literally taken on a life of their own. According to a scientific study published today, computers can now design, test and build their own, increasingly efficient automatons, quite independently of human beings.

The breakthrough, described in the latest edition of Nature magazine, suggests that machines will ultimately be capable of "artificial evolution" - mutating, testing and improving their design far faster than living organisms.

If a "race" of computerised robots is ultimately able to reproduce itself independently - the scenario portrayed in the apocalyptic Terminator movies, starring Arnold Schwarzenegger - historians may look back to this moment as its genesis.

Hod Lipson and Jordan Pollack, computer scientists at Brandeis University in Massachusetts, acknowledge concerns about their work but argue "there are many, many further steps before this technology could become dangerous".

Earlier experiments have produced computers which could design virtual robots and put them through simulated tests, but the Brandeis scientists have gone a step further, connecting a robot-designing computer to a fully-automated machine which can rapidly build each design the software suggests.

Commenting on the experiment in Nature, Rodney Brooks, an expert in artificial intelligence at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said: "This is a long awaited and necessary step towards the ultimate dream of self-evolving machines."

Mutations

Mr Lipson and Mr Pollack gave their computer the task of developing a robot that would move along the ground as efficiently as possible. The programme responded by producing designs at random, assessing them, and then introducing small mutations to the design to discover if the changes improved the machine's speed and efficiency - imitating the natural process of evolution. "Typically, several tens of generations passed before the first movement occurred," they said.

Once the computer had "evolved" a moving robot, it tested it in the real world by sending the design to a "rapid prototyping" machine which built it from a versatile plastic. The robots emerged from the machine fully-formed apart from the motors, which had to be snapped into place by the scientists. That was the only part played by humans in the process.

The computer produced several types of robot which used different methods of motion - some moved sideways like crabs, others swung from side to side, another pulled itself along with two limbs.

"Although both the machines and the task that we describe are fairly simple compared with the products of human teams of engineers (and with the products of biological evolution) we have demonstrated a robotic 'bootstrap' process, in which automatically designed electromechanical systems have been manufactured robotically," the report says.

If left to their own devices, computers could evolve far faster than living organisms, generating mutations and testing them against the environment in seconds instead of thousands of years.

"I'm not saying a computer can replace an architect - at least not yet," Mr Pollack told the New York Times recently. "But our computer did start with a simple algorithm and end with blueprints for structures that it took humans hundreds of years to develop. And when we built the structures, they were functional."

Ultimately, he said the technology could be used to build entire factories which would turn out huge numbers of robots "as cheaply as Sony Walkmans".

The Brandeis scientists argue that to attain artificial life, machines have to gain "full autonomy", not only in their behaviour "but also at the levels of design and fabrication". "Only then can we expect synthetic creatures to sustain their own evolution," they wrote in Nature.

Ominously for anyone who has seen the Terminator films, scientists are not only programming computers with the knowledge that allows them to reproduce, they are also teaching them how to organise.

In the same edition of Nature, computer specialists at the University of Lausanne in Switzerland describe how they have taught robots community spirit, by programming them to respond to each other like ants. Based on a few simple "rules" a large group of small robots reportedly displayed "astonishing feats of organisation".

The Swiss scientists found that these insect-like "antbots" were more efficient working in groups than they were individually, and suggest that swarms of them could explore unfamiliar or hostile environments. Putting these two breakthroughs together, in theory, planets could be colonised by robots capable of infinitely reproducing themselves.

Innovations: Guards and gastrobots

 Thai scientists have just unveiled Roboguard, according to an issue of the New Scientist published today. It totes a laser-sighted gun and can track suspects via infrared sensors. It can fire at will, or it can check with a human via the internet before it attacks. So far the fire command is protected by a password.

"We think the decision to fire should always be a human decision," says Pitikhate Sooraksa of King Mongkut's Institute of Technology in Bangkok. "Otherwise it could kill people."

 A Brussels consortium is working on a full-size, autonomous walking robot dinosaur which will stroll round European museums. The creation of the automaton, based on the species Iguanadon atherfieldensis, has involved McNeill Alexander, the British expert on dinosaur biomechanics. But the robot engineers behind the project are stalking a bigger prize: a "walking" rescue machine that could step through minefields, over avalanches or collapsed buildings looking for human survivors.

 A flesh-eating robot called Chew Chew could be the first automaton to be completely powered by food.

The 12-wheeled "gastrobot" was unveiled this month in Hawaii. It uses bacteria to convert food into chemical energy.

Meat is the most efficient fuel, but a gastrobot could even mow lawns and use the clippings for fuel. A Bristol team has designed a slug-eating robot, and suggested that a fish-eating robot could monitor beaches for sharks.

 Scientists from New York and Israel have co-operated on a robot surgeon which performs human knee replacement operations. Of 200,000 knee operations in the US each year, 10% need to be done again because of surgical error. The argument is that a human-monitored robot hand would always be steadier, would work in finer detail, and never get tired. Next step: robots for surgery.

 Delaware scientists have designed Flobot the Robot. It can hover on a cushion of air and use magnetic grippers to grab a moving object while hovering over a table.

 Los Alamos scientists have built tiny little four-legged robots which have been tested on fields of unexploded ordnance. If a leg gets blown off, the robot carries on with only three, or two, or one.

 Carnegie Mellon University scientists have built Nomad, an automaton which will search for meteorites in Antarctica.

webTitle: Head's appeal hears boy telling of plan to 'get her out'

fields.headline: Head's appeal hears boy telling of plan to 'get her out'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A boy who accused a headteacher of slapping him on the face after he was refused permission to go swimming later told police there had been a plan to get her out of the school, according to a recorded police interview shown to Cardiff crown court yesterday.
fields.body:
A boy who accused a headteacher of slapping him on the face after he was refused permission to go swimming later told police there had been a plan to get her out of the school, according to a recorded police interview shown to Cardiff crown court yesterday.

Marjorie Evans is appealing against her conviction by Abergavenny magistrates for common assault, which brought her a sentence of three months' imprisonment suspended for one year. Her appeal is being funded by the National Union of Teachers, whose general secretary, Doug McAvoy, was in court yesterday for the start of the appeal hearing.

In the interview three days after the incident in September 1999, the boy, who was then 10, told police he had told his friends not to tell anyone because it would "ruin the plan". He said: "There was a plan. If I didn't tell anyone she would be out of the school. If I told anyone the plan wouldn't work. The plan was to get her out of the school."

During cross-examination by Greg Taylor, defending, via a video link yesterday, the boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, twice got up from his chair refusing to answer questions. But he insisted that Evans had slapped him.

He said: "There was a red mark on the side of my face. It was a harder slap than I thought it would be."

Christopher Rees, prosecuting, earlier told the hearing that the boy, who has learning difficulties, became sullen after being banned from going swimming with his classmates.

It was the crown's case that Evans was faced with a difficult pupil and momentarily lost her self-control and slapped him across the face.

"The crown says it was a slap that was not administered as lawful correction, that it was not in self-defence, but that it was, plain and simply, an unlawful assault after she had lost her temper."

Evans, 56, of Usk, south Wales, told police that the boy had pushed, punched and headbutted her, but she denied slapping him.

Outside court, Mr McAvoy said he had total confidence that the appeal, before a judge and two magistrates, would result in Evans being cleared.

He said the case had damaged the image of the teaching profession and was putting off young people who wanted to teach. "Unfortunately, these sort of allegations are becoming more and more prevalent."

The case continues today.

webTitle: Tank order may seal Vickers' fate

fields.headline: Tank order may seal Vickers' fate
fields.trailText: Rolls-Royce yesterday strengthened its hand in any sale of its Vickers Defence Systems by tying up a £250m order from the British army for 66 new variants of the Challenger tank.
fields.body:
Rolls-Royce yesterday strengthened its hand in any sale of its Vickers Defence Systems by tying up a £250m order from the British army for 66 new variants of the Challenger tank.

The deal means that the Rolls-Royce group has secured contracts worth more than £850m in the past 24 hours with the aerospace arm selling 37 Trent engines to International Lease Finance Corporation.

The new engineer tanks will be manufactured by Vickers' plant on Tyneside for completion by 2005. There will be two models, the Titan bridge-laying vehicle and the Trojan, used for mine clearance duties.

Both will be built on the same chassis as is used for the Challenger 2 main battle tank and construction is scheduled to start next May.

The orders from the army via the Ministry of Defence are important because they could lead to foreign contracts.

They also leave in a more healthy financial state a division which many observers believe Rolls is eager to sell.

The tank building division is chasing a large order in Greece and analysts believe that if this is secured there will be a determined attempt to dispose of Vickers.

Rolls-Royce is increasingly being focused on its civil and military aerospace, marine and energy divisions.

On Tuesday it stole a march on US rivals General Electric and Pratt & Whitney by winning a £600m order - the first of its kind - to supply engines for a new generation of super-jumbo jets.

The new deals come at a significant time when Rolls-Royce's reputation has taken a battering.

The shares plunged after the company reported last week a 76% fall in interim profits partly as a result of problems with its industrial Trent engines.

On Tuesday the stock was up 10p at 185p and last night it advanced a further 2.5p to 188p.

webTitle: Hume steps back from front line

fields.headline: Hume steps back from front line
fields.standfirst:
SDLP leader and Nobel laureate to bow out of assembly

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: SDLP leader John Hume yesterday took his first step towards retirement from politics after 30 years in the front line when he announced that he would shortly quit the Northern Ireland assembly.
fields.body:
SDLP leader John Hume yesterday took his first step towards retirement from politics after 30 years in the front line when he announced that he would shortly quit the Northern Ireland assembly.

Mr Hume, 63, said he would be resigning his seat at Stormont to concentrate on his work as Foyle MP at Westminster and as one of Northern Ireland's three MEPs. Colleagues insisted yesterday there was no question of him relinquishing his leadership of the party.

But Mr Hume, who won the Nobel peace prize with Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble two years ago, has been dogged by poor health for several years. His schedule is a punishing one.

He underwent emergency surgery for a ruptured intestine exactly a year ago while at a conference in Austria. His condition was much more serious than initially conceded, requiring four operations, and his subsequent fitness regime includes long walks in the Stormont grounds. Mr Hume, who adores the international political stage, had carefully avoided becoming too tied into the assembly, allowing his number two, Seamus Mallon, to play deputy first minister to Mr Trimble in the power-sharing executive. He had declined to take a place on any committee, indicating he would leave when the assembly bedded in.

Although the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, could order a byelection under the assembly rules, it is more likely an SDLP member will be co-opted. Mr Hume's nominated replacement is Annie Coulter, a member of Derry city council.

Mr Hume said last night: "I have become heavily over loaded with work, and I have had serious health problems over the past year. I am leaving now because I have every confidence in the SDLP team in the assembly, and I feel now the new institutions are on a secure footing."

SDLP assembly member Joe Hendron, the former MP for west Belfast, described Mr Hume as one of the greatest Irishmen of the last 200 years. He said: "I am saddened that John has had to cut down on his workload for health reasons. He will be sorely missed on the assembly benches." Mr Hume told party colleagues at Stormont on Tuesday, but gave them no indication of exactly when he would leave the assembly.

Mr Hume was under most intense pressure when news of his developing relationship with the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, leaked at one of the most bloody periods of the troubles. His clandestine talks with Mr Adams led to the IRA ceasefire in August 1994. It broke down in February 1996, but was renewed in July 1997 soon after Tony Blair's general election victory, and Mr Hume was key in negotiating the Good Friday agreement nine months later.

Mr Hume, an ardent Europhile, was a French teacher at his former school, St Columb's college in Londonderry, before becoming involved in the civil rights movement and then in founding the SDLP in 1970. He was one of the first beneficiares of the Education Act, which allowed many Catholics access to grammar schools for the first time.

He is a pragmatic nationalist, and cites his father's warning after he attended one rally as a boy. He said: "You can't eat a flag, son."

Mr Hume was a member of the first Northern Ireland assembly in 1973, and was elected to the European parliament in 1979. He became an MP in 1983, three years after succeeding Gerry Fitt as SDLP leader.

fields.headline: CMG signals software renaissance
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: CMG brought some sparkle back to leading computer services shares yesterday with a strong set of results boosted by rapid growth in its telecoms businesses.
fields.body:
CMG brought some sparkle back to leading computer services shares yesterday with a strong set of results boosted by rapid growth in its telecoms businesses.

Shares in the Anglo-Dutch group jumped nearly 13% to £12.82p and topped the FTSE 100 leader board after it reported better than expected figures for the first six months of the year.

The rise had a ripple effect on shares in Logica and Sema. Both climbed sharply as dealers took CMG's results as a sign that that software firms which experienced a slowdown in IT spending in the wake of Y2K spending were finally returning to health.

By the close of dealings the three stocks, each of which has a strong focus on telecoms, had climbed to highs not seen since technology stocks slumped in April.

Enthusiasm was driven by the performance of CMG's telecoms division and positive comments from chairman Cor Stutterheim about the state of the market, which he had previously described as "dull" and "frosty".

"The improving business climate should feed through to enhanced turnover growth for the second half for our information communications technology services operations," he said.

Pre-tax profits for the six months to June 30 were up 38% on the previous year to £50.9m, while turnover climbed 20% to £349m. The interim dividend increased 38% to 1p per share.

Telecoms provided the real boost, Mr Stutterheim said, with turnover climbing 166% to £60m and operating profit soaring 786% to £18.6m. Much of the growth derived from the popularity of SMS (text messaging), which is doubling in volume every six months, he added.

Analysts say European firms such as CMG and Logica are well placed to capitalise on the worldwide growth in mobile phone sales because of the region's technological lead over the US.

The low point of the results was the performance of Admiral, which CMG bought for £1.4bn earlier this year. "The performance of Admiral was disappointing in the early months of the year due to difficult market conditions but there has been a marked improvement in June and July," Mr Stutterheim said.

 IT services firm Morse Holdings said it also benefited from growth in mobile and e-commerce. Revenues from its recently established wireless development team, set up to help mobile operators deliver content to users, have already started to filter through to the bottom line, chief executive Duncan McIntyre said.

Pre-tax profits for the year to June 30 rose almost £10m to £32.1m, while turnover was up 80% to £506.3m. Morse shares slipped 2.5p to 565p, giving the company a valuation of around £650m.

Revenues from its recently established wireless development team, set up to help mobile operators deliver content to users, have already started to filter through to the bottom line, chief executive Duncan McIntyre said. Pre-tax profits for the year to June 30 rose almost £10m to £32.1m, while turnover was up 80% to £506.3m. Morse shares slipped 2.5p to 565p, giving the company a valuation of around £650m.

webTitle: Homes wrecked as loyalist tit-for-tat violence continues

fields.headline: Homes wrecked as loyalist tit-for-tat violence continues
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The vicious loyalist feud in Northern Ireland yesterday saw two dozen homes attacked in Carrickfergus, Co Antrim, ravaged as neighbour targeted neighbour in a night-long orgy of tit-for-tat raids.
fields.body:
The vicious loyalist feud in Northern Ireland yesterday saw two dozen homes attacked in Carrickfergus, Co Antrim, ravaged as neighbour targeted neighbour in a night-long orgy of tit-for-tat raids.

The Ulster Defence Association and the Ulster Volunteer Force disputed who started the trouble. There were no serious injuries, but several families were left homeless.

Police were again stepping up patrols in the area, north of Belfast. Homes in nearby Greenisland were also attacked. The housing executive said last night that it was trying to rehouse 70 families forced from their homes since the feud began 13 days ago.

Attempts to find a truce between the UDA and UVF on the Shankill Road, where the dispute began, have stalled after Monday night's shooting in Coleraine, Co Londonderry. Charlene Daly, 11, is in hospital after she was hit in the back while watching television with her family.

First minister David Trimble, Ulster Unionist leader, appealed for an end to the feud. But he sounded an ambivalent note over the re-arrest of loyalist leader Johnny Adair nine days ago, calling it akin to internment without trial.

fields.headline: Getting religion
fields.standfirst:
Hague's new-found enthusiasm for the faithful appeals to Muslims as much as to Christians

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Hague's new-found enthusiasm for the faithful appeals to Muslims as much as to Christians.
fields.body:
When I first heard of compassionate conservatism I sniggered, like many others, that it ought to be consigned to that category of oxymorons which includes smart bombs and honest politicians, rather than form part of an electoral campaign.

But there must be some virtue in a philosophy that has gripped the imagination of the US electorate and looks as if it has every chance of taking George W Bush to the White House. William Hague too, appears to be pinning his party's hopes to the same ticket.

Whereas Reagan and Thatcher would have left a slender welfare state to pick up the casualties of trickle-down, comcons (as they are known) would enable and empower the socially excluded to raise their own status.

The welfare functions of the state are better left to those in the community who really care. A compassionate conservative society would have a well-resourced private sector at the heart of which would be churches, faith-based institutions, volunteers and civic-minded corporations managing people's daily lives. This, its proponents claim, is a more moral and efficient way of running society and government. Call it conservatism with a conscience if you like.

You might say that we've been here before with John Major's farcical back to basics. But this isn't a defensive reaction to rein in wayward ministers. It is a proactive approach which places faith and morality at the core of policy-making.

For people of faith like myself this is the most exciting element of compassionate conservatism - its recognition of religion as a policy instrument to help the weak and marginalised.

Hague spelt out his vision last month in a speech delivered at the Black Majority Churches' joint millennium celebrations in Brighton. Pledging to give "full support" to faith-based welfare programmes, he said that the welfare state can provide people with financial support but not moral support. "Big state bureaucracies are no good at getting alongside and befriending people who may have a complex history of problems and disadvantage to overcome."

What it boils down to in practice are the kind of micro-level schemes running up and down the country that deserve, but are often denied, government support. In particular, Hague has been impressed by Yeldall Manor near Reading, a Christian-run rehabilitation centre for young male drug addicts, and the Kidz Klub in inner-city Liverpool, another Christian initiative which provides for a personal visit to 350 disadvantaged children from a genuine friend at least once each week.

That's not to say that such religious initiatives aren't benefitting under Labour. In inner-city Liverpool a new school is currently going up, the fruit of a partnership between local residents, Liverpool city council and the DfEE. When it is finished Kingsley School will have the distinction of being the country's only state institution to be run according to an Islamic ethos.

Elsewhere, the North London Muslim Housing Association has just secured a tranche of government funding to assess the feasibility of a bold plan which would see the regeneration of abandoned sink estates by new multi-faith, ethics-centred communities.

However, these successes represent small chinks in the secular fortress of government. Overall there remains a hostility towards religion that prevents faith-based groups from claiming their rightful place. Hague hits the nail square on the head when he says that community projects are sometimes forced to tone down or even abandon their religious ethos to make them eligible for state funding. And he strikes a raw nerve when he says that faith-based groups should be free to operate in ways that are consistent with their beliefs and not be excluded from receiving a share of the public funds their members are taxed to provide.

Changes in Tory policy appear to confirm that Hague means what he says. For example, whereas the previous Tory government said that non-Christian faith-based schools were divisive, today the party says that they can give "values-based first-class education". Hague's predecessors said that there was no evidence of religious discrimination; today he acknowledges its presence in state and society and promises to fight it with an "unrelenting war".

Compassionate conservatism also does away with another traditional Tory handicap - its exclusion of non-Christian groups. Belatedly the party appears to have recognised that the nation's religious groups provide rich pickings because they share the same fundamental values: continuity, decency, hard work and family values. Hence Hague is scathing on the erosion of family tax concessions under Labour, and he brandishes section 28 as evidence of its anti-decency, anti-family stand.

Anticipating that religion and its role in the political process will be a key battleground for the "ethical" voter, Hague has ordered his ministers to go out into their constituencies and find out what charity and faith-based organisations are doing. Their findings are to be published later this year in a report on compassionate Britain.

Only time will tell if, like Bush, Hague is engaged in a cynical vote-winning exercise. But whatever his actual intentions, at the very least we are likely to benefit from a two-party race to put the soul back into society. The likely effect of Hague's rebranding of conservatism will be to urge the government to greater efforts. So far Labour has won the admiration of faith groups for its broad policy of inclusiveness (which I believe flatters to deceive since the only point of comparison is the dismal record of the Tories).

The prime minister has shown that he himself is no slouch when it comes to accommodating faith groups. The Wakeham report's recommendations for a reformed upper chamber retain Christianity's current influence and, for the first time, allocate five seats to the representatives of other faiths. Moreover, since his election Tony Blair has made just as much of a point of visiting temples as being seen attending church. Earlier this year he caused quite a stir in British Islam when he revealed that he had twice read the Koran - a claim which, if true, would put him ahead of many Muslims.

I'd like to believe that this is a new beginning. After decades of resisting the positive role of religion, our politicians have come to the realisation that the state cannot replace the human spirit which is the marrow of all healthy communities. In this they are only responding to the public mood. We have learnt - the hard way - that communities aren't engineered around grey concrete blocks by urban planners, they evolve organically from the actions of people who share wholesome values and goals.

People who genuinely care about their neighbours will not harm their children, let their elderly rot in care homes, or neglect the poor and homeless. They are the ones who will help rehabilitate criminals and drug addicts in their midst, not only because the wellbeing of their own surroundings depends on it but because their faith demands it of them. In short, in an increasingly privatised and selfish society, those who have an obligation to a compassionate force beyond themselves will work for the betterment of others.

 Faisal Bodi is a British Muslim journalist

webTitle: G2: Prora,  Hitler's holiday camp is now a resort for young ravers

fields.headline: New kids in the block
fields.standfirst: Hitler had it built as a massive holiday camp for weary Nazi stormtroopers. Now, after years of lying silent and empty, Prora has found a new use: as a resort for young German ravers. John Hooper reports
fields.trailText: Hitler had it built as a massive holiday camp for weary Nazi stormtroopers. Now, after years of lying silent and empty, Prora has found a new use: as a resort for young German ravers. John Hooper reports
fields.body:
They are among the world's spookiest buildings. Massive and identical, six storeys high and made of dun-coloured concrete, the four blocks stretch along one of the best sandy beaches on the Baltic. With gaping, broken windows and boarded-up doors, they offer accommodation only to the bats. Yet they were intended as a holiday camp: Hitler's holiday camp. And even more strangely, they are now a resort for young ravers.

Prora, as the complex is known, was built on the pretty resort island of Rüggen by the Kraft durch Freude ("Strength through Joy") welfare organisation. Its role was to offer Aryan toilers a 10-day break by the sea. "I want workers to be offered adequate holidays," Hitler once said. "I want this because I want a people with strong nerves."

Visitors would come, 20,000 at a time, to stay in Prora's thousands of spartan rooms. Every waking minute was to be occupied with wholesome activity. Loudspeakers were installed to ensure that they were aware of the schedule. "Organising one's free time privately... has no value for the German people," said Robert Ley, Hitler's leisure supremo and the head of the Strength through Joy movement.

Prora had been completed, right down to the swastika-motif beach towels, when war broke out in 1939. The question of what to do with the 3.5 square miles of reinforced concrete is one that has taxed brains since Hitler's defeat.

The Red Army's engineers proposed blowing it up, but then realised the operation would use up half their annual supply of explosives. The communist authorities of the former German Democratic Republic resorted to the less costly expedient of making Prora a top-secret army camp and erasing it from the map.

After German reunification 10 years ago, the site was put under a protection order. There had been talk of it being turned into a leisure complex or conference centre. But no one had foreseen the use to which Nicole Krummhaar, 24, would put it. "The blocks are indestructible," she says. "What else can you do with them?"

In the cavernous ground-floor spaces young, tattooed, pierced east Germans are shuffling their trainers to the sort of techno that goes in through the solar plexus and never re-emerges. For £65 a week they can pitch a tent on the lawn beside the complex. They get a makeshift open-air cinema and beach facilities that include jet skis; and they can spend as much time as they like in the six clubs which Krummhaar has franchised.

There have been accusations of tastelessness in the German press. Krummhaar, who runs a concert agency in the city of Halle, is furious. "This has absolutely nothing to do with ideology," she says. "You don't see people boycotting the autobahns or refusing to use other buildings that were built during the Nazi era."

For the young people at the camp, the point seems irrelevant. None knew who had constructed Prora, or why. "I heard it was built by [the east German leader] Erich Honecker," ventured one; another thought it had been "a barracks for the Wehrmacht".

Krummhaar discovered the existance of Prora as she searched for a way to diversify her business. "By now, everyone in the former GDR has seen his or her favourite band. We were looking for something new."

Clubbing is as popular in eastern Germany as anywhere else but, with 17% of the population unemployed, most young people could not afford even the most basic package trip to Ayia Napa or Ibiza. Krummhaar, who was brought up on the Baltic island of Hiddensee, began searching last year for somewhere on the coast to turn into a ravers' retreat. She approached Germany's state property agency, and was shown several possibilities including the old V-rocket site at Peenemunde. But with Prora it was love at first sight. "Afterwards, I walked up and down outside to find out what kind of impression the place made on me," she says. "It's not ugly. Just interesting. Like an old church."

She tried out the site last year with a week-long beach party. "Everybody was enjoying themselves, dancing in the sea and so on. But the water carried the noise more than we had expected. There were complaints," she recalls.

It was the start of a relationship with the islanders that remains uneasy. When the first batch of ravers arrived by train on July 22, the police were waiting at the station. "They searched them in such an aggressive way that I ended up calling the ministry to complain," says Krummhaar. "I think the main problem is that they don't want young people."

Germany's weather has been as bad as Britain's this summer and attendance has far from lived up to expectations. Even so, there were several hundred at the site when we visited, and by the end of the season several thousand will have had the Prora experience.

If Krumhaar has her way, they will not be the last. "I want to hold parties here. But the authorities are worried about having too many people and if we get a big name from the techno scene we need at least 5,000 before it gets interesting. I want to bring dance groups and theatre groups here and make this a real centre for the Baltic. We could have people coming from Scandinavia, from Russia, all over."

After more than six decades, you get the eerie sensation that history has come full circle. "When the visitor arrives at the resort, he must forget the past immediately," wrote Robert Ley. "I want to construct it in such a way that he enters into a bustle of music, dance and theatre that takes the breath away so that he forgets himself."

webTitle: EMI and Nokia call up any number of tunes

fields.headline: EMI and Nokia call up any number of tunes
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Mobile phone rings are about to move to a new pitch of personalisation after a deal between music publisher EMI and Nokia, which allows the Finnish manufacturer's handsets to ring out with users' favourite tunes.
fields.body:
Mobile phone rings are about to move to a new pitch of personalisation after a deal between music publisher EMI and Nokia, which allows the Finnish manufacturer's handsets to ring out with users' favourite tunes.

Stevie Wonder's I Just Called to Say I Love You has already been nominated by at least one EMI executive to warble from his mobile.

However, those with more up to date tastes will be able to choose from a range of artists including Blur, Robbie Williams, the Spice Girls, Puff Daddy and Janet Jackson.

Nokia and EMI have an exclusive six-month agreement to launch the product. But both companies are negotiating with other parties to extend the reach.

If a favourite band or artist is not published by EMI then the wait should not be too long before mobiles are tinkling Abba's Ring, Ring or Blondie's Hanging on the Telephone. The service should also be available on Motorola and Ericsson handsets in the future.

The fee for downloading a favourite song is expected to be well under £1, according to EMI Music Publishing's director of media, Jonathan Channon.

Downloading a song to a mobile will be available in the autumn through Club Nokia on the internet or by sending a text message to a phone number to obtain the song.

Mr Channon said both companies expect "tens of millions of downloads" by 2003. The revenue for Nokia and EMI is put in the scale of "millions of pounds" because users are expected to change their call songs frequently.

A few companies offer similar services, with Worldpop.com providing a selection of 10 songs favoured by Ibiza fans for use as ring tones on mobile phones. Moloko's Sing it Back has proved very popular.

fields.trailText: Global warming is likely to destroy more than half the earth's colder habitats by the end of the century, causing the extinction of species which cannot adapt or move quickly enough to reach new homes, a report by WWF, formerly the Worldwide Fund for Nature, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Global warming is likely to destroy more than half the earth's colder habitats by the end of the century, causing the extinction of species which cannot adapt or move quickly enough to reach new homes, a report by WWF, formerly the Worldwide Fund for Nature, said yesterday.

Worst hit will be the colder places in the northern latitudes of Canada, Russia and Scandinavia, where warming is expected to be most rapid, and areas like the Cairngorms in Scotland, where Arctic species have nowhere left to migrate.

In order to adapt and survive plants may need to move 10 times more quickly than they did when recolonizing previously glaciated land at the end of the last ice age. Few plant species can move at a rate of one kilometre per year, the speed that will be required in many parts of the world.

High migration rates will particularly threaten rare, isolated or slow-moving species but will favour weeds and pests that can move, reproduce or adapt quickly. Conditions today make it much more difficult for species to move to new habitat than was the case thousands of years ago.

The last time the climate warmed anywhere near as quickly as is predicted this century was 13,000 years ago when sabre toothed tigers and woolly mammoths still roamed the earth and humans had just begun to populate the Americas.

Any plant or animal that needs to move must contend with roads, cities and farms. The WWF study shows that human barriers to climate induced migration will have the worst impact along the northern edges of developed zones in central and north-western Russia, Finland and central Canada.

"As global warming accelerates, plants and animals will come under increasing pressure to migrate and find suitable habitats. Some will just not be able to move fast enough," said Adam Markham, executive director of the US non-governmental organisation Clean Air-Cool Planet, and one of the co-authors of the WWF report.

Birds such as the great tit in Scotland and the Mexican jay in Arizona are beginning to breed earlier in the year, butterflies are shifting their ranges northwards throughout Europe and mammals in many parts of the Arctic, including polar bears, walrus and caribou, are beginning to feel the impacts of reduced sea ice and warming tundra habitat.

In the US, most of the northern spruce and fir forest of New England and New York State could be lost.

In patches of habitat that do survive, local species loss may be as high as one in five in the most vulnerable mountain ecosystems such as northern Alaska, Russia's Tamyr Peninsula and south-eastern Australia.

The report's predictions are based on a moderate estimate that concentrations of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere will double from pre-industrial levels during this century.

However, some projections suggest a three-fold increase in concentrations by 2100, unless action is taken to reduce the inefficient use of coal, oil and gas for energy production.

webTitle: Hague and Norris split over gays

fields.headline: Hague and Norris split over gays
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Steven Norris, the defeated Tory candidate for London mayor, found himself at odds yesterday with William Hague, weeks after being drafted into central office to improve the party's image among gay and ethnic minority voters.
fields.body:
Steven Norris, the defeated Tory candidate for London mayor, found himself at odds yesterday with William Hague, weeks after being drafted into central office to improve the party's image among gay and ethnic minority voters.

In his first interview since his summer holiday, the Tory leader said he disagreed with Mr Norris's recent suggestion that gay marriages should be treated equally under the law.

Mr Norris underlined his determination to change the Tory party's homophobic image when he said over the weekend that there was "no moral barrier" to the civil registration of gay partnerships.

The former minister, who in the mayoral contest appealed to voters who had never supported the Tories, said his party needed "educating" out of anti-homosexual prejudices. Mr Norris also criticised the use of racially discriminatory language by some of his colleagues.

Mr Hague dismissed the remarks by his new vice-chairman in an interview in the Times yesterday, suggesting that Mr Norris may only be allowed to play a token role at central office. However, the Tory leader stressed that he wanted Mr Norris to continue his work improving the image of the party.

"There are still many false perceptions about the Tory party and we have to change them," Mr Hague said.

The disagreement between Mr Hague and Mr Norris came as the Tory leader kicked off his autumn political offensive by challenging the government to introduce a bill to speed up the adoption process or face one devised by the Tories.

webTitle: Man stabbed in his home 'was not intended target'

fields.headline: Man stabbed in his home 'was not intended target'
fields.trailText: A young man was murdered in front of his family on a council estate in Manchester by a mob who mistakenly thought he owed them money.
fields.body:
A young man was murdered in front of his family on a council estate in Manchester by a mob who mistakenly thought he owed them money.

Police said yesterday that Matthew Connolly, 20, could have been the victim of mistaken identity.

He was killed after a gang of six or seven men forced their way into the terraced house on the Mill estate in Moston on Saturday.

Mr Connolly was killed by a single stab wound to his chest. As he lay dying, some of the gang removed a mirror from the wall and smashed it over his head.

Mr Connolly's mother Angela said yesterday: "They were smashing everything up in the house and they had baseball bats.

"My niece was here with her baby son, who is two, and my 11-year-old daughter, Lisa, was told to go upstairs by one of the men, who was wearing a mask. They just started battering him and then he fell forward and was bleeding so much that I realised he had been stabbed."

She described her son as "no angel", but said he was not into drugs and was very quiet.

The murder scene was sealed off by a police forensic team yesterday. Bunches of flowers had been placed close to the Connolly's house by neighbours.

Detective Superintendent Keith Jardine of Greater Manchester police, who is leading the investigation, described it as a cowardly, vicious attack.

"We have no reason to believe that Matthew was the intended target," he said.

Police are appealing for information from anyone who saw the men, who were not locals and were in their 20s and 30s, to contact them.

Det Supt Jardine also appealed to a person who had called Crimestoppers on four occasions in the past few days to get in touch again.

fields.headline: Beckhams drop Morton book battle
fields.trailText: David and Victoria Beckham yesterday abandoned their legal battle to stop biographer Andrew Morton revealing details of their private lives in his forthcoming book, entitled Posh and Becks.
fields.body:
David and Victoria Beckham yesterday abandoned their legal battle to stop biographer Andrew Morton revealing details of their private lives in his forthcoming book, entitled Posh and Becks.

Outside the high court in London, Suzanne Reeves, solicitor for Mr Morton and his publishers, Michael O'Mara Books, said the Beckhams had mounted an "extraordinarily aggressive campaign" against her clients.

"We do not believe that celebrities, particularly those who so actively court favourable publicity, should be able to seek to use the law to silence those who aim to undertake a more objective appraisal of their lives," she said.

The couple are thought to have agreed not to bring a libel or breach of confidence action over the book in exchange for the deletion of 200 words from the 60,000-word manuscript. This clears the way for publication in October, when the book will compete for sales with Mr Beckham's autobiography, My World, to be published by Hodder Headline around the same time.

The couple's lawyer, Michael Tugendhat QC, said the Beckhams had accepted legal advice on "what the law permits to be published in respect to certain passages".

The couple had objected to information given to Mr Morton by their former bodyguard, Mark Niblett, 40, who stopped working for them in May. They argued that Mr Niblett had breached a confidentiality clause in his contract.

Geoffrey Robertson QC, for Mr Morton and his publishers, told Mr Justice Evans-Lombe: "The claimants may not agree with [the book's] contents, but accept what the law allows in a society which holds fast to free speech principles."

Confidential details of the settlement were lodged with the court.

Michael O'Mara, publisher of Mr Morton's controversial biographies of Princess Diana and Kenyan president Daniel arap Moi, later said he was "thrilled" at the settlement, describing it as "a huge climb-down" on the part of the England footballer and Spice Girl.

"In the end it all came down to trifling details," he said. "This was a Robert Maxwell-type action: rich and famous people trying to control all press coverage about them through the courts."

He said the Beckhams' legal challenge had been "extremely misconceived", resulting in the deletion of around 200 words in return for invaluable press coverage of the book.

"We could not possibly have bought this much publicity," he said. "The Beckhams have probably tripled the sales and for that I thank them roundly."

Asked about the book's content, he said: "Andrew was interested in the business of celebrity and how modern celebrities use their fame. Andrew thinks this new form of celebrity is not necessarily all for the good. He wanted to write about it."

Mr O'Mara hinted that the book would centre more on Victoria Beckham than on her husband, whom he described as a "straightforward" man who likes cars and clothes.

"Unlike him she hasn't got an abundance of natural talent at something, but she's taken what she's got and made a hell of a lot more of it. In the book Andrew shows how he admires Victoria for her business skills. She is possibly one of Britain's top businesswomen."

A spokeswoman for the couple said: "David and Victoria Beckham had never planned to ban Andrew Morton's book but had wanted to stop a former employee from revealing details about their private lives.

"A sensible compromise has been reached... clarifying which matters Mr Morton and his publishers are and aren't entitled to publish."

She added: "The case against Mark Niblett continues."

fields.headline: Police launch £7m drive for recruits
fields.trailText: A £7m advertising campaign reflecting the harrowing situations confronted by police officers was launched yesterday in a bold effort to recruit thousands into the service at a time when overall numbers are at their lowest for a decade.
fields.byline: Nick Hopkins, crime correspondent, and Martin Wainwright
fields.body:
A £7m advertising campaign reflecting the harrowing situations confronted by police officers was launched yesterday in a bold effort to recruit thousands into the service at a time when overall numbers are at their lowest for a decade.

The first of three TV commercials with the theme "Could you?" was due to be broadcast during peak viewing time last night, marking the first stage of a three year marketing drive masterminded by the London agency M&C Saatchi.

The first advert features the Falklands war veteran Simon Weston. "People say I'm brave. I've had to deal with a lot in my life," he says. "But to go round to somebody's house to tell a man that his wife and child have been killed by some drunken idiot in a car crash... I'm not sure I could do that."

The actress Patsy Palmer - who played Bianca Butcher in the BBC soap EastEnders - and the former England footballer John Barnes describe different challenges in two other films.

The government is hoping this first national campaign will ease the recruitment crisis facing a service which has been battered by bad publicity in recent years and is suffering from poor morale.

Although the Home Office has set aside cash to recruit 9,000 extra officers nationwide over the next three years, the increase will only be meaningful if forces can retain the staff they have.

Figures released yesterday showed the number of police officers in England and Wales had dropped from 127,158 in 1997 to 124,418 in March this year.

The Metropolitan police has warned if the haemorrhage continues, it will soon have its lowest number of officers on record.

M&C Saatchi was set the task of devising a campaign which would lift the spirits of existing officers while encouraging the right calibre of potential recruits in the key 25 to 35 age group.

Although the TV ads are hardhitting, the home secretary, Jack Straw, and Paul Whitehouse, chairman of the Association of Chief Police Officers, insisted they were not negative.

"We have to show in an honest way the challenges facing police officers," said Mr Whitehouse, who was an adviser to the agency.

"We had to get away from the type of adverts which say 'Join the police and become a chief constable in three weeks' or 'Join and drive a fast car'. If someone is put off policing by the advertisments, then they are probably not the sort of person we need."

Mr Straw said he asked the agency about the defensive tone of the commercials but was assured they had been well received in sampling, especially by the young.

He said the police needed to recruit officers who relied on brain rather than brawn. "The purpose of our campaign is simple. It is to help local forces attract recruits of the highest quality and expertise over the next three years."

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, yesterday said the fall in police numbers was an embarrassment for the government.

"Jack Straw can embark on all the photo opportunities he wants. There is no denying that the thin blue line has got thinner. Jack Straw promised to increase police numbers. He has failed to deliver."

Fred Broughton, chairman of the Police Federation, welcomed the campaign but said it was only a start. "More needs to be done to halt the decline in police numbers. We have been calling for extra resources to boost manpower for the last 10 years. But something is at last being done."

Where low-cost homes make hearts beat faster

"Has Heartbeat started again then?" said the recruitment office at Newby Wiske hall, where North Yorkshire police are finely tuned to the effects of the nostalgic TV series on weary Metropolitan colleagues' minds.

The quiet scrapping of a gentleman's agreement between forces not to poach serving officers from elsewhere has lent a big hand to solving manpower problems for chief constables with rural and low-cost housing beats.

North Yorkshire, which includes two national parks and a wealth of villages out of commuter range, has taken on 24 experienced officers from other forces since placing its first advertisement for transfers earlier this year. Another eight are in the pipeline, along with 45 new recruits without previous policing experience.

"It has traditionally been the case that you did not advertise for people to transfer," said a spokesman for the North Yorkshire force. "But the chief constables decided to drop their unwritten agreement and we put an advertisement in a police publication. We have lost two officers transferring out to other forces, but the balance is heavily in our direction."

The end of the "no poaching" agreement this year has started to free the internal market in police manpower, according to the Police Federation, although no change in the law or force regulations has been involved.

A spokesman said: "Officers have always applied for transfers for various reasons, particularly the cost of housing in some parts of the country, but it has not been officially encouraged until now."

The Association of Chief Police Officers said that the bar on advertising had been "understood, never written down", but chief constables had finally decided to end it.

Demand for police jobs is not entirely a matter of fine landscapes, with a largely urban force like West Yorkshire receiving 2,000 letters of interest for 60 recently advertised jobs for newrecruits.

But North Yorkshire said: "There definitely is a Heartbeat factor. An awful lot of colleagues from elsewhere want to work on the North York moors."

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Matthew Baylis, scriptwriter
fields.trailText: Matthew Baylis, scriptwriter
fields.body:
Drought, disease, poverty. You might have thought East Africa had enough to worry about. But soon, citizens in Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania are to face the additional hazards of soap-opera addiction. The agonising wait between a Friday cliff-hanger and its Monday resolution. The frustration of watching beloved characters take a wrong turn, the despair at missing crucial episodes.

And the august bodies inflicting this on Africa? None other than the United Nations, who sent myself and former EastEnders producer Matthew Robinson to Nairobi in July. Our mission was to work alongside a group of Kenyan writers creating Heart And Soul, the first pan-East African soap.

The UN has long recognised the problem of spreading vital messages - on subjects such as HIV and equality - to communities which stop paying attention if they suspect they are being preached at. But drama, as Bertolt Brecht would tell you, sweetens the pill. It's akin to those physics teachers who began every lesson with a crowd-pleasing stunt, like the van de Graaf generators. First entertain, then inform.

Can you make entertainment out of issues like soil erosion and government corruption? You can, because the key to a soap's success is not so much the stories, but the characters. It ought to be etched, in 6 foot letters, above every writer's desk: if people care, they'll watch. That's not the same as liking, of course. One of Heart And Soul's principle characters, Benja, is a crooked official who's cheated his mother out of her coffee plantation. Kind of Ian Beale meets JR Ewing. The only disagreement between ourselves and our Kenyan colleagues came as we were about to perform a read-through of the first script to an assembly of UN dignitaries. Everyone wanted to play Benja. If that kind of popularity can be translated to the TV screen, then East Africa has a treat in store.
