webTitle: Bribe demand alleged in Rover pay-off

fields.headline: Bribe demand alleged in Rover pay-off
fields.standfirst: Special report: Rover in crisis
fields.trailText: Two managers at Rover's Longbridge plant have been suspended over an allegation that they demanded thousands of pounds in bribes to expedite voluntary redundancy applications.
fields.body:
Two managers at Rover's Longbridge plant have been suspended over an allegation that they demanded thousands of pounds in bribes to expedite voluntary redundancy applications.

The two, and another senior employee in the paintshop at the West Midlands plant, are the subject of an internal inquiry. Rover has been seeking volunteers to help reduce the workforce by up to 1,000, following its purchase by the Phoenix consortium from BMW in May. It is alleged the managers asked individuals for £2,000 or more in return for processing their voluntary redundancy applications. The company is understood to have been alerted by an employee who recorded a conversation with one of the two.

A Rover spokeswoman confirmed three employees were suspended on full pay during an investigation into "irregularities" in the paintshop. She said: "It is standard company practice to suspend employees during the course of such an investigation, and it would be inappropriate to give further details whilst that investigation is ongoing."

Police are not involved in the inquiry, expected to be completed in "a matter of days".

fields.headline: Many medicines 'can cause lung damage'
fields.trailText: More than 300 prescribed medicines, from betablockers to anti-depressants and painkillers, can damage the lungs and cause a variety of symptoms from coughs to pleurisy and breathing difficulties, it was claimed at an international conference yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 300 prescribed medicines, from betablockers to anti-depressants and painkillers, can damage the lungs and cause a variety of symptoms from coughs to pleurisy and breathing difficulties, it was claimed at an international conference yesterday.

The warning came at the world congress on lung Health and respiratory diseases in Florence from a team of French physicians who have compiled a database of drugs with damaging side-effects on the lungs.

Sometimes the problems begin as soon as the patient begins taking the drug, but sometimes nothing happens for several years, lulling doctor and patient into a sense of false security. The side-effects are mostly unpredictable - one person will have problems while another will not for no obvious reason - and some are irreversible, leaving permanent damage.

Philippe Camus of the university medical centre of Dijon, which has been collating reports of lung damage, said the list had reached 310 medicines, many of them in common use, such as certain antibiotics and even paracetemol.

He feared that doctors prescribing medicines for conditions unrelated to lung disorders, such as high blood pressure, allergies or rheumatism, were not aware of the potential harm these drugs could do.

"For some of the problems in the patient that the physician sees, he can see no reason," said Professor Camus in Florence yesterday. "We say look at the prescription, because that may be the explanation."

Often the problem was not spotted until too late to prevent permanent damage. "I have seen in my career about 190 patients with this kind of disease," he said. "In many instances the time to diagnosis was too long."

He did not blame the doctors. In many cases, the drugs were being prescribed by a consultant in a specialty like cancer, heart disease or arthritis, who would not as easily diagnose a lung problem. But doctors should be aware of the possible side-effects of medicines, and patients should be quicker to report them to their physician.

"If you receive a drug to treat a disease, you should get an improvement. If you get new symptoms in other parts of your body, please consult your physician," he said.

There were alternatives for many of these drugs, he said. His team had put together a website for doctors and patients to consult (www.pneumotox.com) which listed all the suspect medicines as well as all the lung conditions they could provoke, graded according to the number of reports of adverse effects there have been.

The site was unique in that it centred on one part of the body and also in that it received no sponsorship from industry, he said.

But drugs were not the only problem, he said. "Medicinal herbs, for instance, have also been blamed for serious lung problems. This means that stricter rules should be introduced for their scientific validation and public sale."

He hoped the public would become more aware that the effects of herbs, although they might have been used in Asia for centuries, had not been tested in the west in particular in combination with conventional medicines.

"It is a new field but the public has to give it attention and not use these supplements in too large amounts or for too long a period of time."

The numbers of drugs linked to lung damage was increasing, he said. The Dijon database contained 204 names three years ago. The latest count was 315.

There were often no warnings of the damage these medicines could do in the standard drug textbooks doctors consulted because negligible numbers of people suffered from them during the relatively small clinical trials conducted to ascertain whether they are safe and effective. But once they were prescribed widely, significant numbers of people might suffer problems.

Lung specialists at the congress said that the side-effects of medicines taken in the past might even be the cause of lung diseases that have them baffled. Doctors were often unable to pin down the precise cause of lung damage.

Martin Partridge, chairman of the British Thoracic Society, said Prof Camus was making an important point about the damage that drugs could cause.

"I think the range of medications which can affect the lung make it very difficult for people to be up to date on it."

Checklist

Medicines include:

 Beta-blockers for high blood pressure

 ACE inhibitors for heart failure or high blood pressure

 Cordarone amiodarone for irregular heart rhythms

 Some antibiotics

 Some anti-rheumatics

 Steroids

 Paracetamol

 Drugs derived from ergot given to help brain functions of the elderly or those with Parkinson's disease

 Iodine, used as a radiographic contrast media

Damaging side effects:

 Coughs

 Breathlessness

 Pleurisy

 Asthma

 Pneumonia

 Inability to breathe

webTitle: Resort hotels ban mayor from their bars

fields.headline: Resort hotels ban mayor from their bars
fields.trailText: Jacqueline Richards, mayor of a Somerset seaside resort, finds herself involved a row with the owner of two hotels that started as a squall but has developed into a storm.
fields.body:
Jacqueline Richards, mayor of a Somerset seaside resort, finds herself involved a row with the owner of two hotels that started as a squall but has developed into a storm.

Pub landlords on Burnham-on-Sea's Pubwatch committee voted this week to bar the mayor from every licensed premises in the town centre, despite receiving a solicitor's letter setting out Mrs Richards' version of the events that had already led to her being barred from the Royal Clarence and Queen's hotels.

The committee decided to bar the mayor for three months and her husband, Stephen, for a year.

A month ago, after a night out at the Queen's hotel, Mrs Richards and her party went on to a disco at the Royal Clarence. Managers there alleged she and her husband became abusive and had to be ejected. She said bouncers made them feel so uncomfortable they left of their own accord. The next evening the couple returned to the Queen's, where Mr Richards was accused of being drunk and abusive. He has said he was defending himself.

Yesterday Mrs Richards, a town and district councillor, claimed she was the victim of a vendetta against Conservative-controlled Sedgemoor district council.

She said she believed that the owner of the two hotels, Ray Hill, was using the ban to get at the council through her over licensing problems.

Mr Hill denied any vendetta. "It is about what happened on those two nights," he said.

fields.headline: Beyond good and evil
fields.trailText: Emmerdale | Hard Evidence Of Aliens Among Us | Nigella Bites
fields.body:
Kelly Windsor's never had it easy, despite what the people of Emmerdale (ITV) say about her. Not a country girl at heart, she has always been too fond of strappy sandals and lipgloss for a life among the hills and dales with not a Miss Selfridge for 50 miles. A liking for such things - coupled with a fiery determination to better herself - practically passes for wickedness in Emmerdale. So when she slept with her stepbrother Scott while married to the saintly but simple Roy Glover, there was hell to pay. And hell doesn't take Top Shop storecard.

Dumped by Roy on her way to Ibiza, Kelly had no choice but to return home, spangly bikini unworn, Vengaboys CD still in the box. There, she has been shunned by the whole village bar Seth and Betty, who need some excitement in their lives, and Ashley, the ineffectual vicar who wrings his hands so much it passes for tintinnabulation. Like Lola the showgirl, she sits forlorn in the bar with not even her eyebrows for company. Kelly has been a bit overzealous with the tweezers, you understand, leaving them whispers of their former selves, like anorexic caterpillars.

Scott has got off lightly, with his mum forgiving him for sleeping with Kelly ("One's weak, the other's wicked. I can forgive weakness.") and for that turn he did on Celebrity Stars In Their Eyes as Robbie Williams. All he has suffered is a bit of ribbing (for extra sensation) from Lesbian Frankie, the manic mechanic, and her gay grease-monkey sidekick - a right circus troupe the pair of them.

Meanwhile, Ashley's beloved Bernice, all curves and demi-waves (who perhaps has been cryogenically frozen since 1957) went to visit Ashley's potential new - and rather grotty - parish with her mum, the wonderful Diane. "Few rolls of calico and some nice nets," Diane advised. "Carol Smillie's built a career on less." Bernice just smiled in a pained Diana Dors kind of way. Crossroads' Debbie Lancaster was right. "Men are lucky. They get women. Women just get men."

According to Hard Evidence Of Aliens Among Us (Sky One) - presented by the kind of man who might play an enigmatic business tycoon in an American daytime soap - extra-terrestrials aren't that fussy. They'll abduct anyone they can lay their big spindly hands on and stick probes in every orifice, creating new orifices if needs be.

Apparently, 50 per cent of Americans believe in alien abduction and 800,000 maintain they themselves have been abducted, including Jesse Long, who says he has been repeatedly abducted since he was a child. Much hypnosis and faux-horrific reconstructions later, Jesse revealed he is the father of nine human-alien hybrids and that colonisation of Earth by aliens was imminent, just like in The X-Files.

In a Kilroy moment, when he was asked what he'd say if he could confront his abductors, Jesse whined "Why me?"... which is exactly what I was thinking. One abductee whispered of her kidnappers "They were tall, they were very thin, with huge eyes." So aliens look like Mick Jagger? Maybe Mick Jagger is actually an alien, preparing us for colonisation.

With a lump of parmesan the size of Gibraltar, stainless steel accoutrements and random bundles of herbs dotted round Ms Lawson's enormous kitchen, Nigella Bites (C4) is either the worst kind of aspirational TV (making you feel guilty you don't make your own sultanas in rum or freeze marinading meat and label the bags) or the best kind (especially if you read Elle Decoration and yearn for a Smeg cooker).

While the food wasn't as interesting as having a nosey around Nigella's house, a refreshing lackadaisical attitude infused the programme with her anti-presentation leanings. Fast food was the theme, and blink and you would have missed lemon linguine and chocolate pudding. Pop to put the kettle on and Nigella was halfway through chicken and couscous. So speedy she was, she could have been on The Crystal Maze. ("Griddle the chicken! Get the crystal!") But if the food wasn't presented prettily, Nigella's life was fetishised.

Taking her son to nursery, eating ice cream in the garden, pointless shots of comfy chairs - the world may soon be colonised by Nigella clones, all of whom cook with tons of salt - and if she carries on the way she does, Siberia will be a hollowed out wasteland by 2005 - while wearing a denim jacket. Which is all very well, but does she clean her own oven?

webTitle: Milosevic challenges UN by planning Kosovo poll

fields.headline: Milosevic challenges UN by planning Kosovo poll
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: A senior official of Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist party threw down the gauntlet to the international community with a surprise visit to Kosovo yesterday, where she declared that Belgrade would set up polling stations in the Serb province for next month's Yugoslav elections.
fields.body:
A senior official of Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist party threw down the gauntlet to the international community with a surprise visit to Kosovo yesterday, where she declared that Belgrade would set up polling stations in the Serb province for next month's Yugoslav elections.

Gorica Gajevic, general secretary of the party, told a crowd of pro-Milosevic Serbs that 500 polling stations would be set up in the Serb enclaves for polling in the federal and presidential elections on September 24.

She also pledged that 200 flats would be built in Kosovo for returning Serb refugees.

Bernard Kouchner, the head of Kosovo's UN administration, immediately dismissed the polling promise. "If they want to have elections in Serb enclaves, that's impossible," he said.

Mr Kouchner plans to hold separate local elections within the province a month after Yugoslavia votes in the local, parliamentary and presidential poll.

Ms Gajevic's move effectively calls the international community's bluff, for UN resolution 1244 and the technical-military agreement signed in Kumanovo before the pullout of Serb troops in June last year state that Kosovo remains a part of Yugoslavia.

However, the return of some Serb forces to the region, as envisaged in the Kumanovo agreement, has not yet happened

Many Serbs unofficially admit that Kosovo is lost to Serbia. Even the opposition presidential candidate Vojislav Kostunica says that it should stay under UN administration for the time being.

Ms Gajevic's visit signals Belgrade's intent to make Kosovo an election issue and exploit the ambiguity over its status for propaganda.

Tomorrow the Yugoslav army will hold exercises of a new Kosovo unit currently based in southern Serbia.

A Belgrade analyst, Bratislav Grubacic, said the state media would probably cover the manoeuvres and announce that the unit was returning to Kosovo. A poll of Serbs in Kosovo could be a fertile area for voting fraud, he said.

An opposition party leader, Professor Zarko Korac, president of the Social Democratic Union, said: "It's another sign of the confusion in Kosovo. The whole point is: who will organise elections?"

He said that opposition politicians had unsuccesfully pressed European governments to support elections in Kosovo at the same time as those in the rest of Yugoslavia. Now Mr Milosevic's party had taken up the theme and would organise the poll.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Talking Head | Material World
fields.body:
John Sergeant, now political editor of ITN, trod the boards with Alan Bennett a lifetime or two ago. Now, in Talking Head (11.30am, Radio 4) he paints an affectionate portrait of the writer nobody really seems to know. There are, naturally, endless stories of Bennett's wit and of his alarming habit of suddenly making written notes of other people's sallies, but no one seems to have burrowed through to the inner man. As George Melly muses, "He doesn't encourage it, you know."

If you have a festering wound there is one treatment guaranteed to put you rapidly on the road to recovery - maggots. Nothing beats diptera larvae at devouring rotten flesh until only healthy tissue remains. The procedure does, however, leave an unfortunate impression of NHS medical practice. In Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4) Quentin Cooper reports on research into the chemistry of the maggots' digestive secretion in the hope that its future deployment will be less revolting.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Palm Beach Story | The Opposite Of Sex | The Conversation | The Seven Samurai
fields.body:
The Palm Beach Story

(Preston Sturges, 1942)

4pm, Sky Cinema

Rich satirical comedy conceived and executed with enormous wit by the ever-reliable Sturges. Joel McCrea stars as penniless inventor Tom Jeffers; Claudette Colbert is his wife, Gerry, who scoots off to the rich men's playground of Palm Beach, Florida, to snare a millionaire.

The Opposite Of Sex

(Don Roos, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Christina Ricci's breasts point to something special in the opening scene. She adjusts them as though calibrating some secret weapon, then heads off to do battle with the world; but the early intimations of a truly subversive and original comedy are soon replaced by more conventional laughs. Still, it is fun, as Ricci insinuates her way into the home of half-brother Martin Donovan and proceeds to wreck his life; and Lisa Kudrow - the funny one in Friends - is a treat as Donovan's repressed friend.

The Conversation

(Francis Ford Coppola, 1974)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Coppola knocked out this compelling tale of obsession between Godfathers I and II. Gene Hackman is Harry Caul, shifty-looking in mac and specs, tipped by the nature of his calling into increasing paranoia. He's hired by businessman Robert Duvall to spy on a young couple and becomes drawn, conscience-stricken, into a murder plot.

The Seven Samurai

(Akira Kurosawa, 1954)

2.35am, FilmFour

Another showing for Kurosawa's epic masterpiece, famously remade by Hollywood as The Magnificent Seven. The plot is straight out of western mythology: a few good men defending a village against a gang of 40 bandits. The samurai, from veteran Takashi Shimura to lowly hanger-on Toshiro Mifune, are precisely, affectionately drawn, their code of honour contrasting with the bandits' rapine and the villagers' self-interest. The prolonged, episodic conflict, ending in mud and pouring rain, remains one of the great screen battles.

The Seven Samurai (Akira Kurosawa, 1954) 2.35am, FilmFour Another showing for Kurosawa's epic masterpiece, famously remade by Hollywood as The Magnificent Seven. The plot is straight out of western mythology: a few good men defending a village against a gang of 40 bandits. The samurai, from veteran Takashi Shimura to lowly hanger-on Toshiro Mifune, are precisely, affectionately drawn, their code of honour contrasting with the bandits' rapine and the villagers' self-interest. The prolonged, episodic conflict, ending in mud and pouring rain, remains one of the great screen battles.

fields.headline: Doubts over crucial Lockerbie witness
fields.standfirst:
CIA cables threaten prosecution case that relies on evidence from Libyan double agent who worked with accused
Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: CIA cables threaten prosecution case that relies on evidence from Libyan double agent who worked with accused.
fields.body:
When the presiding judge, Lord Sutherland, granted another short adjournment to the Lockerbie trial yesterday, as defence and prosecution counsel tussled over access to CIA cables, there was clear regret in the judge's voice.

The biggest mass murder trial in British history has been beset by delays from the outset, but the current delay centres on a crucial witness whose testimony may decide whether the case against the two Libyans accused of the bombing stands or falls.

Since the Scottish court in the Netherlands reconvened last week, everyone has been awaiting the evidence of defector Abdul Majid Razkaz Salam Giaka, codenamed Puzzle Piece WF 140440 by the US witness protection scheme.

But after legal argument yesterday it became apparent the wait will be lengthened: over the next month the CIA will search its files for transcripts of its agents' dealings with Mr Giaka. When that task is completed, Mr Giaka looks set to become the crown's last - and most vital - witness in the case over the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 in December 1988, which killed 270 people.

As the trial has progressed the importance to the prosecution of the man who operated as a double agent while working at Malta's Luqa airport alongside Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, the Libyans accused of the murders, has become increasingly apparent.

A succession of witnesses who failed to live up to expectations has heightened the crown's reliance on Mr Giaka. One witness mistook a Palestinian terrorist for a defendant in a photo line-up. A star witness, Edwin Bollier, who was intended to link the accused Libyans to the bomb's detonator, changed his story with such frequency that even the crown questioned his credibility.

"The crown have yet to lead evidence from a witness who says they saw al-Megrahi or Fhimah make the bomb, put it in a suitcase and load it on to the plane at Malta. They haven't even established - beyond the notion of a theoretical possibility - that the bomb was even put on the plane in Malta. They need Giaka to do that," said Robert Black QC, the Edinburgh law professor who first proposed holding the trial in the Netherlands.

But there is growing concern that Mr Giaka's testimony will not live up to that promised as far back as 1991.

Initially, Mr Giaka was expected to give evidence by the middle of last week. It became obvious last Tuesday, however, that there would be delays.

At the start of June, the prosecution met CIA officials in the US embassy in the Hague and had first sight of the unedited cables. Those present guaranteed not to make notes or disclose any of the information in the cables. The defence was given no such access: they saw only transcripts with large areas blacked out by the pen of an American censor.

Then, at the start of last week, the defence discovered the discrepancy. Under the European convention on human rights, already incorporated into Scots law, the defence and prosecution must have equality of arms. The defence counsel, Richard Keen QC and William Taylor QC, demanded unedited versions of the cables.

The lord advocate, Colin Boyd QC, said the blacked out sections were of no relevance to the defence and could not be revealed without endangering America's national security. The judges disagreed and told Mr Boyd to approach the CIA and ask for unedited version of the cables to be made available to the defence.

"The defence couldn't realistically cross examine Giaka without seeing what his CIA handlers had to say about him. This is vitally important stuff," said Prof Black.

In an unprecedented step, the CIA agreed to release the cables. By Friday, Mr Keen, counsel for Fhimah, had made a first assessment of them. He told the court the idea they did not impinge on his client's defence was inconceivable.

On Monday, as classified US intelligence documents were produced for the first time in a foreign court, the relevance of the cables was becoming apparent. One of the names in a cable was a pseudonym for a defence witness. They contained details of payments that could be given to Mr Giaka in return for giving evidence. Mr Taylor, counsel for al-Megrahi, asked for an adjournment to consider his client's defence.

As the court reconvened on Tuesday, defence lawyers demanded that all classified American intelligence documents relating to Mr Giaka be passed to the court. Lord Sutherland rejected a defence request that the court ask the US attorney general, Janet Reno, to appoint a federal judge to examine all the CIA documents and make available everything that was not a threat to national security. But Mr Boyd was told to go back to the CIA and ask directly for the documents.

Yesterday, the CIA agreed to search its files for documents concerning Mr Giaka. Again, it will take the unusual step of making public intelligence information on the Libyan's status as a double agent - and, crucially, the groups and individuals the defence claims are responsible for the bombing.

Meanwhile, further details about Mr Giaka emerged. Under codename P1, he was paid $1,000 a month for information by American intelligence agents. However, the CIA threatened to stop payment in September 1989, nine months after the Lockerbie bombing, unless he came up with better information about JSO, the Libyan intelligence service.

Before he even takes to the stand, such information - coupled with his eligibility for a $4m (about £2.75m) reward on conviction of the two accused - threatens to undermine Mr Giaka's credibility.

Legal sources are beginning to wonder to what extent he will directly link the accused to the bombing. In the late 1980s, Mr Giaka worked for Libyan Arab Airways alongside the accused at Luqa airport. He admits to being a member of Libyan intelligence services; al-Megrahi and Fhimah are accused of being Libyan spies. After he defected to the US in July 1991, he gave testimony to the FBI which formed a key part of the indictment issued in November of that year. He went into hiding. In the years that have passed he is said to have become increasingly paranoid.

When defence solicitors went to take a precognition (witness statement) before the trial, he insisted they were blindfolded. Mr Giaka wore make-up and a Shirley Bassey wig. It is understood the solicitors came away lacking the confidence in Mr Giaka which the prosecution must have in court.

But the testimony he gives -in a disguised voice, behind screens - will be pivotal. "His evidence is absolutely vital," said a legal source. "If he fails to directly blame the Libyans, at the very least the defence will claim no case to answer and the whole thing could end much sooner than anyone expected."

webTitle: £1m a year for City's top lawyers

fields.headline: £1m a year for City's top lawyers
fields.trailText: Partners in City of London law firms earn more than £1m a year, according to a survey of lawyers' incomes. The highest earning pocket £1.2m, according to this month's Commercial Lawyer magazine.
fields.body:
Partners in City of London law firms earn more than £1m a year, according to a survey of lawyers' incomes. The highest earning pocket £1.2m, according to this month's Commercial Lawyer magazine.

Leading stockbrokers, investment bankers and barristers earn more - up to £2m - but stockbrokers' and bankers' pay packets are inflated by bonuses.

Leaving aside bonuses, which are unpredictable, partners in big City law firms rake in the highest of a range of professions.

They average £708,000, more even than the average £643,000 for chief executives of FTSE 100 companies, though share options give chief executives a bigger overall package.

Without their bonuses, stockbrokers and investment bankers average £525,000 and £413,000.

Commercial Lawyer concludes that City solicitors' pay is justified by the pressures of the job - "long, intense hours, personal sacrifices and demanding expectations".

fields.headline: Restaurant banks on plane food
fields.trailText: Two businessmen yesterday said they were planning to convert a former passenger jet into a restaurant - but stressed they would not be serving airline food.
fields.body:
Two businessmen yesterday said they were planning to convert a former passenger jet into a restaurant - but stressed they would not be serving airline food.

Bobby Sodhi and his father, Kane, have bought a 177ft long Lockheed TriStar.

Now they plan to move it to the centre of Derby, and have the interior refitted as a restaurant. The project is expected to cost them more than £1m.

Bobby Sodhi, 26, said they wanted to have the plane cut up and transported to Derby. It would then be reconstructed at Pride Park, close to the home of Derby County football club.

Mr Sodhi is well known around Derby after buying a 20-tonne tank and taking to the road in it.

Alan Mullarkey, chairman of Derby city council's planning committee, said that a full planning application had already been submitted.
Press Association

webTitle: Natural way to decaf coffee or tea

fields.headline: Natural way to decaf coffee or tea
fields.trailText: Scientists today foresee a world in which caffeine free coffee or tea is grown naturally on genetically modified bushes.
fields.body:
Scientists today foresee a world in which caffeine free coffee or tea is grown naturally on genetically modified bushes.

Alan Crozier of the University of Glasgow and four colleagues from three Japanese institutes list the bad qualities of caffeine in a report in the magazine Nature: "palpitations, gastro-intestinal disturbance, anxiety, tremor, increased blood pressure and insomnia."

But removing the alkaloid is not only costly, but "to discerning customers, flavours and aromas are lost".

The scientists have identified and "cloned" the gene that makes caffeine in leaves of Camellia sinensis, the source of tea - thus opening the possibility of removing the gene from both the tea plant and from Coffea arabica, the coffee bush. Such a step could even enhance tea's healing benefits - it has ingredients thought to be helpful against heart disease that caffeine may cancel out.

Some selected strains of both species are naturally low in caffeine - but a breeding programme to produce a decaffeinated crop would take 20 years. Large scale production of GM tea and coffee plants is more practical, the scientists say, though finding quite how the gene controls natural production of caffeine is still a way off.

webTitle: Rider fights for life after eventing fall

fields.headline: Rider fights for life after eventing fall
fields.trailText: An eventing rider is fighting for her life in hospital after falling from her horse during a competition.
fields.body:
An eventing rider is fighting for her life in hospital after falling from her horse during a competition.

Fiona Chesterton, who has competed at national and international level, is on a life support machine in the neurological unit at Southampton general hospital where her condition is described as "critical but stable".

The accident is the latest to cast a shadow over the sport. In just over a year there have been 10 fatal accidents, six of them in Britain. Ms Chesterton, 25, was riding her horse Nothing But Purple at the Kilmington horse trials in Wiltshire at the weekend when the horse slipped on the flat just after the second fence, leaving the rider with severe head injuries.

She was taken to Salisbury hospital but later transferred to the neurological unit at Southampton. Her mother, Christine Ranson, said Ms Chesterton, a mortgage broker from Cullompton, Devon, was devoted to horses, and was well aware of the dangers of eventing.

Mrs Ranson, who lives near Saltash in Cornwall, said: "When you compete at Fiona's level you must be aware of the dangers and accept that accidents will happen. I'm sure that if she recovers enough to ride again she will want to."

But she added that the sport's governing body, the British Horse Trials Association, should continue to examine the safety of the sport.

Ms Chesterton has been riding since she was a child and started eventing at 15. She has three other horses and wears distinctive purple cross country colours.

In 1996 she was fourth in the Young Rider National Championships and in 1994 she also qualified for the Young Rider European Championships.

fields.headline: Crackdown over attacks on scientists
fields.trailText: The home secretary Jack Straw is considering new powers to tackle the rising violence by animal rights extremists who target the scientific community, it was confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
The home secretary Jack Straw is considering new powers to tackle the rising violence by animal rights extremists who target the scientific community, it was confirmed yesterday.

Mr Straw is planning a full review of police powers to combat what he described as the"preposterous" and "terrible" activities of some extremists.

Scientists who met Home Office officials last month called for urgent action to clamp down on the violence against the homes and property of scientists and major shareholders in laboratories using animal testing.

Mr Straw said police were also calling for more powers to curtail protesters' activities after police figures showed 1,200 reports of animal rights attacks last year alone, causing an estimated £2.6m damage to property. But animal rights campaigners said criminal laws were already in place to deal with violent protesters.

Mr Straw told Radio 4's Today programme: "We are looking at whether there are changes in legislation that we can take which are being sought by the police to see whether we can strengthen action against these animal rights extremists.

"It is worth bearing in mind that many of us would not be able to lead healthy lives were it not for the pharmaceutical companies being able to test their drugs on animals."

The announcement follows a spate of violence against laboratory staff, culminating in the explosion on Monday of petrol bombs under five cars belonging to employees of Huntingdon Life Sciences, a research centre in Cambridgeshire.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • If you had £250,000 going spare, should you blow it on a new Corniche? That is the question we address today, as we review the car so bravely lent us by Rolls-Royce and events ensuing after Gerald Kaufman, Richard Adams and myself arrived on Friday morning at Crewe.
fields.body:
 If you had £250,000 going spare, should you blow it on a new Corniche? That is the question we address today, as we review the car so bravely lent us by Rolls-Royce and events ensuing after Gerald Kaufman, Richard Adams and myself arrived on Friday morning at Crewe.

Our museum tour guide and tutor on the car's controls, former machinist John Spragg, mentioned visits from Nigel Mansell ("lovely man, fascinating, and hilarious") and Mike Tyson ("lovely man, very knowledgable about our history"). Beginning the journey to Leeds, all three of us admiring the plushness of the sheepskin carpets and the 76 buttons to move the seats, and it was not until 33 minutes had elapsed that a Beatles tape (the Red Album) became stuck ... and, in trying to fix it, I yanked off the front of the cassette player.

 "Baby you can drive my car," as John Lennon puts it on that album, "Yes, I'm gonna be a star." Well no, I'm not. You're not going to be a star of motoring journalism, are you, if on level seven of Leeds' Schofield NCP car park you drive an automatic Corniche into a wall. Still, in a certain light (candle) you'd barely notice.

 The thing about driving a navy blue open-top Corniche with cream leather interior through areas of urban deprivation is that you do get noticed. Yet there was little hostility ... just the one "wanker" hand gesture. "What has happened to the class envy that made Britain what it was?" mused Richard. What happened to tall poppy syndrome?

 Gerald Kaufman loved the airy boot, I enjoyed the superb suspension and the smoothness of the seven litre engine, and Richard was struck by the speed of cigar lighter. "Isn't it amazing, what they can do these days for £250,000?" he said. However, he was upset by the lack of a cigar compartment light.

 To Stephen Corley who wrote of seeing RR1 "on the hard shoulder of the M1 with hazard lights flashing" late on Friday, what happened was this. For some reason, John Spragg omitted from his "cockpit drill" any warning against selecting reverse at nearly 90mph. The car snatched up sharply and lost all power, and "check gearbox" flashed up. A lovely moment. We rested on the hard shoulder, nervily restarted the car, went into drive and drew away. What a car to recover so quickly.

 The real question for anyone with £250,000, then, is have you got the nerve? I haven't. Although the car survived a night in Shepherds Bush, the next morning it went to a gentler suburb until they came to collect it on Tuesday - by which point the Spirit of Ecstasy emblem was stuck in the retracted position and the alarm system had broken. A quiet weekend, then, for RR1. As for the Diary, its career as a car reviewer ends at this apex. Richard is now working on borrowing a yacht.

webTitle: White House contenders spar over TV debates

fields.headline: White House contenders spar over TV debates
fields.standfirst:
Gore and Bush jostle for advantage on the head-to-head clashes that could win or lose the US election

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore and George W Bush have become locked in an increasingly acrimonious debate about debates, with the two White House contenders jockeying for advantage over the format of their televised confrontations this autumn.
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush have become locked in an increasingly acrimonious debate about debates, with the two White House contenders jockeying for advantage over the format of their televised confrontations this autumn.

In an attempt to break with the traditional televised set-up, the Republican candidate, Mr Bush, is pressing for the debates to have a more informal, round-table character, moderated by hosts who he hopes will adopt a softer, more conversational approach.

The Bush camp would like at least one, and possibly more, of the debates to be modelled on a session which took place during the Republican primary race earlier this year, in which the rival contenders were interviewed around a table by CNN's Larry King. Mr Bush said this week that such debates were "more free flowing".

But the Democrat nominee, Mr Gore, has already accepted a plan put forward by a neutral commission for three debates in October along traditional lines, with the two men standing at lecterns and being grilled by senior political reporters.

Mr Gore has also said repeatedly that he will debate with his rival "any time, anywhere, any place", though whether he would actually do so is likely to depend on Mr Bush's willingness to agree to the prime-time network events as well.

Such debates about debates are not new in American presidential elections, but the Gore-Bush argument has come earlier than usual and reflects the immense stakes which both camps have in the outcome of this year's televised head-to-head sessions.

With most of the opinion polls now showing the White House race to be a close one, both men see the debates as one of the few major opportunities to shift voters' minds in the run-up to the November 7 election.

As a result, the Gore and Bush camps are both desperate to ensure that their opponent does not get an inbuilt advantage from the way the debates are structured and conducted. Mr Gore's camp believes that its man will outshine Mr Bush in high-profile debates, while Mr Bush's handling of the argument suggests that he fears Mr Gore could be right.

At this stage of the campaign the two men only agree on two things - that there will be presidential debates of some description this autumn, and that only Mr Bush and Mr Gore will take part in them.

The two main candidates both oppose any efforts by the Reform party's Pat Buchanan or the Green party nominee, Ralph Nader, to be included in the debates.

Earlier this year, the independent Commission on Presidential Debates, a bipartisan group which has sponsored nationally televised presidential debates in each of the last three American elections, put forward proposals for three debates between the presidential nominees and one debate between the vice-presidential candidates.

They would take place between October 3 and 17 and all four would be broadcast by the three major US networks - ABC, CBS and NBC.

Mr Gore accepted the commission's proposals this week and also agreed to a suggestion from the Bush camp for a second televised match-up between Dick Cheney and Joe Lieberman, the vice- presidential nominees.

Mr Bush's reluctance to make the same commitment prompted a barrage of attacks from the Gore camp. "George Bush is trying to do everything he can to avoid prime-time presidential debates that will be seen on all three networks," a spokesman Mark Fabiani said.

Such attacks riled Mr Bush. "Who said we don't want prime-time exposure?" he retorted at a meeting with reporters on his campaign plane. Mr Bush said he would "pick and choose" the venues, formats and ground rules for the debates.

fields.headline: Catherine Bennett
fields.standfirst: Raj Persaud, a psychiatrist for every occasion  Mr and Mrs Snowflake  Paedologists beware
fields.trailText: Raj Persaud, a psychiatrist for every occasion  Mr and Mrs Snowflake  Paedologists beware
fields.body:
No shrinking violet

At one of the Edinburgh Television Festival's more heated debates, Dr Raj Persaud, a consultant psychiatrist who once stood in for an ailing Esther Rantzen, warned of the possible psychological damage facing the Big Brother contestants.

"It's like putting an alcoholic on a drinking game show", he said. "These people are obsessed with becoming famous and so are not making decisions that are in their own best interests."

While no one would underestimate the agonies of the Big Brother victims as they resign themselves to a lifetime of showering in private, there must surely be more immediate concern for the well-being of Persaud, a man whose enthusiasm for the public eye makes the game show exhibitionists look like so many shrinking Miss Havishams.

For some time many of us have been worried that Persaud does not always make decisions that are in his best interests.

Should this bright young winner of the Royal College of Psychiatrists' research prize and medal really be squandering quite so much of his talent on Richard and Judy's Good Morning show, where he is the "resident psychiatrist"?

Does the author of a paper called "Psychiatrists suffer from stigma too" help his profession by writing multiple-choice How to Know Yourself quizzes for the Telegraph, by contributing features to every national broadsheet and by broadcasting, what seems incessantly, on Radio 4 - speaking of which, don't miss his next contribution, the Science of Humour (trailed in a half-page feature he wrote for last Tuesday's Daily Telegraph).

Nor should we forget his regular column in Cosmopolitan, his contributions to Men's Health magazine and his - well, anyone interested in exploring the extremity of Persaud's love affair with the media would do best to check out the biography on his internet home page, in which he lists his contributions and includes a few of the choicer compliments to have come his way since he first began to entertain us, back in the early 90s: "The Independent on Sunday said he was 'The undisputed king of the media shrink pack' and the Spectator in 1998 asserted he is 'the most eminent psychiatrist of the age... he is the guru of common sense.'"

Whether through this very abundance of common sense or through lack of space, the king of the shrinks' website does not mention his sideline as a media quotesman for all occasions, nor does he begin to itemise his numerous contributions to tabloid newspapers, in particular the Sunday People, with which he seems to have some sort of special relationship.

Not long ago he provided psychiatric input for a piece which asked (re Neil Morrissey) "Why do girls fall for men behaving badly?" "Many women put up with men behaving badly because they love the rollercoaster ride of emotion," explained Persaud. "There is never a dull moment. And when he does give his lover attention she feels more euphoric than if he had been eating out of her hand from the start."

To his credit, the doctor appears to be in control of his former habit of analysing celebrities he had never met, but there is no room for complacency: weeks ago he could not resist offering the Sun his thoughts on the perils (re Robbie Williams) of celebrity dating: "Celebrities have difficulty maintaining relationships with each other because they are always very busy, jetting all over the world and so on."

More worrying than this idiosyncratic application of his skills, however, is the emergence of certain inconsistencies in Persaud's clinical thinking. Earlier this year the Independent asked for his views on the sitcom psychiatrist Frasier. Persaud was damning: "Frasier doesn't ask the questions that we would ask, and he doesn't get the proper background to make an accurate prognosis." Which is not what he told the Mirror about Frasier in 1997: "I used to do a regular phone-in slot on a radio station and identify with him."

Which Persaud is the true one? The one who identifies with Frasier, or the one who does not? The ubiquitous showman or the earnest clinician? The contributor to Schizophrenia Research or the Cosmo agony uncle?

When the Big Brother show comes to an end the producers should not repine: all they need do is replace their 10 contestants with Persaud and let his multiple personalities fight it out.

With this chocolate flake, I thee wed

From Max Clifford to the Sun, from Garry Bushell to the president of Family and Youth Concern, the forces of righteousness unite in horror over the Bovey-Turner nuptials. Not, as might once have happened, because the groom abandoned his three small daughters for love of the refulgent former lottery show presenter, but because the institution of marriage is thought to have been tainted by the presence of confectionery.

Although it is unappealing, the degree of outrage seems disproportionate. Are the happy pair not looking forward to a future of shared mastication?

Moreover, given that they had already auctioned their intimacy, Mr and Mrs Anthea Snowflake - and their many Hello! and OK! predecessors - seem to have shown unusual restraint. Any celebrity couple wanting to make the most of this special promotional day will naturally want to exploit every one of its marketing opportunities. What is a wedding dress, for example, if not a gigantic empty hoarding, with space for 1,000 times the number of logos that conventionally adorn the suits of formula one drivers? In future the Snowflakes may come to feel they sold away their wedding rights for something less than a mess of pottage, to wit: two crumbly white flakes covered in milk chocolate, each containing 200 calories, 2.7g protein, 22.2g. carbohydrate and 11.4g fat.

Paedologists beware

No sooner had David Blunkett announced his national spelling bee, than the behaviour of vandals in Newport suggested that knowing how to place letters in the correct sequence might not in itself be enough. Not long ago, the oafs who forced a woman paediatrician from her home, believing her to be a pervert, probably had as much difficulty with spelling paedophile as they would have done with the more commonplace accommodation, or millennium or desperate.

Now - thanks, no doubt to the News of the World - they have memorised the correct spelling of "paedo", without grasping that other words beginning with the same prefix might mean something different. Happily, not too many other words start this way, though paedologists in the Newport area should be on their guard. Ditto peddlers and podiatrists. And anyone trying to make a living by letting out those charming little pleasure boats called pedalos might like to consider switching to punts.

If Rebekah Wade is interested in making amends this might be a good time to feature a little etymology item in her paper, for readers who wish to persecute sex offenders but lack the required literacy.

webTitle: Rivers hit by wave of pollution accidents

fields.headline: Rivers hit by wave of pollution accidents
fields.trailText: Anglers and environment agency staff were yesterday in despair after the 14th big river pollution incident in the last month spilled 50,000 gallons of toxic farm slurry into the river Dart in Devon.
fields.body:
Anglers and environment agency staff were yesterday in despair after the 14th big river pollution incident in the last month spilled 50,000 gallons of toxic farm slurry into the river Dart in Devon.

Teams of environment agency staff spent more than 24 hours trying to contain the pollution near Tiverton when it threatened to enter the Exe, one of Britain's most important salmon rivers.

Last night they reported that they had largely succeeded in controlling the pollution and prevented it entering the Exe.

This involved the environment agency and South West Water pumping hydrogen peroxide into the river to raise the oxygen levels, pumping the worst of the polluted water on to nearby fields and increasing the flow of the Exe.

Hundreds of fish are known to have died but the full extent of the pollution has yet to be established.

The source has been traced to a slurry store on a local farm but it is too early to say what the full environmental effects may be.

Work is now under way to remove more slurry found on a nearby hillside, which could run into the Dart if it rains. Martin Weiler, of the environment agency, said it was a "major incident". "We will be carrying out a full investigation with a view to a possible prosecution."

The last five weeks have been some of the worst on recent record for river and canal pollution incidents.

Up to 250,000 fish have been killed in 14 incidents on British waterways around the country.

The worst incident is thought to have been on the river Dee near Chester when an unknown chemical polluted up to 20 miles of water killing approximately 100,000 fish.

Agency staff are still investigating the incident. Other incidents this year have been on the river Smite in Nottinghamshire and the Trent and Mersey canal, near Stone in Staffordshire.

Last week, up to 1,000 protected crayfish were wiped out along a stretch of a Cumbrian river polluted with sheep dip.

The chemical which caused the pollution is believed to be a synthetic pyrethroid, extremely toxic to aquatic insects, with small quanitites able to contaminate large amounts of water.

Yesterday the environment agency, which is still investigating many of the incidents, suggested that most of the pollution was due to carelessness rather than deliberate releases. "It's been a really bad month. There is so much negligence. Part of the problem is that the penalties for polluting the environment are risible. Polluters say, 'What's a few hundred pounds?'," said a spokesman.

Earlier this year a Nottinghamshire farmer was fined £1,000 with £450 costs for killing 44,000 fish.

Average fines in 1999, say the agency, were about £3,500 for major incidents which might destroy a riverine habitat for years.

The National Federation of Anglers, which has 230,000 members, was dismayed at the incidents, especially because British waterways are generally less polluted than in the past.

"It's been a disastrous year for fish kills," said Rodney Coldron of the federation. "It can take up to 10 years for rivers to recover from pollution incidents like these.

"Magistrates and judges must understand this is very serious."

fields.headline: No: 1711
fields.standfirst: Lorraine Heggessey
fields.trailText: Lorraine Heggessey
fields.body:
Age:
43

Appearance:
Elaine Paige's younger, stroppier sister.

Obligatory accompanying adjectives:
diminutive, bustling, gutsy, driven, achingly ambitious.

Not "feisty"?
Naturally, but it seems inadequate: this is someone who once cruelly ambushed Roger Cook with a film crew while he ate breakfast and rasped: "Answer the question, you fat bastard!"

But I thought she was the priggish, schoolmarm-style BBC children's TV boss who told kiddies during the great Blue Peter cocaine scandal: "Richard has let himself, the team, and all of you down"?
It's the same woman.

Is there not a secret romantic side to this fireball?
I'm glad you asked. Her husband is a Dutch musician she fell in love with at first sight on a Greek island. "Dutchmen are a lot more liberated than Englishmen in many ways," she reckons.

Specifics?
Alas, no. Nothing to do with drugs, obviously.

So, anyway, she's replacing Peter Salmon as BBC1 controller?
Looks like it - when a spokesman says "Peter is not going to do this job for ever", it's pretty clear that...

Salmon sleeps with the fishes?
No, no, this is the BBC. He'll get a lucrative "strategic" post.

Why's he set to go?
The Vanessa mess, the Queen Mum bummer, and what enemies call ratings salmonella. But also because Greg Dyke wants to revamp BBC1 as a fun'n'fiction network...

So Heggessey's been lined up, because her CV almost entirely consists of...
Exactly the kind of factual series that Dyke wants to banish.

Yes, odd, that.
Unless you switch to the "Mini Me" theory.

Which is?
Wherever Dyke goes, he makes a mascot out of someone who, like him, is short, hyperactive, raucous and not afraid to irritate - Roland Rat at TV-am, Jeremy Beadle at LWT, Dawn "Scary" Airey at Channel 5. Airey's not available, and Heggessey fits the bill.

Don't say:
How are the Live & Kicking ratings doing?

Do say:
Whatever happened to Roger Cook?

webTitle: Passengers tell of terror as metro train derails

fields.headline: Passengers tell of terror as metro train derails
fields.trailText: A packed Paris metro train derailed and flipped on to its side yesterday, injuring 24 people. It scraped to a halt barely a metre short of a stationary train on the opposite track.
fields.body:
A packed Paris metro train derailed and flipped on to its side yesterday, injuring 24 people. It scraped to a halt barely a metre short of a stationary train on the opposite track.

Police and rescue workers said another 42 people were severely shaken by the accident, which happened during the lunchtime rush hour at the Notre-Dame-de-Lorette station in the north of the city.

"There was a horrible noise on the bend just before the train arrived at the station," said Peter Marsh, a British tourist in the derailed train who escaped with only a few bruises.

"Then the lights went out, and the train began to gather speed before the front carriage left the tracks. The carriage began to fill with smoke and a burning smell. It was terrifying, absolutely terrifying."

Evangelos Tzonis, a French resident of Greek origin who was in the front carriage of the stationary train, said he was looking through the driver's window when he saw the first carriage of the approaching train turn on to its side and career towards him.

"The noise was indescribable in the tunnel, like an earthquake," he said. "I really thought we were all going to die. Then there was panic, people were screaming and crying, and about a dozen people covered in blood pulled themselves out of the windows of the collapsed carriage."

Most of the injured suffered severe cuts and bruises, but there were also several complex fractures and one person's leg was broken in three places, Christian Decollorado, an emergency services spokesman, said.

Some 170 police and rescue workers sealed off the station within minutes of the accident, the first of its kind in living memory on the Paris underground, which carries 4.4m passengers a day.

The most badly hurt were given first aid on the platform, and a nearby cafe was commandeered for those who could leave the station unassisted. Eleven people were taken to hospital, none in a critical condition, and a further 12 were treated for shock.

"It all happened terribly quickly," said one woman lying on a stretcher outside the station. "My legs were trapped, and my neighbour had to help me clamber up and out through the window."

The chief of Paris police, Philippe Massoni, said the accident could have been far more serious if the derailed carriage had collided with the second train. "We could have had a very serious accident indeed," he said. "The engine fell on its side and did not run its full course. This is a miracle."

Alain Caire, safety director of the Paris regional transport authority, RATP, said the accident seemed to be due to a technical failure. "The approaching train was moving at about 35kph [22mph] when it flipped on its side onto the opposite tracks and slid towards the second train," he said. "The two trains were barely a metre apart when it came to a halt."

Mr Caire said it was the first time in 31 years at the RATP that he had known a carriage to flip on to its side. "There was no explosion," he said, "and I can't see people tampering with the tracks during one of the busiest periods of the of the day - though I understand there is a suspicion of something on the tracks. We will have to await the results of the inquiry."

The Paris metro, which celebrated its centenary this summer, has had only two serious incidents since it opened. In 1903, a fire killed 84 people at Couronnes station, while in 1943 an Allied air-raid blew in the roof of the Porte de Saint-Cloud station, killing 403 people sheltering there.

France's new interior minister, Daniel Vaillant, visiting yesterday's accident site with Mr Massoni, promised a full judicial inquiry in addition to the technical investigation launched by the RATP.

"There's no explanation for this right now," he said. "It is dramatic and very regrettable, though it could have been much worse. This has just never happened before - we will have to see what might have caused it."

Additional reporting by Elodie Ratsimbazafy

Evangelos Tzonis, a French resident of Greek origin who was in the front carriage of the stationary train, said he was looking through the driver's window when he saw the first carriage of the approaching train turn on to its side and career towards him. "The noise was indescribable in the tunnel, like an earthquake," he said. "I really thought we were all going to die. Then there was panic, people were screaming and crying, and about a dozen people covered in blood pulled themselves out of the windows of the collapsed carriage." Most of the injured suffered severe cuts and bruises, but there were also several complex fractures and one person's leg was broken in three places, Christian Decollorado, an emergency services spokesman, said. Some 170 police and rescue workers sealed off the station within minutes of the accident, the first of its kind in living memory on the Paris underground, which carries 4.4m passengers a day. The most badly hurt were given first aid on the platform, and a nearby cafe was commandeered for those who could leave the station unassisted. Eleven people were taken to hospital, none in a critical condition, and a further 12 were treated for shock. "It all happened terribly quickly," said one woman lying on a stretcher outside the station. "My legs were trapped, and my neighbour had to help me clamber up and out through the window." The chief of Paris police, Philippe Massoni, said the accident could have been far more serious if the derailed carriage had collided with the second train. "We could have had a very serious accident indeed," he said. "The engine fell on its side and did not run its full course. This is a miracle." Alain Caire, safety director of the Paris regional transport authority, RATP, said the accident seemed to be due to a technical failure. "The approaching train was moving at about 35kph [22mph] when it flipped on its side onto the opposite tracks and slid towards the second train," he said. "The two trains were barely a metre apart when it came to a halt." Mr Caire said it was the first time in 31 years at the RATP that he had known a carriage to flip on to its side. "There was no explosion," he said, "and I can't see people tampering with the tracks during one of the busiest periods of the of the day - though I understand there is a suspicion of something on the tracks. We will have to await the results of the inquiry." The Paris metro, which celebrated its centenary this summer, has had only two serious incidents since it opened. In 1903, a fire killed 84 people at Couronnes station, while in 1943 an Allied air-raid blew in the roof of the Porte de Saint-Cloud station, killing 403 people sheltering there. France's new interior minister, Daniel Vaillant, visiting yesterday's accident site with Mr Massoni, promised a full judicial inquiry in addition to the technical investigation launched by the RATP. "There's no explanation for this right now," he said. "It is dramatic and very regrettable, though it could have been much worse. This has just never happened before - we will have to see what might have caused it." Additional reporting by Elodie Ratsimbazafy

fields.headline: Neo-Nazis jailed for race killing
fields.standfirst: East Germany is facing the menace of rightwing extremism, and it is not alone
fields.trailText: Three young neo-Nazis were yesterday convicted of a vicious race murder, in a case that has brought to a head the German government's concern over the far right's activities in the east of the country.
fields.body:
Three young neo-Nazis were yesterday convicted of a vicious race murder, in a case that has brought to a head the German government's concern over the far right's activities in the east of the country.

The widow of their victim, Mozambique-born Alberto Adriano, stayed away from the hearing at a court in the eastern city of Halle after receiving a death threat.

The court sentenced Enrico Hilprecht, 24, to the maximum of life in prison. His two 16-year-old co-defendants, Christian Richter and Frank Miethbauer, were each given nine years in jail, one year less than the maximum sentence for juveniles.

The judge called the deadly assault on June 11 "the latest in a long chain of attacks to which we must put an end".

Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, called yesterday for the speedy imposition of a ban on the radical far-right National Democratic party of Germany (NPD). The government has moved gradually towards supporting a ban, despite the misgivings of its interior minister, Otto Schily.

Critics, including senior officials in the counter-intelligence service, have argued that such a ban would merely make surveillance of the neo-Nazi scene more difficult.

Mr Schröder will today lay a wreath at a memorial erected at the spot where Adriano was attacked so savagely that he later died of his wounds. The killing was the third this year alleged to have been carried out by members of the far right.

The court was told that the younger defendants had previous convictions for daubing swastikas.

Tolerance of neo-Nazi violence is widespread in eastern Germany, especially among the young. In an effort to end this tolerance, the chancellor yesterday appealed to east Germans' pride in their recent history, encouraging them to take a stand like the one that put an end to communist rule in 1989.

He said Germany needed a "repeat of what people in the east of our country recognised in the peaceful revolution 10 years ago", adding that the easterners had to "involve themselves and fight for the right thing".

In Dessau, where Adriano was killed, police said his German-born widow had received a threatening letter which the public prosecutor's office was investigating. A spokesman for a foreigners' rights group said she had decided not to attend the final session of the court because she was "simply too scared because of her children".

Mr Adriano, who was 39 and worked in a meat packing plant, left behind him three children, of whom the youngest is six months old.

His killers yesterday sat expressionless in court yesterday as the verdict was read out.

The defence had pleaded for shorter jail terms and for manslaughter or deadly assault charges, saying prosecutors had failed to prove that the attackers intended to kill Adriano when they set on him in a park after a drunken rampage through the city.

A defence lawyer, Sabine Grunow, said all of the accused expressed regret in brief closing statements at the end of the four-day trial. Hearings were closed to the public because of German law regarding juveniles.

Adriano was walking home in the early hours of the morning, when the three attacked him, screaming racist abuse. When they had kicked him unconscious, they stripped him of his clothes as a final humiliation.

In a further instance of racist violence, prosecutors in the northern town of Lübeck said they had arrested two skinheads for attacking and injuring a 33-year-old African man whom they had taunted with racial slurs.

Police in the German town of Waiblingen detained two men after two foreigners were slightly injured in an early-morning arson attack on a home for asylum seekers.

Late on Tuesday, a 21-year-old German man was given a five-month suspended sentence and fined 500DM (£160) for punching a Hong Kong-born photojournalist who was trying to cover racism in the east.

webTitle: Rise of the far right sees Denmark's liberal traditions under attack

fields.headline: Rise of the far right sees Denmark's liberal traditions under attack
fields.trailText: A wry smile plays across the face of the fair-haired young man as he explains his feelings about asylum-seekers. "When refugees are no longer in need they should go home but they don't and that's the problem. About 6,000 come here every year and if they bring their families that can add up to as many as 16,000 people."
fields.body:
A wry smile plays across the face of the fair-haired young man as he explains his feelings about asylum-seekers. "When refugees are no longer in need they should go home but they don't and that's the problem. About 6,000 come here every year and if they bring their families that can add up to as many as 16,000 people."

Such views have struck a chord with many in Austria and eastern Germany but this is Denmark, a country whose liberal tolerant society has long been the envy of the world. But things are starting to change. The young man is Carl Christian Ebbesen, a board member of the ultra-nationalist Danish People's party (DPP) whose popularity ratings were as high as 15% earlier this year. The DPP's staunch opposition to Denmark ditching the krone in favour of the euro in next month's referendum has done wonders for its image and won it new-found respectability.

Its leader, the 53-year-old self-styled housewife Pia Kjaersgaard revelled in a public one-on-one debate with the Danish prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, on the euro last week. An elfin-like blonde lady and mother of two, she does not look like a demagogue. But appearances can be deceiving and the core policies of the DPP or the Dansk Folkeparti as it is known in Danish are far from respectable.

If it ever does win power, Denmark's reputation as a liberal society would be shattered forever. Aid to the third world would be privatised and poor countries forced to take action to "restrict population growth" if they wanted to receive any help. Recidivist paedophiles would find themselves forced to undergo "medical castration" and the criteria for Danish citizenship would be severely tightened.

Refugees should, the DPP argues, be repatriated to their country of origin and only small numbers provisionally accepted. "Denmark is not a country intended for immigration and the Danish People's party disagrees with the statement that Denmark will develop into a multi-ethnic society," the party's programme reads.

The party is also hostile to the EU and would like to see the European Parliament, where it has one MEP, abolished.

Just 4.5% of Denmark's population of 5.3 million is made up of immigrants but the DPP has shown itself adept at whipping up popular anti-EU and anti-foreigner sentiment.

In 1998 Pia Kjaersgaard urged Danes to rally at Denmark's border with Germany and protest at cooperation between Jutland and Germany's Schleswig Holstein region. According to Bendt Bendtsen, the leader of the Danish Conservative party, the "cooperation" involved only minor activities such as student exchanges and a joint ambulance service. It was portrayed, however, "as a joint EU-German attempt to regain control over old German territory in Denmark."

Mr Bendtsen adds: "It was tasteless, but by playing this tune on nationalistic strings they have distorted public discussion in Denmark to a point where a real dialogue is no longer possible."

Former EU commissioner Ritt Bjerregaard warned last week that if Danes say 'nej' to the euro next month it will be seen as a swing to the DPP. Earlier this month even Jörg Haider's Freedom party refused to meet with Kjaersgaard.

Yet the DPP is a real political force in Denmark. It polled 7.4% of the vote in the last parliamentary elections in 1998 and has 13 MPs in the Folketing (parliament). Now suggestions are growing that it may soon be in a strong enough position to prop up a centre-right government in exchange for a slice of power.

webTitle: New European secrecy controls come into law

fields.headline: New European secrecy controls come into law
fields.trailText: Sweeping new controls on information, including details of a proposed new European paramilitary police force, have been ratified by EU governments.
fields.body:
Sweeping new controls on information, including details of a proposed new European paramilitary police force, have been ratified by EU governments.

The new EU secrecy code was agreed earlier this month by "written procedure", preventing any debate by the European parliament. It became part of EU law on August 23.

The code was drawn up in secret by the EU security supremo, Javier Solana, who is also secretary-general of the EU council of ministers, in cooperation with his successor as Nato secretary-general, Lord Roberston.

The controls were rushed through despite opposition from the European ombudsman, Jacob Soderman, who warned this week that the code could be applied to policy areas presently open to public scrutiny.

When Tony Bunyan, editor of Statewatch, the British-based civil liberties bulletin, asked in July for details of the Solana plan, he was told by a senior EU council official that the release of such information "could fuel public discussion on this subject".

Under the Solana plan, all classified documents relating to "security and defence of the union or one or more of its member states", or to "military or non-military crisis management", will be permanently excluded from public scrutiny.

The blanket secrecy rules will cover proposals to set up a 5,000-strong EU paramilitary police force as well as plans for a rapid reaction force. They could cover all EU discussions on criminal justice, border controls and trade policy.

The code will also enable Nato and non-EU governments to veto the disclosure of EU documents.

Documents passed to State watch show that the plans go much much further than purely military operations.

The commission says the proposed rapid reaction force could be used to quell "growing violence destabilising law and order, breaches of the peace, outbreaks of fighting, armed conflicts" and "massive population movements".

Documents which would have been suppressed under the new controls include minutes of a meeting of paramilitary police from Spain, Portugal, France and Italy in January at which they discussed the creation of a "European security and investigation force" as a "tool" at the disposal of the EU and Nato.

Paramilitary police forces, they say, are particularly qualified for the "restoration of public security", providing capabilities for "intelligence, general surveillance, judicial police [and] maintaining order".

webTitle: Kurdish rebels killed in Turkish crackdown

fields.headline: Kurdish rebels killed in Turkish crackdown
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Kurds
fields.trailText: Sixteen members of the Kurdistan Workers Party, the PKK, have been killed this week in renewed fighting in south-eastern Turkey, military officials said yesterday. Operations involving thousands of   troops are continuing in remote mountainous areas.
fields.body:
Sixteen members of the Kurdistan Workers Party, the PKK, have been killed this week in renewed fighting in south-eastern Turkey, military officials said yesterday. Operations involving thousands of troops are continuing in remote mountainous areas.

The clashes come almost exactly a year after the PKK's imprisoned leader Abdullah Ocalan instructed his followers to observe a ceasefire and withdraw from Turkish territory. Thousands of fighters have obeyed the order, and relocated across Turkey's eastern border to camps in Iraq and Iran. However, several hundred members of the PKK, who are divided into small mobile groups, are still thought to be in Turkey. The armed forces have vowed to hunt them down until they surrender or have been killed.

The current fighting is taking place in two separate locations - the border province of Hakkari where seven rebels have been killed, and the province of Tunceli, a traditional PKK stronghold, where nine bodies have been recovered. The Turkish armed forces are taking a hard line against the PKK. They dismiss the ceasefire as a temporary tactic, designed to try to save Ocalan from the gallows and to buy the PKK some time to regroup.

After taking office last week the new army commander, General Hilmi Ozkok, said the PKK had realised it could not win on the battlefield, and he vowed that it would not be allowed to achieve its objectives by other means. "The Turkish army lost thousands of martyrs in the struggle against separatist terrorism", he said, "and it will continue to prevent the traitors from attaining their political goals".

PKK hardliners believe armed struggle is their only option, but Ocalan has appealed for calm. He says he has abandoned all thoughts of a separate state, and he wants Turkey to grant its substantial Kurdish population a range of cultural rights. "Peace has to be put into practice", he said in a statement released through his lawyers last week. "I am calling on everyone who is involved to make a more meaningful effort".

Meanwhile Ocalan sits in heavily guarded isolation on the prison island of Imrali in the Sea of Marmara. The European Court of Human Rights is expected to discuss his case in November.
